TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Tasmania: VHF, UHF Transmission
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned residents of Tasmania respectfully showeth:
That the mountainous terrain and geography of Tasmania makes VHF television transmissions the most suitable for the State.
That more than 30,000 Tasmanians will have to purchase new television receivers and new antennae if commercial television in the State is forced to change from the VHF to the UHF band.

Your petitioners therefore request that the requirement by the Department of Transport and Communications to force Tasmania's two commercial television stations to change from the VHF to the UHF band by 1993 be immediately rescinded.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Violent Television Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
We are concerned about the increase in violent television programmes for children and particularly those programmes promoting violent toys that are available for sale in Australia.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That you support the Broadcasting (Prohibition of Violent Programmes for Children) Act 1988 which has been presented by WA Independent Senator for Nuclear Disarmament, Jo Vallentine. This Act aims to prohibit the broadcasting of children's TV programmes that are violent and that promote toys modelled on characters, weapons or other war accessories which are also available for sale in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Aidex 89
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned:
(1) are opposed to the holding of an arms bazaar, AIDEX '89, at the National Exhibition Centre in Canberra on 28-30 November 1989;

(2) believe that it is inappropriate for Australia to seek to offset its balance of payments deficit incurred through the import of expensive and unnecessary military equipment by seeking to double military exports over the next three to five years;

(3) regard it as offensive that on one hand we offer foreign aid to neighbouring countries to improve their material standard of being, while on the other hand the merchants of death seek to persuade their rulers to buy military equipment which is entirely inappropriate to the needs of the people;
Your petitioners respectfully request that the Senate urge the Government to cancel this exhibition just as its predecessor, PADEX, was called off in 1986, the International Year of Peace.
As in duty bound, your petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated and Violent Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:
The petition of citizens of Australia points out:

that all State Governments, States Attorneys-General, most women's groups and the majority of men in Australia, including significant numbers of members of Parliament, are totally opposed to the importation and distribution of `X' and excessively violent `R'-rated video pornography in Australia;
that most `X'-rated material available in Australia is imported;
that the Federal Government, by its Customs power under the Constitution, and not the A.C.T. Government, is solely responsible for controlling the importation of this pornographic material;
that by continuing to allow the importation of such pornographic material, the Federal Government is neglecting its responsibility to the women, children and families of Australia.
Your petitioners, therefore, request the Senate to:
1. Ban `X'-rated pornographic material at the point of entry into Australia.
2. Exclude from the `R'-rated all gratuitously violent material.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Abortion Funding Abolition Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the Senators in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That in 1988/89 the Federal Government paid $6.9 million from taxpayers' funds for 64,788 abortions under Medicare Items 6469 and 274/275 alone.
That in the same year Federal Government grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State public hospitals.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by supporting the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill 1989 and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That these Bills be now read a second time.

Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL
The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1989, which is now before the Senate contains a number of amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1987.
Firstly, Schedule one, operative on and from the first of January 1988, allows continued duty free treatment of ethyl hexanol.

Schedule two operates on and from the first of July 1988 and provides a free rate of duty for rye grass seed and certain gasoline and other oils. This rate was previously applied by the Customs Tariff (Rates Alteration) Act 1988.
Schedule three contains a minor amendment to subheading 9616.10 to align it with the international harmonised system. It will operate on and from the fourteenth day of October 1988.
Schedule four, operative on and from the first of March 1989, provides for the accelerated liberalisation of trade in textiles, clothing and footwear goods of New Zealand origin.
Schedule five, operative on and from the first of July 1989, contains:
Further changes under the ANZCERTA agreement to remove tariff and quota restrictions on apparel from New Zealand and achieve free trade access a year earlier than originally proposed;
Amendments to take account of changes in the names of a number of countries or places which qualify for preferential treatment;

Amendments to give effect to the Government's decision on the mining, construction and agricultural equipment industries. These changes allow duty free entry to certain mining and agricultural equipment not normally made in Australia; and

A reduction in the rate of duty on soda ash to compensate for the effect of changes to the customs valuation system made on the first of July 1989. This reduction follows a report by the Industries Assistance Commission and subsequent discussions with the industries concerned.

Schedule six operates on and from the first of August 1989. It provides quota free and duty free access for certain ski boots and cross country ski footwear. It also implements a free rate of duty for certain fabric woven from PVC coated polyester, and woven cut corduroy.
Schedules seven and eight contain amendments to correct industry assistance anomalies resulting from the introduction of the harmonised tariff.
Schedule seven, operative on and from the twelfth of October 1989 provides a free rate of duty for certain cast coated paper and paperboard.

Schedule eight amendments will operate from seven days after this Bill receives royal assent. The goods covered in this schedule include machines for working metal, knives and cutting blades for wood chipping machines, plywood, sensitised papers and certain machines containing a computer controller.

Also contained in schedule eight are amendments to extend the provisions of the Australian system of tariff preferences (ASTP) to Poland and Hungary. Far-reaching reforms in the political and economic spheres are in train in both these countries. The government attaches priority to the coordinated action being taken by western industrialised countries to give support and encouragement to these changes. Our action is consistent with measures already adopted or being adopted in various other countries such as USA, Japan and New Zealand.

Finally, in schedule nine, which is to operate on and from the first of January 1990, is an amendment to item 19 in schedule four as a consequence of changes proposed by the Customs and Excise Legislation Bill (No. 4) 1989.
FINANCIAL IMPACT
The effect of the amendments to the textiles, clothing and footwear arrangements contained in this Bill are considered to be negligible.

The revenue impact of changes to the mining, construction and agricultural equipment industries is expected to be virtually nil as the equipment concerned is not manufactured in Australia in the normal course of business.
The amendments relating to soda ash involve no budget outlays.

Provision of ASTP status to Poland and Hungary can be expected to result in some increase in imports though this is unlikely to have any significant impact on domestic markets. Imports in 1988/89 were approximately $31 million from Poland and $28 million from Hungary. Customs revenue forgone as a result of the application of developing rates is expected to be approximately $1 million in respect of Poland and $0.7 million for Hungary.

It is difficult to assess the net financial impact of the proposed tariff changes to correct tariff anomalies. Some will have the effect of reducing or removing import duty, others will increase duty or permit reinstatement of bounty. However, the measures proposed will generally only restore the position which applied before 1 January 1988 and are not likely to result in any substantial change to revenue or outlays.
Details of the amendments contained in this Bill have been included in an explanatory memorandum which has been circulated for the information of honourable members.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 4) 1989

This Bill is an omnibus measure proposing a series of amendments to the principal Customs Act 1901 and the Excise Act 1901, along the lines of the similarly titled Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bills introduced into this place over the last few years. In addition, this Bill proposes a series of repeals of various unproclaimed sections of early 1980s Customs and Excise Acts, following a recent review of unproclaimed Customs-related legislation.
The main proposals contained in the Bill relate to:
(i) the termination of manufacturing in bond, announced by the Government in the context of the 1988 May Economic Statement (Clauses 7 and 8);
(ii) the amendments to the Commercial Tariff Concession System (Part XVa of the Customs Act 1901) announced by the Government on 14 September 1989 (Clauses 18 to 29); and

(iii) the new requirement that all potable spirits imported into Australia in bulk containers be repackaged in licensed premises prior to entry for home consumption (Clause 9), and that locally produced spirit be repackaged in non-bulk containers prior to entry for home consumption (Clause 37) as announced by the Government on 18 December 1988.
I shall refer briefly to each of those proposals now.
Manufacture in Bond
Manufacture in bond arrangements permit the production of prescribed goods in a manufacturing warehouse licensed by Customs, for both domestic and export markets.
The stated objective of the manufacture in bond scheme is to promote local manufacture of goods. The scheme is meant to assist local manufacturers by:
Allowing them to defer payment of duty on imported inputs used in production until the completed (manufactured) product is entered for home consumption; and

Allowing goods manufactured in bond to be entered for home consumption at the lesser amount of either the combined duty of the imported components or the duty payable on the finished article if it were imported.

Other inherent benefits of the scheme are that wastages of imported materials and/or components in the production process are not dutiable, duties are not payable on imported inputs used in the manufacture of goods for export and, prior to the May Economic Statement of 1988, manufacturers were not liable for duty on imported inputs used in the manufacture of goods sold to Commonwealth authorities.

In January 1987 the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) reported to the Government on export concessions (Report No. 399 dated 16 January 1987) and recommended, inter alia, that manufacture in bond be abolished.

The commission found that the original objectives of the scheme have not been pursued. At the time of the inquiry the only goods being produced were blended oils (manufactured by one plant) and telecommunication equipment (manufactured by 14 licensed warehouses, which has subsequently been further reduced to only 4 warehouses).

The manufacture in bond scheme has not promoted Australian manufacturing industry and it tends to discourage investment in, and the sourcing of, materials and components from other domestic import competing industries, because with concessional entry under the scheme, it is often cheaper to source materials and components from overseas.

The scheme has also not been effective in promoting exports as only a small proportion of the goods produced in bond have been exported. The IAC noted, and the Government accepted, that there are alternative and more effective assistance schemes in existence which provide duty concessions on imported inputs, notably the commercial tariff concession system and, from the viewpoint of export promotion, schemes such as the duty drawback and by-law for export schemes.

The Government accepted the IAC's recommendation to abolish this scheme and announced, in May 1988 as part of the May Economic Statement, its intention to terminate manufacture in bond. The proposed amendment in clause 8 of this Bill will terminate the manufacture in bond facility as from 1 January 1990. The activities of blending and packaging however, will still be permitted in licensed warehouses.
Commercial Tariff Concession System

The main purpose of the amendments to Part XVa of the Customs Act (relating to the commercial tariff concession system) is to overcome the narrow interpretation that has been placed on the provisions contained therein by decisions of the Federal Court such as that in Corinthian Industries (Syd) Pty Ltd v Comptroller-General of Customs and others, contrary to the original intent of the Government when the scheme was introduced in 1983.

Notwithstanding that the Government has announced that the new Industry Commission will review the overall objectives and operation of the commercial tariff concession system, it believes immediate action is necessary to implement the proposals contained in this Bill, in order to restore the original intention of the system, overcome operational problems and provide additional benefits to industry. The changes proposed will enable the system to be effectively administered in the period up to the Industry Commission report, expected in late 1991.
By way of background to the proposed changes in clauses 18 to 29 of this Bill, it is opportune to recall the original purpose and intent of the legislative provisions in this part of the Customs Act.

On 2 July 1982 the Industries Assistance Commission reported to the Government of the day recommending that a modified commercial by-law system be introduced. The Government accepted the report and introduced the commercial tariff concession system with the clear intention that it would be broad in interpretation and predictable in administration.

The system provides a mechanism to allow the duty free entry of goods, where goods serving similar functions are not produced or capable of being produced in Australia in the normal course of business.

Experience with the system has pointed to several changes which could be made to improve operational efficiency. In the May 1988 Economic Statement the Government announced that it would modify the system to more closely align its operation with the Government's industry and technology policy objectives.
Subsequent to that Economic Statement, decisions by the Federal Court have highlighted restrictive and narrow interpretations to various definitions contained in the legislation.

To restore the Australian Customs Service's ability to administer the legislation in accordance with the Government's intentions, it is necessary to make appropriate changes to the legislation and fine tune operational aspects of the system. The amendments proposed in this Bill seek to achieve this.

In particular, it is proposed to delete from the legislation the interpretation of ``particular goods'', ``serving similar functions'' and ``capable of being produced/repaired in the normal course of business'', and the term ``particular'' from the phrase ``particular goods'' where it is no longer relevant. (Clause 18 refers).

These definitions have proven to be a source of contention and have forced administrators to interpret the legislation more narrowly than the Government intended. The removal of these definitions from the legislation and their replacement by principles for the interpretation of key phrases (Clause 19 refers), will ensure that administrators, importers and local manufacturers have a clear understanding of the system's objectives and will provide the flexibility to ensure that the system can be administered as the Government originally intended.

Further, as the Federal Court has determined in Corinthian Industries that the existing legislation limits the scope of a concession order to the particular goods that are the subject of an application, legislative amendments are necessary to enable commercial tariff concession orders to be issued in relation to the relevant class of goods rather than the narrowly specified products sometimes described in applications. This power, contained in clause 20, is necessary because, under the current provisions, neither the applicant nor the Comptroller-General of Customs is empowered to change the wording of an application. In practical terms this means that if, for example, after approaches to local manufacturers, an applicant accepts that a concession can only be issued for a narrower range of goods than that applied for, such a concession cannot be granted unless a new application is made. This results however, not only in a substantial loss of time, but importantly, the loss of the original operative date of the concession.
Another proposed amendment concerns section 269e, relating to the national interest discretion, amongst other matters.

Currently the Comptroller-General of Customs has the power to refuse to grant a concession order if he considers such a concession is not in the national interest. The Government considers that such power is more appropriately vested in a Minister, and therefore clause 22 effects the necessary amendment in this regard.

Finally, amendments are proposed to sections 269n and h of the Act by clauses 27 and 24 respectively to facilitate the granting of specified period concession orders, and simplify the date of commencement of all orders.

Currently, an application can be preceded by a notice of intention to make a concession order which allows the applicant twenty eight days to obtain and present the information required for a legal application. If the application is received within the twenty eight day period the date of lodgment of the notice of intention becomes the operative date when a concession order is issued. The Government proposes to abolish this practice and automatically make the date of effect for all concessions twenty eight days prior to date of lodgment of the application. Such action will reduce paper work for clients and unnecessary checking by administrators.

Similarly, under the current legislative regime concession orders cannot be granted for periods during an application's processing time. The Government believes in principle that in such circumstances a concession should be available, an initiative widely supported by industry. It is therefore proposed to amend the legislation to allow a concession order to be granted from cessation of availability of locally produced goods or from the normal date of commencement to the day local production commenced or a local manufacturer satisfies the capability to produce criteria. (Clause 27 refers).
Abolition of out of Bond Bottling/Packaging

The final matter I wish to address concerning this Bill relates to the proposed amendments to the Customs Act 1901 and the Excise Act 1901 in Clauses 9 and 37 respectively relating to the new control regime for imported and locally produced potable spirits.

The amendments propose that all potable spirits be bottled or packaged into non bulk containers in licensed premises prior to their entry for home consumption, which is the point at which duty is assessed and collected. The amendments will have the effect of removing the facility which currently exists for such spirit to be entered into home consumption in bulk containers. Such a practice has been identified both by this Parliament's Public Accounts Committee, and by the Industries Assistance Commission in its report No. 408 of 19 November 1987 on the Customs and Excise Bond System, as one which increases the possibility of illicit spirit production via the mixing of duty paid spirit with illicit spirit.

To address the possible risk both to Commonwealth revenue and public health from this practice of bottling or packaging spirit outside of licensed premises, the Government proposes as from 1 January 1990 to effect the change outlined.

The remaining provisions in this Bill propose a series of minor policy or technical drafting changes, which are explained in detail in the explanatory memorandum to this Bill. One of the proposed amendments however, I would like to touch on briefly here. That relates to the amendment in Clause 6, which provides a head of power to permit the making of regulations to impose a fee for services to defray the costs incurred by the Australian Customs Service in respect of preparing certain kinds of import entries lodged under Section 36 of the Customs Act 1901.

The Government appreciates the sensitivity which attaches to any cost recovery initiatives, and will only proceed with such fees after suitable consultation with relevant government agencies and industry bodies.
Financial Impact Statement
The proposed amendments in this Bill have no direct financial implications.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the accompanying explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.
