BROADCASTING AMENDMENT BILL 1989
This Bill represents the first stage of legislation to reform the operation of broadcasting regulation. It contains measures that address some immediate deficiencies in the Broadcasting Act 1942.

The Bill gives the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal access to more appropriate remedies in cases where a commercial radio or television licensee does not meet the basic suitability requirements that are currently applicable to a licence. It also includes amendments to:
confirm that the Minister can initiate, and the Tribunal can hold, joint inquiries into the grant of a licence for a supplementary or independent commercial FM radio service in a regional area;
allow aspirant public broadcasters to transmit sponsorship announcements when conducting test transmissions; and
allow public licensees to broadcast community promotional material.

Further reforms are to be developed quickly and will be contained in amendments to be introduced in the Autumn and Budget Sittings of Parliament next year. The reforms to be introduced early next year will focus on measures to improve substantially the operation of key areas of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's responsibilities, in particular, the ownership and control enforcement scheme. These reforms will be consistent with the wider review. The final package, to be presented in the second half of next year, will incorporate the conclusions of the wider review of broadcasting regulation.
I will deal now with the ownership and control provisions of the Bill.

At present, the Tribunal would be faced with extremely limited options if, after conducting an inquiry that it was required to hold, it were to find that a commercial licensee was no longer ``fit and proper'', or no longer had the financial, technical or management capacity to provide an adequate and comprehensive service. It presently may only impose licence conditions or suspend, revoke or not renew the licence. But if the licensee's unsuitability was due to the conduct or character of a person in a position to control the licensee company or its operations, licence conditions may not be an effective remedy. This is because the conditions may not be capable of affecting the influence of the relevant person on the licensee company. The only other remedies available-suspension, revocation or refusal to renew the licence-would put the service off the air.

Cessation of a service would penalise not only the licensee company, but also the viewing or listening public and other innocent shareholders and creditors. There is a need to give the Tribunal more flexible and less draconian remedies. This Bill achieves that objective.

The Bill allows the Tribunal, where it finds that a commercial licensee is no longer suitable to hold the licence, to issue specific directions to relevant parties and/or to impose appropriate licence conditions.
These provisions do not create new substantive powers for the Tribunal.

In the case of licence conditions, the Bill simply confirms that the existing power of the Tribunal under section 85 of the Act can be used as an alternative to licence cancellation. Similarly, in the case of directions, the Bill only extends the current directions power under section 92m of the Act to enable it to be used in the event of a failure by a licensee to meet basic suitability requirements.

In some circumstances, licence conditions or directions may still be insufficient to deal with the situation. In these cases, the amendments allow the Tribunal to order divestment of relevant interests.

If a relevant interest is directed to be divested a strict six month deadline will apply. This is because by then it would have been fully established by the Tribunal, if necessary through court and Administrative Appeals Tribunal avenues, that the licensee failed to meet the suitability requirements and that divestment was the appropriate remedy.
At this stage the Government proposes no change to arrangements for any divestment that may be required in other circumstances, such as following a breach of ownership limits.

The Bill also provides powers for the Tribunal to impose licence conditions and to issue directions to apply pending divestment. These powers will mirror the existing provisions that are available to the Tribunal pending its consideration of a share transaction. The purpose of this power is to enable the Tribunal to prevent actions that might adversely affect the service.

The range of licensing remedies provided in this Bill enables the sanctions of licence suspension or revocation to be put in a clearer perspective. These remedies are best used as an ultimate deterrent against repeated or serious breaches of the Act. This Bill will remove concern that such draconian actions could be taken by the Tribunal because it had no other real alternative.

At this point I would like to refer more generally to the powers that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has long held under section 85 to impose licence conditions at any time, and, under section 92m, to issue directions pending an inquiry into an ownership transaction. In recent months some doubt had been cast on the possible validity of the section 92m, power and a possible procedural requirement may have inhibited its use in practice. These doubts had led to calls for additional powers to be provided to the Tribunal. In the light of advice from the Attorney-General's Department, the Government now considers that the current section 92m powers are valid. There are no undue obstacles to the use of these powers, or to the imposition of licence conditions, in cases where such steps would be properly warranted by the circumstances. Accordingly, the Government is not proposing any amendments in this respect at this stage.

This Bill also makes some minor adjustments and clarifications that reinforce existing policy and do not pre-empt the Government's ongoing review of broadcasting regulation about which I will say more, later in these remarks.

The Bill places beyond doubt the power of the Tribunal to inquire concurrently into applications for grant of both commercial radio licences and supplementary licences in the same market. These amendments answer arguments that the Act may require those applications to be considered sequentially, an interpretation that could substantially delay the introduction of new, competitive radio services in non-metropolitan markets.

The Bill also will permit public broadcasters to transmit community promotional material. Presently, public broadcasters may transmit community information, which under recent interpretations, may not be promotional in nature. The Government considers that this is too restrictive and that public broadcasters should be able to promote actively genuine community events of interest to their listeners.

While the promotion of commercial sponsors will continue to be prohibited as a form of advertising, the Government is considering the implications of recent Tribunal findings (and a Federal Court decision) on these aspects, and may propose further clarifying amendments if that seems necessary.
The amendment has been cast in broad terms on the basis that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has power to make Program Standards in this area if the Tribunal considers that to be appropriate.

The Bill will also allow public broadcasters undertaking test transmissions to broadcast sponsorship announcements as if they were licensed services. This will assist aspirant public groups to pay for the tests, and enable them to gauge the level of support likely to be available within the community. Any breaches of the sponsorship requirements during the test would be an offence, and may also be taken into account by the Tribunal when it comes to determining who should be licensed.

The continued growth of public broadcasting as an integral element of the Australian broadcasting system is fully appreciated by the Government and these amendments will continue to assist that growth.

The changes proposed today serve to introduce immediate improvements to the present system. The basic legislation needs further improvement. I turn now to the question of further, more fundamental reform.

The Broadcasting Act has rightly been described as a complex, unwieldy piece of legislation. The Government is committed to its ongoing reform. In November 1988, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure tabled a report making recommendations on changes to the role and functions of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. This was followed by a supplementary report in May 1989. Both reports have proved to be valuable contributions in pointing out deficiencies in the present system and setting out issues for reform.

In July of this year, the Minister for Transport and Communications, released a Departmental discussion paper, ``Review of Broadcasting Regulation'', that focused mainly on the current regulatory system and suggested some options for change. Public comment was sought on that paper.

Most of the submissions received so far in response to the Departmental discussion paper have argued for extensive changes to the system of broadcasting regulation. Several interest groups have asked for more time to address the issues before making their full submissions, and the Minister for Transport and Communications has agreed to this.

The public debate has provided valuable further perspectives on difficult problems. There is widespread agreement on the need to introduce measures to increase the efficiency and effectiveness of the ownership and control scheme. But even more importantly, there has been general support, properly qualified by the need to protect the public interest, for the view that there would be merit in a more wide-ranging examination of broadcasting regulation. The submissions consistently argued for this.

The Minister for Transport and Communications has asked his Department to proceed with options for ongoing reform, building on the reforms already introduced by this Government. In 1987 this Government fundamentally reformed the television ownership and control limits in the Act. The following year we reformed the limitations on the ownership and control of commercial radio stations.

We replaced the old two station rule for television ownership with limitations based on audience reach. We replaced the old limits on radio station holdings with new limits which recognised growth and development in the radio industry. We also introduced cross media limits between radio, television and newspaper outlets in the same marketplace. Broadcasting ownership and control policies have thus been clearly stated and implemented by this Government. The rules embodying these policies have been laid down in the Act. In this area efficiency reforms are now called for.

At present the limitations on ownership and control are enforced by complex mechanisms, including an extensive system of notification and approval of a wide range of commercial transactions. Other areas of commercial activity do not have the same degree of oversight upon them-be it by the Trade Practices Commission, the National Companies and Securities Commission, or the Australian Stock Exchange-this is because, historically, the community and the Parliament have considered broadcasting to warrant a higher level of public scrutiny.

However, there needs to be a mechanism to scrutinise and enforce ownership and control limits by means that impose less of a burden on licensees, investors and the Tribunal. We intend to bring forward in the Autumn Sittings next year a package of measures to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the ownership and control scheme.

Ownership and control rules serve four separate main purposes. The first is to limit the concentration of ownership, control and influence of the media. The second, which is related to the first, is to encourage competition and diversity in programming and the range of views to be presented. The third is to restrict foreign ownership. The fourth is to support the present licensing requirements including the suitability of prescribed interest-holders in individual licences. There may be merit in developing legislation that addresses these aspects separately, so that non-controlling investors are not unnecessarily caught up in regulation addressing the suitability of those who control licences, and so that there is greater consistency with general business regulation that affects foreign ownership or aspects of ownership that affect competition.

This ``efficiency package'' may also streamline the Tribunal's public inquiry processes. However, in addition to taking immediate steps to introduce efficiency reforms in well settled areas of broadcasting policy there is a need to examine the principles of broadcasting regulation from a wider perspective. This aspect of the review will be directed at ensuring that future legislation more clearly serves explicit Governmental policy objectives, in particular, that the industry is subject only to the minimum regulation necessary.

Clearly, full deregulation is not appropriate for this industry because it involves so many important public interest issues. For that reason appropriate licensing arrangements and standards are still necessary, as are rules to limit cross media ownership, audience reach and multiple licence ownership.

The regulation that is retained in the revised scheme will need to be capable of efficient administration. There will need to be certainty for all affected parties, while maintaining appropriate public access and providing for natural justice.

Because of the high level of public interest in this area, I will now outline briefly its scope and the direction that the Government will be pursuing in its ongoing reform of broadcasting regulation. We will be addressing seven key areas.

First, future broadcasting legislation must serve the explicit policy aim that there be no more regulation of industry than is necessary to support stated objectives. The Government has previously spelled out objectives that address diversity and quality of programming, Australian content, local programming needs, concentration and diversity in broadcasting media ownership and control. It is the responsibility of Government to provide the environment in which broadcasting objectives can best be met.
This requires further consideration of the proper balance between structural measures-including an appropriate level of competition, perhaps linked to some self-regulation-and external regulation.

Secondly, Mr President, there is the area of new services and service delivery methods. The current scheme of legislation in broadcasting, radiocommunications and telecommunications needs to be re- examined to recognise the interactions
between broadcasting services and broadcasting-related services, such as Video and Audio Entertainment and Information Services or VAEIS and narrowcast services;
between broadcasting services and some emerging value added telecommunications services;
between broadcasting services and the cinema, video-hire and other VCR-derived services; and
between broadcasting and the Australian film, music and entertainment production industries.

This is certainly not to say that any regulation should be applied uniformly-or at all-to the various types of services; indeed quite the contrary. When the Minister for Transport and Communications released his Department's discussion paper, he said that the Government is committed to ensuring that services are not subjected to unnecessary regulation.

Where different technical or commercial arrangements deliver services that are essentially similar to the user, then it is inappropriate to subject them to different regulatory regimes. At present there are quite different regulatory arrangements governing programs provided in the cinema, on video-tape or through broadcasting. But as the differences in the means of access to programs become less significant, the regulatory differences need to be reduced or eliminated.

New applications for communications technology are being developed, and the distinction between broadcasting services and these new applications is becoming increasingly unclear. We need regulation that facilitates and encourages these new services. This means that they should not be subject to ad-hoc regulatory arrangements; nor should they be artificially forced into a traditional-and even outdated-broadcasting regulatory regime.

At the same time we need to recognise the interlocking nature of the various pieces of communications legislation, and continue to ensure their consistency and integration, and their relevance to what is happening out there in the real world. But this does not necessarily mean an all-embracing single communications Act. Rather it means the progressive updating of the legislation to achieve the objectives.

The third area comprises all those activities that are traditionally referred to as ``planning''. Communications planning processes need to be restructured to ensure accountability through a more transparent process.

Present arrangements require the Minister and the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to be heavily involved in judgments about when a service area needs or can support new commercial services. We need to develop arrangements that provide greater scope for broadcasters to take initiatives and carry them forward on their own responsibility to tap new markets and new market segments. We also need to examine whether community needs are better recognised and met by the integration of planning and licensing arrangements under the umbrella of an independent authority.

Mr President, the fourth area is that part of the Act dealing with ownership and control. The continuing need for limitations on ownership and control in the broadcasting industry-notably in the areas of foreign ownership, audience reach, cross media limits-is generally accepted.

Efficiency reforms are now called for in the regulatory mechanisms which presently supervise and enforce these limits and the Minister for Transport and Communications intends to introduce such reforms in the Autumn Sittings next year. The wider review, however, may consider other aspects of ownership and control not dealt with in the efficiency package.

The licensing system is the fifth area. This needs to be examined to achieve a more efficient and rational approach to licence allocation, review, and renewal. A broadcasting licence is still a valuable and marketable asset. There is a case for greater use of pricing mechanisms in licence allocation. This is the basis of the Government's National Metropolitan Radio Plan and has already been used in the process of AM/FM conversion for commercial metropolitan radio stations in all the mainland State Capital cities. There is now scope to extend such arrangements further.

At the same time, a licence carries with it certain public responsibilities and there are minimum suitability and service requirements that need to be met. The present legislative formulation of these requirements warrants further examination. However, whatever the outcome of such examination, allocation methods will need to continue to take account of these responsibilities and requirements; and regulatory powers are needed in this area.

The present Bill addresses some of the immediate problems in this area of licensing. But there is a need for further efficiency amendments and scope for further and more fundamental reform. This will be addressed with a view to developing arrangements that support the objectives of diversity, quality, and responsive commercial programming while eliminating undue regulatory intervention.

Sixth, the regulation of programming standards needs to be examined to ensure that quality is maintained in the broadcasting system. It is the Government's responsibility to safeguard the public interest, but this can be achieved by creating the right regulatory environment for industry to provide services of an acceptable standard. The question of whether standards need to be established by statutory regulation or self regulation needs to be looked at. However, this Government has no intention of abandoning its support for Australian content, quality children's programming and safeguards for community standards.

The seventh, and final, area involves the re-examination of the nature, responsibilities and method of operation of the regulatory agencies and the divisions of responsibilities between them and the Government. Regulatory policy is a matter for the Government and the Parliament. However the administration of regulation, as well as the provision of advice on its substance, can be and is presently assigned to, different regulatory agencies. Arrangements for administering regulation need to be consistent with the policy objectives for that regulation. While we need appropriate transparency and accountability in important regulatory decision making, we also need to find ways to streamline procedures so that regulatory processes provide opportunities for community involvement and do not unduly impede commercial arrangements.

While many of these issues have been addressed to some extent by recent review activity, we need to look at them again from a wider, more fundamental perspective. Proposals received during recent public consultations provide a valuable foundation for this exercise.

In examining future options, there will be wide consultation, both within the Government and with all interested parties outside Government. The Government wants to see the fullest public debate. This will include scope for further public comment directed to the Department of Transport and Communications throughout the review process and the release of position papers on relevant issues as the review progresses.

The Australian broadcasting industry has generally met audience and community needs well over many years. While we need to maintain continuity with this past achievement, we also intend to ensure that arrangements are in place to foster new and emerging market opportunities and to meet community needs and aspirations.

Mr President, the Government does not underestimate the complexity of the task that we have set ourselves. Those who may suggest that the fundamentals of broadcasting regulation are amenable to quick or simple reform fail to comprehend either the complexity and importance of the issues or the constraints of the existing legislation. Nonetheless we would hope to be in a position to introduce further legislation to improve regulatory efficiency during the Autumn Sittings, with the balance of our reform program being presented during the Budget Sittings.
Financial Impact
The Bill is expected to have no significant impact on Commonwealth expenditure or revenue.
I commend this Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum.
INDUSTRY COMMISSION BILL 1989
As foreshadowed in the budget, this Bill is to establish the Industry Commission.

The Bill sets out the scope of the Commission, its functions and policy guidelines, the constraints on Government changes to industry assistance without a Commission report, and composition and procedures.
It also proposes repeal and transition provisions with respect to the Industries Assistance Commission Act 1973 and the Inter-State Commission Act 1975.

On Budget night, the Government announced that the Industries Assistance Commission is to be restructured and renamed the Industry Commission which will become the Government's major review and inquiry body in industry matters.

Since that time, the Government has attached a high priority to the introduction of legislation enabling the establishment of the Industry Commission. That priority has reflected the Government's assessment of the need to continue the process of structural reform in this nation. The Industry Commission will be central to that.

Through its advice to the Government, the Industry Commission will play a key role in helping industry to become more efficient, more productive and more internationally competitive. And that is central to ensuring better growth prospects and better economic conditions in this nation over the years and decades ahead. Promoting efficiency is about promoting a better economic environment where growth and employment can be sustained.

Since coming to office, this Government has undertaken structural reform over a wide area of industry and business activity. Too quickly, people forget the fundamental nature of the financial market deregulation-including the freeing-up of capital movements and the floating of the exchange rate-that has fully brought Australia into the international economy. As a result, Australian industry has been forced to face squarely the imperatives of doing business in an international environment-and it is only in that environment that Australia will be able to provide the basis for sustained and rising living standards.

Structural reform has also been embodied in the fundamental reviews of taxation announced in 1985 and since. We have moved to a situation where Australia has a fairer and more efficient taxation system. That has been conducive to creation of a healthier business environment where firms and individuals are rewarded more for enterprise and hard work and less for their ability to secure unfair advantages through a distorted tax regime.
Equally, the Government has instituted major programs of reductions in tariff and other assistance to industries.
As announced in May 1988, tariff protection is being progressively reduced bringing Australia more into line with the sort of competitive pressures that our trading partners face.

More recently, the Government has begun a process of major reform on the waterfront. This will be, of course, a progressive process, building on the understanding already achieved, and which will continue to draw on the commitment and patience of all relevant parties. In stark contrast, our predecessors were too apt to put the problem in the too hard basket. The reforms of the waterfront and coastal shipping will provide a sound basis for achieving greater efficiencies in the movement and distribution of our goods. Employment prospects at large will be enhanced as the benefits of that greater efficiency flows through the economy.

Moreover, the Government has not shied away from the fundamental reforms required in the labour market. Together with the trade union movement and employers, the Government is working towards the development of a system that will promote greater productivity and modernisation of labour and management practices. That reform has gone hand in hand with seeking moderation in wages growth consistent with the requirements of the macroeconomic situation.

Substantial employment growth in the economy has already been achieved. These labour reforms offer the prospect of generating still more jobs and, through more productive and competitive industries, creating greater job security in the future.

All these reforms are bringing and will continue to bring real benefits to the Australian economy. They have also been part and parcel of a more sophisticated appreciation in Australia of the economic realities facing this nation. Those realities include the need to be more competitive and the need to be more hard-nosed about the use of Government resources. That debate is to be warmly welcomed-and the establishment of the Industry Commission and the transfer of the functions of the Inter-State Commission to that body will allow the Commonwealth to continue to play its major role in the development of sound industry policy in this nation.

The formation of the Industry Commission represents a new phase in the Government's ongoing strategy of structural adjustment. It is evidence of the Government's commitment to repond to the more sophisticated debate throughout the community on industry development and of the consequent greater requirements for information on policies of industry assistance and development. The Industry Commission will be better placed to participate fully in these developments and we must not waste any time in facilitating that process.

In that regard, the Industry Commission will further the important role that the Industries Assistance Commission has played in the structural adjustment process in Australia. It will build on the Industries Assistance Commission's earlier work which was instrumental in awakening the community to the costs of many industry assistance policies. As an institution, the Industries Assistance Commission has been an important force in economic policy in Australia, building community awareness of the need for Australian industry to be outward looking and inter- nationally competitive.
But the Industry Commission will have a broader charter and, with new guidelines attuned to the challenge ahead, will be an important stimulus for reform.

By providing independent and expert advice to the Government and through its public inquiry processes, the Industry Commission will facilitate the ongoing structural change that is needed in the economy. The Industry Commission will work to involve a wide range of groups in its inquiries as part of the process of building community awareness.

Consistent with that broader charter, all references on transport matters will in the future be sent to the Industry Commission rather than to the Inter-State Commission. The staff and functions of the Inter-State Commission will be absorbed by the Industry Commission.

This is particularly timely. We are all fully aware of the need to continue to address vigorously the transport issues confronting Australia. They go right to the heart of the question of how we in Australia can move our goods across vast distances at the lowest cost with due regard to the broader needs of safety and possible alternative uses of existing transport systems.

The Inter-State Commission has been at the forefront of inquiry and analysis of transport issues. It has been a dispassionate, objective and expert source of analysis in this area and has established a high quality network on transport issues which can be integrated into the Industry Commission. That expertise and experience must be fully brought to bear in the broader charter of the Industry Commission. In this enlarged body, the resources of the Inter-State Commission will have a key role in the identification and analysis of the interrelationships between all sectors of the economy and the transport sector. The ISC's expertise needs to be brought out in the wider economic perspective provided by the Industry Commission.

For a start, sound policy development should be based on a full appreciation of the facts. For instance, we should be aware of the extent to which subsidising railways for passenger operation is a cost to the Australian community; and we should be aware of the need to build on the recent reforms in coastal shipping and the need to improve railfreight operations in order to ease the burdens on our roads. All these aspects are interlinked. And that is the essence of what the Industry Commission is about. Namely, the identification of economic interrelationships and the specification of the costs and benefits involved in these relationships. It is only with this sort of information that the Commonwealth Government-and, indeed, the State Governments-can make sensible and considered choices as to future policy. Choices that will ensure better and more sustained growth prospects for all Australians.
The Government has also decided to establish an Office of Business Regulation as an administrative unit within the Industry Commission to absorb the functions of the Business Regulation Review Unit.

That Office will have a very important role. It will be dealing with matters that go to the heart of productivity in this economy. Inordinate and unnecessary regulation has a cost-just like any other barrier to efficient operation of business-and that cost is ultimately borne by the community.

Impediments to efficient operation of business and industry through regulation require as much attention as impediments flowing from other forms of industry regulation and assistance. It is therefore fully consistent with the charter of the Industry Commission that the functions of the Business Regulation Review Unit should be absorbed into this body. It will, apart from anything else, allow the Business Regulation Review Unit to gain the benefit of the economy wide perspective that will flow from the broader operations of the Industry Commission.

In all of this, the Government sees the establishment of the Industry Commission as providing an opportunity for a renewed and reinvigorated role for the States in the consideration of industry assistance matters in this nation. The States, of course, have responsibilities in many sectors of the economy-in intrastate transport, port authorities and electricity generation-which can impact significantly on the efficiency and competitiveness of industry. The Government will therefore be looking to cooperate closely with the States in the future on structural reform of the Government sector in Australia.
In particular, the Government would welcome the States' positive and full participation in the Industry Commission's process of public inquiries.

With that in mind, the Commonwealth will be approaching the States for their assistance in drafting the terms of reference for three inquiries that cover matters relating to State Government responsibilities. As announced by the Treasurer earlier this month, those matters relate to railways, the operation of statutory marketing arrangements and the generation and distribution of power.

We will be inviting the States' full participation in those and all other relevant inquiries. We trust that the States will grasp the opportunity in using the Industry Commission as a source of analysis and information on matters relating to the Australian economy in general-not just those matters falling within the purview of the Commonwealth Government.
This then is the context. I turn now to the key features of the Bill.
It should be noted that the Bill draws largely on the provisions of the IAC Act 1973, but also draws on appropriate provisions of the ISC Act 1975.
Except for an aspect of the repeal of the ISC Act, the Bill proposes that the commencement date of the Act would be by proclamation, or six months from Royal Assent, whichever is the sooner.

The definitions clauses include a broad definition of industry, which is intended to reflect the broadened charter for the Commission and the widest possible scope for its inquiries relating to industry.

Definitions also include ``subject of Commonwealth power'' which follows the provisions of the Constitution. This is relevant to the scope of matters on which the Commission can require evidence and information relevant to an inquiry.

The principal functions of the Commission are to hold inquiries and make reports on industry matters referred to it by the Minister. Bearing in mind that the Commission is to contribute to the process of structural change as described generally in policy guidelines for the Commission, the Commission's functions also allow it to do anything incidental to its functions.

The Government intends that, as part of analysis and advice on microeconomic reform issues, the Commission will give advice on business regulation, and prepare occasional research and information papers that contribute to enhancing community understanding of issues relating to structural reform.
The Bill sets out general policy guidelines to which the Commission must have regard in the performance of its functions. These are:
to encourage the development and growth of Australian industries that are efficient in their use of resources, self-reliant, enterprising, innovative and internationally competitive;
to facilitate adjustment to structural changes in the economy and to ease social and economic hardships arising from those changes;
to reduce regulation of industry (including regulation by the States and Territories) where this is consistent with the social and economic goals of the Commonwealth Government; and
to recognise the interests of industries, consumers, and of the community likely to be affected by measures proposed by the Commission.

The Commission must also have regard to any other matters notified by the Minister. For example, as in recent inquiries sent to the IAC, the Commission may be asked to have regard to the Government's environmental objectives in relevant inquiries.

Reports resulting from an inquiry process will be required to be tabled by the Minister within 25 sitting days after receipt. There is a provision for delay recommended by the Commission; for example, where the Commission is made aware of Governmental trade negotiations that might be disturbed by the timing of publication of a report.

The Bill contains provisions similar to those in the current IAC Act which constrain a Commonwealth Minister from taking certain prescribed actions unless a report by the Commission has been received within the previous 12 months. Allowance is made for a delay in the receipt of a Commission report.

Prescribed matters follow those in the IAC Act 1973 and concern changes in import duties and restrictions, and changes in financial assistance to an industry for more than two years. Financial assistance and an industry are defined.
Exemptions to prescribed matters are also set out.
Principally these include:
payments to Commonwealth corporations;
the imposition, increase or reduction of a tax (other than customs duty);
changes in customs duties that are only made to match corresponding changes in excise duties;
maintaining the level of customs duty previously applying where a decision by a Tribunal or Court on a tariff classification has had the effect of altering the duty;
the making of a commercial tariff concessional order or a by-law under the Customs Act 1901; and
action concerning international trade agreements and developing country tariff preferences.

The conduct of inquiries into matters referred to the Commission by the Government is intended to provide, as in the Industries Assistance Commission Act, for the fullest possible participation by all interested parties. The Commission is given wide discretion into how inquiries are to be conducted, and will not be overly bound by formal legal procedure, although there are appropriately strong protections and penalties for breaches with respect to a range of inquiry procedures.
The Commission will widely publicise the existence and the nature of inquiries.

The Government does not consider it necessary to restrict the flexibility of the Commission by overly prescribing the Commission's procedures. There are therefore no standing provisions requiring draft reports to be prepared pursuant to inquiries, or for the Commission to present a range of options in making recommendations to Government. These procedures may be left to the discretion of the Commission, it being understood that, as is the case with the IAC, the Commission will usually produce a draft report pursuant to an inquiry, thereby facilitating community debate, and will usually present a range of options in its recommendations to the Government. The Minister, in referring a matter to the Commission, will be able to require the publication of a draft report or the development of options in any particular case.

In order to make clear the Government's intention in respect of these matters, the Government has decided it is worthwhile to bring forward an amendment to the Bill during the course of its consideration to provide explicitly for possible requirement of a draft report and options in recommendations.

The Commission will have powers to obtain relevant information and documents for the purposes of an inquiry and the power to hold hearings, which will be held in public unless confidential material is involved. The Commission will also have power to summon persons to attend hearings and to answer questions or produce documents.
The Bill provides that the Commission is not to be given false or misleading evidence or information, and is not to be taken in contempt.

In order to contribute to widest possible community debate and understanding of the issues of an inquiry, the Bill provides for documents, statements and submissions received in the course of an inquiry to be made public. Nonetheless, there are provisions for information to be held as confidential where a person objects and the Commission considers the evidence should be protected.

The Bill maintains the protection of witnesses to an inquiry, and people making submissions to an inquiry, that are in the IAC Act. In particular, the Bill provides for penalties on persons who prejudice another person's employment because of their participation in an inquiry process.

The Bill specifies that the exercise of the Commission's powers for the purposes of an inquiry, for example to obtain information and documents from any person, including a State, is limited to the extent that the subject matter relates to a subject of Commonwealth power. The definition of subject of Commonwealth power is given in terms of constitutional provisions.
As for the IAC, the Commission will have a Chairperson and from four to eight full-time Commissioners, these being statutory appointments by the Governor-General for up to five years.
To supplement the Commission's resources and expertise from time to time, there is provision for the appointment of Associate Commissioners by the Minister.
There is a range of procedural provisions concerning Commissioners, which follow those of the IAC Act and other Acts providing for statutory appointments.
The Bill contains a separate part dealing with repeals and transitional arrangements.

The Bill provides for the IAC Act 1973 to be repealed. It also provides for the repeal at the same time of all but specified sections of the ISC Act, which remain as long as there is a holder of the office of Commissioner of the ISC. The Bill makes separate provision for the repeal by separate proclamation of those remaining parts of the ISC Act relating to Commissioners should there no longer be a holder of that office.
These repeal provisions are based on advice of the Solicitor-General in order to be consistent with provisions in the Constitution relating to the ISC.
The Bill provides for moneys and staff of the IAC and ISC to be transferred to the Commission. Similarly, current inquiries by the IAC are to be transferred and completed by the Commission.
There are provisions protecting the terms and conditions of appointment of ISC and IAC Commissioners who become Commissioners of the new body.
Transitional provisions protecting prior records and witnesses are also included.

Finally miscellaneous provisions of the Bill include a requirement that the Commission prepares an annual report which is to be tabled within fifteen sitting days of its receipt. The annual report is to address the economic performance of industry and the effects of assistance and regulation on industry and on the economy generally. The Government sees this report as an important component of the Commission's role in increasing community understanding of issues concerning structural change.

Indeed, a key contribution to the transparency of industry policy is to be made by the publication and tabling in Parliament of annual reports of the Commission. With a broader charter, the Commission's annual report will continue and expand the benefits that have flowed from the IAC's annual reports.

Earlier today, the IAC's annual report was tabled. That report ranges widely in its discussion of the benefits of micro-economic reform. It puts forward robust views and analysis of current industry policy issues, including a critique of strategic trade theories. It provides a stock-take of sectoral assistance measures.

There have been times when sectional interests, and even governments, have been uncomfortable with the perspective the IAC has brought to structural reform. No doubt this will also be the case with the most recent annual report. It will no doubt continue to be the case with the Industry Commission's annual reports-and it will continue to be an inescapable part of promoting transparency, vigorous community debate and broader understanding of industry issues.

To conclude, the establishment of the Industry Commission represents the Government's continued commitment to that transparency and full community debate in the development of policies relating to industry.

The Commission is intended to make a major contribution to further structural reform in Australia. It will be a catalyst for productivity and efficiency gains, and thereby lay the groundwork for income and employment growth and security. It will build on, and broaden, the strengths of the IAC and the ISC which it succeeds.

The Commission's economy-wide perspective, its broad charter and public inquiry process will play a key role in promoting policies at both government and business levels to improve the competitive and dynamism of Australian industry.
This Bill provides for an effective and broad ranging institution to serve the needs of Parliament, the people and government.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill, and I commend the Bill to the Senate.
HOUSING ASSISTANCE BILL 1989

The Housing Assistance Bill 1989 authorises the Commonwealth to enter into a new 10 year housing agreement with the states, the Northern Territory and, for the first time, the Australian Capital Territory, and appropriates moneys for financial assistance to the states and these territories for housing purposes in 1989-90 and for the years 1990-91 to 1992-93.

The Hawke Labor Government was elected in March 1983 with a firm commitment to renegotiate Federal Housing Arrangements with the states. The key objective of this Government's housing policy platform was to ensure that all Australians had access to adequate and appropriate accommodation at a price they could afford.

The Commonwealth-State Housing agreement is the Commonwealth Government's major housing program. It aims to relieve housing related poverty and to deliver housing assistance equitably to people in different housing tenures. Financial assistance has been provided to the states under a series of such agreements since 1945.

In 1984 we introduced legislation for the Housing Assistance Act 1984 and a new Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement to take effect from 1 July 1984. That agreement reflected the consensus view of Commonwealth and State Housing Ministers of how best to deliver an effective and equitable program of public housing assistance and demonstrated our commitment to a long term public housing strategy.

We backed up these changes with massive funding levels. In the five years ended 1988-89 we provided almost $3.4 billion under the CSHA, more than double the $1.6 billion provided in the last five years of the previous government.

Our initiatives have allowed us to boost the stock of public housing dwellings considerably, from 245,000 at 30 June 1983 to 316,000 at 30 June 1988, an increase of almost 30 per cent. While public housing accommodates about 5 per cent of all Australian households, it is targeted on those most in need in our society. At 30 June 1987 almost 70 per cent of public housing tenants were on pensions or benefits representing 26 per cent of the total number of pensioners and beneficiaries who rent. Almost 1 in 4 families with children who rent live in public rental dwellings.
These figures show that our targeting of public housing assistance and the level of funding provided have made a major impact on housing related poverty in this country.

But pressure on public housing has continued to grow and there is an ongoing need to ensure that our programs remain well targeted and effective. Against this background, we undertook a major review of the existing policies and practices under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement with the aim of identifying improved strategies for the future.

This review found that the viability of the CSHA was under threat and that unless action were taken by the Commonwealth, there would be a significant diminution of states' public housing effort in future years.

This was because states had been using commercial borrowings to meet their matching requirement and the resulting debt servicing obligation, combined with a growing rent rebate Bill, had been eroding their capacity to fund new public housing. The review concluded that significant changes should be made to the current arrangements for financing, targeting and administering public housing.

The review recommended a number of specific changes to CSHA provisions for funding, including changes to matching and the use of funds. These recommendations were designed to put the provision of public housing on a more secure long term financial basis, and to ensure states make a greater financial contribution to the provision of public housing.

Following consideration of these recommendations, we put forward a proposal to the States for a new CSHA at the May 1989 premiers' conference. After detailed negotiations with states a new agreement was developed which forms part of this Bill.

The new agreement will represent the most significant reform of public housing since the CSHA was first introduced by the Chifley Government in 1945. At the same time, the principles introduced by this Government in the 1984 agreement remain valid. These are to alleviate housing related poverty and to ensure that housing assistance is, as far as possible, delivered equitably to persons resident in different forms of housing.

Under the new agreement it is proposed that in each of the 10-years from 1 July 1989, Commonwealth financial assistance to the States under the CSHA will be provided entirely in the form of grants, rather than as a mix of grants and concessional loan council moneys. Half of States' matching effort will also be required to be met with grants. This will result in a major increase in real State effort and will ensure that States' ability to finance public rental housing will no longer be constrained by a burgeoning debt servicing obligation.
In the five years ended 1988-89, state contributions made in the form of grants were only about one-tenth of the value of Commonwealth grant contributions.
States have also agreed to absorb any future losses on their rental operations.

From now on the great bulk of Commonwealth and State matching funds will be used for the direct provision of public rental dwellings. Based on 1989-90 funding levels we expect that the impact of these new arrangements will allow around 52,000 net additions to the public dwelling stock over the next five years. At the same time around 650,000 people will be able to be offered public rental housing, an increase of around 20 per cent on the past five years.
This public housing effort will allow a greater focus on those in greatest housing need-very low income earners and social security recipients for whom home ownership is not an option.

Prior to this agreement, a large proportion of Commonwealth funds were being provided through loan council borrowing arrangements. While adding to overall funds, loan council arrangements distorted the allocation of funds among states, so that the funds were not sufficiently targeted to areas of highest need. For example, the Northern Territory received about half the level of funds received by New South Wales, in spite of the vast difference in population.

This anomaly will be rectified under the new agreement. All funds will now be provided as grants and their distribution among states will move to a per capita basis. This will be a major step in directing assistance to where that assistance is needed. The phasing in of the per capita distribution over three years will allow states time to adjust their operations.

The new agreement demonstrates our commitment to improving access to home ownership for low income earners. States will continue to be able to draw on funds retained from past allocations to finance their general home purchase assistance programs. The net level of these funds is currently of the order of $360 million. States are encouraged under the agreement to gear up these funds with private sector funds, to boost the assistance available. States' capacity to draw in private sector funds will also be expanded considerably as a result of our decision to clearly exempt such raisings from loan council borrowing limits. This removes any uncertainty which existed in the past.
A proportion of new CSHA funds also will be directed to home purchase programs from 1989-90 onwards and these will be targeted to existing public tenants and applicants on the waiting list.
In addition states are able to meet the other half of their matching obligation with home purchase assistance loans and this will add a further incentive for them to expand their programs.

These changes will encourage a far more efficient use of funds than in the past and will allow states to considerably expand their home ownership lending programs by implementing innovative schemes to closely meet the needs of low income home buyers.

Over the next five years we expect that around 200,000 low and middle income home buyers will receive home purchase loans under CSHA programs. This is a substantial increase on the 68,000 home loans provided in the five years ended June 1988. Because repayments on CSHA home loans are linked to income, this initiative will significantly boost access to affordable home ownership for lower income earners.

Assistance under the agreement is well targeted, and priority in granting assistance is determined by need. However, a key change will be made to existing administrative arrangements to ensure that we continue to meet these objectives, and improve our linking of public housing with other assistance programs.

In the past States have been able to use general agreement funds without any reference to specific Commonwealth priorities or objectives. A new system of priority setting will be implemented under the agreement through the establishment of a joint Commonwealth-State planning process. Through this process we are aiming to ensure, without inefficient duplication of administration, that the provision of public housing assistance remains in accord with the principles of the CSHA and responsive to the needs of clients. It will focus on improving equality of access to appropriate accommodation and will ensure better co-ordination of public housing provision with other programs.

It is envisaged that the development of Commonwealth-state plans will ensure that the priorities of all groups, including youth, people with disabilities, Aboriginals and the aged are met under public housing arrangements. There is a range of Commonwealth programs which need to be linked to public housing provision (for example, programs covering accommodation for the aged and people with disabilities), and the joint planning process will ensure this occurs.
As part of the joint planning process we will be consulting with community groups, to ensure a full range of views on public housing is taken into account.

There is an increasing awareness in the community of consumer protection issues to uphold the dignity, independence and freedom of the individual, to preserve people's rights and to provide protection of those rights.

The new agreement provides that information will be made available to clients about housing assistance and policies. In addition independent appeal mechanisms are to be established in each state by September 1990. These initiatives link with our user rights strategies for service provision in the areas of aged care, supported accommodation and home care.

The position of clients is to be further enhanced under the new agreement. The Commonwealth and states are to examine the issues of increasing choice of housing between public rental and home purchase assistance, portability of eligibility for assistance between states and improved maintenance arrangements.

Mr President, this government has backed up the new arrangements with funds. In 1989-90, for the first time, over $1 billion will be made available in grants under the agreement. Furthermore, the Commonwealth government will guarantee at least this level ($1.028 billion) for each of the three years 1990-91 to 1992-93. Total funding for those years will be determined annually in the Budget context. This $4 billion guarantee is unprecedented and shows this government's determination to deliver on its social justice commitments in housing.

The Bill also provides for two further appropriations in 1989-90. $9.8 million will be appropriated for specific grants to the states and the Northern Territory for housing assistance for young people.
These funds form part of our social justice package for young Australians which is part of the response to the problems highlighted in the Burdekin report on youth homelessness.
The funds will be used to provide accommodation linked to support services for homeless young people. This will help them become more independent and guide them to longer term stable accommodation.

$14.7 million will also be appropriated to provide additional mortgage relief funds. These funds will be provided to the states and the Northern Territory to assist low and moderate income earners who are experiencing difficulty in meeting their mortgage commitments. These funds were earmarked in the Budget and are additional to those already provided through the mortgage and rent relief scheme.

Mr President, the Commonwealth government is committed to housing access, and to the Commonwealth-state housing agreement. The structural reforms embodied in the new agreement together with the substantial increase in funding and forward commitment for future years will significantly enhance our public housing effort. Based on current funding, over the next five years we expect to see around 650,000 people offered public rental dwellings, 52,000 additions to the public rental stock and around 200,000 home loans provided to low and moderate income families.

I believe that we will be able to make significant inroads in alleviating housing related poverty in 1989-90 and over the 10-years of the agreement. We will also see improved public housing effort by all parties to the agreement, better targeting of assistance to high need areas, improved choice of assistance and more open, accessible and responsive administration.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
I now present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.
Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) agreed to:
That these Bills be listed on the Notice Paper as separate Orders of the Day.

Department of Administrative Services

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Department of Administrative Services covers an inordinately wide range of activities and there was very considerable debate during the Estimates Committee hearings on many of those aspects. I do not propose to go over again too much of what was covered in the Estimates Committee hearings. The Department of Administrative Services is obviously undergoing some major changes. There is a process of commercialisation in much of its activities, a principle that we on this side of the chamber support. I have the impression that, in that process of moving towards a more commercialised basis of operations, there have been a few hiccups along the way, and I guess that is understandable. I do not know whether, in responding to my remarks, the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) might wish to comment on that general impression that I certainly gained.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to pursue a couple of matters a little further. After the Estimates Committee hearings, I received answers to some of the questions I had put on notice. They were not available at the time of the hearings. The first to which I refer particularly is an answer that I received to my question about how much, if any, office space leased by the Commonwealth, both domestic and international, was unoccupied in 1988-89 and, in each case, what was the approximate cost of this unoccupied space and its allocation.

The answer that I received was very detailed. It listed all of the properties involved. What amazed me was that the cost of office space leased by the Commonwealth and unoccupied during 1988-89 totalled a staggering $9.95m, nearly $10m, which was expended on, to quote the Department's words, `unoccupied leased office space in Australia'. In the answer it was also stated that, of this amount, $5.93m was attributable to rent paid for unoccupied office space during planned fitout but, nevertheless, I find that figure extraordinarily high. On my calculations it represents 2.51 per cent of total rent outlays, so $1 in every $40 that the Commonwealth spent in 1988-89 on rent has gone for dead rent.

There are some notable examples in the list of properties given. In my own State of Victoria the amounts range from $22,559 for a property at 33 Railway Parade, Camberwell-I do not know what that is-to $920,907, or almost $1m, in 1988-89 in dead rent for one property alone at 538 Collins Street, Melbourne. Another $682,366 was spent on dead rent for a property at 340 Albert Street, East Melbourne and $208,313 was spent on a property at 58 Queensbridge Street, South Melbourne. They are the biggest ones. The list goes on. The total for Victoria, in round figures, was $2.46m which was close to the New South Wales total of $2.6m. It seems to me that the total figure for dead rent is extraordinarily high. I should like the Minister's comments on what I have raised and, in particular, what steps are being taken or will be taken to prevent similar waste in future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short's calculations are right but the conclusions he draws are somewhat unfair. The question of dead rent is trending down. Anybody who goes back through the transcripts of a series of Estimates Committee hearings will see that that is right. I think it is ironic that the Government is being criticised for a 2 1/2 per cent average dead rent when, time and time again, I hear in this chamber that the commercial sector is more efficient, lean and so on, and its average dead rent is 4 to 6 per cent. I am not saying that 2 1/2 per cent is a satisfactory figure, but it is trending down and a lot of that results from questions asked at Estimates Committee hearings and pressure coming from the Minister to reduce the figure. As I say, compared with the commercial sector, it is quite an achievement.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that Senator Short's major concern was rent paid for a property at 538 Collins Street. That was intended for the National Crime Authority. At first it said it was satisfactory but it came back later and said that the security aspects were not satisfactory. I do not think that the Department of Administrative Services can be held to account for that particular site. It is now being occupied by the Australian Taxation Office. I would have thought that higher security would have been needed for Tax on some occasions than for the National Crime Authority, but nevertheless, Tax has gone there. In conclusion, no-one likes dead rent. No government, either Labor or Liberal, has liked dead rent. But at least the trend is down and well below the commercial sector. We must be vigilant to make sure that that trend continues down.

TALK.START.PARA: —While on this subject, could the Minister let us know what the $900,000 was for-I think that was roughly the figure-which was involved in the Zenith Centre at Chatswood? SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately I have a longer corporate memory than my advisers. I will have to check and get the honourable senator an answer. I thought that when I first attended the Estimates Committee this was one of the questions I was raising. I was sure that a substantial amount of government money went to the Menzies Foundation. I will check my memory and get back to the honourable senator on the matter. I will take that part of the question on notice and will give the honourable senator the amount and the comparison between the grants to these foundations in real terms. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister in anticipation of his checking that. My understanding is that the Menzies Foundation had never received Commonwealth funds. Indeed, that was one of the reasons why, in 1979, the Fraser Government refused to provide the Evatt Foundation with a grant of funds from the taxpayer. One of the other reasons was that the whole basis of the Menzies Foundation was very different from that of the Evatt Foundation as it was then proposed, because the guidelines or rules and regulations relating to the Evatt Foundation at that time-and I think I am correct-was that a person had to be a member of the Labor Party to be involved with the foundation at all. As Malcolm Fraser said back in 1979 in the debate in the House of Representatives, the then Government refused to provide the foundation with a grant because:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . some of the purposes of the Foundation, as revealed by one of the documents-
that were presented to the Government in relation to the application-
indicate a very close relationship to the Australian Labor Party rather than to broader national perspectives.

I would be interested to hear the contrary view expressed by the Minister, but I do not think that there is any doubt that the H. V. Evatt Foundation is an ALP front organisation. It was established by the ALP and its original constitution provided-and this is what I was referring to before-that only current members of the ALP National Executive are eligible to become members of the foundation. I think in later years that has changed, but that was certainly the case when the foundation was established and in its first couple of years. In 1987 the foundation established a research centre which, according to an ACTU circular, consists of a:
. . . network designed to give Trade Unions and community groups access to researchers.

The Evatt Research Centre, under that guise, jointly with the Australian Public Service Federation, recently undertook a project and produced a document entitled State of Seige designed to promote the public sector. The following opening sentence of that document sets its tone and the whole flavour:
This book extends the union movement's analysis of public sector funding and reform to the State tier of government.

What the Government has done with its funding of the H. V. Evatt Foundation is to give a commitment on the basis of a letter written in 1984 from the then President of the Foundation, who I think at that time was the then Australian Council of Trade Unions President, Cliff Dolan, although I am not 100 per cent certain of that. According to the answers I have received from the Department in response to my questions on this, in April 1984 the President of the H. V. Evatt Foundation wrote a letter to the Government seeking a commitment of funds. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) replied in July 1984 saying that the Government had agreed to commit $2.5m of taxpayers' funds to this Foundation over a period of 10 years. That is an awful lot of money. Without any doubt, it is reasonable to say that that is money for purely party political purposes and I think that the taxpayers have every right indeed to be very cranky at parties that shell out their moneys for organisations whose whole purpose is party political. I would welcome the Minister's comment on this because it is, in my view, a very important issue. Some might say that $2.5m is not very much over the spread of government expenditure, but it is a lot of money and there is a very important principle involved as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —A bit of dexterity has been used by Senator Short when he goes back to the 1979 constitution and later admits that it has been changed, but does not spell out how it has been changed. I certainly refute the suggestion that Senator Short has made that the H. V. Evatt Foundation is very close to the Labor Party, et cetera. I have been on the National Executive of the Labor Party for seven years and I have had hardly any contact at all with that organisation. Maybe the odd letter has come in saying that it is providing this scholarship or this research fund. Even in the internal wings of the Labor Party, I cannot ever recall a discussion in which the H. V. Evatt Foundation has particularly come up.

SPEECH.PARA: I am still trying to get the honourable senator an answer to the early part of the question: did any money directly-and, I should add, indirectly-go to the Sir Robert Menzies Memorial Trust from the Government. I do not know whether the money went there by way of tax deduction or as a direct grant, but my recollection is that the stimulus for the H. V. Evatt Foundation to apply for money came from what it saw as money going to the Sir Robert Menzies Memorial Trust. However, I do say that it is only my judgment, but it is not fair to say that the H. V. Evatt Foundation is a Labor Party front. I really do not think it is. I do not think that the Labor Party has much influence in the way it operates-certainly not in an organisational sense. I have no doubt that some members of the Labor Party are involved in the H. V. Evatt Foundation. As to the second question of whether that organisation is entitled to that amount of money, that is a government decision; it is a decision that the Government has to justify and the Government has to live with.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wanted to raise a couple of points. I am sorry that they are a bit all over the place. I understand that the retiring Electoral Commissioner, Dr Hughes, in a recent interview said that, for practical, administrative reasons, it would be impossible to hold an election later than, I think 5 May. I wondered what are the constraints. Are they constraints of staff or something else that bring forward that date, which I thought otherwise, constitutionally, would have been much further progressed into May?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Without agreeing with Dr Hughes on that subject-I read the article and heard him interviewed-I wish to say that the constraints on getting a Senate vote counted are not staff restraints, per se. It is one of those things: the number of staff can be trebled but there might be no more productivity because it is the competency of the staff which is involved which is important. The reality is that, if there were to be a half Senate and House of Representatives election, it would be something like two weeks after the date of that election before the Commissioner can strike a quota for the Senate. He has to wait for all postal votes and all absentee votes to come in. Technically it could be done earlier, but then one in 1,000 counts would go astray-something of that magnitude. Having done that, given the counting methods now involved, following that there could be up to a six-week count in New South Wales, in particular, because of the number of ballot papers cast and because of the large number of candidates running. That is the factor that is involved. The more candidates who run, the more likely a long delay.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1987 this Parliament put two other provisions into the Act. One was bulk exclusion by which, at the very last quota, all the rubbish, if I can call it that, can be thrown out in the knowledge that they can never get up to the two or three main candidates. The second is the provision for delayed transfer of preferences. Again, that speeds up the process. I think Dr Hughes was probably lodging a bit of an ambit claim for the fifth, but certainly it would bring enormous pressure and difficulty if the election were to be held in late May. Let us not specify in between times. If it were late May, that would bring an enormous pressure to get the count done. It is not a question of just saying, `We will throw in an extra million bucks', because competent people are needed to track those preferences through. Remember that 80 to 85 per cent of voters in the election for the Senate provide no difficulty in the count because they put the number 1 in the box and, therefore, it is all automatic, because it is from a registered how-to-vote card. It is for those 20 per cent who vote below the line that the mechanical transaction is needed. If the number of staff is doubled but the competence is reduced by half, it is back to square one.

So essentially he is right in saying that there is that sort of constraint. It has always existed. The more complex the counting system, the more it pushes the barrier back into May. I would say that, certainly by late May, the options run out. I do not know what the constitutional situation is if the election is not declared by 1 July when senators are due to take their place here. I do not want to know; I do not want to see that happening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 October I raised in the Estimates Committee hearing in the discussions with the Australian Construction Services area the issue of tendering on major construction projects for architectural and engineering services in joint venture arrangements with private contractors or private consultants. On that day the officers of the Department-this is at page E93 of Hansard-took a number of points on notice and have since responded in a letter dated 8 November 1989 to the Estimates Committee E.

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned that the answer given does not properly address the policy issues that have been canvassed. My specific question was the extent to which the resources are being applied by the Department where various State divisions were, in effect, involved in competing for the same projects in conjunction with other private tenderers or contractors seeking to get work from the Government. The reply I received from Mr Ian Woonton, the Acting General Manager, was as follows:

I have canvassed our State offices and there were two projects in which different State divisions of Australian Construction Services were involved. These were the Alice Springs Airport development and the Darwin International Terminal building.
On the Alice Springs project, three State offices, Queensland, Western Australia and South Australia/Northern Territory submitted expressions of interest, all with different joint venture partners.
On the Darwin project, the Queensland State Office undertook some design work and the South Australia/Northern Territory Office submitted a proposal to a tenderer.

I have not provided specific details of the resources applied and the costs involved. At the hearing, Mr Jacka indicated that this information would not be regarded as ``Commercial-in-Confidence''. I have since discussed this matter with Mr Jacka and we agree, on reflection, that it is.

With respect, I do not believe that I am seeking the individual arrangements that are made with particular tenderers or contractors; rather, I believe that the departmental resources involved in cross-subsidisation on a particular project where different divisions are participating is a quite serious misuse of Commonwealth expenditure. I would like to know the extent of funds that have been applied and the resources involved, given the extensive nature of the two projects named-the Alice Springs Airport development and the Darwin international terminal building.

I fail to see how the departmental resources applied to professional architectural and engineering services of this nature would be less than some considerable thousands if not hundreds of thousands of dollars. I believe that further information in this regard should be provided to this Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, the honourable senator overlooked the last paragraph of that letter, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Generally, the resources applied by ACS were insignificant, due to our subsidiary role to the major proponent.

Even if that were not the case, there is a dilemma. These people are asked to behave in a commercial way and, if they act in a commercial way and become profitable or break even, I cannot see any basis for a complaint. One cannot retain all the old restrictions on these sorts of bodies and expect them to operate in a commercial way. I think Senator Short mentioned that there were some hiccups in relation to the commercialisation aspect, and that is so. Having freed them up, governments would find it difficult to resist interfering and to say, `Yes, we have freed you up, but we still want you to abide by this or that', which constraints do not apply to the private sector. If the stage were reached where the sort of competition about which the honourable senator speaks was running these bodies into a loss situation, I believe he would have a much stronger point, but surely one must spend a dollar to make a dollar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The dollars the Minister wants to spend are obviously quite significant, and I dispute the point that is made in the last paragraph of Mr Woonton's letter. Let me reinforce the point by again quoting a portion of his letter. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: On the Alice Springs project, three State Offices, Queensland, Western Australia and South Australia/Northern Territory submitted expressions of interest, all with different joint venture partners.
On the Darwin project, the Queensland State Office undertook some design work and the South Australia/Northern Territory office submitted a proposal to a tenderer.

Three different divisions of the Department were involved on one project and two were involved on the other. In relation to funds, what is the Minister's definition of `insignificant'? There can be only one successful tenderer at the end of the day and, whilst I would draw the comparison with the commercial sector, I am sure that, if we had a professional architectural or engineering office of national significance which sought to look at a particular project, it would coordinate the resources of its various State divisions and it would ensure that three State divisions did not waste significant resources.
