Will the Minister quantify the extent of resources that have been applied on these projects and, as part of the commercialisation project, does the Government intend to allow State divisions to run around willy-nilly, without coordination, on other government projects which are all off the taxpayers' nipple and which involve a considerable wastage of taxpayers' funds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an interesting economic theory. The honourable senator is effectively saying that competition does not lead to lower price tendering. On the major point as to whether there should be a national overseeing of tendering processes, I will refer that to the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) for his consideration, because I never dismiss those sorts of suggestions out of hand. The trouble with that sort of centralised approach is that managers are not really allowed to manage. They have to be overseen from Canberra and then the whole freeing up process begins to be pulled back: if they are overseen in this regard, why not oversee them in regard to industrial relations or a dozen other practices? Why not reimpose a whole variety of controls? If that occurs, we are back to square one.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I will refer to the Minister for Administrative Services the suggestion that it would be a better practice to have some national overseeing body of competitive tendering. I repeat that I do not believe that the taxpayer will necessarily be worse off in the end. One would hope that much of the creative competition would lead to a lowering of prices, if there was no collusion, and then those other government departments could effect considerable savings. Hopefully, if they tender for other Government jobs and compete in the marketplace, it will lead to a lower price. If it does not lead to a lower price, perhaps we will have to revise the philosophy of market capitalism.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not believe that the Minister addressed the other question relating to the resources that were applied to these projects and the extent of the funds that would have been committed on both the Alice Springs and Darwin projects. I would also like to know whether the Department's arrangements on either of these projects have been successful.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Through lack of knowledge, I am not in a position to answer the latter part of the question. I will take that portion on notice. The honourable senator asked me to define the word `insignificant'. He really invites me to be cruel, but I will not. Mr Ian Woonton regarded the resources as `insignificant'-that was his expression. I suppose that I could ask him to provide a further definition for the honourable senator. All I did was read out the passage that he omitted so as to round off the situation. I will try to obtain a definition in that very restrictive sense in terms of these costs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise a matter which was raised in debate last year, because I think it is important. The practice to which I refer does not seem to have changed very much. The Government has adopted the practice of increasing its ministerial staff strength through the use of consultants. In answer to my question on notice about this matter I received the advice that in 1988-89 Department of Administrative Services expenditure on ministerial consultants was $1,996,670, or nearly $2m. That information is published each year in the annual report, as required under the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act 1984, but that report has not yet been tabled. The advice I have had from the Department is that the annual report will be tabled before the end of this calendar year, but that will relate, as I understand it, to the cost of consultants in 1988-89 presumably. It is not possible to ascertain from the Budget Papers the cost of consultants in the current financial year 1989-90. Apparently, these costs- and I quote from the answer I received from the Department-are met from within the appropriation for running costs, namely, division 120.1. The item could be as long as a piece of string and, in my view, there should be a requirement on the Government to reveal at the time of the Budget how much it is proposing to spend on ministerial consultants.

SPEECH.PARA: Apart from that, I again raise the question about the propriety of the use of ministerial consultants on Ministers' staffs and the way the Government has been doing it. Ceilings are supposed to apply to ministerial staff, just as there are ceilings on the staffs of shadow Ministers. Ministers are already supplied-I know it varies from one Minister to another-with something like 10 staff on average, at public expense, and that is probably an underestimate. These people are employed as professionals to meet the Ministers' political and ministerial requirements. Over and above that, we have had this device, which has been increasingly used since 1984, of putting consultants on the payroll as well. Indeed, there has been a 500 per cent increase since 1984 in the annual cost of consultants on Ministers' staff. In 1984 the figure was $364,092; last year the figure was almost $2m. It has gone up sixfold, a 500 per cent increase. All up, the cost since 1984 is now about $7.5m. Those figures exclude completely the cost of the thousands of consultants, I would think, nowadays employed by government departments and agencies. I am not suggesting that government departments and agencies should not use consultants; I think in many cases it is a very sensible thing to do. But I make the point that the figures I am talking about now completely exclude those.

The other aspect of the use of consultants on ministerial staffs that concerns me, and I note it with interest, is that if one looks through the list of consultants, whilst there are some exceptions, it almost looks like a who's who of former Labor parliamentarians, Party members and candidates. Having looked at the list of people that are employed as consultants and the purposes for which they are supposedly employed, there is no doubt that many people on those lists are not there because of any expertise they have in the particular areas for which they have been engaged; they are there simply because of their links with the Australian Labor Party. We have gone through this before. We have named on previous occasions certain consultants who stand out strikingly in that context, and I do not propose to do that again.

The other point I raise in relation to this-and I think it was my friend and colleague Senator Boswell who asked the question that elicited this information-is that the total staff of Ministers, throwing in consultants, the ministerial media group and Ministers' staffs, has shown a staggering increase. Ministers' staffs have gone from 165 in 1983 to 228 in 1989.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you include the Government Information Unit in the base figure?

—Yes, I think so. I think this is information supplied by the Department in response to Senator Boswell's question. For example, the number of consultants has gone up from three in 1983-84 to 28 in 1989. Indeed, there was more than 28 used in the course of the year as a whole; but there has been an enormous increase in consultants. The ministerial media group has gone up by several. Anyway, the total increase in Ministers' staffs, on the figures that became available in response to Senator Boswell's question, over the period is 63, from 165 to 228. Over the same period, the Opposition's additional staff has gone up by 11, from 48 to 59. So the Opposition resources have gone up by 11 and the staff resources available to the Government have gone up by 63.

SPEECH.PARA: In every case under the Hawke Government there has been a mighty increase in the number of staff it has allocated to itself. A point that concerns me very much is that these increases are over and above the Remuneration Tribunal's determinations, as I understand it. The Government gets around the determinations of the Remuneration Tribunal by, in particular, the use of consultants. I think it is a practice which is open to very considerable abuse. I would be interested to hear the Minister's comments on this. It is not an issue that we are raising for the first time. It is an issue that has concerned us on this side of the chamber for some considerable time. That is the reason we have been raising it. There does not seem to be any response to those concerns. I think it is about time that there was a response, and I would be interested to know whether the Government, through the Minister, has changed its attitude towards this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The figures I had available to me suggested that in 1983 there were 203 people working in this area, and it has gone to 287 at the end of 1989.
—Two hundred and three to 287?
—Yes.
—That is an even bigger increase than I was giving credit for.

—I am just putting the figures down that have been given to me. Of course, the creation of three extra ministries accounts for 25 of those individuals. We were roundly criticised for having a ministry of 30. We have now got a shadow Ministry of 31-odd.
—No, we haven't; 30.
—It is back to 30, is it? Somebody must have gone. It is not surprising that I did not notice.
—If you don't notice things, it doesn't surprise me.

—Gee, some of the shadow Ministers-not Senator Puplick; I could not miss him with that tie-fair dinkum are not hard to miss. Senator Boswell should not smile; I have never missed him. I think the first great act of the Fraser Government when it came in was to reduce the Opposition staff entitlement. So when the Opposition comes in here and bleats about how it is being treated, do not expect me to break down and sob. In fact, the Opposition has been given a 19 per cent increase in staff, whereas Mr Anthony and Mr Sinclair, as soon as we went out of government, made sure that we were fitted up nice and properly.

SPEECH.PARA: However, in a more serious vein, Senator Short makes a point about the use of consultants and the philosophy of consultants. It has been discussed many times before about whether it is better to increase average staff over time or bring in specialists to do a certain job. I have to declare a self-interest in this: I have never employed a consultant, so I do not have personal experience as to how they operate. I notice that one of the consultants, Mr Garnaut, was employed by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans). I do not agree with everything that is in it, but it is a marvellous report. It was certainly value for money.

I would like Senator Short to add, for my education, whether the coalition, if it were returned to office at the next poll or the one after, would not employ ministerial consultants. If he would not say that, would he say so now? Would he tell me how many consultants it would employ so that we can measure its bona fides and see whether its criticisms are valid? Or is it just a case of an out-group whingeing about what an in-group has and doing exactly the same when it becomes an in-group? Would he let us know how many consultants the coalition thinks government should hire in any one year, so we can see whether we can hold it to its promises? I do not recall a coalition spokesman giving us a guarantee on that. Can Senator Short guarantee that the Opposition, if it ever wins office, would maintain the staffing level for the opposition, or would it slash it as it did in 1976? Can Senator Short say in advance what he thinks is the appropriate level of consultants for Ministers and would the Opposition abide by that in government?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always interesting to see the Minister in a self-righteous mode. The figures that he has just given to the Committee demonstrate the most disgraceful partisan approach possible to the provision of staff. He beat his chest about how, he claims, the Australian Labor Party was badly done by in opposition. Let me dramatise the significance of the figures which the Minister has just cited. An increase in staff from 203 to 287 represents a 42 per cent increase.
—We gave you 19 per cent.

—That is right, a rise of less than half the percentage increase that the Government donated to itself. That is a typical example, along with the stamp allowance, of the way the Government has set out to try to diminish and disadvantage the capacity of the Opposition to have the backup services that it is so happy to provide to itself. I would not mind if it were straightforward and honest and if it said, `Yes, we are kicking you to death', but to have that supported in this chamber by the sanctimonious stuff that the Minister has just given us is irritating. The Government has kicked us to death and yet the Minister claims some kind of virtue in the sense that the Government gave us a bit of an increase-an increase less than half the size of the increase it gave itself. If that is supposed to be fair and open-handed and the Minister is being virtuous for having been involved in it, heaven preserve us from the situation that may develop if it ever stops being `noble' in such a way. Diminishing the present Opposition's capacity to counter the enormous resources the Government has given itself has the same impact as a government reducing an opposition's actual staff numbers while keeping its resources stable. It seems to me that there is no difference in principle. Therefore, I cannot see what the Minister's self-righteous mode is aimed at, except to obfuscate the clear reality that the Government has handed itself massive resources, at enormous cost to the public, and has failed to allow the Opposition to have resources to match that kind of increase. The figures which Senator Ray has revealed demonstrate how ludicrous the self-righteous approach is that he has adopted in the chamber today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not believe that I am being self-righteous. I just point out that when the Fraser Government came to government in 1976 it cut back Opposition staff. That was one of the first things it did. It was not aimed at saving money; it was just out of vengeance. Because it had such a majority it thought that it would be in office forever. The Opposition has had an increase in staff of 19 per cent. When have we ever established a correlation or ratio between government and opposition staff? If the Opposition had done that in government it would now have a strong point. From 1975 to 1983 the then Government said, `The Opposition will get 30 per cent of what ministerial staff have'. If we had put that in as a formula we could run with it. But the Opposition still has not answered the central question; it whinges about consultants. I ask it how many it would employ if it won government. What guarantees can the Opposition give the public? Would it employ six, 10, 12, 15 or what? There is no use criticising the Government unless the Opposition is willing to put its colours up on the flagpost and say what it would do. But it will not do that. It does not want to tie itself down because it does not want to be measured off in future when it ignores it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no capacity to give an undertaking, except one: a coalition government would not rip off the public purse with an open-ended cheque for consultants, pay for jobs for the boys and girls, create jobs for members of parliament who have lost their seats, and so on, as this Government has done indulgently ever since it has been in office. I give the Minister another undertaking: there will not be a tenfold increase in the number of consultants as has taken place under this Government. I give the Minister that undertaking clearly and unequivocally.

SPEECH.PARA: I move on from the self-righteous nonsense that we have just heard to a matter of some detail. In response to questions taken on notice, we have been informed that publications issued by the Parliament House Construction Authority include Expressing Australia-Art in Parliament House. We were advised in the printed response that 3,000 copies were produced at a cost of $114,800. That works out at about $38 each for the publication Expressing Australia-Art in Parliament House. Does the Minister have details as to who received copies of this publication: was it sold and, if so, at what retail price? Is it a large or a small publication? What information does the Minister have about it; if any?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —None at the moment. It is a question better taken on notice. I will try to get Senator Baume an answer. I will not start a long debate on who has looked over who, but I remember the long list that we produced in about 1981. I tell those boys over there-and girls, if there are any-that they did not do too badly. They gave Bill Yates a position on Christmas Island and gave consulates to other people. Going back over 20 years there was not a defeated member who was not looked after. I defend that. I defend using ex-parliamentarians, but not if they do an incompetent job.
—We didn't create new phoney jobs.

—Come on! The Opposition had so many other positions to fill that it did not have to do so. It had many people to look after. Let us not denigrate politicians when they leave this place. This is the most expensive tertiary institution in the country. Most leave it well qualified to do other jobs. Virtually all those diplomatic appointments on the Liberal and Labor side have been very successful.
—Hear, hear! I totally agree.
—I am glad that Senator Baume agrees with me. I am sick of people saying, `Ex-politicians are getting jobs'. What are they supposed to do when they leave this place?
—The ex-President of the Senate has been outstanding.

—That is one example, but there are many on Senator Baume's side. Former Senator Robert Cotton was one of the greatest ambassadors we ever sent to Washington. A couple of people sitting in this chamber have had the experience of being an ex-politician. What does a politician do when he leaves this place? One's whole life has been disrupted when one leaves here.
—Make money if you are sensible.

—Some people do. I do not see anything wrong with government employing former politicians. If it is a phoney job, the honourable senator has my support; they should not be employed. I was fairly close to being right about the Sir Robert Menzies Trust. It got only $3,925,643-game, set and match!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise again the matter of empty properties. This relates to a written response to a question taken on notice about the Transport and Storage Division of the Department. A schedule was attached to the reply listing, among others, 2 Forrester Road, St Mary's, where there is a 23.7 hectare site. Under the heading of `Proposed Rationalisation' it states:

SPEECH.PARA: Approximately 9.34 ha of vacant undeveloped land which will not be required for future activities is being sold.

I wonder how long this 9.34 hectares of vacant undeveloped land in the Sydney metropolitan area, which must be worth a very large amount of money, remained in Government possession and unoccupied? What is the estimated value of the land and what prompted the Government to the view that it will not be required for future activities? What has been the time delay between the decision that it will not be required and putting in train the procedure to dispose of it, if it has been put in train?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The questions are detailed and I do not have the answers in my head. I will take them on notice and try to get a response sent to Senator Baume as quickly as possible.

—During the Estimates Committee hearings, we pursued questions in relation to the Australian Government Publishing Service (AGPS) about the overdue trade creditors it appeared to have. We subsequently received answers to questions put on notice. In the latest financial year there was a trebling from $1m to $3m in overdue amounts by AGPS to suppliers, private sector. I asked for a break-up and it was established clearly that several amounts had been overdue for more than 60 days. For example, in 1987-88, $6,000 had been outstanding for more than 60 days; in 1988-89, it had increased to $179,000. The answer to the question taken on notice then gave some examples of the worst of the overdue payments. One was to Watson Ferguson Pty Ltd which was owed $5,113.14 for 156 days. Obviously I understand that some disputes are involved with some of these sums, but I wonder to what extent the clear problem of a substantial increase has been resolved and whether steps have been taken to ensure that it will not happen again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to expand on this at some stage, but the problem arises because AGPS now pays private printers on behalf of clients, which it did not do before. That is the reason for the increase, but I would like to take this question on notice also so as to provide an explanation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that response. We have also received in answers to questions we put on notice an outline on the prices of Budget Statements. In 1988-89, the Budget Statements were sold for $29.95; in 1989-90, they were sold for $49.95 a copy, which is an 80 per cent increase. In the written response, AGPS says that it currently prices publications on a cost recovery basis. It continues:

SPEECH.PARA: To achieve this end the retail prices are determined by multiplying the run-on cost (or marginal cost) per unit by 6.

In determining the multiplier of 6, AGPS has been guided by its past performance which has shown that this factor leads to retail prices which cover costs incurred. In other words, higher factors would tend to lead to profit-making outcomes whilst lower factors would lead to losses on publishing operations.
The application of this formula to the 1988-89 Budget documents gave the result listed in the tables below . . .

The answer then showed that the run-on cost of Budget Statements Nos 1 to 8 was $5.25, which figure multiplied by six gave a retail price of $29.95 in 1988-89. The number of pages involved was 440. I may be wrong, but I am unaware of the fact that the Budget Statements this year to any significant degree were larger than or different from those last year, although they may have been. Could we have an explanation as to why there has been an 80 per cent increase in the retail price of the Budget Statements and whether the criteria for pricing have changed? I ask this question particularly in the context of the fact that it is vitally important to many people to have possession of the Budget documents. On the face of it, an 80 per cent price rise seems larger than even the rate of inflation which the Government has managed to push on the Australian economy this year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The price increase is some 72 per cent greater than the rate of inflation this year; it is very perceptive of the honourable senator to see that. The real question to ask ourselves is whether there has been an unfair rise or whether there was an unfair subsidy beforehand. Senator Baume mentioned the formula by which the AGPS calculates these things, but I wonder whether he understands it.
—A six times multiplication number.

—Yes, but does the honourable senator understand all the ramifications of it? The explanation is not always given at Estimates committees because it is a very complex thing. I am not sure whether Senator Baume and others understand it yet, but I will certainly--
—I understand the concept of marginal costs very well.

—I understand that, but it is the way the other calculations are made that puzzles me at times. The real question to be asked is whether there was an unfair subsidy beforehand. That is the first question. The second question is whether there has been an undue increase. Another question in spite of all that is whether government has a responsibility to make sure that certain publications available to the public appear at a certain price. Certainly that should be done by a government directly allocating money rather than expecting some enterprise to carry the cost. There is no doubt that future governments may take up the suggestion in this area. I am sure the suggestion has already been taken up with respect to some publications, or so I would assume. I refer to certain vital publications that we would want to appear as cheaply as possible. It is the old tariff-bounty argument. We are almost arguing on the bounty side of this equation. I agree with Senator Baume that the cost of Budget Papers at that price is getting prohibitive. I am thinking of scalping my copy. But it is really then up to a government to determine whether it wants to subsidise it. That then becomes a government policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to refer to portfolio program estimates 1989-90 of the Department of Administrative Services, Budget Paper No. 3, which relates to the policies on purchasing and sales. In the explanatory notes that were distributed at the time of the Estimates committees the objectives were stated as:

SPEECH.PARA: To exploit the public sector's collective buying power by securing price leverage and advantageous terms of commercial dealing for our client agencies . . .
It then went on in some considerable detail with regard to enabling the client agencies to undertake and to do different things. The objectives of the subprogram `Purchasing' were:
To assist our client agencies to achieve their program objectives by providing them with:

ready access to supplies of new technology, equipment, consumables, goods and services via easy to use common use contracts with suppliers that have been negotiated using the public sectors collective buying to secure best prices and advantageous terms of commercial dealing; and
a professional, economical and convenient purchasing service which offers expertise in tendering and contracting.

Can the Minister please define for me the client agencies that are envisaged in this particular program and the extent to which it will have an impact in remote and regional communities around Australia? For example, by way of explanation, the Minister may be aware that considerable media coverage has been attracted to various activities of the Department in the Northern Territory in recent weeks. This largely arises from a letter from an officer of the Department, a Mr J. Harrison, the Area Manager, Northern Territory Operations, which has been distributed throughout the Northern Territory to various organisations and bodies that have obscure and indirect links to the Government, offering various facilities to them. The letter states:
This letter is to introduce you to a Commonwealth Service Organisation called the Purchasing and Sales Group of the Commonwealth Department of Administrative Services.
As our Group title suggests we are the centralised National Purchasing and Disposal Body, for the Commonwealth Government, with offices in all States and Territories.

Recent Government endorsed changes to our charter has meant that the way in which we have operated in the past and to whom we can offer our services has also changed. Please refer to the attached glossy flier for a broad overview of these changes.

What these changes mean to your organisation is that this now gives you the opportunity to access our Commonwealth Government period contracts to obtain better prices for your organisation's requirements because of the Commonwealth's bulk volume purchasing power.

Please note however, that in the future there will be a small surcharge on most contract items which will be incorporated in the price of the items on contract. The contractor will then remit this surcharge to our Group. Your organisation will not have to make any additional payments. This surcharge will in time be eroded through even cheaper contract prices for these quality items due to the additional buying power, which accrues from you using our National Contracts.

The range of items on the Commonwealth Contracts is vast. They range from vehicles of all types, office furniture and equipment, personal computers, domestic furniture, refrigerators, washing machines, room airconditioners, office requisites and foodstuffs (both fresh, frozen and tinned-available from Northern Territories Contractors). I have not by any means exhausted the list of contract items. It is to be noted however, that these items are in the main free of sales tax. If your organisation is not sales tax exempt then the appropriate sales tax surcharge will have to be added to the contract rate.

The letter goes on in considerable detail and invites these various arm's length, obscure and indirect organisations dealing with government to now take advantage of this particular aspect. What concerns me in particular is the imposition that this has in remote and regional areas of Australia. I accept that competition is always a good thing, and, depending on the Minister's initial argument, I will be pleased to pursue that a little bit further because of other information. I would like to ascertain from the Government the extent to which this new centralised purchasing organisation will in effect impact on the economies of remote parts of the community. As I said, the Minister will probably be well aware that the Northern Territory media in the last week or so have reported considerable impacts right across the small business community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tambling first of all asks who the clients are. They are all Commonwealth departments, government business enterprises, statutory authorities, State government authorities, local government authorities and-but I will have to check the next definition-non-profitable, charitable organisations, that is, those that are not subject to sales tax. They are the potential clientele.

SPEECH.PARA: At this stage I am not terribly well informed on the effect of this policy as it applies to the Northern Territory. I understand that no vehicles, for instance, have yet been sold, but some may be in prospect. Senator Tambling is looking doubtful about that, and that is why I said it is subject to checking. I will have to put on notice that part of his question which relates to the effects on remote areas, and get an answer to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I could pursue the matter, I notice that, amongst the tabled papers today, the Minister has tabled a document from the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) which is entitled Commonwealth Procurement: Policy Framework. It is dated October 1989. The advertising gimmick on the top of it is `Better Buying', with a great tick mark underneath it. The Department obviously is now acknowledging that it has a purchasing reform group as part of this. The logo is `Service is Our Business'. The document is quite comprehensive and I will address it briefly this afternoon at the appropriate time in addressing papers. With regard to the various sections of this there is a chapter headed `Open and effective competition'. It states that the Department acknowledges that effective competition requires timely and adequate information, independent action, absence of bias or favouritism and ease of market entry for new and small sellers. It continues:

SPEECH.PARA: The degree of available appropriate competition will vary with each purchase. The Government accepts that negotiated offers may be required, for example, where market factors limit the value of competitive bidding.
Negotiations may also be desirable in some cases within the framework of the competitive process.
A balance also needs to be struck between costs which may reasonably be incurred in promoting competition and the benefits to be obtained.
Sound judgment is required to determine the purchasing strategy which best takes account of competition principle while safeguarding the value of money objective.

In addressing this issue, can the Minister account for the requirements of regional and remote areas of Australia and the impact that this will have in many areas of business if various Aboriginal communities and charitable and other government agencies can benefit from the proposal? Will any organisation which receives Commonwealth funding now be eligible to join onto the Purchasing Reform Group's new Commonwealth procurement policy?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course the rules have not changed. What has changed is an attempt to get a greater market share, if you like. I will draw the comments of the honourable senator to the attention of the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr West. I can always guarantee that he reads the full text of these Estimates debates.

—In the formulation of the new Commonwealth procurement policy what consultations have taken place with organisational groups in the community such as the Australian Small Business Association, the Business Council of Australia, the confederations of industry in the various States and other similar groups? Have those organisations lodged any objections with the Government with regard to these new initiatives?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am informed that the seminars were held right around Australia. Various bodies such as the Chamber of Commerce were invited to attend the seminars and have a two-way dialogue on the matter. When I say right around Australia, I do not mean every electorate in Australia. I cannot guarantee that every part of Australia was covered, but certainly the larger centres were.

—Invitations may have been issued but what participation took place? To what extent did the various organisations participate? More particularly, what consultations took place in remote and regional parts of Australia as distinct from the capital cities?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think remote parts of Australia were covered. Senator Tambling also asked what sort of involvement there was. I am informed that more than 100 people attended the Perth seminar and that the Department was very happy with the level of attendance at these seminars.

—I would like to raise a couple of points on behalf of Senator Short, who has been called out of the chamber for a short period. He wanted to raise the matter of a publication called Workplace Change, which is clearly an Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) document and which was inserted in the Australian Financial Review. The questions placed on notice by Senator Short reveal that 180,000 copies of the third edition of this document were printed at a cost of $98,858. Its cost was on top of the costs of the earlier editions. Edition No. 1 cost about $24,000 and No. 2 cost about $30,000, as there were much shorter print runs. Senator Short wants to know why taxpayers are footing the bill for what is essentially a publication of the industrial wing of the Australian Labor Party-that is, the ACTU-particularly when less than half of the work force are members of the ACTU.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I guess it has been handled more as an advertising matter. I will get back to Senator Michael Baume on that. I will not respond to the silly political chestnut Senator Baume has entered into the ring about the Australian Council of Trade Unions being an industrial wing of the Australian Labor Party. Not all unions affiliated with the ACTU are affiliated with the Labor Party. I will let that one slide. I think that Senator Baume wants a response to the Government's rationale for printing this document and having it distributed. I will get the information for him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: -I was listening to Senator Tambling's contribution and alarm bells started to ring. I think that the enormity of the impact that the Commonwealth procurement policy will have on small business escapes Senator Robert Ray. I have just had a brief look at this policy framework. Effectively, it will bypass many small businesses set up in areas that rely on semi-government instrumentalities for their source of business. As I read this document, any person or instrumentality that gets any government money whatsoever, whether it be an Aboriginal organisation, a nursing home or a hospital, will be able to buy through the Commonwealth procurement policy. The Government is establishing a form of socialism. It is establishing--
—At last; thank goodness!
—I accept the interjection and hope that it goes on the record.
—I hope the irony also goes on the record.

—The irony is there. All sorts of businesses that provide services for communities and rely on these semi-government instrumentalities such as nursing homes or local government to maintain their business will not be viable unless they get the business from those particular semi-government instrumentalities.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to a hypothetical situation. Kingaroy has a General Motors-Holden's Ltd dealership. If that dealership does not enjoy business from the Aboriginal community, the local nursing home or local government, it will have an adverse effect on that business. The whole business infrastructure of that town is interlocked. If one business such as the motor vehicle dealership is taken out, all the other businesses will be adversely affected.

I ask Senator Ray to take up this matter with the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, Mr Barry Jones. I am sure that the Government is playing with dynamite as far as the small business community is concerned. I do not say this with any sense of ungraciousness, but many people on the other side of the Parliament do not understand small business. This will have a devastating impact on communities in Queensland. A government instrumentality, funded by taxpayers' money, is being set up to compete with people who have to pay all types of taxes such as sales tax and pay as you earn tax and make superannuation payments. I ask the Government to review this policy before it causes immense problems in the small business community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think that Senator Boswell has to panic to such a degree at this stage. First, on the balance of probability, very few of the smaller groups will use this particular scheme. Secondly, it is not being kept afloat by taxpayers' money. It is supposed to be a profitable operation. Of course, the further its influence is spread, the less will be the requirement on taxpayers' dollars. So it is the other way around. I have some doubts as to whether this is socialism by stealth. I would be happy to arrange for Senator Boswell to be briefed on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The car aspect mentioned is fairly sensible. Negotiations are under way between this group and the car manufacturers to make sure that it does not have the impact that Senator Boswell alluded to. It is not being done with total insensitivity. I doubt that it will have the impact that Senator Boswell thinks it will have. I offer him a briefing on the subject so that he can convince himself one way or the other on the way this will operate. One should not take it that everything is included in a pamphlet because not everything can be fitted in a pamphlet.

TALK.START.PARA: —As shadow Minister for regional development I accept the invitation from the Minister to have a briefing on this matter. It would benefit all concerned to understand the full implications of what will happen if this Commonwealth procurement policy bites into the retailing industry and small business industries throughout Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tambling and Senator Boswell referred to a document entitled Commonwealth Procurement: Policy Framework. I would like some advice on an item in that document. The Minister might be able to follow it up at a later stage as he probably does not have the document with him at the moment. Page 4 refers to ethical behaviour. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is committed to maintaining high ethical standards in purchasing and in fair dealing with suppliers. It has agreed to the adoption of a code of ethics for observation by all staff responsible for purchasing.
Could the Minister provide a copy of that code of ethics and could he explain why such a code of ethics was considered desirable?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —That will be provided by this afternoon.
-I thank the Minister. The second part of my question was whether he could tell the Committee why a code of ethics for the observation of staff involved in purchasing was considered desirable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Because a fairly high risk factor is involved owing to the degree of commercial dealings in this particular area, which would be particularly vulnerable because staff are constantly dealing with contracts and making contacts with the commercial world.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed expenditure agreed to.
Attorney-General's Department
Proposed expenditure, $646,672,000

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did hope that the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) would be present during the consideration of these estimates so that he could address the comments I will make because they relate to some statements that he has made.
—It should be Senator Tate who takes the Attorney-General's estimates through.
—My comments relate to the Trade Practices Commission and I understand that Senator Bolkus is responsible for it. As he is not in the chamber he may care to take up my comments at another time.

SPEECH.PARA: Since June 1988 the Trade Practices Commission has been studying the petroleum industry with a view to introducing a system of rack pricing. The Commission's brief was to formulate an industry code of conduct along with price discrimination guidelines. The statements were due for release in the middle of 1989. However, on 20 June this year, the Minister for Consumer Affairs issued a press release stating that he wished the Prices Surveillance Authority to investigate the pricing of petroleum products. That press release effectively prevented the Trade Practices Commission from releasing its report.

At the moment, the petroleum retail industry has a form of rack pricing which was put down by the six major oil companies with no guidelines from the Trade Practices Commission. The result is that there is great concern in the market. Some people would even say there is chaos in the market. Some would say that the system is working slightly better than the retail pricing system that existed before the rack pricing system came into effect. Other people say that it is worse. There is great concern in the petrol retailing industry.

On 13 November, the industry put down a special code of conduct but the price discrimination guidelines cannot be released until the Prices Surveillance Authority has finished its inquiry into petroleum prices. It is crucial, particularly in my State of Queensland and I assume in every other State, that the guidelines be put down at the earliest opportunity. The guidelines were originally promised in July and it is now nearly 18 months since this urgent matter was referred to the Trade Practices Commission.

The distributors, the lessees of service stations, are trading now in a marketplace that is disorganised and confused. A system of rack pricing has been introduced to create stability and that has not been the effect. On 14 November, the Motor Traders Association of Queensland passed a resolution to allocate $13,000 to commission an inquiry into the retail pricing structure. For the last three or four weeks, rack pricing has been stuck on the maximum price allowed by the Prices Surveillance Authority. I think it is 52.8c. A number of people are buying below that price.

That is the price at which a lessee dealer would buy. A small discount of 1c to 1 1/2c per litre is allowed to distributors who own their own service stations and distribute to farm outlets or industrial outlets. Many people claim that the 1 1/2c is not a sufficient discount for those people to survive and run a distributing business. Ironically, Postal Institute employees, because of strong market forces pulling together, can go into a service station and, by using a credit card, pay a retail price of 51.2c a litre for their petrol. The petrol companies pay the service station lessees 2 1/2c a litre for pumping the petrol into the tanks. If the 2.5c is deducted from the 51.2c a litre paid by the Postal Institute employees the result is 48.7c, which is less than the amount paid by a distributor who has to take the fuel out of tankers and supply it to trawlers, farms or industrial buildings. The distributors handle large volumes of petrol, even up to 15 million litres a year, yet the driver of a motor bike can purchase four to five litres of petrol for less per litre than a distributor who handles 15 million litres a year receives per litre.

I notice that the Minister for Consumer Affairs has entered the chamber. I welcome his presence because I have discussed this matter privately with him and I know that he is concerned about it. I realise that he must have entered the chamber during my speech. I do not know how much of my speech he has heard. For his benefit I say again that, as the Minister for Consumer Affairs, it is imperative for him to use his influence to get the guidelines of the Trade Practices Commission out in the marketplace now so that the people in the petroleum industry will know what they are doing. The press release that he issued on 20 March has hindered that. I do not know that he did it intentionally; I assume that he did it with the best intentions in the world, but the effect of it is that he has confused the marketplace by not allowing those guidelines to be presented to the petroleum industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: CONSUMER AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Boswell mentioned that the Prices Surveillance Authority (PSA) inquiry was approved on 20 June this year. That inquiry was initiated for a number of reasons. There had not been an inquiry into petrol pricing for about five years and there had been some quite significant changes in the market since 1984, both internationally and domestically, including changes by oil companies in the pricing policies for both dealers and distributors. The inquiry was sought by a number of organisations for a number of reasons, in view of that background. For instance, the major oil companies proposed a more open and predictable method of setting maximum wholesale prices for fuel by the PSA and the inquiry will be looking at the way that the Prices Surveillance Authority approaches its task and role in setting maximum wholesale prices.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the other aspects of this inquiry is to ensure that the public also has a wider understanding, by the implementation of a more transparent price-setting mechanism, of how prices are set. It was generally recognised that there was a need for the Prices Surveillance Authority to have an inquiry into the industry and also to review the way in which the Authority approaches pricing policy in that area.

Having tackled that part of Senator Boswell's question, the other part of his question related to the Trade Practices Commission and its guidelines. Senator Boswell is right in saying that that inquiry has been going on for some time. In respect of the Trade Practices Commission, it is fair to say that it is within the responsibility of the Attorney-General, and the concern that Senator Boswell has raised in respect of the Trade Practices Commission coming forward with its recommendations will be put to the Attorney-General in the context that, on the one hand, there is concern for this to happen quickly, as expressed by Senator Boswell, and, on the other hand, it is recognised that the Trade Practices Commission is very much an independent authority which is subject to very strict legal prerequisites and cannot be directed in any way as to how it should run or complete its inquiries. I will make sure that the relevant Minister is made aware of the point raised by Senator Boswell and that his views are passed on to the Trade Practices Commission to see whether it can expedite its processes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for his response. I am fortunate that two Ministers are in the chamber. On other occasions I have taken problems of the small business community to Senator Tate and he has dealt with them very sympathetically. He is the Minister responsible for the Trade Practices Commission in the Senate, as Minister representing the Attorney-General, and Senator Bolkus is the Minister for Consumer Affairs. We are fortunate that the two Ministers who can help the industry are present in the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: For the benefit of Senator Tate and Senator Bolkus-I do not want to overemphasise it or be a panic merchant-I reiterate that there is a massive problem at the moment amongst Australia's 8,500 service station lessees and distributors. People are bleeding, hurting and going out of business. If the Trade Practices Commission puts the guidelines down it will take some of that uncertainty out of the marketplace. I ask both Ministers to deal with this as a matter of extreme urgency.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: CONSUMER AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —For the sake of completeness, I indicate to Senator Boswell and the Committee that the point he makes about the concern and agitation in the community has been brought to my attention, particularly in Townsville by the local Federal member, Mr Ted Lindsay, through his representations to me. In fact, when I was in Townsville three months ago Mr Lindsay organised a meeting with local traders and small business people who were quite forceful in putting forward the views of the Queensland petrol industry and trading industry. They made sure that the Government understood that the industry there is probably composed of more independent traders than in the industry in other parts of Australia. Mr Lindsay has followed that up with me on a number of occasions. I say that in order to make the honourable senator aware that this point has been brought to our attention. Given the constraints of being unable to force an independent authority to complete an inquiry, and recognising that the Trade Practices Commission would be approaching this in a most comprehensive manner, as it always does, I will ensure that Senator Boswell's comments are also put to the Trade Practices Commission through the relevant Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), who is at the table, will probably be aware of why I am rising to speak on these estimates. I want to refer to a subject that was given a good deal of consideration at the Estimates Committee hearings when we were examining departmental officials. It was a subject on which I asked a question in this chamber on 24 October. The matter relates to the agreements that the Commonwealth has entered into with Victoria and Queensland in relation to the future administration of companies and securities.

SPEECH.PARA: The state of play is that I requested that both agreements be tabled and made public because of their very great significance and importance. On 23 October the agreement between the Commonwealth and Victoria, together with some other relevant documents, was tabled, for which I thank the Minister. However, the agreement with Queensland was not tabled, although a statement by the Queensland Minister for Justice was made available. For some reason the Queensland Government did not want the agreement itself tabled. At that stage I indicated that I would expect that agreement to be made available to the Committee before these estimates for the Attorney-General's Department were passed. I inquire of Senator Tate whether that Queensland agreement is available and, if so, whether he will now table it. I would like the opportunity of seeing the document before we complete this debate. Perhaps the Minister could indicate whether it is available yet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not available. When the agreement was entered into the Queensland Government asked for confidentiality in respect of the document. The honourable senator will be aware that under the Appropriation Bill that is before the Committee at the moment there are no funds sought to meet the Commonwealth's commitment to return a share of the revenue to Queensland under the terms of the agreement. That will not arise until 1 July 1990. Therefore, in a very strict sense, the question of the relevance of the document to these appropriations does not arise.

SPEECH.PARA: However, that is not a sufficient answer and I am informed that yesterday the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) approved that Mr Skehill-an officer who appeared before the Estimates Committee-should write to the Queensland Government asking it once again to reconsider its request for confidentiality and whether it would permit the tabling of the agreement as requested by Senator Durack. We believe that the Queensland Government ought to reconsider that matter and a letter will be written to the Queensland Government to seek its concurrence in that matter. I think that request for confidentiality is something we would wish to respect. Certainly when appropriation funds are sought next year, but earlier if possible, I think we should seek to get Queensland to agree to release the document. I am certainly not trying to hide anything; it is just that that was the mutual understanding of the Ministers when they came to this agreement, and the Attorney-General does not want to breach that mutual understanding.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very disturbed indeed by the Minister's answer, although I am sure he is doing his best to assist in this matter. I believe we are dealing here with very serious questions about the division of Commonwealth revenues between the Commonwealth and the States. The scheme the Commonwealth is seeking to follow is to get the States to refer their residual powers in relation to companies and securities to the Commonwealth so that there can be a watertight national scheme, as it is called. The very generous settlement in relation to that division of profits is really a carving up of fees that will, presumably, in due course be imposed under the national scheme by legislation. The Minister can take the technical point that these regulations are not before the Parliament and that there are not any appropriations specifically on the matter, but the fact is that the Commonwealth has persuaded two States, namely Victoria and Queensland, to withdraw their constitutional challenge to the legislation. I hope Senator Boswell is taking note of the fact that Queensland has withdrawn its challenge. This is a matter of very great public interest and concern, and I am outraged to learn that the Commonwealth has entered into a secret agreement with Queensland. That is what it amounts to: the Commonwealth has agreed to secrecy on the Queensland agreement and, apparently, has now to get the permission of the Queensland Government before it can make public the financial rewards that Queensland will get from having welshed on the arrangements it had already made with the other States to challenge the Commonwealth legislation in the High Court. The agreement is based on the fact that Queensland has withdrawn a challenge it had been mounting with other States for some considerable time. The Commonwealth has bought off Queensland by an agreement which it has agreed shall be secret. I think this is outrageous and I hope that the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) when he writes to Queensland will point out some of the facts of this matter in no uncertain terms.

—Before the honourable senator passes to a new topic, I just want to emphasise that confidentiality was sought by the Queensland Minister at this stage-I think that was the way he more or less put it. We know what that stage is. I would imagine that within a couple of weeks he will be more amenable to making the matter public. But I do not want to allow the impression to be given that the secret deal is at great variance with that which we already know is the general structure of the Queensland agreement. In fact, I think in the written answer given to the honourable senator it is noted that, whilst in some respects the agreement with Queensland is couched in different terms from the Victorian agreement, it does not embody any matter different in principle from the matters agreed with Victoria. I know that the honourable senator's quite proper reply would be, `Well, I would like to see it and verify that for myself'. For example, in relation to the distribution of funds, the idea that 95 per cent of the profit should be distributed amongst the participating jurisdictions in relation to the number of registered companies within their jurisdictions obtains for Queensland, as it does for the Victorian agreement. That gives some idea of the sort of return they might get. It is, as I say, because of the current set of circumstances that the confidentiality was requested by the Queensland Minister. I think that that will be resolved. Certainly, as soon as a copy is agreed to be released by the Queensland Government, I will ensure that it is tabled in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I again thank the Minister for his attempt to be as helpful as he can in the very unsatisfactory circumstances with which he is faced. I propose now to turn to the Victorian agreement. I might say that one of the first concerns we have about the Victorian agreement is the fact that at the Senate Estimates Committee in the first place we were given information about the Victorian agreement which was then not borne out when the agreement was finally tabled. So the mere fact that we are told that there is not much difference between the agreements is not very comforting, particularly when we know that we did not get the right information about the Victorian agreement in the first place when questions were asked about it in the Estimates Committee on 5 October.

SPEECH.PARA: I now propose to deal with this question. We had already heard from public statements that had been reported that a nice cosy deal had been entered into between the Commonwealth and Victoria about senior positions in the new Australian Securities Commission and the takeover panel that were going to be given virtually on the nomination of Victoria. So questions were asked early in the piece under this item. I am pleased we had present Mr Hartnell, the new Chairman of the Australian Securities Commission. Questions were asked by both Senator Short and me. On page E140 of Hansard Mr Hartnell is reported as saying:

. . . the Government of today has entered into an agreement with the State of Victoria. It has the effect that the Chairman and the Deputy Chairman reciprocate between New South Wales and Victoria. They do not rotate; it depends on where the particular incumbents are to be located. But it is impossible to run a commission with a chairman located in Melbourne.

There was some further discussion about that matter. Some further concern was expressed about what was meant by the rotation of the position between Victoria and New South Wales, and on page E141 I said:

You mentioned the agreement with Victoria . . . On this point of the alternation, roughly, between Sydney and Melbourne for the chairman, I hope that it is only confined to the fact that the position of chairman is going to be virtually equally divided as to location between Sydney and Melbourne, not that a Victorian or a New South Welshman will alternate the chairmanship.
Mr Hartnell said:
That is correct. Your statement of the situation is my understanding.

I do not know whether or not Mr Hartnell had seen the agreement, but that could be a relevant fact in relation to what was told to the Senate Committee. Subsequently, on page E143, after more questions along those lines as to the situation between Sydney and Melbourne, Senator Tate stated:
It is not a rotation, it is a reciprocation. I think that was the term that you used earlier, a reciprocity. So, if the best person selected to succeed Mr Hartnell-
Mr Hartnell has lived in Sydney for some years-
chooses to live in Sydney or chooses to live in Melbourne-and he may be from Perth or Brisbane or Launceston-then once having made that choice, the deputy goes to the other major commercial capital.

After a great deal of questioning, the answers given did not really clarify the matter, but at the end of the hearing the general situation appeared to be that the positions of Chairman and Deputy Chairman would have to be located in Sydney and Melbourne, being the two major commercial centres in Australia. I do not think that that is an unreasonable proposition, particularly as Mr Hartnell explained that there would not really be one head office or central location in either Sydney or Melbourne but, rather, it would operate as a sort of dual setup where the Chairman would be located in one city and the Deputy Chairman in the other.

As honourable senators can see from my own remarks I was immediately concerned. As I come from Western Australia, I suppose that my concern was a little sharper than others. I am aware of the cosy arrangements that are made in the legal world in many instances between Sydney and Melbourne. No Western Australian was appointed to the High Court of Australia for 79 years, until Mr Justice Wilson was appointed-and so on. So I am somewhat sensitive about this situation.

As honourable senators can also see, I stated that I hoped it did not mean that a Victorian or New South Welshman would share these very attractive spoils of chairman and deputy chairman, but, rather, it would relate only to location, and Mr Hartnell agreed with my understanding, which was confirmed by Senator Tate.
A couple of weeks later the agreement was tabled. I seek leave to have that agreement incorporated in Hansard so as to make my speech a little clearer.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
BASIS ON WHICH VICTORIA WOULD AGREE TO SETTLE WITH COMMONWEALTH
1. Victoria to refer full power over companies securities and futures legislation to Commonwealth.
2. Victoria will not participate in any constitutional challenge.
3. Victoria will hand over all CAV databases and software owned by Victoria to the ASC and on all other matters of administration will co-operate with the ASC in establishing its operation.
4. Subject to identification of suitable available appointees, Commonwealth to appoint suitable Victorians to the following positions:-(a) Chairperson or Deputy Chairperson (b) Chairperson, Panel

Such appointees to have their principal office in Melbourne. Other appointees to the ASC, the Advisory Committee and the Panel will be for the Commonwealth to decide on merit, but Victoria will have the opportunity to suggest suitable available appointees.
5. Financial Arrangements:
Commonwealth to pay to Victoria on an ongoing basis 28% of 95% of profit arising from matters subject to reference of power. Such sums to be paid quarterly on basis to be agreed.

6. If the Commonwealth enters into a proportionately (to the percentage of Australian companies incorporated in a State/Territory) more favourable profit sharing arrangement with another State/Territory, the financial arrangement outlined in paragraph 5 above will be amended accordingly.
7. Payments to Victoria under this Agreement would not be used to the prejudice of Victoria in Loans Council and Premiers' Conference negotiations.

8. CAV staff required by the ASC shall become Commonwealth Public Servants at the changeover date. Victoria will be liable for all staff costs, including accrued costs, up to the changeover date and the ASC will be liable thereafter.
9. All staff arrangements to be subject to negotiations with relevant staff associations and staff.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Committee. To my astonishment, particularly in light of the discussions in the Estimates Committee, I discovered what a great settlement the Commonwealth got, because Victoria agreed to refer full power for companies, securities and futures legislation to the Commonwealth. The agreement states:

SPEECH.PARA: Victoria will not participate in any constitutional challenge.
That sounds all very fine, but what is the price? The price is contained in paragraph 4 which reads:
Subject to identification of suitable available appointees, Commonwealth to appoint suitable Victorians to the following positions:
(a) Chairperson or Deputy Chairperson,
(b) Chairperson, Panel.
Such appointees to have their principal office in Melbourne.

Some other nuggets-not crumbs-are thrown to Victoria in that paragraph, but that is irrelevant for the moment. Apart from the phrase `subject to identification of suitable available appointees'-and I will come to what that means in a moment-Victorians, and not people based in Victoria, are to be appointed to these positions of not only deputy chairperson but also chairperson of the Takeover Panel, which is a very important part of the administration. I do not think we were told at the previous hearing that Victoria was to receive that additional benefit.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the definition of a Victorian?
—It is not an Australian based in Victoria. It would be somebody who was at least resident in Victoria.
—Somebody born there, is it?

—Not born there, but somebody who is resident in Victoria. I imagine that is what it means. As Senator Harradine would agree, it is a very different situation: these positions are reserved for people residing and practising in Victoria, whatever their profession may be. The Government is reducing its power to appoint the best person for these jobs because they are reserved for Victorians. We know that the other position has been reserved for New South Wales, so those three positions will be confined to New South Welshmen or Victorians. Paragraph 4 states `Subject to identification of suitable available appointees', so if a suitable person cannot be found in Victoria--
—That is discrimination in employment.
—Why does the honourable senator think I am so outraged?
—I am only realising it now.

—I think that Senator Tate recognises this problem, because he has already said that it did not mean that an appointee could not come from Launceston or, heaven forbid, Perth. But there might be a suitable person in Perth, Launceston, Adelaide, or Canberra. If there is a suitable Victorian-and there will always be a suitable Victorian, because Victoria is one of the major commercial centres and has numerous practitioners in this field, as does Sydney, and in answer to a later question Senator Tate has already acknowledged that there is likely to be a suitable Victorian-under this agreement, the Victorian gets the two jobs. We are told that this is a national companies scheme, but preferences are given to Victoria and New South Wales. There is no agreement with New South Wales, but the appointment speaks for itself. The first chairperson comes from Sydney. In future, the positions will alternate between Sydney and Melbourne.

SPEECH.PARA: I have no problem with location but, in case there is any suggestion that this agreement does not means what it says-and some people believe that often legal documents do not say what they mean-the Victorian Attorney-General issued a statement dated 12 September as to the meaning of the document. The agreement is undated; it is not limited in relation to time. If a national scheme exists, the agreement applies. However, on 12 September the Victorian Attorney-General, Mr Andrew McCutcheon, made a statement which indicated he was very pleased with himself-and he had every reason to be so. He had already conned the Commonwealth in no uncertain terms. Among other matters, Mr McCutcheon's statement states:
Mr McCutcheon said that in return-
that is, in return for the reference of powers-

the Commonwealth had agreed to appoint a suitable Chairperson of the Companies and Securities panel and a Victorian as Deputy Chairperson of the ASC. Mr McCutcheon said these appointees would be based in Melbourne.

So it is not talking about these positions being based in Melbourne. He would not say that they would be based in Melbourne. He was making the distinction between being a Victorian and being based in Melbourne. The agreement also makes the distinction because it says that the appointees of the principal office will be in Melbourne. So it is making the distinction between a person just being based in Melbourne and a Victorian. Of course, Victoria wants to get a Victorian.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Your time has expired, Senator Durack.

—This is quite a serious matter, and in order to enable Senator Durack to proceed I rise in my place. I am very eager to hear more. I think I have almost heard enough to realise that the Commonwealth is not an equal opportunity employer. It will give equal opportunity in employment to everyone in this instance except to a Tasmanian, a South Australian, a Western Australian and a Queenslander-never mind the Northern Territory, which does not even count. It really is quite a serious matter. As Senator Durack has pointed out, it is not a question of the location of the officers. It stipulates that the appointees in the areas with which Senator Durack was dealing must be Victorians. I think this is a very serious matter. I had not realised it was so serious. It sets a very dangerous precedent indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Harradine for his intervention and support. I was getting very close to the end of my remarks, but in order to complete the record I want to refer to a question which I asked Senator Tate in Question Time on 24 October. After this agreement had been tabled at the Estimates Committee hearing on 23 October, I asked Senator Tate a question in the Senate along the lines on which I have been speaking. I was concerned, as I still am, about two matters. In my view, the Senate Estimates Committee was clearly misled by the statements made by both the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) and Mr Hartnell. In fairness to Mr Hartnell, he may not have seen the agreement. He did say that my statement of the situation was his understanding of the position. Nevertheless, it is a very serious matter. As far as I can see, no attempt has been made by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) or the Government to correct the statements that were made. The questions I asked Senator Tate about this matter appear on pages 2064 and 2065 of Hansard of 24 October. Senator Tate pointed to clause 4. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I think the preceding part to clause 4 of the Victorian agreement that was tabled indicated that the first duty was to look for a suitable possible appointee.

Of course, it is subject to identification of suitable available appointees. The Commonwealth has to appoint suitable Victorians. So it is clear that the Commonwealth may look around Australia to find the most suitable person, but it has got to appoint a suitable Victorian, even though there may be better suited people around Australia. He went on:
It may be that that canvassing of possible appointees could lead us to say that there was not a suitable Victorian-
maybe-
and possibly that somebody from Perth, Launceston, or wherever was suitable. That is a preliminary hurdle that has to be jumped in terms of clause 4 of the agreement that was tabled.
Senator Tate was agreeing that that is all clause 4 does. Whether clause 4 was intended to do that is another matter. In view of what Senator Tate had said, I asked him a supplementary question:

Is it not highly probable that people resident in Victoria would be suitable for either position? In that event, does that agreement not virtually guarantee that there will be a Victorian in one of these top positions?
Senator Tate answered:

It is likely that there will be a Victorian who qualifies for that appointment, in which case the terms of the agreement are very clear. I am simply saying that there is no automatic assumption that that is the case.
He went on to say what seemed to be rather odd things, but I agree with them. He said:

. . . it is essential to go for the best possible short list of available candidates and not to be restricted in an extremely hidebound way. I concede that one would hope to find within the Victorian business and commercial world a person of sufficient eminence to qualify.

I do not know whether he has to be eminent to qualify, because all he has to be is suitable. My point is that the Commonwealth, by this agreement, has greatly restricted in practice the appointments it can make to this most important new organ of government in Australia. The appointees are going to be at the very top of the administration of our corporate, companies and securities laws. Heaven knows how important that is. Problems of great magnitude arise constantly in this area which concern the Australian economy and a great many shareholders in Australian companies. We have had instances only in the last week of the enormous tasks and responsibilities that are imposed upon the people in charge of this scheme; and here at the apex of the scheme we have the three most important positions and the Government has limited its choice of who are the best and most eminent people in this field to those whom the Government can persuade to take on this job. It may be a difficult job to take on. Certainly the last thing that the Government should do, quite apart from equity and equal opportunity around Australia-and I emphasise that this is a national scheme; anybody would think that this was a Victoria-New South Wales scheme-is be greatly restricted in this agreement. It should get the best people it can get for these jobs.

The position is not just unsatisfactory; it is really quite alarming. I have already mentioned that there is no time limit on this agreement. It has been confirmed by the further questioning at the Estimates Committee that there is no time limit on this agreement. The Commonwealth has entered into another agreement with Queensland, but from what we know of that agreement Queensland has been pretty short sold. I do not know whether Queensland knew what the deal with Victoria was, but from the States rights sentiments that we hear so often from the Queensland Government perhaps it is so embarrassed that it would not want to admit, with the election going on there at the moment, how it had been dealt with by the Commonwealth, because it has well and truly been outsmarted by the Victorians in this deal with the Commonwealth.

So, if I may say in passing, it is a pretty sorry old comment on the Queensland Government. How could the Queensland Government have got a deal such as Victoria got? The three plum jobs had been given to New South Wales and Victoria. There was not very much left for Queensland, but it too was conned into withdrawing its challenge under an agreement the terms of which we do not really know, although we are told that they were similar. They may have been similar on financial matters, but we do not know. I am not interested in the financial matters at the moment; I am interested in the best possible administration of this new scheme.

The Government has made a sorry start in the new national scheme which for so long it has been vaunting as so vital. The Victorians have withdrawn their constitutional challenge and have agreed to refer their powers to the Commonwealth, thus allowing Victoria to have control over the Commonwealth for as long as the scheme lasts. It is no good saying, `We can renegotiate this scheme. This does not mean what it says. If the very best person for the job happens to be in Brisbane we will be able to say to the Victorians that we have given them a fair crack of the whip because they have already had two of the three top jobs for a few years and now we want a change'-the usual things that the Commonwealth does when dealing with the States.
