On this occasion it will not be able to get away with it because Victoria will also have a whip handle; it will have the reference of powers. It will not matter if the High Court finds totally in favour of the Commonwealth; there will always be some residual State powers. In order to have a proper national scheme, the Commonwealth will have to have reference of powers from the States. Even Sir Maurice Byers admitted that in the opinion he gave the Commonwealth. The Victorians will also have the Commonwealth over a barrel because they can withdraw the reference of powers. If the Commonwealth does not abide by this agreement, the Victorians can withdraw their powers. The Commonwealth will come to heel pretty smartly because it will be very reliant on that reference of powers from Victoria.

The Government has created in this very cosy deal-as I call it-with Victoria a very serious and deplorable situation. All members of the States House of the Commonwealth should be outraged that the Commonwealth has taken such an attitude to its national responsibilities. With this whole new national scheme the Commonwealth has got off to the worst possible start by hamstringing its power of appointment to the top jobs in the way it has under this agreement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Apparently Senator Durack regards the setting up of the Australian Securities Commission and the persons to whom it is intended should be appointed to the top jobs as having got off to a very sorry start. He seeks to portray the situation as if New South Welshmen and Victorians had a guaranteed access to the top jobs. Tony Hartnell was appointed as Chairperson of the Australian Securities Commission purely because of his eminence and expertise, and no doubt because of his very extensive contacts through both the government and non-government sectors-the commercial and trading securities world of Australia. The premier commercial and trading securities capitals of Australia are to be found in Melbourne or Sydney. But we are not talking about locations; we are talking about persons. It is not true to say either that Tony Hartnell was appointed because he is a New South Welshman or that a New South Welshmen is guaranteed one of the top jobs. There is no agreement with New South Wales. There is no guarantee that a New South Welshperson will ever be appointed to the top three jobs which Senator Durack has mentioned.

SPEECH.PARA: As to whether a Victorian might fill one of those top jobs, I was realistic in my answer-I was not trying to be half smart, although I suppose I could have been utterly artificial, legalistic and abstract-when I said that one would expect to find in Victoria somebody who was, as I put it, well qualified. When Senator Durack asked the question on 24 October I said:
I concede that one would hope to find within the Victorian business and commercial world a person of sufficient eminence to qualify.

But that person must qualify in terms of clause 4 of the agreement with Victoria, which is preceded by that hurdle. The agreement would be very different if that first hurdle were not in the agreement and, therefore, did not have to be jumped. The agreement states:
Subject to identification of suitable available appointees, Commonwealth to appoint suitable Victorians to the following positions:
(a) Chairperson or Deputy Chairperson
(b) Chairperson, Panel

That preliminary hurdle, that condition precedent, has meaning and it protects the Commonwealth from having foisted upon it a mediocre person who might be a Victorian but might not be able to serve best the interests which Senator Durack properly pointed to-namely, the Australian Securities Commission, being so important, should have the very best personnel in those top jobs. It was, I am informed, a constant part of the negotiations that the Commonwealth would not guarantee Victoria access to those top jobs in an absolute sense. That is why that preliminary part of the clause was put in. That is why the condition precedent is there. If it turns out to be the case that, in the judgment of the Commonwealth, a suitable Victorian cannot be found, I can assure the Committee that there will be no appointment of a Victorian to one of those jobs.

Going back to the hearings of Estimates Committee E, I think that Senator Durack used the term `secret protocol'. He was worried that a secret deal had carved up the jobs and so on. The agreement has been put on the table. I think that it indicates openly the sort of deal that was done. I use those terms because I do not deny that a political deal was done between Victoria and the Commonwealth. But the terms of the agreement have been exposed and tabled in this chamber. I believe that the points which Senator Durack has raised are not valid when he put it so strongly as a deal being done to ensure that New South Welshpersons and Victorians have an absolute precedence and an absolute guarantee of access to those jobs. That is not the case with regard to New South Wales and, as I have said, a very high hurdle, I believe, has to be jumped before a Victorian would qualify.

I do not accept that this agreement will disable the Australian Securities Commission at the start from having access to the most highly qualified of personnel to undertake the very onerous duties and statutory duties that will be placed upon them. Given the fact that we know that it is going ahead, I am sure that Senator Durack will join with me in hoping that those who hold the positions will discharge their responsibilities in a way which gives great satisfaction to the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tate is still falling back on the phrase `subject to identification of suitable available appointees'. But the clause goes on to say `Commonwealth to appoint suitable Victorians'. It does not say `subject to the identification of more suitable or available eminent people', but `appoint suitable Victorians'. The Attorney-General of Victoria is in no doubt-I have already quoted what he said-that the Commonwealth agreed to appoint a suitable Victorian as chairperson of the panel and a Victorian as deputy chairperson. There is no question about that. The Commonwealth can argue until the cows come home that there is an overriding intention to get the most eminent person, as did Senator Tate. I am glad that he thinks that is the appropriate course, but as I pointed out Victoria has them over a barrel. The Victorians are in no doubt about what it means and about what they intended. Mr McCutcheon has made it quite clear.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Justice is ignoring the political realities that will occur because the Victorians can point out to the Commonwealth that it made a deal with them. They are perfectly entitled to interpret it in that way because that is also how I interpret it. When I first saw the agreement during the Estimates Committee hearing, I nearly fell off my chair. I could not believe it. Then I saw that Mr McCutcheon takes exactly the same view as I do. He is the man who will call the shots here; make no bones about it. His successors as Victorian Attorney-General will take exactly the same view. Let there be no doubt about it: they have the Commonwealth over a barrel and they will insist on their pound of flesh as to what the agreement means. The Commonwealth has given Victoria an enormous advantage and there is no doubt that Victoria will use it to its full extent in the appointments that are coming up and in all future appointments.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Justice ought to respond a little more on this matter. For example, if two persons, one in Victoria and one in Tasmania, were available and deemed to be suitable for appointment to an Australian Securities Commission position which is named in the Victorian-Commonwealth document of agreement, under the agreement would preference be given to the Victorian over the Tasmanian?

—This is a hard matter to judge. If, indeed, the two candidates were of an equal eminence then in this situation the Victorian would get the guernsey. But I do not know whether it works out as simply as that in real life. If in all other respects the two were equal, the Victorian would get the guernsey.

—I refer to questioning shown on pages E145 to E151 of the Hansard record of Estimates Committee E and the understanding given by the Chief Censor of films, Mr Dickie, to respond to a question that I asked of him and to his response to that question. INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Temporary Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.
The Temporary Chairman having reported accordingly-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Pursuant to sessional order, the Senate will now proceed to a discussion of matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter I wish to raise today is one of grave importance. It involves the national security of this nation; it quite possibly involves the very lives of certain people; it involves the reputation of a member of this Parliament. It is obvious, therefore, that I am taking this action of speaking in the Senate today only after the most deliberative, serious soul-searching consideration. Before reaching this decision to speak today I have taken considerable advice and counsel.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter to which I refer is the activities of the Yugoslav secret police in Australia. The Yugoslav secret police is commonly known as the SDB and I will refer to it as such in my following remarks. However, as I shall reiterate in my remarks, my concerns are not only with the SDB but as well with the allegations of an upsurge in recent times of the activities of the secret police forces of several foreign powers to monitor the activities of their emigre communities. These allegations have been made not only about Yugoslavia but also about several other countries, including, in particular, Vietnam. The Senate will recall that on 29 August of this year I asked Senator Tate, in his capacity as Minister for Justice and as Minister representing to the Attorney-General, whether he was aware of a recent series of articles and reports in the Australian newspaper concerning the activities of the SDB. In particular I referred to an article of 29 July this year alleging that the SDB `has formed close ties with a Federal member of Parliament'. That report stated:

. . . a source in the Yugoslav Department of Foreign Affairs in Belgrade . . . said information that may have originated from the MP, a Labor Party backbencher, has shown up in the dossiers of Croatian exiles in Australia, held at UDBA-
that is, the SDB-
headquarters in the Yugoslav capital.
I asked Senator Tate:

Has the Australian Government investigated these allegations, particularly the allegation that the UDBA is operating in Australia? If not, why not, and will it now establish an official inquiry into the allegations? If the Government finds that there are UDBA or other agents provocateurs operating here, is it the Government's policy to expel them? Finally, can the Minister assure the Senate that there is no known connection between any Australian Labor Party member of Federal Parliament and the Yugoslav secret police?
Senator Tate took that question on notice. Three days later, on Friday, 1 September, he responded:
I am aware of the articles and the various allegations made in them. I follow the practice of successive Commonwealth governments in not commenting on matters concerning national security.

I have learned subsequently that other members of this Parliament, including the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock, and the Labor member for Corio, Mr Scholes, received similar responses from the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, to similar questions that they had put to him in writing. In a statement released later that day following receipt of Senator Tate's answer I said that in my view it was not permissible for the Government to be allowed this time to fall back on the excuse of national security. I pointed out that what is involved are allegations, firstly, that a foreign government-in this case Yugoslavia's-is conducting clandestine secret police operations of a terrorist nature in Australia; secondly, that certain Australian citizens are the victims of these clandestine operations; and, thirdly, that a Labor member of Federal Parliament is alleged to be aiding and abetting these clandestine operations against Australian citizens. I said in that statement that the Australian electorate has a basic right to information about these allegations and that at the very least the electorate has a basic right to know whether one of its own elected representatives is deliberately engaged in activities designed to damage Australian citizens.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Short, before you go any further, perhaps you do not mean to do so but it will not be in order to name a particular member of Parliament who it is alleged may be involved in these things. A general remark is in order. If you named someone individually that would not be in order. I am telling you this before you make the statement, otherwise there may be a problem.
—I do wish subsequently to read a statutory declaration, Mr Deputy President, which will refer to a member of parliament.

—You must understand that if you raise it in this way you will be casting a reflection on the integrity of the member of the House of Representatives and that would be in breach of standing order 418. Perhaps you can do it in some other way but I think you should not name him. Perhaps you could read the statutory declaration and blank out the name of the actual member concerned. There are ways in which you can deal with this but not in this type of debate where you cannot cast reflections on the integrity of a member of the House of Representatives, by name. We may discuss the point; my ruling is not absolute.
—The point I raise concerns the point of order we seem to have moved into.
—I was only giving Senator Short a warning before he said anything.
—The point is really this: how is one to know whether it casts a reflection until one knows what is in the statutory declaration?

—What I am saying is that by the time a statement is made, it is read. I am warning Senator Short, in view of the development of his argument, that he must not name a member of the House of Representatives in a way that reflects on his integrity.

—I will not in my own comments reflect on anyone, but I will defer to your ruling as I go along, perhaps. In an adjournment speech in this chamber on 7 September I referred to reports that the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, ASIO, suspected that Yugoslav secret service agents had links with a number of senior Australian public servants. Following my question in the Senate my colleague in the House of Representatives, Mr Aldred, also raised the activities of the SDB in Australia. Amongst other things Mr Aldred discussed allegations that in Belgrade there are dossiers of information which has originated in Australia, from the SDB. Mr Aldred said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I am led to believe that several of these dossiers substantially originated from the Yugoslav Welfare Association based in Fitzroy in Melbourne. The Association ostensibly is a non-government community organisation catering for the welfare of Yugoslavs in Australia.

The current chairman of the Yugoslav Welfare Association and one of its co-founders, as we have said in earlier debates, is the present Labor member for Hotham, Mr Lewis Kent. Mr Kent will not be that for much longer, however, because he has been ejected by his Party as the member for Hotham to make way for Simon Crean at the next election. Instead, he will be contesting the new seat of Corinella for Labor.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, it has been hard to follow the trail exactly. The identification now follows some commentary which has been made, I think to the effect that certain material has been passed from an Australian organisation and has been discovered to be in the archives of an agency of a foreign power. That seems to me to be getting very close to imputing--
—No, it is not.

—It is certainly a personal reflection, surely, on the member concerned to indicate apparently that he is the co-founder and chairperson of an organisation which has passed material to an agency of a foreign power.

—Order! I understand the point of order. I did give Senator Short a warning before. I have been listening carefully to what he has been saying and he is entitled to say what he has. It would be, he would understand, completely out of order to suggest a member of the House of Representatives, for instance, is an agent of a foreign power. That would be a gross reflection and would be quite out of order. Nevertheless, what he has said so far is in order.

—All that I am saying at the moment is on the public record, in the Hansard report of my speech in this chamber on 7 September and in speeches in the House of Representatives. I am not saying anything new at this stage at all. Included is the fact, which is in the House of Representatives Hansard, that Mr Kent was born in Yugoslavia and has been in Australia since 1954. In 1959 he changed his name by deed poll from his Yugoslav name, Lajco Kapolnai, to Lewis Kent. The allegations which have been made in the press and from other sources about activities of the Yugoslav secret police in Australia, about the links between the secret police and a Labor Federal member of parliament are of the utmost--

—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy President. It is quite clear that using a general sentence about a member of the Parliament and a link with the Yugoslav secret police and immediately preceding that by reference to Mr Lewis Kent can have no other purpose than to leave in the mind of the listener an identification of the unnamed member, in one sense, as being Mr Lewis Kent. The link is being made for the purpose of the whole argument or the whole speech that Senator Short is trying to develop. You cannot take each sentence, in my submission, separately. There is quite clearly an attempt to colour the general term `a member of parliament' by the identification which has now been made, I think twice, of the honourable member for Hotham.

—Mr Deputy President, apart from supporting what Senator Tate has just said, I draw your attention to the fact that this is a matters of public interest discussion. This is a very controversial point being raised under that heading at this time of the day.

—No, that is not a valid point. The change of the system from matters of non-controversial debate, which was the original thing, to matters of public interest did change the nature of this debate. The only ruling is that there shall be no divisions during this period. But this is a matter of public interest. What I am concerned to see is that it does not improperly vilify a member of the House of Representatives. Senator Short, I ruled earlier that to name a member of the House of Representatives and suggest that he was a foreign agent would be a gross reflection on him, and that cannot be done in this forum in this form. You may move a motion which could enable that, but not under this system. I take it that you have accepted that ruling that the discussion you are developing has no direct and intended linking with the particular individual-the honourable member for Hotham. Is that correct? If so, you may proceed, as long as it is quite clear that you are not making these remarks directly about the honourable member for Hotham.

—I find myself in a very considerable quandary, Mr Deputy President. Everything that I have said up to date has gone unchallenged, including matters I have raised in the presence of Senator Tate and Senator Evans on previous occasions. I have, since making those earlier statements-and at the end of which statements I said that the matters about which the allegations had been made affect our national security, affect the institution of Parliament, and go to the very core of our nationhood and our democratic freedoms-called for a full inquiry into the allegations. I said that the inquiry should be public, without advocating any one form of inquiry over another. In response to my speech in the Senate on 7 September Senator Evans tried to denigrate my call for an inquiry. At the same time he refused my request specifically, using the time worn excuse, and in this instance I believe totally inadequate excuse, that governments do not comment on operational matters affecting security and intelligence agencies. I want to say to the Government today that that excuse is no longer acceptable, if indeed it ever was. I say this because I have in recent days received additional material to support some of the allegations that have already been made. I am in possession of a statutory declaration--

—Mr Deputy President, I do not know that you have actually ruled on my request that Senator Short effectively no longer continue his remarks because of the colouring and the inferences that he was making and his linking of the identification of the honourable member for Hotham and the succeeding sentence which spoke of a link between the secret police of the Yugoslav Government and a member of parliament.

—I did, in fact, rule on that matter. I said that it would be out of order to make a reflection of that nature on the honourable member for Hotham. That would be clearly out of order under standing order 418. So I said Senator Short could continue as long as it was clear that what he was developing was not directly linked with the honourable member for Hotham. He is now continuing, I take it, with a hypothetical case of a single member of parliament without naming him. That is in order.

—Could I just seek your ruling, Mr Deputy President, for my clarification? Are you saying that if I have a statutory declaration which names a member of parliament as being an agent of the Yugoslav secret police, I cannot use the name?

—The fact that it is in a document makes no difference. What you are not permitted to do under this procedure, under standing order 418, is to cast reflections on the integrity of a member of the House of Representatives. There are procedures in which it may be done, but it may not be done in the course of a speech of this nature. Does that answer your question, Senator Short?

—Yes, thank you. I will obviously abide by your ruling, Mr Deputy President, and I will have to seek other procedures in this chamber, obviously, to make the points that I want to make, that need to be made because they are matters of the gravest national importance. They are matters that demand a full inquiry, as I have said on previous occasions, and the additional evidence that I have now received in the form of a statutory declaration and other material names persons-one of whom is a member of parliament, but others as well-as being agents of the Yugoslav secret police in Australia.

—This chamber and this Parliament are from time to time referred to as a coward's castle. In the last quarter of an hour we have heard reasons why it should be referred to as a coward's castle. Senator Short, in concluding his remarks, said that he will find other avenues in order to raise the matters that he wants to raise within this chamber. There are plenty of opportunities. The honourable senator can walk out the front door, the side door or the back door of this building and say these things publicly. I challenge Senator Short to indeed do that, to stand up with a degree of integrity and not hide behind the privilege of the Parliament in order to seek to denigrate a very respected, very hardworking member of the Australian Commonwealth Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like also to develop briefly just one aspect of the whole issue of banking which I have been addressing for almost 18 months now in this place. I have attempted to put before the Senate sufficient evidence to justify an inquiry into banking. On two occasions now the Senate has chosen not to support the proposition of a major inquiry into banking. I will return to that proposition as time goes on. However, I would like to explain simply, in a couple of moments, one of the techniques of the banking sector. Those in dispute with banks or financiers in this country often find themselves confronted with a particular technique which is virtually impossible for them to counter. I cite the case of a Michael Bourke. I have tabled affidavits from Michael Bourke and other documents in relation to his circumstances previously. Michael Bourke is a businessman from the Newcastle area who now finds himself in dispute with a bank in three courts: the New South Wales Supreme Court; the Federal Court; and he is listed to carry one of his disputes into the High Court of Australia. In short, Michael Bourke is a man determined to pursue his grievance with this particular bank. Quite obviously, the bank with which he is in dispute-or one of those banks with which he is in dispute-is anxious that this should not happen and that these matters should not get into court. In fact in recent days it has done everything in its power to bring the man into bankruptcy in order to terminate his access to one of the courts.

SPEECH.PARA: The technique that the banks have used is an interesting one and one which I draw to the attention of honourable senators. Michael Bourke was the owner of 80 acres of heavy industry land in the Rutherford area in Maitland and at the time that he bought this property it was valued, independently, at approximately $400,000. He then secured an advance, a loan, from the Beneficial Finance Corporation Ltd-which is the financial wing of the South Australian State Bank-with this 80 acres of industrial land as security. At the time that that loan was made, there was an independent valuation of $500,000 on this plot of industrial land. Subsequently, down the line, the bank has chosen to foreclose, for its own reasons. It has foreclosed on that loan and in fact has sold the property, the 80 acres of heavy industrial land, in an attempt to recoup its advance.

At the time of reselling that property, the bank had a second independent valuation done and that valuation was $350,000. So we have had three valuations-one of $500,000, one of $400,000 and one of $350,000. But the bank actually sold that land for $45,000. In fact, it sold the land for 15 per cent of the average of three independent valuations. This meant, of course, that Mr Bourke, who had the bank before the court, was placed into a position of technically becoming bankrupt, and by virtue of technically becoming bankrupt he does not have access to the courts. The Bourke case is legally acknowledged in previous judgments of the Supreme Court of New South Wales as being a critical case. It is progressing its way to the High Court of Australia, and is listed in the High Court for February of next year.

What do ordinary business people do? I do not regard Michael Bourke as being an ordinary business person; the nature of the projects which he enters into suggest that he is a fairly extraordinary and very succesful business person who happens to have fallen foul of his financiers for reasons that he believes are unreasonable and which he is challenging in the courts of the land. This technique of foreclosing and selling at fire sale prices is a common technique. In the 300 cases which I have before me, including in excess of 60 cases that I have tabled, supported by sworn affidavits or other sworn statements, there have been numerous examples of banks foreclosing on assets and selling them promptly at prices which are in the vicinity of 10 or 15 or 20 per cent of their value. The implications of course are horrendous for the individuals involved, and it flies in the face of all of the procedures that are applied in anticipation of people being declared bankrupt. In fact it makes a mockery of the processes that come before courts in this land. I cite this extreme case that has been brought to me by Michael Bourke, and I have described it to the Senate as being typical of what is occurring out there in and outside our courts in relation to banking in this country.

As I have said, Mr Acting Deputy President, it is my intention to do three things: to continue to table evidence for the consideration of honourable senators; to continue to push subsequently for an appropriate inquiry into these sorts of processes, and into banking generally in Australia; and to carry these matters, including the cases that I have tabled here in the Senate, before the Australian Bank Council and put them before the bank ombudsman early in the new year when it is anticipated that such a person will be appointed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of members of this Parliament belong to the Parliamentary UNICEF Group because of an interest we have in the welfare and hopes of the world's children. We receive regular briefings but I have a briefing here today which I do not think has gone to the UNICEF Group. Nevertheless, it should be of interest to the Parliament. Honourable senators will recall that in 1984-85 there were great crop failures in Ethiopia which led to an enormous number of deaths and to the need for international intervention. I have received yesterday a note from the National Director of UNICEF Australia, Mr Robert Nestdale, concerning a new emergency situation now arising in Ethiopia. It had with it a United Nations Children's Fund assessment of the Ethiopian situation which in a moment I will seek to incorporate. I have already checked it with Senator Evans, who was here earlier. This emergency and drought, according to the assessments made, will be worse than the 1984-85 drought in terms of crop failures. One part of the report says-and I will not read much of it:

SPEECH.PARA: This drought-according to the results of assessments of the main harvest planting by UN agencies, including UNICEF, and by the government of Ethiopia-will be worse than in 1984-85 in terms of crop failure.
In Eritrea the crop failure is estimated to be 90 to 100 per cent, while in Tigray it reaches 40 per cent. At least 242,000 metric tonnes of food assistance is needed according to WFP-
I think that is the World Food Program-
to meet the needs of 1.85 million people.

It goes on to set out in some detail the extent of the drought and the extent of its impact. UNICEF is now launching a special appeal to respond to this new emergency. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the document entitled The Emergency Information Note that has been forwarded to UNICEF Australia, so that honourable senators can have a chance to be aware of the full scale of this problem.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
13 November 1989
ETHIOPIA 4

As anticipated in Emergency Information Note Ethiopia 3, dated 4 October 1989, UNICEF is now launching an appeal for Emergency assistance to the population affected by the drought in Ethiopia's northern regions of Eritrea and Tigray.

This drought-according to the results of assessments of the main harvest planting made by UN agencies, including UNICEF, and by the government of Ethiopia-will be worse than in 1984-85 in terms of crop failure.

In Eritrea the crop failure is estimated to be 90 to 100%, while in Tigray it reaches 40%. At least 242,000 MT of food assistance is needed according to WFP, to meet the needs of 1.5 million people. The Relief and Rehabilitation Commission in its official appeal estimates the needs at 333,000 MT of grain for 1.85 million people.

UNICEF appeal for US$ 9.05 million focuses on non-food emergency assistance to the 1.2 million Eritreans who are directly affected by the drought, and to another 300,000 people who are expected to walk in search of food from Tigray into Eritrea during the next 12 months.

UNICEF in responding to an emergency appeal launched by the Government of Ethiopia on 26 October 1989. UNICEF appeal closely follows on the appeals launched by other agencies such as the World Food Program, and the Ethiopian Red Cross Society. It has been co-ordinated with other UN agencies in Addis Ababa most of which will concentrate on food aid.
Background

For the third time in less than 10 years, Ethiopia is confronted with a drought of catastrophic proportions. In 1984-85 up to one million people starved to death in the northern regions of the country; in 1987-88 a similar tragedy could be averted thanks to the early appeals of the Government of Ethiopia and to a prompt reaction by the international community.
This time the situation is considered worse than in 1984-85, mainly for two reasons.

1) A nearly total crop failure is being reported in the whole Eritrean region as Meher rains-the long rains of mid-June which determine food availability during the following year-started late in July and ended too early in September. In Tigray the crop failure is estimated to be 40%. Furthermore, these two regions are afflicted by civil wars respectively 28 and 15 years old, which restrict movements of goods and people and limit the access of assistance.

2) For the first time since 1984, the food pipeline is virtually empty. Ironically, this is a result of the extensive good rains of 1988 which gave Ethiopia a satisfactory food availability for 1989. Because of the good harvests and of substantial carry over from 1988 emergency food aid, there has been no request of assistance from the Government of Ethiopia since November 1987. Consequently the food pipeline which had been kept continuously supplied by successive appeals to donors from the Ethiopian Relief and Rehabilitation Commission was not replenished and is now at its lowest level. As of September 1989 wheat stocks were estimated at some 47,000 MT. These stocks will be exhausted very early in 1990 if additional food assistance is not provided immediately.
Up to 2 million people affected

Approximately 1.5 million people are estimated to be directly affected by the drought, 300,000 of which are expected to arrive in Eritrea from affected areas in Tigray which are currently inaccessible. But this number could reach up to 2 million as famine conditions develop in 1990. The first signs of famine have already been reported not only in the border towns of Eritrea where influxes of displaced people are on the increase, but also in other areas, in particular in Akele Guzay district where farmers are selling their livestock at only one third of the normal price. Livestock disposal at very low prices is one of early warning indicators that a drought situation is becoming alarming.

Staff members from UNICEF Asmara visited the drought-stricken areas of Eritrea from 18 to 28 October 1989 to fully assess the extent of the current emergency. In all the 25 distribution centres which they visited they noticed a severe shortfall in food stocks, in many cases warehouses were empty. Water and health services were much below adequate levels, many facilities had no supply of drugs or medicines and needed vehicles to provide health services to the population. However, UNICEF team observed that water points can be reactivated within three to six months with the appropriate supply of equipment and reservoirs.
UNICEF APPEAL FOR EMERGENCY ASSISTANCE 1989-90
Focus of UNICEF Assistance

UNICEF will concentrate on assistance to displaced women and children in the areas of supplementary feeding, health, water, shelter relief, and general organizational support to the emergency effort, e.g. warehousing, transport, manpower and management/coordination.

It will first address relief operations in the immediate period, and then move on to rehabilitation once the peak of the crisis passed. The duration of UNICEF assistance will cover approximately 12 to 18 months.

UNICEF's intervention will take two approaches: geographic, i.e. focusing on definite locations where displaced persons will seek food and non-food assistance; and functional, i.e. working in partnership with governments and non-government agencies which run emergency programmes in Eritrea. The majority of these agencies have worked with UNICEF during the previous drought emergencies.
The projects in the appeal have been grouped therefore by implementing agencies, and not by sectors, as it was found that the same agencies in Eritrea work in a variety of emergency projects.

Geographical `pressure points', i.e. locations of potential concentration of people seeking food and non-food assistance during the next 12 months, have been identified. The main pressure points are district and sub-district capitals, especially those close to the war fronts. The Relief and Rehabilitation Commissions has listed 25 food distribution centres which correspond to the main pressure points.

Some of these points are already seeing large influxes of refugees. For instance, Keren/Hagas, in Keren district, has doubled its population in the last 7 months to 90,000, half being displaced people living in self-built temporary shelters with water in very short supply.

The participating agencies which UNICEF will be working in partnership are: The Relief and Rehabilitation Commission/Eritrea Regional Office (RRC), the Ethiopian Water Works Construction Authority (EWWCA); the Water and Sanitation Agency (WSA); the Ministry of Health/Eritrea Region (MOH); the Asmara City Council Health Services Department (CITY); the Ethiopian Catholic Secretariat/Joint Relief Partners (ECS/JRP); the Evangelist Church of Eritrea (ECE); the Social Welfare Centre/Vicariate of Asmara (SWC); and the Capuchin Fathers/Eritrea (CFE).

Project N. 1: RRC Relief Operations-Estimated budget: US$2,250,000. As the government agency concerned with disasters, the Relief and Rehabilitation Commission is in charge of the big task of meeting the food and non-food needs of the 1.2 million people in Eritrea who will be directly affected by the drought. As the drought progresses, some 200,000 to 300,000 people from the neighbouring region of Tigray are expected to seek assistance at RRC distribution centres in the border areas in the south, and people from the north are expected to converge into Keren. 200,000 people have already taken refuge in Eritrea's towns and in shelters after having fled the areas of conflict. The RRC plans to open 25 food distribution centres to meet the influx of people which is estimated by UN agencies to grow from about 750,000 by end 1989 to about 1.5 million by mid 1990 for Eritrea alone. UNICEF will assist the RRC in the supply of supplementary food in the form of locally produced faffa, high protein biscuits, and purchases of local pulses. UNICEF will also assist with the transport, providing support vehicles and water truck tankers, with field support materials and equipment, and manpower costs. Shelter relief materials (such as blankets, soap, water containers, cooking and feeding kits, tents, grinding mills and temporary storage, will be also supplied for displaced families, and school materials such as exercise books and pencils, will be provided for the displaced children.

Project N. 2: Ethiopian Catholic Secretariat-Estimated budget: US$1,850,000. The Ethiopian Churches, Catholic, Orthodox and Protestants, have banded together in 1984-85 into the Joint Relief Partners (JRP) with the Ethiopian Catholic Secretariat as its coordinating body in Eritrea.
The ECS has built 34 health and food distribution centres, including water points with reservoirs, all over Eritrea, it also maintains 20 health clinics in the region.

UNICEF assistance will cover both ECS relief and rehabilitation assistance. Relief assistance will be in the form of shelter relief items, supplementary food, drugs and medicines, medical supplies and equipment, clothing and blankets. ECS capability to build and improve its water points will be strengthened in the form of pumps, pipes and fittings, and water reservoirs and truck water tankers. Its 20 health clinics and outreach health programmes will also be strengthened through the provision of drugs and medicines, ORS, medical supplies and equipment, and support vehicles. Moreover, assistance will be given to ECS projects of soil and water conservation, reforestation and small irrigation as a measure of disaster preparedness.

Project N. 3: Asmara City Council-Estimated budget: US$850,000: Asmara City Council has requested UNICEF assistance to increase its health and sanitation support systems in view of the influx of some 200,000 people from the surrounding countryside.

UNICEF will provide assistance in the form of equipment and supplies for health promotion and education, of cold-chain equipment for increased immunization, supply of vaccines, ORS, pesticides/rodenticides, drugs and medicines, and in the form of construction of additional water points and provision of handpumps, construction of improved latrines, procurement of sludge tank collectors, mounted garbage disposal units, and water truck tankers. Operations and monitoring systems as well as transport equipment for supervision will also be provided.

Project N. 4: Ethiopian Water Works Authority-Estimated budget: US$550,000. The EWWCA is expected to increase water capacity in some of the 25 distribution centres which will be opened by the RRC. This project will consist of forming three water rehabilitation teams to quicken the pace of water scheme rehabilitation. It will require the provision of pipes, reservoirs, truck water tankers, vehicles, workshop tools, monolift and handpumps, temporary warehouses, field rescue tents and equipment, and field work support to maintain water teams on the field for stretches of 30-days work.

Project N. 5: Social Welfare Centre-Estimated budget: US$650,000. The Vicariate of Asmara founded a centre for displaced children and women and mothers as a result of the 1984-85 drought and of the internal conflict which has been plaguing Eritrea for 28 years.

Aside from its network of urban child care, it maintains outreach stations in ten locations in Eritrea. In the city of Asmara, it also feeds 6500 children from Tigraean displaced families daily, and maintains centres for street children, abandoned mothers and other destitute people. The Social Welfare Centre supports a paediatric ward in the Asmara hospital for abandoned babies.

In the coming drought the Centre expects its operations to increase four-fold. Already, UNICEF has provided one vehicle for managing the Centre's many facilities, and supplied blankets, soaps, medicines and feeding kits. Additional supply of the above items and supplementary food will be needed, as well as support for the Centre's immunization programmes implemented in its 15 clinics, provision of ORS, of equipment to strengthen the Centre's soup kitchens as well as of light trucks, water tankers and light vehicles.

Project N. 6: Water and Sanitation Agency-Estimated budget: US$750,000. The WSA is a newly created agency for local water management in urban centres. Much of the Ethiopian Water Works Authority projects have been turned over to this new agency. UNICEF will provide assistance in the form of pumps, pipes and fittings, diesel engine prime movers, water reservoirs, rips and vehicles for service and supervision. WSA projects will be addressed to the outlying towns of Eritrea.

Project N. 7: Ethiopian Red Cross Society-Estimated budget: US$250,000. The ERCS is the national organization of the Red Cross and is affiliated with the League of International Red Cross. In the last 6 months ERCS has been assisting 300,000 people in Eritrea and more recently 10,000 people in Dahlak Islands half of which were displaced fishermen from Bore peninsula. The ERCS took over the relief operations of the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) when this was asked to leave northern Ethiopia in 1988.

The ERCS has launched its own appeal for the current emergency. UNICEF assistance was requested in supporting their water trunk tanker fleet in terms of fuel, operations and maintenance, as well as in providing technical assistance and training in the field of Primary Health Care.

Project N. 8: Capuchin Fathers/Eritrea-Estimated budget: US$950,000. The Capuchin Fathers have been assisting the displaced population, with UNICEF support, since the 1987-88 drought. They are now planning to expand their service to the 200,000 displaced currently in Eritrea and to the expected displaced families which will arrive from Tigray and from the countryside in the next months.

UNICEF will provide blankets, clothing, soap, supplementary food, drugs and medicines, water reservoirs, jerry cans for families, cooking and feeding utensils, grinding mills, exercise books for school children, and transport equipment including mounted water tankers.

Project N. 9: Evangelical Church of Eritrea-Estimated budget: US$1,200,000. Since the 1984-85 drought, the Evangelical Church has specialized its assistance to drought affected people in the construction of micro-dams as a form of drought mitigation and as a concrete measure of disaster preparedness. To date, the ECE has built 16 micro-dams; each micro-dam costs US$ 125,000 in terms of heavy equipment and food for work labour intensive construction. In any dam project 2000 to 3000 people are provided with food for work. ECE estimates that its 16 dams are now servicing some 300,000 people.

UNICEF will assist ECE to continue its dam construction programme by providing pipes, handpumps, monolift pumps, water reservoirs, construction equipment, surveying equipment and technical consultancy in irrigation methods. UNICEF will also supply drugs and medicines, medical equipment, as well as exercise books, pencils and blackboards for ECE's health and education projects. Vehicles for construction and general programme management have also been requested.

Project N. 10: Support to Local Government/UNICEF Sub-Office-Estimated budget: US$750,000. Together with UNICEF sub-office in Asmara, local officials are expected to assist the regional government in coordinating and managing the activities related to the displacement of people and the provision of relief.

UNICEF assistance is requested in the form of temporary warehouses for the storage of relief materials in the major transport/port locations, of cargo handling equipment, grinding mills, cash assistance for manpower support, clearing of cargo from the ports, and transport of relief materials. Support to district authorities office and field organizations, to increase their administrative capacity, has also been requested.
Breakdown of Requested Funds by Sector

(a) Life Saving Drugs. Provision of drugs, medicines, medical supplies and equipment to strengthen the existing health programmes of the government and non-government health facilities in Eritrea ...

(b) Water Supply. Provision of water pumps and prime movers, water reservoirs, truck tankers, water containers, pipes and fittings and related equipment and supplies to increase potable water capacity during the emergency ...
(c) Supplementary Food. Provision of high-protein biscuits, local faffa, oil, pulses, sugar and milk products ...

Total: ...
COORDINATION
Government Coordination

The main government counterpart of the UNICEF Emergency Section in Ethiopia is the Relief and Rehabilitation Commission (RRC). The RRC not only implements projects in the field, but it is also the national coordinating body for relief and rehabilitation assistance from all the multi-lateral and bilateral agencies and from NGOs.

The Government of Ethiopia recently adopted a ``National Disaster Preparedness and Prevention Strategy'' which clarifies the roles of government agencies in emergencies, and lays out guidelines for RRC co-ordination of emergency activities.
UN Coordination

UNICEF is a member of the EPPG (Emergency Preparedness and Prevention Group) which is the coordinating body for emergency activities carried out in Ethiopia by UN agencies such as UNDP, UNDRO, WHO, UNHCR, WEP and FAO. Meetings, under the chairmanship of the UN Assistant Secretary-General for Ethiopian Emergency who is also UNDP Representative, are held twice a month.

UNICEF is also a member of the Informal Bilateral Donor's Committee where monthly UN agencies brief bilateral and multi-lateral donors on the status of the emergency situation, and donors inform each other of their assistance to Ethiopia.
NGO Coordination

UNICEF implements its projects through major international and national NGOs. These include the 64 religious NGOs of the Christian Relief and Development Agency, the Ethiopian Churches members of the Joint Relief Partners, as well as other major and smaller NGOs such as Save the Children Fund (UK), Radda Barnen, Oxfam, Medecins Sans Frontieres, the Ethiopian Red Cross Society, World Vision International Action Aid, LWF.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. It remains only to say that I hope that the Australian Government will find some resources to assist with this appeal and to make a response to this emergency in conjunction with UNICEF Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -Honourable senators will recall that last year the nation voted on four referenda questions, which were defeated. Certainly as part of the campaign that led to that defeat there was a great deal of propaganda pushed by the Right, urging a No vote. Prominent amongst those groups were the Australian League of Rights and the Logos Foundation. The polemic tone of the literature published by such groups adds, unfortunately, to the reservoir of hate which is infecting the political debate in this country. At the moment in Queensland there is an election campaign being waged, and there has been an intervention in that campaign by the Logos Foundation.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is important to highlight the exercise by which the Logos Foundation deals with a variety of matters. One of the most significant understandings which this type of religious fundamentalism has of itself and the world is that its followers are, in fact, a holy people of God surrounded by the enemy. This enemy is to be identified and, if possible, eliminated. In other words, what we are looking at is, as it were, the establishment of a Christian ayatollahism. The view that the Logos Foundation in Queensland in the last few weeks has lent on can be analysed. There are four main steps in that tactic of creating fear and establishing the enemy. The first one, of course, is the identification of the enemy, and the enemy is seen as someone who would overthrow the Christian way of life. This identification is designed to play on latent prejudices against minority groups and to reinforce a fortress mentality.

I do not think the exercise in Queensland needs to be detailed in full, but the second tactic after the identification is vilification of the enemy. This is to suggest that that particular enemy is less than human, or if it is human that it is so evil that it should be regarded as less than human and certainly less than `our people who would never stoop to these types of activities'. The third tactic, of course, is brutalisation. Having created this climate of fear, they create a climate in which people within our community feel free not only to identify and vilify but also to move to physical abuse and maltreatment. Hence, we have seen, for example, that in Queensland many minority groups have been subjected to physical attack and beatings. The exercise is one which I think those who have ever bothered to study any history would know very well.

The last element, of course, having arrived at such a circumstance, is to move to the political strategy of the elimination of the enemy. Once that enemy has been seen as non-human, as evil, and as a diseased cancer, then a surgical removal is suggested. Indeed, the Logos Foundation wants to go to the ready-made surgical removal exercise, and that is the reintroduction of the death penalty. If I can quote from a broadsheet put out by that organisation on this one, I think the various points they have raised so far will be clear. It says this:
The divinely-ordained purpose of the State is the upholding of social order and the restraint of evil, not the reformation of the criminal.
Unless there is an ultimate sanction-capital punishment-in the restraint of evil, the criminal has no reason not to commit the most reprehensible of crimes.
The opponents of capital punishment are undermining the common good by siding with evil, and are showing more regard for the criminal than the victim of the crime, and are . . . encouraging murder.

I think honourable senators will agree that such exercises within our community do not sit with either our historical or democratic traditions. We have a vigorous and healthy political system in this country that can well do without the exercise of creating evil enemies that end up having very little rights, if any, to exist within our community.

Of course, this is all fed by a world network, in terms of the New Right and publications, but mainly, of course, support comes from the United States where the type of money that is necessary for the publication of books and articles and the production of videos and other material seems to be readily available, despite the fact that some of their reasonable proponents have been locked up for 30- or 40-odd years. The exercise of what I would call this politics of resentment and hate of course is designed to appeal to strong leadership. If only a leader will come forward to take control and offer simple solutions, those who feel alienated from the political process are quite happy to follow, even at the cost of democratic freedoms. One commentator, in his book Thunder on the Right, says this:

It is a vast conspiracy, indeed, that thwarts the will of the people, so the New Right rationale goes. So vast, in fact, that everyone is a member except the tiny minority of the New Right ideologues and their constituents. The society, indeed the age, is the conspiracy.

In assessing the part played by fundamentalist religion in reinforcing this politics of resentment one has to look at the reliance on resources and literature coming from the United States. Most Australian leaders of the religious Right are in fact in agreement, but it is interesting that in the Queensland context the leaders of the mainstream churches have issued very strong statements disassociating themselves from this lunatic fringe, disassociating themselves from this politics of hate and resentment, and have sought rather to focus on issues that they believe and that I believe are the fundamental types of issues that certainly the Christian churches have always propounded. In the Logos Foundation appeal called `Shareholders in the Nation of Australia', there is this:

We are witnessing a deliberate and specific attempt in Australia to change our value systems: in classrooms, on television programmes, in the newspapers and throughout the social fabric of our nation.
Our moral values, family values, business ethics, judicial principles . . . are all undergoing change.
The issue is not a political one, in the sense of a socialist or conservative government. It is a question of which value system will undergird our nation and its institutions.
The central issue is, which value system do you wish to base our society on-a Christian one, or a non-biblical, humanistic one?

Leaving aside the rather dubious claim that Australia was ever established on Christian values, the above is fairly typical of the type of material put out by the Logos Foundation in which there is a projection of this threatened conspiracy. I think it is time that Australians saw through this constant and destructive projection of enemies as a tactic to win support. I think this rejection is essential to support for our democratic institutions. Where such views are presented as Christian, I believe the Australian church, all the mainstream churches, ought to have the courage-as they have had-to expose the strategy for what it is; that is, a perversion of the Christian gospel. I think that those people, in all of the churches, who have worked in Australia for the poor, the needy, the oppressed and the sick would find this type of equating of Christianity with hatred to be the utter perversion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I get to the matter I want to talk on I will make a comment on the previous two speakers. First of all, I congratulate Senator Macklin on his excellent contribution exposing the Logos Association in Queensland for what it is. But I would also like to support the remarks of Senator Peter Baume about the situation occurring in Ethiopia. I have already, in the last couple of months, taken up with the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) the need to prepare to provide additional aid to Ethiopia, Eritrea and the Horn of Africa because there is every evidence that there could be a calamitous drought in that area over the next few months, putting at risk more lives than were at risk in the dreadful drought of 1984-85.

SPEECH.PARA: What I want to speak on today in this matters of public interest debate is something that may be considered similar to what Senator Macklin talked about, but in a different area. It concerns the activities of a fringe political group that is masquerading as something that it is not. I was quite surprised that two weeks ago I received on my desk a press release announcing that the Democratic Socialist Party had been formed in Australia. It was dated 11 a.m., 1 November. In the opening paragraph the press release said:

The Socialist Workers Party announced today that it has changed its name to Democratic Socialist Party. The name change was approved by a recent meeting of the SWP National Committee following a referendum of the membership which supported the change by a margin of six to one.
At the bottom of the press release it says:
For further information or interviews phone DSP National Secretary Jim Percy . . .

It then gives the telephone number. I must say that anybody who has shown any interest in the ideology of the fringe parties of the Left would recognise that this statement is an absolute fraud. There is no way that the Socialist Workers Party, after what it has been doing politically in Australia over the last decade, could now just suddenly call itself the Democratic Socialist Party and make itself out to be something quite different-particularly when one sees the influence and involvement of Mr Jim Percy, now calling himself National Secretary. I am sure that Senator Vallentine would recognise Jim Percy's name very rapidly because Mr Percy was the person who organised the infiltration of the Nuclear Disarmament Party at the time of the 1984 election which forced Senator Vallentine and other well-known people such as Mr Peter Garrett to resign. He made it quite clear that the Nuclear Disarmament Party had been infiltrated and taken over by supporters of the Socialist Workers Party and it was a classic Trotskyite policy of entryism.

It seems to me that Mr Percy has realised that the Socialist Workers Party has absolutely no future in Australia-it has been identified for what it is-but is now looking at establishing a new party, or renaming the party to try to attract support on the basis of misleading people as to what the real function of his party is. In the full press statement Mr Percy talks about calling a conference next year, in January, the theme being `For a Green, Democratic and Socialist World'. The party will consider a new draft program and a revised constitution. The press release goes on to talk about the extraordinary events going on in eastern Europe, suggesting that bureaucratic socialism is coming to an end and therefore it is most appropriate for the Democratic Socialist Party to come into existence.

I just want to put it on record that I do not believe that anybody in Australia should be in any way misled. The Democratic Socialist Party name is an absolute fraud for Mr Percy's use. What I find particularly objectionable about the use of the democratic socialism philosophy is that in the opening sentence of the principles of the Australian Labor Party-and I am a member of that party-we declare ourselves to be a democratic socialist party. That has been our philosophical basis for 90-odd years. As a result of that philosophical basis we have been granted membership of the Socialist International, made up of all three democratic socialist, Labor and social democrat parties around the world.

It seems to me that Mr Percy hopes to attract some support by renaming the SWP as the Democratic Socialist Party. I think he has recognised that in the coming months, if not years, with the decline of bureaucratic socialism, of Stalinist communism in eastern Europe, many of those people who are demonstrating for democracy are saying that they do not want to go to full capitalism. They are using the phrase `democratic socialism', and I suspect that Mr Percy is trying to jump on the bandwagon and run with a name that I think will become increasingly popular in ideological terms in western Europe. Even in western Europe it was announced the other day that the Italian Communist Party will drop the `Communist' from its name, and it has applied to seek affiliation to the Socialist International. That is an historic announcement by the Italian Communist Party. It recognises that its survival in a western democratic system will mean that it is going to have to change some of its philosophies. But it is doing that quite openly and without the subterfuge of this very small minority that Mr Percy represents. I must say, when he says the name change was carried by a margin of 6 to 1, I suspect only seven people voted in the proverbial telephone box to get that result.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek the leave of the Senate to incorporate this short press statement into Hansard and hope that it can be a basis for people around Australia being vigilant about what Mr Percy is up to.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
PRESS RELEASE
Democratic Socialist Party Announced
11am, November 1

The Socialist Workers Party announced today that it has changed its name to Democratic Socialist Party. The name change was approved by a recent meeting of the SWP National Committee following a referendum of the membership which supported the change by a margin of six to one.
The name change is only one aspect of a comprehensive renovation process that will culminate in an effective relaunching of the party at a national conference in January.
The theme of the January conference will be For a Green, Democratic and Socialist World and it will consider a new draft program and a revised constitution for the DSP.

It will also consider new policy documents on environmental protection and other pressing concerns. The environmental document, titled Socialism and Human Survival, will offer a detailed analysis of the environmental crisis and the relevance of socialist solutions.
The national secretary of the Democratic Socialist Party, Jim Percy, said today:

``The renovation process we are undertaking is motivated by both international and domestic considerations. On one level there is the need for urgent global action to prevent a nuclear holocaust or an environmental catastrophe.
``Secondly we see the need to defend and extend the democratic rights of people in this country against the continuing trend towards monopolisation of political and economic power.

``And thirdly, we are convinced socialism offers the only secure and lasting solution to nuclear and environmental threats and to desperate problems of social injustice that plague the capitalist world.''
Percy said the DSP's concern for the environment and democratic rights is widely shared, but its ongoing commitment to socialism may not be so well understood:

``Some recent developments in the socialist world-in countries like Poland, Hungary, East Germany and China-have led many to believe that socialism is about to make its exit from the historical stage. We reject that view. In fact, we are very excited about the worldwide renovation of socialism that is taking its cue from the introduction of perestroika and glasnost in the Soviet Union.

``There is a crisis of bureaucratic socialism and a firm rejection of the approach that has led to things like the crimes of Stalin and this year's massacre in Beijing. The DSP identifies fully with the reform movement initiated by the Gorbachev leadership in the Soviet Union and we now see similar movements spreading throughout Eastern Europe.
``Our view is that we are witnessing the emergence of a new, more democratic form of socialism and our name change is aimed at reinforcing our identification with this trend.''
For further information or interviews phone DSP National Secretary Jim Percy on (02) 690 1240 or 690 1230.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also want to put it on record that if Mr Percy attempts under the political process of Australia to register with the electoral commissions of Australia, either State or Federal, where one has to register a party's political name, I would hope that there will be strong opposition to the registration of his party as the Democratic Socialist Party because it would be a complete fraud on the Australian electoral process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I want to inform the Senate of my experience in what has been a most disturbing performance by the Headmistresses Association of the Independent Girls Schools in Victoria. Nearly 50 years ago the headmistresses were given a very valuable property, Invergowrie, which is now possibly worth $10m although the value is difficult to estimate accurately in the present confused market. The headmistresses were given the property by the McPherson family, who have been remarkable benefactors of education in Victoria. They gave the Emily McPherson College of domestic economy, the Engineering School at Swinburne Institute of Technology and, in a different field, the Jessie McPherson wing of the Queen Victoria Hospital.

SPEECH.PARA: My particular concern is what is happening to the donation the family made of their family home, Invergowrie, an historic building in the inner Melbourne suburb of Hawthorn, to the Headmistresses Association of the Independent Girls Schools. This gift was made nearly 50 years ago, partly so the headmistresses could run a homecraft hostel designed to fill a large gap in the education system as it then was, that is teaching girls how to run homes economically, but more importantly, to preserve the historic Invergowrie homestead. The house itself was built in 1846 and is by any standards one of the most important historic buildings in Victoria. It was, for instance, the site of the signing of the Deed of Separation of Victoria from New South Wales. Even more important, it has almost three acres of parklike surroundings, including a tree which is a remarkable Aboriginal relic. In this tree one can see clearly where the Aborigines have carved out a canoe. By any standards, the preservation of this historic building and its surroundings should be of great importance to the entire Australian community.

Here, Mr Acting Deputy President, I should reveal a personal interest. My wife was a McPherson, the daughter of one of the donors of Invergowrie. This has, of course, the advantage that I am well informed of what went on and what the family intentions were. It must be accepted that the concept of a homecraft hostel, teaching girls how to run homes, is no longer viable. Girls who until the 1970s would have attended Invergowrie now go to university. Whether or not they learn there how to run homes efficiently could be a matter of dispute. Whatever the facts are about that, the fact is now that people are no longer going to come to a homecraft hostel to be taught how to run a home.

But that is not the end of the matter. This building and its surroundings were given to the headmistresses, as far as the donors were concerned, in trust to preserve it for the community. Now it is to be sold without any covenants at all. I do not want now to go through the saga of the court case, of whether it was or was not a trust, or what financial benefits would flow to the headmistresses from the sale, but I will have more to say on this matter if the sale actually goes through. The good news is that the headmistresses are apparently seriously considering an innovative use for this property rather than its sale. The suggestion is that it should become a centre concerned with research, administration and special training resources for the pursuit of excellence in the field of serious music. Its aims could perhaps be likened to those of the Australian Institute of Sport, which works alongside already established bodies in its field. The project is the brainchild of Mr Max Cooke, reader at the Faculty of Music at Melbourne University. I have seen the costings for this project and they seem realistic and feasible. If this project could be brought off it would achieve the twin objectives of preserving the historic Invergowrie Homestead, for which the headmistresses have a moral duty, and at the same time making a notable contribution to culture in Australia. The matter is urgent. The sale of this property is scheduled for next Tuesday. I hope the headmistresses will be able to see their way, and their duty, clearly.

DEBATE.TITLE: JUDICIAL AND STATUTORY OFFICERS REMUNERATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 30 October, on motion by Senator Button:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: LOCAL GOVERNMENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the revised explanatory memorandum relating to the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the Judicial and Statutory Officers Remuneration Legislation Amendment Bill. Its purpose is to increase the salaries of Federal Court judges in accordance with the Remuneration Tribunal's decision of June 1989. Those changes would apply retrospectively to 1 March 1989. It provides for some increases in travel allowances, enables Family Court judges to receive the same remuneration as Federal Court judges, as per the Government's decision of 13 July 1989, and amends the Remuneration Tribunal Act to give the Tribunal the power to determine rather than recommend judicial salaries subject to parliamentary disallowance.

SPEECH.PARA: As I indicated, we support this increase of Federal Court judges' salaries. We are concerned when Federal judges' salaries fall significantly below those of State judges. We understand that, particularly in relation to Queensland, there is considerable disparity. We recognise that salaries must be such to attract hopefully the best from within practice. Although it might be difficult to provide strictly competing salaries, they must not be such as to deter good people seeking to contribute to a national well-being on the Bench. We have been concerned in the past, and I think I spoke on the equivalent of this Bill a year or two ago, about this problem which had been raised in a number of legal conferences by very senior members of the legal profession. So we support the fact that salaries are being updated somewhat. The other changes we also support, particularly the change regarding the Remuneration Tribunal so that it makes a determination. It seems to us to be a further step towards depoliticising those decisions, and that is in the best interests of the whole system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: LOCAL GOVERNMENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Hill for his contribution to the debate. As he has indicated, the Judicial and Statutory Officers Remuneration Legislation Amendment Bill implements increases in remuneration for members of the Federal judiciary. The Government was unable to accept the substantial salary increase recommended for the judiciary in the Remuneration Tribunal's 1988 review. Members of the Tribunal were asked by the Government to prepare a special report on appropriate remuneration of the judiciary in the current wage fixing context. Their report recommended that an inequity of remuneration between Federal and State court judges be rectified by the granting of a 16 per cent increase. Also, the Tribunal recommended that the August 1988 national wage case increase of 3 per cent and $10 a week be applied and the expense of office allowance be absorbed into salaries.

SPEECH.PARA: The Tribunal will in future be empowered to determine judicial remuneration rather than make recommendations as at present in respect of judges and judicial office holders. This will bring the setting of judicial remuneration into line with the setting of remuneration for all other officers within the Tribunal's jurisdiction except Ministers. As is the case for these other officers, determinations will be subject to disallowance by either House of Parliament. A further examination of judicial salaries will be undertaken by the Tribunal in light of the August 1989 national wage case decision. The review will also assess the appropriateness of the relativities of remuneration between Federal Court judges and a number of statutory office holders. I thank Senator Hill and commend the Bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: LIMITATION OF LIABILITY FOR MARITIME CLAIMS BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 August, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Limitation of Liability for Maritime Claims Bill amends the Navigation Act of 1912 and the Admiralty Act of 1988. The Navigation Act of 1912 implements the 1957 International Convention relating to the Limitation of the Liability of Owners of Seagoing Ships. This convention was agreed to in Brussels many decades ago. The 1957 convention replaced rules which were initiated in 1924. The Bill before the Senate today will enable Australia to become a party to the updated 1976 convention, known as the Convention on Limitation of Liability for Maritime Claims. This convention came into force internationally in December 1986.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the years there has been considerable debate about the need for a limitation of damages. It is considered that a limitation is necessary because of the potential economic effect of just a single accident involving a number of deaths. That concern is, of course, demonstrated by the Herald of Free Enterprise disaster in Belgium where tragically 193 persons lost their lives. The decision to accede to this 1976 convention was made at the 75th meeting of the Australian Transport Advisory Council in 1987. Acceding to the convention, Australia joins the United Kingdom, France, Japan, the Federal Republic of Germany, Liberia and the Scandinavian countries. The convention is contained in schedule 1 of this Bill. Notably, this convention will not apply to ships of the armed forces of a foreign power, according to clause 7.

I would just like to take a few minutes to look at the differences between the two conventions. Firstly, there is a difference in the amount available for compensation. This convention makes available $6.1m for personal claims, $2.7m for property claims and, if applicable, $29m for passenger claims for an accident involving a ship of 10,000 tonnes gross. Under the current or 1957 convention the total amount available would be only $3.22m. In addition, this convention does not permit State parties to exclude damage to harbour works, bases and waterways and aids to navigation from liability.

There is also a considerable difference in the two conventions as to the behaviour or conduct which will bar a shipowner from the right to limit his liability. There is a change to the associated burden of proof provisions. Currently, the burden of proof lies with the person seeking to establish the right to limit liability. Under the 1976 convention, which this Bill seeks to have Australia become a party to, this burden is on the claimant.

I would now like to look briefly at the main provisions of the convention. Article 1 of the convention allows shipowners to limit their liability. Article 2 covers the claims that will be covered by the convention-personal injury, death, property damage, delay, breach of contract or the removal of a wreck or cargo. Article 3 states the exceptions. It states that claims in respect of salvage, oil pollution or nuclear damage will not be covered. Article 4 provides that a person will not be able to take advantage of the limit if the loss results from an act or omission committed with the intent to cause the loss knowing that such loss would probably result. Chapter 2 deals with the limits of liability based on weight of the ship and categories of claims, chapter 3 provides for the establishment of limitation of funds, and chapter 4 covers the application of the convention. Article 19 allows for the renunciation of the convention a year after it has entered into force, by the lodgment of an instrument to that effect.

Mr Acting Deputy President, the Opposition supports the Bill. Before closing, I would just like to reiterate the comments of my colleagues in another place-that the situation of regularising claims with respect to the aviation industry still lags behind. We would hope that this Government will move soon to bring this situation more up to date-if it has time before losing the next election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: LOCAL GOVERNMENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator MacGibbon for his contribution to the second reading debate but I have to disagree strongly with his final comments. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
Sitting suspended from 1.49 to 2.00 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, representing the Prime Minister and the Treasurer. Given that the October current account deficit of $2.24 billion brings the cumulative deficit for the year to $8.17 billion, which is 46 per cent higher than for the same four-month period last year that ended with a total deficit of $18.2 billion, will the Government revise upwards the 1988-89 Budget forecast of $18.5 billion?
—No wonder Walshie took the day off. He was not prepared to be here to face up to these figures.
—Senator Boswell will have to take a day off soon up there in Queensland. He will be suffering from shock when that shonky lot of his gets thrown out of office.
—Put your money where your mouth is.

—It is hollow laughter, Senator Boswell. Of course, I would have to consult with the Treasurer about any revision of the figures, but this question has been asked on each occasion the monthly current account figure has been published since July. On each occasion I have given the same answer. The cumulative current account deficit in original terms was $8.2 billion.
