Senator Chaney said $8.17 billion, I think, but it is not material to the answer, is it?
—No, it is not.

—That is almost 45 per cent of the forecast deficit for the whole of 1989-90. However, in seasonally adjusted terms the deficit is less than 40 per cent. At this stage I do not believe that it is necessary to consider changing the Government's forecast. I said earlier that I would speak to the Treasurer about that issue; the Budget forecast was, of course, $18.5 billion. The Government has always said-and the Budget Papers clearly set it out-that we expected high monthly current account deficits in the first four to six months of this financial year and much better deficit figures in the subsequent six months of the financial year.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. With reference to the latter part of the Minister's answer, which referred to the Government's expectation that the situation would improve in the second half of the financial year, is the Minister saying that in fact the Budget forecast is on track? Given the level of the figures so far, does this not indicate that the Government is expecting a severe economic slowdown to help bring about the sort of monthly current account deficits that would be required to meet the estimate? In other words, as month by month-and we are now in the fourth month-these very large figures come out, if the Government is saying that its estimate is still on track, that suggests a very severe downturn next year. What is the view of the Government about that likelihood?

—The monthly current account deficit is a lagged indicator of economic conditions. I believe that there is already substantial slowdown in the economy and that that will be reflected in the lagged figures which come forward in the second half of this financial year. If I could put that another way, the downturn in the economy is not expected to be fully reflected immediately in current account figures.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NATIONAL ENERGY RESEARCH, DEVELOPMENT AND DEMONSTRATION PROGRAM

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and relates to advertisements placed in national newspapers by the Government calling for expressions of interest by consultants in evaluating the operations of the national energy research, development and demonstration program. Can the Minister inform the Senate what the objectives of the evaluation process are and how the process is going? Can he tell the Senate how the program as a whole has gone in the 10 years it has been in operation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 November I announced that the Government had decided to appoint a team to evaluate the national energy research, development and demonstration program. I have now appointed a consortium consisting of the Centre for Technology and Social Change at the University of Wollongong, Energy Policy and Analysis Pty Ltd of Canberra and the science policy research centre of Griffith University to undertake the review for me.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators will know that the national energy research, development and demonstration program was set up in 1978 to meet the Commonwealth's energy policy objectives through selective support of energy research, development and demonstration projects. The purpose of the review is to report on the extent to which the key objectives of the program have been achieved and what steps can be taken to overcome any deficiencies that might be identified. In particular, the team will look at the processes used to effect better program delivery and the development of cost competitive technologies within reasonable time frames-and by that I mean to look at the conversion of liquefied natural gas to a transport fuel, at the prospects for coal liquefaction, at the prospects for shale oil in Australia, at wind, solar, tidal, biomass and geothermal renewable energy technologies to see whether we are meeting our objectives across all of those frontiers.

The survey will also look at the transfer of technology to prospective users. By that I mean the marketability of technologies that might be discovered or developed, what their market applications might be, and how one would popularise alternative energy forms in ordinary community consumption of energy. It will also evaluate the effectiveness of the current program. My angle there is to make sure that taxpayers' money spent on this program is efficiently targeted.

Today I announced new research grants totalling $18.3m to 94 projects. The biggest beneficiary was the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, which obtained a grant of $3.36m for research on and analysis of energy. That brings to $250m the total amount allocated by the Government since the program commenced. The 1989 annual report of the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council noted that the program received a high level of collaboration, so the $250m I have referred to is only the Government component. Often that constitutes but a third of the total expenditure. Some $57.9m was committed to the program from all sources, with $30m, or 52 per cent, coming from private enterprise and $14.5m, or 25 per cent, being appropriately directed by the Commonwealth.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Prime Minister and, in the absence of Senator Walsh, the Treasurer to an article on the front page of today's Australian newspaper which states:

QUESTION.PARA: Mr Miyamoto-
senior manager and Australian securities manager of Japanese broker Nomura Securities-
said Nomura was buying Australia and was telling all of its friends to do the same.
The report further cites Mr Miyamoto as saying:
We are advising our clients and institutions to buy Australian-dollar denominated assets in equities, fixed interest, property, manufacturing-everything . . .

In this same vein, I refer the Minister to a recent study by Citibank Ltd, which predicts that Australian assets held by foreigners are likely to almost double, from $223 billion to $429 billion, over the next five years. Firstly, does the Minister welcome these outcomes of his Government's policies? Secondly, in particular, in his own portfolio capacity does he welcome the further upward pressure on the Australian dollar which will be induced by Nomura Securities' advice to its clients to `buy Australia'-`everything'? Thirdly, what measures does the Government have in mind to reverse this enormous accumulation of Australian assets by foreigners?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of questions have been asked by Senator Stone. I will try to deal with them one by one. The fact that Mr Miyamoto has made that statement of Nomura's intentions and the advice which it may be giving clients is not relevant in itself. Any substantial financial house anywhere in the world, particularly in Japan, may well do that in respect of countries such as the United States, Australia and a number of European countries. Lest there be any special Queensland-type concern expressed in Senator Stone's question about levels of Japanese investment, let me say that Japan is not, in aggregate terms, in any way the largest investor in Australia. The United Kingdom remains, in aggregate terms, the largest investor in Australia. The United States remains the second largest investor; Japan remains the third. It is not in the least surprising: Japan currently being, I think it is fair to say, the richest country in the world and the country with the most available investment funds in the world; a country which has been able to buy banks in the United States, the Rockefeller Centre and Warner Bros-all the symbols of the more successful period of America's past.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact that Nomura intends to buy assets of the kind described by Senator Stone is in some ways encouraging. I would have thought that Senator Stone would have been aware of the pattern of Japanese investment in Australia in the last few years. It has been highly directed towards the tourist industry, for very logical reasons, as predictions of Japanese tourists coming to Australia are very high as are predictions of tourism from North Asia generally. That is a natural and sensible investment for Japanese. They have made the same sorts of investments in Hawaii but to a much greater extent. I would welcome some further Japanese investment in parts of the Australian manufacturing sector for reasons which Senator Stone might know about, and, if I do not get in first, interject about. Up until now that investment in a number of industries has not been forthcoming. The fact that Nomura Securities says that it will now be investing is an encouraging sign about structural change in Australia. Senator Stone used the somewhat emotive expression `Australian assets held by foreigners'.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not emotive.

—That was the expression used: `Australian assets held by foreigners'. The point of his question-if I do not misjudge him-is that he likes some foreigners but not others. I have never heard him objecting in this place to British investment in Australia or making the suggestion that there is something wrong with British investment in this country. He now makes the point about particular countries that he mentions. As to Nomura Securities' statement of intention and advice to its clients possibly putting upward pressure on the Australian dollar, I do not think that anything will happen with precipitate haste as a result of an article appearing on the front page of the Australian quoting Mr Miyamoto about these matters. Of course, if it does cause upward pressure on the Australian dollar, that would be cause for concern. But I do not think one can draw those conclusions from the statement made by Mr Miyamoto on behalf of his company.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce for his most informative answer. First, I refer to his reference to what he called the `special Queensland-type concern'. I took it from that that he was referring to the fact that the question was based upon a press statement by a representative of the largest Japanese securities firm. Will the Minister convey his lack of concern on that matter to the Leader of the Opposition and, indeed, the Australian Labor Party in Queensland, Mr Goss, who has recently been uttering the most inflammatory statements on that subject during the course of the Queensland election campaign? Indeed, he has taken out public advertisements indicating that he would forbid and ban such investments if we were to have the signally unfortunate instance of him being elected on Saturday week. Secondly, during the course of the Minister's remarks he made a rather deliberate misrepresentation of my question by referring to the phrase `assets held by foreigners'. He implied that I was referring to the fact that these assets are to be held by Japanese. Will the Minister confirm that the question contained no such suggestion and that any such suggestion has been derived only from his vivid imagination?

—In answer to the first part of the question, there is room for considerable discussion about these issues. When Mr Goss is Premier of Queensland I will not mind having a discussion with him about that. As to the second part of the question, Senator Stone's question was couched in these terms: he quoted from Mr Miyamoto, the Chief Executive of Nomura Securities, and then made the statement-in his own words-`Is the Minister concerned about these Australian assets held by foreigners?'. The connection was in his question. If the cap fits, he has to wear it; not me.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and refers to the reported assassinations in Lebanon. What will be the effects on the people of Lebanon of the appalling incident which occurred overnight when the new President of that country and some 20 other people were murdered?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that all honourable senators will join me in deploring the brutal assassination of President Muawad in Beirut overnight. I take this opportunity, as the Prime Minister has just done in the House of Representatives, to extend Australia's deepest sympathy to the wife and family of the late President and of the others killed in this appalling and barbaric act. Mr Muawad was elected President at a session of the Lebanese Parliament on 5 November, which also ratified the Ta'if agreement. Australia welcomed that agreement as a breakthrough in the search for a peaceful and negotiated solution to the situation in Lebanon. Mr Muawad was elected to the Lebanese Parliament in 1957 and served in three governments between 1960 and 1982. Throughout his time in public office, Mr Muawad was a firm advocate of Christian and Muslim detente and of Lebanese sovereignty. President Muawad, whose election attracted widespread international support, did not underestimate the enormous task that lay ahead of him. In his inaugural address he called on Lebanese to join the peace and reconciliation process under the umbrella of equal opportunities, justice and equality.

ANSWER.PARA: It is a very sad irony that President Muawad was assassinated on Lebanon's national day. The Governor-General of Australia had sent a message of congratulations to the President in which he expressed the hope that his election and ratification of the Ta'if agreement would prove to be historic steps in the return of peace and prosperity for Lebanon.

Obviously, the death of President Muawad is a tragic blow to the recent efforts of the Arab League and the Lebanese Parliament to secure political reforms and end the years of senseless fighting in Lebanon. Our immediate concern is that the ceasefire may end and that this will lead to a further round of intercommunal violence and result in yet more suffering for the Lebanese people. So, yet again, we call on all parties in Lebanon to refrain from such violent responses and to avoid any actions which will raise further tensions in Lebanon, and in particular any action which will see a resumption of fighting with the attendant horrifying loss of life and destruction of property which has plagued Lebanon for the last 14 years.

About the only encouragement to be derived in this depressing and distressing situation in Lebanon comes from reports that members of the Lebanese Parliament have been called to meet to elect a new President. We simply hope that that will occur and that some normality can be restored to the situation. Finally, we urge all parties to support a continuation of the process agreed to at Ta'if and to cooperate with the new President in achieving the objective of national reconciliation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women aware that, under current social security legislation, a male who is entitled to an age pension is able to claim, as a dependent spouse, a female of any age while a woman who is entitled to an age pension is not able to claim her husband as a dependent spouse if he is below pensionable age? I ask the Minister whether it is correct that, as a letter signed by an officer of the Department of Social Security stated:

QUESTION.PARA: The . . . anomalies stem back to the traditional concept of the male being the sole provider, whereas nowadays the trend of male/female equality is to the fore. Unfortunately, Social Security legislation as set down for payment of pensions has not caught up with the modern trends.

Does the Minister consider that this is an appropriate situation to continue? If she does, could she explain why? If she does not, can she say what action the Government intends to take to rectify the matter and when the anomaly is likely to be removed?

TALK.START.PARA: —There is absolutely no doubt that I am aware of the situation to which Senator Haines has alluded. The details of the response, however, rest with my parliamentary colleague Senator Bolkus, and I ask him to take up that question.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Given that this is one example of legislation that completely discriminates against women and, in particular, women over pensionable age, I would have thought that the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women would have been the appropriate person to have knowledge of this matter and to be taking some action in regard to it. I repeat the last part of my question: What action will the Minister take to get the Government to rectify this situation and for how long do we have to wait for that action?

—It is an issue of which I have been aware and about which I have had discussions. As has been said before in this place, there are ministerial arrangements that are absolutely appropriate and I ask Senator Bolkus to take up the details.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Consumer Affairs been drawn to comments by a Department of Social Security social worker who claims that between 15 and 20 per cent of Australians receiving social security benefits suffer from literacy problems? Is the Minister aware that that departmental officer also expressed concern at the number of people who were eligible for benefits but were not claiming them because of their inability to comprehend the language of departmental forms? Will the Minister take steps to ensure that the problems of illiteracy will not in any way hinder or prejudice the rights and opportunities of individuals to receive maximum entitlements and assistance from the social security system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to answer two questions at this stage. I will pursue with the Minister for Social Security the matter raised by Senator Haines in her question and get back to her with a detailed answer.
—So you don't know, either? He is jumping to his feet to say he didn't know.

—I point out for the benefit of Senator Hill that the matter raised by Senator Colston in his question has been of concern to the Government. Judging by the jovial look on Senator Hill's face, he probably has not thought about this problem that people in the community have in terms of barriers to participation in and access to government programs and, particularly in this case, social security programs.

ANSWER.PARA: The recent press reports to which Senator Colston referred concern a study conducted by the Department of Social Security into ways in which that Department can better communicate with people who have literacy difficulties. The study has been addressing those problems. The main aim of the study is to fit in very much with the policy objectives of the Department and the Government in addressing this question of barriers to participation, in this case poor literacy skills as well as barriers because of language skills.

The two questions that the Government is addressing are, first, to find out whether many people are missing out on their entitlements because of poor literacy skills and, secondly, how the Government can address and redress that barrier. One approach adopted by the Government is investigation of the development of symbols to help people with literacy problems to find their way through the social security system. As I said, this matter is under examination and this study is part of that examination.

The Government has recognised that literacy and language problems can be a barrier and, to that extent, over recent years we have implemented programs to try to address these particular problems. Basically there has been a five-pronged response by the Government which is geared towards eradicating barriers because of literacy and language based problems.

In the first instance, staff training packages relating to both client contact and client awareness include issues associated with clients who do have literacy problems. Second, a major area that the Government has addressed is those who have poor English language skills and, to that extent, the telephone interpreter program which was introduced in January this year has already assisted 40,000 Australians by way of direct contact with them and helping them through the social security system. The third aspect is to use new technology. The Government has used this technology to simplify and improve access and to address communications in plain English language. The fourth part is the special awareness programs that have been conducted from time to time. A recent one which has been quite successful was the program geared towards family allowance supplements and particularly the television campaign to ensure that people have access to their rights and benefits. Lastly, special attention has been given to Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders who have been assisted through a special interpreter service in their parts of Australia.

The Government is concerned that literacy and language barriers do not stop people from having access to government services. The study to which Senator Colston referred is geared towards building on, first, the recognition of the problem and, second, our actions so far, and it is very much part of the Government's intention to address questions of barriers to participation in the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In the light of the Government's typical `send it to a committee' approach to the major recommendations of the Garnaut report, will the Minister tell the Senate the Government's timetable on the report? In other words when, if ever, will the Government announce some firm decisions? Will the Minister give the Senate an assurance that the key changes urged by this report will not simply be added to Senator Walsh's famous list of 200 programs about which nothing will be done because, to quote the Minister for Finance, `we don't have the political courage to do so'?

—Senator Lewis has the unhappy knack of leading with his chin. The Garnaut report was published two days ago. Senator Lewis is part of the active team on the Opposition benches who leap to their feet and take immediate action in response to everything. With his great record, he asks when the Government will respond with firm decisions. As I have said on numerous occasions, the Government will respond at an appropriate time. I do not want to remind Senator Lewis of this but, in regard to some of the key recommendations of the Garnaut report, when Senator Lewis's Party was in government--
—Get on with it. It is seven years ago.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lewis says it was a long time ago. Last week the Liberal Party was described by an economic commentator in the Sydney Morning Herald as being a spineless party, a party with a spineless response to the economic issues facing this country today. That is how it was described. That description was applied to the contemporary Liberal Party. Look at the shadow Minister responsible for the transition to government. From whom is he getting his advice at the present time? Sir Henry Bolte! Does anybody remember Sir Henry Bolte? One man who does remember him is Jeff Kennett, the former Liberal leader in Victoria. He got advice from Sir Henry Bolte prior to three elections and look what happened to Jeff Kennett. Look where Jeff Kennett is today. That is where Senator Lewis will finish up.

ANSWER.PARA: To come back to my point, the present Government has a big structural adjustment task. In the late 1980s and the 1990s in this country there is a big structural adjustment task for any government. The reason there is such a big structural adjustment task is that, on the key recommendations of the Garnaut report, the Opposition did nothing throughout the 1970s.
Senator Chaney interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry, Senator Chaney, I beat your interjection. In 1977 the Liberal Party received a report from the Industries Assistance Commission recommending a general reduction in tariffs, but the Liberal Party ran right away from it. John Howard was then the Minister filling my shoes and he ran right away from that report and rejected it. The Opposition talks about subsidies to Kodak, but during the same period John Howard provided temporary assistance--

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. Standing Orders require that Ministers answer the questions that are put to them. This Minister is talking about the history of the politics in this country without relevance to the question that has been put to him, and I ask that you, Mr President, bring him to order and that he answer the question.
—Order! There is no point of order, but we would get a much better answer if there were fewer interjections.

—The simple point is that this country faces an enormous structural adjustment task now because in nearly 30 years of Liberal-National Party government in this country-and particularly in the last seven years of the Fraser Government-that Government did nothing about any of these issues. Since the beginning of the 1970s there has been a 65 per cent reduction in tariffs in this country and not one percentage point of it was accomplished by a conservative government. Senator Lewis gets up in this chamber and asks when this Government will act on the Garnaut report which was published two days ago. I ask: what is the honourable senator's credibility in any of this? This is why this country is in a mess at the present time.
—After seven years the country is in a mess.

—Senator Puplick must not get too excited. I am simply making the point that Senator Lewis asked me a question that is essentially about structural adjustment and my rhetorical question to him is: what is his credibility on any of these issues? Throughout the 1960s, 1970s and even last week in the publication of the Liberal Party's Fosters family package, the Liberal Party has been described as a spineless political party.
—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Is the Minister telling the Senate that he is satisfied with the pace of reforms under his Government?
—No, I did not say that.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SOUTH-EASTERN NEW SOUTH WALES FORESTS: PEACE PLAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Resources received details of the peace plan which the Australian Business for the Environment group and the South-East Forest Alliance are said to have drawn up for the timber industry in the Eden region of New South Wales? If he has, can he inform honourable senators whether or not it contains positive and constructive ways to end confrontation in the region? Does it have the capacity to assist the Commonwealth Government's own plans for timber industry development in the region? Can the Minister inform honourable senators what progress has been made with these plans and, in particular, its plantation development, better utilisation of forest resources and other industry development programs for the region?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have now obtained for myself a copy of the peace plan for the south-east forests and I say at the outset that I welcome any contribution by any group to work constructively to try to resolve what is clearly a matter of community controversy in the south-east. In that light I am pleased to look at the peace plan. I should say, though, that officially I have not received a copy and no letter has been written to me enclosing the plan. I was not consulted about it prior to its being drawn up. No request has been made of me to meet and discuss it, and no forum has been suggested to thrash out a peace settlement because of it.

ANSWER.PARA: That being said, I did obtain a copy through one of my staff and I can say of the plan that, if imitation is the sincerest form of flattery, then to a large extent the Government is flattered by the content of this plan. Many of the proposals in the plan go to how better to utilise the existing forest resource, how to add to the forest resource by the use of commercially viable plantations, how to add value to the product of the forest as well and how to offer long and enduring employment for people employed in the timber industry in New South Wales.

Those objectives mesh with the studies that I have commissioned into the flora and fauna properties of the south-east forest, the flitchmill study that I referred to yesterday to extract maximum sawmillable material from logs, no matter what the condition of those logs, the study on the better use of small and round wood-wood that is normally regarded as waste material in the forest-the study on the value added to the sawmill product that comes out of sawmills and the plantation study that I announced yesterday. Many of the aspects of the report deal with those elements. Therefore, I find nothing at all offensive and a lot to compliment the report about because of the objectives it expresses in that sense.

However, one of the problems that I apprehend about the peace plan is that it argues for an effective cessation of cutting in National Estate areas and I do not believe it would be possible to obtain a balanced outcome in the south-east forest if that condition were implemented. I say that for the reason that the Australian Heritage Commission makes decisions on what forest is to be regarded as National Estate and what is not, and it does so on heritage properties of the forest and not on economic criteria. I do not wish to interfere with the heritage evaluation of the Australian Heritage Commission, but simply because a forest is declared as one for the National Estate, does not mean to say-when one balances objectively the competing demands for that forest-that the heritage value-if there are no prudent and feasible alternatives to finding other resources-ought to be the predominant value. Those questions are to be examined exhaustively.

The final point I make is that of recent days, in a form of shuttle diplomacy between conservation and industry groups, I have been endeavouring to put in place the missing last piece of the jigsaw, a community consultative group in which unions, industry, conservation groups and the community in the south-east forest area can sit together and try to work through what are admittedly thorny difficulties about resolving conflict there and to do so in such a way as to reach some agreement that is enduring. I find that I have now been mired down in definitional questions of what the terms of reference of a group might be and, therefore, I will now be embarking upon a proposal that I will discuss with various interest groups by simply calling a meeting of all of them and putting on the agenda for that meeting for discussion, not a terms of reference issue at all, but the reports from various consultancies that I have commissioned and the interim report of the flora and fauna study which is due on 11 December. I would add to that list-if it is the wish of the conservation movement-the proposed peace plan and invite industry, unions or the community to include any proposals that they wish to put forward to include them. Without terms of reference we could simply embark upon a seriatim discussion of those issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I ask: does the Minister agree that the decision to subsidise the operations of Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd in Australia is in direct conflict with the Garnaut report's call for much greater internationalisation of the Australian economy? Therefore, will the Government refrain from legislation to authorise the handover of $36m of taxpayers' funds to this multinational company?

—First of all, let me say that I would not get too excited with populist jargon about multinational companies. We have many of them in this country and a lot of them are very good corporate citizens for Australia. I am surprised that somebody of Senator Short's perspicacity should fall into that particular trap. As to whether the decision to subsidise the operations of Kodak is in conflict with the Garnaut report-the answer is no; the Garnaut report said nothing about that issue.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Local Government. Recent press articles have pointed out that some local authorities are considering hiring out equipment and other council resources to maximise the use of these resources and as a means of increasing revenue. Can the Minister indicate whether, in her opinion, this is an appropriate use of council resources?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to Senator Child's question, I would have to say that it is local government's responsibility to determine what is appropriate use of resources. The circumstances will vary from place to place. Councils are being encouraged to develop more effective management skills and techniques for assessing the most efficient arrangements for the management of their human and capital resources. Councils are getting involved in a range of entrepreneurial activities. They are also getting involved in using means such as tendering for contracts in areas such as land development, construction material haulage, hiring out under-utilised resources or pooling of resources, services and equipment between councils; others are taking on entrepreneurial activities such as the construction of office buildings. They are adding valuable revenue to their operations. Councils that get involved in such activities should ensure that they have the best possible advice. Through our local government development program we have funded a number of projects to ensure that local councils are familiar with the pitfalls that could come about from moving into an entrepreneurial area where they do not have the necessary expertise.

ANSWER.PARA: To come to the specific area of Senator Childs's question, the press article stated that Bankstown City Council was considering a unique plan to hire out idle plant and equipment and staff to maximise the use of these resources and so increase revenue. I comment that it really is not a unique proposal. Councils have been involved in this type of activity for some time, particularly in the more remote areas of Australia. For instance, the Hay shire is sharing resources in the road construction and maintenance area, which has led to significant savings. Bombala Shire Council operates a number of quarries supplying aggregate and other road-base materials to users such as other councils and road construction authorities. In addition, the council also hires out plant and equipment on a fee-for-service basis.

In Tasmania, the Bruny Island municipality is actually an agent for the State Government. I know that Senator Bjelke-Petersen and others will be familiar with the fact that, similarly, that occurs in Queensland, as I am sure it does in a number of other States. One has to remember that in many parts of Australia councils are the only bodies that have, in particular, the capital resources for undertaking some of the specialised work under consideration.

So I think my answer to Senator Childs would be yes, it is appropriate, but it is important that councils get the best possible advice and learn from those councils that have already been involved in entrepreneurial activities so that they undertake such entry in a way that is appropriate and does not become a misuse of ratepayers' dollars.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I refer the Minister to reports early last month that two loads of Californian strawberries imported into Australia in August were infected with exotic virus-carrying insects and escaped quarantine detection and that the insects were not detected until routine testing for pesticides by a Queensland Department of Primary Industries entomologist, who discovered that they were rife with live thrips, bugs and mites. As the thrip, if unchecked, is capable of causing immense viral damage, not only to Australia's $280m tomato industry but also to potatoes, eggplants and other similar crops, what action has the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service taken to ensure that insects in the next such shipment from the United States, due in May, do not go undetected and survive fumigation? What guarantees can the inspection service give the rural community that its ability to protect horticultural producers from potential disasters is not in doubt?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can inform Senator Bjelke-Petersen that the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service is very efficient in guaranteeing that the importation of produce into Australia is done at minimum risk to the Australian farming, agricultural and, in this case, horticultural communities. I might say I am becoming somewhat agitated at the fact that there is developing in this country a debate which is really about the fact that Australia is advocating free trade in the world and is setting itself up as an example of free trade. There is a debate from some producers who fear the impact of competition on their particular commodity because of an opening in the Australian market and who are using argument about the effectiveness of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service to mask their real concern. Thus, they are attacking the efficiency and standards of the inspection service when their real beef is facing a wider degree of competition than they would normally face domestically.

ANSWER.PARA: Having said that, I can go to the question of Californian strawberries. During August of this year two lots of Californian strawberries were purchased by the Queensland strawberry growers at Flemington markets after they had been released from quarantine. Some insects-a maximum of three per fruit-were found under sepals, which are the leafy petals at the base of the fruit, and included western flower thrips, which have not been recorded in Australia before. As a consequence, the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service suspended imports of strawberries from all sources on 13 October and reviewed the inspection and treatment procedures. Since then approval has been given to import strawberries from New Zealand, subject to stringent inspection and treatment requirements. Insects are thought to have survived because not enough fumigant penetrated to insects under the sepals. However, these insects may have died before completing their development.

Industry and the press have suggested that, because of the damage it can cause and because of its ability to transmit viral diseases, there would be significant economic consequences to horticulture if western flower thrip became established. Their claims can be considered as sensationalist and, in most instances, erroneous. Thrips are plant pests but they are not as devastating as has been suggested. There are already species of thrips present in Australia attacking crops that western flower thrips might infest. Consequently, there may be little additional cost associated with control. Although present in New Zealand, this species is not considered a serious pest of any cultivated crop and has never been found infesting strawberries. Western flower thrip is a vector of tomato spotted wilt virus, which is distributed widely in Australia and transmitted by thrips that are established here. No new strains of the virus are likely to be imported with introduced thrips.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. Is the Minister aware of the British Government's attempt to privatise the Central Electricity Generating Board of Great Britain? Is he aware that the Government has been unable to sell Britain's nuclear power stations because banks and financial institutions have judged that the cost of decommissioning nuclear power stations will exceed their lifetime economic benefit? Is he aware that the present Energy Secretary of the United Kingdom Government, Mr John Wakeham, has admitted that past administrations had made false claims regarding the economic viability of nuclear electricity? Do these recent revelations alter his perception. or that of his Government, of Australia's role as a supplier of uranium to the nuclear industry? Do they not cast doubt on the viability of uranium mining in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of that debate. In February this year I met with the then United Kingdom Secretary of State for Energy, Cecil Parkinson, and discussed with him at some length the details of the proposed privatisation of the Central Electricity Generating Board in the United Kingdom. I note that since that time he has been replaced by John Wakeham.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the second part of the honourable senator's question, it may be the case that financial institutions or banks have had something to do with the British Government's decision to withhold from privatisation the nuclear facilities, but I understood that the primary reason was that the magnox series of nuclear power generator had come to the end of its commissioned life cycle and the cost of decommissioning was considerably higher than anticipated. In fact, it had not yet been quantified. For that reason, the British Government-and, as I say, the banks may have had an influential role in this matter, but I am not aware of it-decided not to privatise its nuclear power generating facilities.

The third part of the honourable senator's question related to the current Secretary of State for Energy, John Wakeham, and various false claims. The debate about privatisation of energy provision in the United Kingdom has been a very hot debate which, in terms of the assessments made, depends on different variables from time to time, such as the level of interest rates and costs. Various estimates have been associated with things of that nature. It seems that, on recent evidence, there is some credibility to suggestions that the cost of nuclear power generation is three times the cost of coal fired power generation, if one includes in the equation the likely decommissioning costs of the existing nuclear power generators. For that reason, these considerations must be taken into account.

Having said that of the British nuclear power generating capacity, I should also say that it appears-and I do not have absolute figures on this point, but it is as a result of information and evidence-that the French, Japanese and German nuclear power generating facilities are more efficient than those of the British and the cost equation that applies in Britain in relation to nuclear versus coal probably does not apply in those other countries. I think that the honourable senator's question raises an interesting point which Senator Richardson has placed on the agenda for debate in Australia; that is, if it is true that nuclear power generating is more costly, in a greenhouse conscious world is that a cost the community would be prepared to pay for the prevention of emission of greenhouse gases through coal fired power generation? I think that in the past Senator Richardson has had something to say about this matter and, in terms of an environmental question, it is a moot point and one that deserves debate.

As to the final part of the honourable senator's question about Australian uranium, we are a cost efficient and low cost supplier of uranium. It is for individual countries to make up their mind as to their energy mix and we should not editorialise to them on this matter. I believe that the market will decide whether the Australian mining industry is viable. That matter should not be decided by Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister investigate my implicit assertion that it is the case that the British Government has failed to sell its nuclear power stations because the banks and financial institutions have simply refused to provide financial assistance to those companies that might have bought those nuclear power stations and, indeed, that, as a consequence, the British Government has had to recreate an electricity generating facility which will be totally government owned and will own the nuclear power stations? Finally, if it is true that that is the position with respect to the economic efficiency of nuclear power, does the Minister not consider that the Australian Government should play a role in determining whether we do or do not open further nuclear facilities, particularly uranium mines, in Australia?

—I have an interest in the general debate on this matter and, as the honourable senator has raised a question of which I was not aware-and I refer to his assertion about the banks and financial institutions-I will investigate that aspect. However, I do not think that, as Minister for Resources, I am under any obligation to reply on that basis, but I will share the information with the honourable senator. As far as the opening of nuclear facilities in Australia is concerned, the Australian Government's policy is clear. We do not propose to support nuclear power generation. The Australian Labor Party is currently reviewing its policy on uranium mining.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Has the Minister noted that the Ambassador to Ireland, Mr Brian Burke, who is at present visiting Perth, has intervened in domestic politics in Western Australia by sending a note to the current Premier denying having attempted to delay a corporate affairs inquiry into one of the many business disasters which have marked Labor's term in office? In light of Mr Burke's intimate involvement in a series of serious abuses of government in Western Australia, will the Minister ensure that the Ambassador does not return to Dublin until his role in the Swan Building Society affair and the other failed business dealings initiated by his Government can be properly investigated?

—I will do nothing of the kind, Mr President. This question does not bear in any way on the conduct of Mr Burke's duties as Ambassador to Ireland, which he has been performing with admirable competence. We have had nothing but a tirade of scuttlebutt and innuendo from Senator Chaney, of which he should be ashamed.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Does the Minister have any knowledge at all of the concerns which are widespread in Western Australia about matters such as the Swan Building Society affair, the contretemps involving the police force, which is no doubt well known to his colleague Senator Tate, and the general concerns about the loss of $175m of taxpayers' money in a deal which was intended to bail out the Government from the Burke Government's $150m guarantee of the National Australia Bank Ltd debt? Is it a fact that the Ambassador, who represents this country, has had to address a series of matters raised during that period? Is that consistent with his duty to Australia as an ambassador? Why will the Minister not consider the public interest and the requirement to ensure that these matters are dealt with in a proper way?
—I am aware that a number of squalid partisan allegations have been made about Mr Burke in this respect and I am sure that his shoulders are big enough to deal with them.

—My question is also directed to Senator Evans in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. Is the Minister aware of yet another exploding crisis in the broadcasting arena, namely, the fact that Imparja Television Pty Ltd, the Central Australian remote commercial television service, has not made any payments on its own account in respect of leasing costs for its Aussat transponder since June last year? Is it a fact that similar 30-watt transponders are available internationally for about $500,000 and the Indonesian Palapa satellite is currently available for $700,000, yet Aussat's going rate is $4.2m per year, due entirely to its crippling debt burden, which is a direct result of the Government's refusal to allow Aussat to earn a decent living in competition with Telecom Australia's massive monopoly? Is the Government aware that more than four months ago Mr Willis said on an Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio program that the Government had received an auditor's report on Imparja and that it would be necessary to make a decision `in the very near future'? In view of the fact that the South Australian Government continues to welsh on its firm commitment to make funds available because it is allegedly waiting for Mr Willis to do something, can the Minister explain how much longer this latest intolerable example of ministerial incompetence will be allowed to continue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is fully conscious of and is sympathetic to the economic difficulties which are currently faced by remote commercial television service (RCTS) operators, including the particular circumstances of Imparja. To describe those circumstances and difficulties as constituting an exploding financial crisis, however, is a bit of vulgar rhetorical overkill of the kind that we have come to expect from Senator Alston. The Minister, Mr Willis, met with Imparja representatives this morning. He had wide-ranging discussions on the future options for Imparja and its financial position. The options for providing additional commercial television services to the Northern Territory, South Australia and those parts of New South Wales and Victoria not included in the present equalisation plan were discussed, including a possible role for Imparja in this respect.

ANSWER.PARA: A departmental discussion paper reviewing RCTS is expected to be released shortly for public comment. The governments in Queensland, Western Australia, the Northern Territory and South Australia will be consulted. The Northern Territory Government, with which I would have thought the Opposition might have had some affinity, is known to be very strongly supportive of Imparja's continuance in this respect. The Government will address Imparja's situation generally in the context of the RCTS review, which is scheduled to take place early next year. The Hawke Government is, of course, responsible for establishing the RCTS services. It was a major initiative to give remote people their first commercial television services. I remind Senator Alston and the Senate that the Government was also responsible for giving Australian Broadcasting Corporation television and radio to remote areas.

It is the case that providing remote broadcasting services is economically difficult due to the high cost of satellite transponders and small fragmented populations. That is an endemic phenomenon of which we are all aware. It is not a new discovery of Senator Alston's. The Government is committed to doing everything possible to meet the communications needs of remote communities. We commend Imparja for the very high quality service it provides for Central Australia, and all available options to deal with this situation will be considered to ensure the continuation of the remote broadcasting services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This morning we had the opportunity in the consideration of appropriations to look at the programs relating to the purchasing and sales policies of the Government as administered by the Department of Administrative Services. As I pointed out in the debate this morning, the expansion of the Commonwealth Government into the field of retail sales should cause major concern to everyone, particularly those people living in remote and regional parts of Australia. This policy document which has been tabled today entitled Commonwealth Procurement Policy also has the words at the top of the first page `Better Buying', `Purchasing Reform Group' and `Service is Our Business'. Obviously, the `perestroikaing' of the Hawke Labor Government is now choosing to move into so many other areas of activity that are normally the prerogative of small business. This Government has been well known for so long as one that seeks to interfere and centralise all its activities.

Looking briefly at the various headings within this report relating to the purchasing principles, one sees the headings `Open and Effective Competition'; `Ethical Behaviour and Fair Dealing'; `Planning Procurement'; `Professionalism'; `Common-use Purchasing Arrangements'; `Other Centralised Purchasing Arrangements'; and `Related Government Policies'. There is then a series of headings relating to `National Preference Agreement'; `Offsets'; `Partnerships for Development'; `Consideration of Community Groups'; and `Administrative Responsibilities'.

The point concerning me is that the Commonwealth Government is choosing to use its period contract for purchasing and expanding not only these facilities to various government departments, et cetera, but is now basically providing a facility for any agency which receives Commonwealth Government funding, in effect, to get onto the Government nipple of government purchasing contracts. This is going to have a very significant impact and import in regional and remote parts of Australia. It is not just going to result in better prices for organisations, but because of the additional surcharges and the range in which it will impact, particularly in the small communities of outback Australia, there will be serious consequences to small business and to so many areas of traditional operation.

In a letter from the Department of Administrative Services to various agencies of the Commonwealth-and I use that word `agencies' in the very broad sense-it is interesting to note that the Department is touting for business in the areas of vehicles of all types, office furniture and equipment, personal computers, domestic furniture, refrigerators, washing machines, room air- conditioners, office requisites and fresh, frozen and tinned foodstuffs. So it is quite easy to see that the Commonwealth Government is now seeking not just to be a provider of services that are so traditional but also to enter the open marketplace with what is already being adequately and properly provided by many important pioneering businesses throughout the remote and regional parts of Australia.

The major changes to government purchasing were certainly flagged in a press release from the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr West, on 23 November 1988. It is only recently that the Department has chosen to become aggressive in this particular area. As I mentioned, certainly in the Northern Territory, it has come to my attention that traders are now beginning to feel and see the consequences of these financial changes. Whether it is the supply of spare parts in the motor vehicle industry or in office supplies and other areas, business is certainly going to be affected. I know that the Northern Territory Confederation of Industry, the Small Business Association and the Motor Traders Association of the Northern Territory have all expressed major concern, and certainly they have been given fobbed-off answers by the Federal member for the Northern Territory, Mr Warren Snowdon. This report has major consequences for small business throughout Australia, particularly if the Northern Territory is an example.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: -I would like to make some comments regarding the paper entitled Commonwealth Procurement Policy: Better Buying. It was by chance that this morning I heard my colleague Senator Tambling mention this particular issue during the appropriations debate. When I heard him I felt that he must have had it wrong. I did not believe that anyone in his right senses could actually do to small business what this Government is trying to do with this Commonwealth procurement policy. In essence, what this policy will do is close many country and regional towns down. It will be devastating to small business. It shows no thought whatsoever and shows that this Government has no understanding of or feeling for small business.

SPEECH.PARA: In the letter that the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) has put out, he points out that more than 3,000 government employees work in purchasing and related activities to get the best prices. Three thousand public servants, funded by the taxpayers of Australia, have set out to compete against private enterprise in Australia, using $8 billion of purchasing power against the individual traders of this nation. This is a most serious and devastating policy. It is going to have the most serious consequences for small business. This Government has got to withdraw this policy and examine what in effect will happen if people can purchase cars, hardware and food from a central office controlled by government paid public servants, bypassing the retail traders, the chains of distribution set up throughout this nation. It is now feasible for any government funded or semi-government department, local government or any organisation funded by any government department to bypass the petrol stations, service stations, food industry distribution points and motor vehicle distribution points and buy from a centrally located place in Brisbane, Melbourne or Sydney.

This Government has to understand what will happen to those small towns. The Red Cross, the Blue Nursing Service, kindergartens, schools, local government departments, boy scouts and so on would be able to avoid purchasing through the normal points of sale. I challenge Mr Barry Jones, the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, to stand up for small business and to re-examine the Commonwealth procurement policy and the effects that it will have on all small business people in Australia. If Mr Jones is not prepared to re-examine this policy and take it back to Cabinet, he does not deserve to represent the small business people of Australia. Small business people pay about 60 per cent of the tax paid by this nation and they provide most of the jobs. The policy is another example of the Government's absolute lack of understanding of what the small business community provides for this nation and it is just not good enough. The policy has to be re-examined. I challenge Mr Jones to take it back to Cabinet and make a special representation on behalf of the small business community of Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

Looking at the Affirmative Action Agency's annual report for 1988-89, one should recognise first of all that this is the mechanism whereby private enterprise reports annually to the Agency on its implementation of affirmative action provisions. This was the first year of reporting for firms which employ 500 to 999 staff. One of the interesting points in the report concerned the difficulties which the Agency has had in identifying those firms which fall within that category. Obviously that area will require greater attention.

I was also interested to note the surprise that the Agency showed as to the low compliance level of the consultation requirement with the trade union movement. I would have thought that the Agency would have realised by now that there is very low trade union movement coverage in private enterprise firms. As a result, it is not at all surprising that many firms answered that the requirement was not applicable to them. Certainly this will become more evident as more and more people in the public sector are covered by unions and more and more people in the private sector drop out, for quite obvious reasons.

One of the things that disturb me in the report is the fact that a number of firms appear to have difficulty recognising that the purpose of the legislation is not only to deal with direct discrimination but also to deal with indirect discrimination. It appears that the reporting firms have a lack of understanding as to what exactly they should be looking for and dealing with in trying to prevent indirect discrimination, such as the requirement of so many people that in order to get a job people must have experience. But in order to get experience they have to be eligible for jobs along the way. In the defence forces, which do not come under this legislation, women often cannot get experience in a job. They are denied the opportunity for the prerequisite which goes to promotion later on. The same thing happens in private enterprise.

I am glad to see that the Agency has had some extra staff and will get a few more this financial year. One of our continuing concerns in the Opposition is that the Agency is not fulfilling the role which we believe was its main purpose-that is, to evaluate the mechanisms which have been put in place in the private enterprise world for removing all forms of discrimination. Currently it has developed an evaluation plan, but it has not yet moved beyond a numerical evaluation into a qualitative one. That is very important. At present the Agency is doing a compliance audit, which is a desk audit. Its second strategy is process evaluations, which is pretty vaguely worded. The third strategy on page 48 entitled `Evaluation Projects' reads:
. . . affirmative action programs will be evaluated to provide better information about the factors which help or inhibit the development of effective programs.

They have not started yet. The effectiveness review, which is the fourth strategy, will not take place until 1992. So that also is down the track. We are looking at a body which is still in the process of getting established after three years. I would have hoped that we would have been getting more evaluation by now. We in the Opposition support the principle of affirmative action and we have been watching the Agency's progress with interest.

I find it curious that, in an organisation of 18 people of whom 15 are described as women, it says that it has to appoint a sexual harassment contact officer and is having a policy on sexual harassment distributed to all staff. I presume that the three members who are not described by sex must be male.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are in great danger. That's what it is.
—Perhaps that is the way one should read it. As women make up 83 per cent of the staff. I am not quite sure who is harassing who. I wish them well and I hope they solve the problem soon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to rise to support Senator Newman's comments on the Affirmative Action Agency's annual report for 1988-89. My concerns with the report arise from some of the things written and they are based on the experience that I had when I represented the Opposition on the working party that sought to establish some of the mechanisms before the appropriate legislation was passed. The view I took then on behalf of the Opposition was that, if we were to have the legislation and the Opposition had a view on it, it might as well work. We fought for and obtained certain provisions, including the provision of appropriate and not too onerous sanctions for those companies which did not comply with the provisions of the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that the higher education sector has complied, although a large part of that sector was late in reporting. I also note that more than half the companies that were due to report both in band 1 and in band 2-depending on the size of the company-reported late. Further, I note the concern of the Agency that a number of companies seem not to understand the provisions of the legislation. Since it is merit-based, it is very important that adequate information be given to employers to enable them to understand what the legislation is about. Senator Newman has indicated some of her concerns.

If we look at the actions taken by the Agency, pursuant to the provisions of the legislation, to follow up the backsliders-the companies that were not reporting-we find that between 14 and 16 August the Director of Affirmative Action sent a letter to 40 employers, 21 from band 1 and 19 from band 2, who had still not lodged a report which, at that stage, was quite late. She advised them of her intention to name them if a report was not forthcoming. At the end of the day, after companies had done various things-some had responded; some had demonstrated that their employee numbers were not in excess of 500, so they were not covered, which is possible; one indicated that it had already reported under a different name, probably as part of a group, and that was all right; five companies subsequently provided sufficient information as to cause the Director to exercise her discretion not to name them-eight companies were required under the law to report and although they were invited by the Director to submit one they did not do so. They were then warned by the Director that she would name them but they still did not report. One has to ask: Why is this? The fact is that I may not like all the laws which operate in this country but if there is a law and it affects my operation I believe that I, as a member of a party that believes in the rule of law, have to comply with that legislation. I note the names of the eight companies. I hope that we will not see those names again next year, but I note that one of the companies has now been named in the Parliament for the second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which one is that?

—I will name that company. It is Suttons Investments Pty Ltd. I have no idea where it is located. I am concerned, however, that Tandy Australia Ltd, which is a big electronics firm, is also named as not having performed its duty under the appropriate legislation. There are six other companies.

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned that the Director should now take action to contact each of those eight companies to find out what is going on. Is it an ideological refusal to take part or is there a simpler explanation? Is it that the companies do not understand, or that they believe that the provisions are onerous, that they need more explanation about the merit basis of the legislation? The 40 companies that were late in complying with the legislation all provide a prime target for quite pro-active intervention now by the Director on behalf of the Agency. I will look very carefully at next year's report; I hope that I will not see there the names of those same eight companies. In any event, I would like the directors to tell in due course why their names are there and why they have refused to do their part in responding to their obligations under the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too address some remarks to the annual report of the Affirmative Action Agency and welcome that report. I commend the Director, Valerie Pratt, and the media for reports which have come out subsequent to yesterday's tabling in the other place. Picking up the point on which Senator Peter Baume concluded, the Australian Democrats believe and have believed since the outset of the affirmative action legislation and during the time of its drafting that the sanction issue is one which we have not yet met squarely. It is a difficult one, as Senator Baume outlined, and perhaps it is underlined by the fact that Suttons Investments Pty Ltd has now been mentioned a second time. For the information of Senator Baume and other people, Suttons is an investment company but also a car dealer and is in Sydney. I specify that here because, as many of the media reports have suggested, there may very well be further sanctions beyond its being named in Parliament. Other such sanctions include what have been termed boycotts, but what might more relevantly be called `girlcotts'. They also include other public expressions of dissatisfaction with non-compliance with the legislation. That is the type of sanction which can be carried out.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not up to just the Director of the Agency to pursue those companies. It is up to people in the community to express their concern. I for one will not be buying my Christmas presents at Tandy this year, whereas I might very well have done so, given that I have two young teenage boys who can hardly tear themselves away from Tandy whenever we go shopping. I will certainly discourage them and my purse will not be opened there, and so on down the line. It raises the question of the attitudes of the business sector to the Agency, to this legislation, when we see one company named two years in a row; when we see the extraordinary proportion-more than half, as Senator Baume said-of band 1 and 2 companies which have been late with reports; the lengths to which the Agency has had to go to pursue reports; and perhaps even the nature of some of the companies which have not complied in the end. Unfortunately, there is still a lot of evidence that in the business sector attitudes to women's employment and to women in general are still not good. I refer to a Bulletin article some time ago which addressed the question of women's representation on the boards of management of companies. The Bulletin did a phone-around. When it asked someone at Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd whether it had any women on its board, the answer was, `God, no!'. When Telecom was asked the same question, the answer was, `What? Do you mean the switchboard?'. Those sorts of attitudes still prevail in the corporate world. It is a big challenge for the Affirmative Action Agency and for all of us to change those attitudes.

South Terrace Real Estate Pty Ltd has been named. That company operates the Jewel food stores. A press report points out that the Chairman of South Terrace said that over half the staff were women and that women were employed in all areas, including management, buying and security. He claimed that the company had conformed, but that the Agency had required the information from the parent company and that it had not complied because it was a only a small company which had only two employees and therefore did not bother. It is that hairy-chested attitude that we see in business that is thumbing its nose at this Agency. I call upon women and others concerned for genuine equal opportunity in this country to take the sanctions beyond the Parliament. I remind the Senate too that affirmative action is not quotas. I point to the glossary of the report which points out that we have also had affirmative action for men; land grants for returned servicemen is the example given. It is not a quota system and we should not ever have to hear any more of that sort of garbage in this place in relation to the legislation. I wish the Agency well; I do not wish the eight companies named a particularly good year this year.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I take the opportunity to comment on the annual report of the Australian Manufacturing Council. Its major project is the industry development project which is known under the title, `The Global Challenge: Australian Manufacturing in the 1990s'. The aim of the project is to develop a vision for the manufacturing industry for the 1990s.

Speaking recently at an Australian Manufacturing Council in Melbourne, Professor Bruce Scott from Harvard University categorised economies into three groups. The first group comprised outward looking economies which ideally have a realistic exchange rate, open markets with export subsidies and open or uncontrolled factor markets. Secondly, there are the producer-oriented economies which exhibit an undervalued currency and protected markets for their products with heavy emphasis on the promotion of manufacturing and subsidisation of producers by consumers. Professor Scott placed Japan and Korea in these categories.

The third category, the one in which Australia was grouped, was made up of inward looking economies. Typically, inward looking economies exhibit an overvalued currency and protect and control their factor markets. Factor markets include such items as labour, prices, interest rates and the like. Also typical of inward looking economies is their tendency to be resource dependent. However, the Australian Manufacturing Council suggests that our resource dependency could provide the answer to Australia's current record current account problems. While resources dominate our export trade, the bulk are exported in a raw state. This applies not only to our minerals, but also to wool, hides, cotton and woodchips.

Australia enjoys a comparative advantage with regard to these items. Therefore, the scope for boosting export revenue by the downstream processing of these resources is enormous. For example, in aluminium alone, exports are worth $5 billion, but this could be $15 billion if all bauxite and alumina were transformed to metal. Similarly, wood processed into pulp would earn four times more export revenue than it does as woodchips. Going the next step, wood processed into pulp would earn 10 times that revenue. Australian manufacturers need a vision, something to strive towards, a sign of hope, particularly in these bleak economic times. Therefore, I commend the work of the Australian Manufacturing Council, particularly in relation to global challenge projects.

Manufacturing in this country is facing enormous problems, especially in a regime of high interest rates. In those industries those companies that are highly geared are facing almost extinction. I would like to draw the Senate's attention to the current rumours that are circulating particularly in the textile, clothing and allied industries to the effect that 2,000 jobs are to be lost in the next four to six weeks, following a severe downturn in the industry because of the monetary policy pursued by this Government and the very high interest rates that are prevailing. I conclude by saying that high interest rates are killing industry, particularly manufacturing industry in this country.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
