DEBATE.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF THE PARLIAMENTARY REPORTING STAFF

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to section 9b (2) of the Public Service Act 1922, I present the annual report of the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff for the year ended 30 June 1989.

DEBATE.TITLE: REPORT OF THE PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO YUGOSLAVIA, CZECHOSLOVAKIA AND HUNGARY JUNE-JULY 1989

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I table the report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Yugoslavia, Czechoslovakia and Hungary from 18 June to 11 July 1989. I had the honour to lead the delegation that recently visited eastern Europe. I think it is significant that this report should be presented at a time when historic events are taking place throughout eastern Europe. The delegation was fortunate to have had the opportunity to visit eastern Europe at the time of the onset of the most significant political events in the region since the Second World War.

INTERJECT.PARA: The delegation's report contains a number of interesting insights that we gained into the sources and nature of the pressures for political and economic reform in Yugoslavia, Czechoslovakia and Hungary. The delegation met with heads of state, government Ministers and many senior officials of the Communist Party in each country. We also met with members of dissident and opposition groups. While the pressure for change was evident while we were there I am sure that none of us would have believed that within a few months the Berlin Wall would have been opened or that a quarter of a million people would be demonstrating in the streets of Prague. I do not believe that anyone anticipated the pace with which political reforms would sweep through eastern Europe.

It will now be important for the international community to provide practical support to those countries during the extremely difficult times ahead in adjusting to the new political and economic environment. When members of the delegation asked about the type of assistance that would be required, the Hungarian Minister for Trade told us, `We don't want fish; we want the net to catch the fish'. In that vein I was pleased to hear the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) announce on 15 October that a significant package of Australian assistance to Poland and Hungary will include not only food aid but also measures to assist those countries to improve their economic performance.

I take this opportunity to pay tribute to all members of the delegation who worked tirelessly throughout a long and demanding program. I also wish to thank the many people who were responsible for the organisation of the visit. I particularly acknowledge the assistance I received from the ambassadors of Yugoslavia, Czechoslovakia and Hungary in arranging the itinerary for the visit. I also take the opportunity to thank both the Usher of the Black Rod, Rob Alison, who was secretary to the delegation, and my former Principal Private Secretary, Rob Walsh, for their assistance during the delegation's visit. The task of the secretary to the delegation was particularly demanding, given the tight schedule. Mr Alison carried out his duties in a most admirable way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

I would just like to add some remarks to those that you, Mr President, have made in tabling the report of the delegation of which we were members and of which you were leader, to eastern Europe in June-July of this year. On a personal level I would like to congratulate you, Mr President, on the splendid job that you did in leading the delegation and in keeping it down to business at all times and for maintaining a very high level of morale throughout the whole of a very busy-I hesitate to say exacting because we enjoyed the visit so much-and useful trip. I also pay my respects and regards to the Usher of the Black Rod, Mr Alison, for the efforts that he had to make to keep the delegation members on time and in order. When we were in Europe we never lost anything, as far as I am aware. It was a very pleasant, informative and rewarding experience.

I rise because I want to refer particularly to Czechoslovakia. The report covers the visit to four countries-those mentioned in the report as well as Austria. We also had a useful time in that country. I want to refer to Czechoslovakia for several reasons. One is that I have had a special interest in Czechoslovakia since I first visited that country in 1950 when I was an observer to a student conference in Prague which was held just a bit over two years after the communist coup d'etat in February 1948. It was a matter of great interest to see the state of affairs in Czechoslovakia 40 years later, in 1989.

Another reason I want to refer to Czechoslovakia is that events have moved even more rapidly there than they have in the other countries we visited-perhaps not more rapidly than those in East Germany and Poland-since we were there. But, as the President has said, there have been very great developments just in the few months since our visit. In Czechoslovakia those developments are more striking than those in any of the other countries we visited.

I also want to mention one or two other matters that are not suitably mentioned in an official report but which I think might be of interest to the Senate. Firstly, I refer to the changes in Czechoslovakia that I was able to observe after nearly 40 years since I was there. There certainly had been an improvement in the general state of the economy and in the morale of the people. In 1950, two years after the coup d'etat, the people of Prague were still in a state of shock and despair. Prague was almost a ghost city. There was hardly any movement of traffic or of people around in the grand Wenceslas Square and other parts of what I think is probably the finest city in Europe. It was paralleled by the tragic atmosphere of the student conference, which spent a great deal of time passing resolutions praising Stalin and chanting his name, to the horror of the few of us from the West.

Certainly Prague had changed for the better on the physical level. There was a liveliness about the city. A great many tourists from the West were there and great improvements had been made to the city itself, particularly in the preservation of the old medieval city, which is still a very large part of Prague. The Government, much as we may be critical of it generally, certainly has done a very good job in preserving and improving the environment generally of the magnificent medieval city that Prague still is. So it was a very much greater pleasure to be able to move around the city and feel the improvement in the quality of life for people there. Clearly Czechoslovakia's food production had improved and, generally speaking, the economic circumstances in Czechoslovakia were better than in the other countries of eastern Europe, as far as we could see. I think that may be one reason why Czechoslovakia has not moved as quickly on reforms as Poland or Hungary.

As to changes that have occurred since we have been there and the sorts of protests that have occurred in Prague in recent weeks, I do not think any of us expected such rapid movement for change. Certainly the old guard, so to speak, of the Communist Party was firmly in control. Most of the people that we met at our appointments, as described in the report, were of a great age-even older than myself! They seemed to have been there forever and looked as if they would try to stay there in Brezhnev style. It was clear that something would give before long; things could not last much longer. But I certainly did not anticipate the protest against this regime, which had obviously run completely out of steam and which was maintaining a great deal of oppression of people even though its members might have been reasonable managers of the economy. I do not want to praise them too much but they had done a reasonable job according to their own doctrines so that people had a reasonable standard of living.

But one got the impression of a ramshackle government. The sort of people in government and the doctrinaire approach they had to their task, their country and their people is nowhere better expressed than in the two paragraphs on page 20 of the report, which records discussions we had with the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Obzina. The thing that sticks in my memory-which I am pleased is included in the report-is that when Mr Obzina was asked about the restriction on the church, on freedom of religion and the ability of the cardinal archbishop to communicate with his flock in pastoral letters, the Deputy Prime Minister said, `We have got a shortage of paper in Czechoslovakia and that is why he has got to be restricted, the same as Rude pravo has to be restricted'. Funnily enough, Mr Obzina was perhaps of a slightly younger generation than most of the other leaders in Czechoslovakia, but he certainly was as hidebound, doctrinaire and intractable as the rest of them in relation to any reforms.

There were some very interesting indications of reform. There had already been some protest. A movement known as Charter 77 had been able to broadcast on Western European radio about its members' desire for democratic reforms in Czechoslovakia. Certainly the church was standing firm for its own rights, although they were being suppressed to a great extent. Priests had to be licensed by the Government and publications by the church and so on were censored. But there were signs of resistance. It was suggested that at the next conference of the Communist Party some changes would certainly be proposed and that some of those may well be supported. But, by comparison with what had already occurred in the Soviet Union and Poland and what we were to find in Hungary, there was, as recently as the end of June this year, little indication of the great events which have occurred in Czechoslovakia.

All of us greatly welcome the events which have occurred and the pressures that are now being placed upon the old, tired, doctrinaire Government to accord some reforms, to increase the freedoms of Czechs and to do something to improve the economy. The Czechoslovakian economy has a basic strength because it was part of the industrial powerhouse of Europe up until the takeover by the communists in 1948. It has a fundamental strength, and if it had been allowed to perform properly over the last 40 years, the standard of living in Czechoslovakia would possibly be as high as in parts of Western Europe. Political reforms are not the only reforms that are needed. Despite what I have said about the economy and standard of living, there is certainly room for great reforms on the economic front. There was some recognition of that in the discussions we had with officials.

But there was suppression of freedom of thought, expression, assembly and religion. One case which we took up with the Deputy Prime Minister, which was mentioned in the report, involved a publisher who had been arrested and had had all his materials and archives confiscated because he was publishing a periodical of some kind that displeased the Government. We took up his case but it made no difference. We have since learned that an appeal against his conviction has been dismissed. With the new developments that have occurred in Czechoslovakia, many cases of that kind, hopefully, will be rectified, and the people involved will be set free.

I also want to mention the opportunity we had in Czechoslovakia to meet Cardinal Tomasek, who is the Catholic primate of Czechoslovakia. This was not an official visit by the delegation but arrangements were made by our Ambassador, Mr Herron, for those of us who wished to meet the cardinal. Several of us had a very long and interesting session with him when he told us about his problems with the regime and about maintaining freedom of religion. We took up many of those matters with the Deputy Prime Minister and we received the incredible replies which are included in the report. I am very grateful to Mr Herron for having organised that. He also organised for us-again, it was an unofficial matter; it was not part of the delegation, but a number of us took advantage of it-a meeting with a small group of dissidents one evening in a restaurant. Actually, several of those invited did not turn up because they had been called in for questioning an hour or two before the dinner was to begin. This was another indication of the oppressive nature of the regime. However, we had an interesting discussion with those who did attend.

I express one disappointment about our visit, and that is that we did not have a meeting with Mr Dubcek. This matter was raised with the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade before we left Australia. Unfortunately, Foreign Affairs apparently took the view that it would be counterproductive for an Australian government to even seek a delegation meeting with Mr Dubcek. To some extent I can understand it forming that view. I have described the representatives of the Czechoslovakian Government. Nevertheless, it is not really acceptable for an Australian government to be too over-diplomatic and over-cautious in standing up for rights of people in this way. The delegation would have been very interested to meet Mr Dubcek, but it was felt more diplomatic not to even seek to do so. However, no steps were taken to prevent the unofficial meetings with the cardinal and other dissidents which I have mentioned.

I cannot help feeling that if the matter had been left in the hands of our Ambassador or his staff, it may have been possible to arrange, without any hindrance from the Government, a meeting with Mr Dubcek. His actions in 1968 have now been amply justified. His leadership in 1968, the Prague Spring, will be an inspiration to so many of the oppressed people of Czechoslovakia. His great standing even after 20 years, has been retained in many people's minds. He was demoted to a menial job which he has had to have for 20 years. Obviously, he will in due course be restored. Whether he will be in a leadership position is another matter but there will certainly be proper recognition of his tremendous contribution to the freedom of Czechoslovakia and, indeed, the whole of eastern and central Europe from the communist yoke. It would have been interesting to have met him.

I conclude by saying that the imminent changes in Czechoslovakia are very welcome. The spirit of Czechoslovakia has clearly not been broken, as many people may have thought, by the way their Prague Spring was repressed in 1968. It is clear from the delegation's discussions with many people that the Soviets-and we know this from Mr Gorbachev himself-have a very different policy today and that tanks will not be sent in to stop these movements of reform. People in eastern Europe do not expect that to happen again. So there seems to be every reason to believe that the movement in Czechoslovakia which is already apparent will proceed down the road pioneered by Poland, Hungary and East Germany. It is a most welcome movement. I sincerely hope that it will proceed apace in Czechoslovakia as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was my privilege-and I underline the word `privilege'-to be a member of the Parliamentary Delegation to Yugoslavia, Czechoslovakia and Hungary. It was quite an extraordinary delegation in that we had the opportunity to be in this exciting part of the world a mere few weeks ago. I join with Senator Durack in extending my congratulations to the President of the Senate, who led the delegation in a most competent manner. It was a very hard working delegation with high morale. It was quite an extraordinary experience. The President's leadership of the delegation contributed greatly to that. I also extend my thanks and congratulations to the staff of the delegation, particularly to the Usher of the Black Rod, who was the secretary to the delegation and who did everything in his power to ensure that nothing untoward happened to anything other than my luggage, a bag of which is now somewhere in space, never to be recovered. The administration of the delegation was quite superb. It was a tireless effort on behalf of those people who administered it on our behalf.

SPEECH.PARA: What is happening in central Europe is really quite historic and extraordinary. I was fortunate enough to have been in the Soviet Union last year in the two weeks prior to the major conference in which Mr Gorbachev finally put into place perestroika and glasnost. At that time it was apparent that a great deal was in the wind. I do not think anybody anticipated that the spillover would have been as fast and as dramatic as it has been into the remainder of eastern Europe and the communist bloc. I was therefore very fortunate in being able to follow my visit to the Soviet Union only a few months later by being in Yugoslavia, Czechoslovakia and Hungary at this extremely exciting time.

I will share with honourable senators some of the highlights, as did Senator Durack. He cited two of the highlights that I certainly would regard as very insightful. One was our discussion with Cardinal Tomasek a few days before his ninetieth birthday. He is seen as being the focal person in Czechoslovakia. He was the focal person for the dissidents. His ageing heart must be much cheered by what has happened in the last two months. From his comments to us, he would not have envisaged that things could move as dramatically and as rapidly as they have in the last four months since we spoke with him; nor would the seven dissidents with whom we were more or less surreptitiously to meet in a restaurant in Prague, four of whom were detained and could not join us. It must be an incredibly buoyant experience to now see literally hundreds of thousands of their countrymen and women in the streets of Prague asserting themselves upon the repressive regime which they, as a handful of individuals, have been attempting to stir against, literally for decades.

It is indeed democracy on the move. That was particularly apparent at the time when we were in Hungary when we had the good fortune of meeting with the leaders of the emerging opposition parties. The Government in Hungary was voluntarily introducing political reform. The architect of Hungary's political reform was the Special Minister of State, Mr Imre Pozsgay. I very clearly recall his words when we spoke to him. I quote from page 35 of the report. He said:
We have a general social, economic and political crisis. We can no longer draw on the existing model.
Of course, he was referring there to the Marxist communist model and he continued:
All its components have to be changed. It is a non-Hungarian model.

He was simply saying that the Marxist model, as it had been implemented particularly in the hands of Stalin, was bereft, had not delivered to those who had embraced it and the time had come when it needed to be dramatically overhauled. He embodied the spirit of reform in Hungary and, of course, that spirit of reform was born out of perestroika and glasnost and spilled over dramatically into Poland and now, progressively, is spreading throughout eastern and central Europe. It is summarised well in a cartoon in one of this morning's newspapers. It showed a series of dominoes falling over and the former leaders of these nations were running forward and saying, `It seems to us that we have heard about these dominoes before'. Democracy on the move in central Europe is a demonstration to the rest of the globe that the spirit of democracy is alive and well. President Bush, in his recent comments, perhaps encapsulated the hopes of all of us in the Western world when he hopefully predicted that the 1990s would indeed prove to be the decade of democracy.

In conclusion may I say that it was a privilege to be a part of this delegation. It was exciting for both myself and my wife Nola. I thank those who led, planned and administered this very fruitful and exciting delegation on our behalf.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I present a report entitled Third World Debt: An Australian View, incorporating a dissenting report, together with the transcript of evidence and minutes of proceedings. I seek leave to move a motion that the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

In December 1987 the then Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade asked that the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade inquire into appropriate Australian policy responses to the present international trade and financial situation including debt and, in particular, measures that Australia could take to improve its own balance of trade in goods and services. Given the broad nature of the reference, the Committee has divided its inquiry into two parts, the first being the subject of this report, Third World debt.

The Committee considers that, for many developing countries, debt problems have been severe and chronic since the beginning of this decade; and in particular it recognises the desperate plight of many poor people in developing countries. Increasing public attention has been focused on the debt problem in recent years. The debt crisis has been crippling national economies and adversely affecting social fabric particularly among the poor. Developing debtor countries have suffered sharp declines in standard of living, large increases in unemployment, nutritional problems and rising infant mortality rates. Increasing risk spawned the spectre of loan repayment default, and a number of major banks were highly exposed. Although the risk of bank collapse has receded recently, nervousness about high risk over-exposure has led the commercial banking sector virtually to turn off the tap for new funds to developing countries. The debt crisis is a real crisis, will not go away quickly, and requires reforms by the world's governments, international bodies and the private business sector. The recommendations urge a more active Australian presence in international bodies such as the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank and in particular urge Australian support for debt and debt service reduction proposals such as the Brady proposals. Other actions are recommended to relieve the world debt problem and to revitalise the economies of those countries so that they can grow out of debt.

The Committee received 40 written submissions for the report and heard evidence from 17 witnesses. As a member of the trade subcommittee I wish to record our thanks to those people who gave evidence to the inquiry and also to those who made submissions; their interest and effort were useful and are appreciated. I would also like to express my appreciation of the efforts of those of my subcommittee colleagues who, between them, spent hundreds of hours working on this inquiry. The subcommittee wishes to acknowledge the contribution made by our staff, in particular our secretary Mr John Pulley and parliamentary officer, Mrs Lesley Cowan. We are also indebted to the main Committee, its Chairman, the honourable member for Kingston, Mr Gordon Bilney, and the secretary, Mr Peter Gibson. The recommendations in this report are, I believe, positive and practical and if implemented should solve some of the severe economic problems confronting the Third World. I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: COURTS AND TRIBUNALS ADMINISTRATION AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Cook) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill is a significant development in the Government's continued commitment to the financial and management independence of the Federal Court, the Family Court and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The Bill will ensure that the courts and the tribunal are independent from day to day control by the Attorney-General's Department and will provide them with the capacity to make decisions which they believe will best enhance their efficient and effective operation.

The Bill is not, however, about judicial independence in so far as that expression relates to the independence of judges and members of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in the exercise of their judicial or adjudicative responsibilities. An essential element of justice in this country has been the real separation of the powers of the judiciary from the powers of the government. All in this Parliament would agree that it is essential that this independence be maintained. It is unfortunate that some have suggested that the question of administrative and management independence is the same as judicial independence. To reiterate that they are different issues in no way diminishes the importance of enabling courts and tribunals to operate separately from the mainstream of Government administration.

But in providing a statutory basis for independent administration and management it does not follow that the courts or the Administrative Appeals Tribunal will or should be free of the need to account for their operations. It is the Parliament which appropriates the funds to these bodies and it is to the Parliament that they will be answerable. Courts and Tribunals, no less than other areas of public administration, must be accountable for efficiency in the management of their affairs.

Ultimately, of course, the courts must be accountable to the public. Within the resources provided by the Parliament the judicial system must ensure that it provides to all who use the courts impartial adjudication of issues which come before it without undue delay.

Public accountability is essential for without public confidence the judiciary may well come under threat. The provisions of this Bill will place with the courts and the tribunal responsibility for their own administration and provide them with the capacity to operate as they see fit within the resources provided by the Parliament.

Some have suggested that the level of judicial salaries in some way directly affects the degree of independence exercised by the judiciary. Such a proposition is offensive because it suggests that judges will be influenced in the decisions they make because of the level of remuneration. What is important is that the constitutional guarantee that remuneration cannot be reduced during judicial office is supported. The Judicial and Statutory Officers Remuneration Legislation Amendment Bill enhances that constitutional guarantee by placing the ultimate responsibility for the determination of the level of judicial salaries in this parliament. That is not to say that the level of salaries is unimportant. Quite the contrary. Because without adequate remuneration capable individuals will not make themselves available to serve in our courts.

For some time the Government has been conscious of the need to move in the direction of enabling the Federal and Family courts and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to manage their own affairs. The High Court has enjoyed such administrative independence for some years. The situation with the other courts and the Tribunal is that they have operated under the administrative umbrella of the Attorney-General's Department with the Secretary of that Department exercising the powers of a departmental secretary of the Public Service in relation to the staff of those courts and the Tribunal.

As a first step towards self-management, from the beginning of this financial year, the Federal Court, the Family Court and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal received separate appropriations in the supply bills. This placed them, in this respect, on an equal footing with the High Court. The purpose behind this move was to place the courts and the Tribunal in a position where their funding allocation would be controlled by themselves and they will now be able to negotiate direct with the government concerning the appropriate level of future funding.

As an additional step towards increased administrative independence, a number of the departmental secretary's powers were delegated to the chief administrative officer of each court and of the tribunal.

This Bill now provides a statutory basis to fully implement the self-management of the courts and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The effect of this Bill is to transfer from the Attorney-General's Department to the courts and the Tribunal responsibility for the supervision of their own financial management and practices and the courts and the Tribunal also take control over the management of their other administrative affairs.

Self-management will mean that the courts and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal will be free to make their own decisions in human and financial resource management. This will maximise the flexibility of the courts and the tribunal to cope with changing pressures and priorities throughout each year. This move is welcomed by the chief justices of the Federal and Family courts and the President of the Tribunal. It is also consistent with initiatives they have taken and, no doubt, will be taking in relation to their case management procedures and in the reduction of delays.

The Bill will also mean that these bodies will be given an administrative independence similar to that enjoyed by the High Court. There are two differences of substance between the arrangements in this Bill and the position of the High Court. First, unlike the High Court, the Federal and Family courts and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal are not given power to acquire interests in land. The accommodation needs of these bodies are, of course, significantly greater than those of the High Court. Because of the geographic diversity of their operations, the Federal and Family courts and the Tribunal require facilities across Australia and the acquisition of those facilities is enhanced if they can have the opportunity to work under the umbrella of Government purchasing and building arrangements. This is also a more efficient arrangement, in particular, where accommodation might be shared by these bodies in purpose-built accommodation. The other difference is that, unlike the High Court which operates its own bank accounts, the Federal and Family courts and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal will operate on the Commonwealth Public Account under arrangements with which they are familiar and which they have agreed should be retained. Use of the Commonwealth Public Account will not subject them to the control of the Attorney-General's Department as they will operate as separate departments.

To facilitate the proposed increased administrative responsibilities of the courts and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the Bill creates a new executive management position in each body to carry out the new management functions under the overall direction and control of the chief judge of each court and the President of the Tribunal.

Unlike the Federal Court and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the Family Court has two separate mainstreams of personnel-those concerned with the delivery of court counselling services and those concerned with the legal aspects of the proceedings before the court. In recognition of this fact (and noting, of course, that the Family Court is the largest and most diverse court in Australia), the Bill creates a new statutory office of chief executive officer in that court. In the Federal Court and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal the responsibilities of the registrars have been altered to incorporate the responsibilities in respect of the courts and tribunal administration previously conferred on the Secretary of the Attorney-General's Department. Both positions of registrar will cease to be public service positions and both registrars and the chief executive officer will hold appointments from the Governor-General. In relation to the other officers and staff of the courts and the tribunal the new office holders will be given the powers of departmental secretaries. The existing position of the principal registrar of the Family Court will remain as at present and that officer will continue to exercise the functions of the principal registrar and the supervision of the officers of the court carrying out ``legal'' functions.

Many of the provisions of the Bill are standard provisions and consequential amendments which are necessary for the creation of these new statutory offices. The remaining provisions in parts 2, 4 and 5 of the Bill cover the new administrative duties and responsibilities which are to be taken on by the courts and the Tribunal.

The amendment to subsection 78 (3) of the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Act is also a consequential amendment arising from the change in the position of the Registrar of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal from a public service position to a statutory office-holder. Currently, the registrar of the Tribunal is also the registrar of the Security Appeals Tribunal established by the ASIO Act. This is because the workload of the Security Appeals Tribunal is such that it does not justify full time registry appointments. The amendment will mean that the Registrar of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal would still be eligible to be the Registrar of the Security Appeals Tribunal.

The other amendments made by this Bill relate to the setting of fees in the High Court. Currently these fees are set by the judges of the High Court in the High Court Rules. After consultation with the High Court, it has been agreed to transfer this fee-setting power so that in future it can be dealt with by regulation. This brings the position in regard to the High Court fees into line with the position in regard to fees in other courts and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The Bill amends the relevant sections of the Judiciary Act to give effect to this proposal.

This Bill is a major reform by the Government in the area of judicial administration. However, in presentating this reform, I must say that the Government is conscious that it could not have reached this point had it not been for the support and commitment of the Chief Justices of the Federal and Family Courts and the President of the Tribunal.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Knowles) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Cook) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a revised explanatory memorandum and I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill is an omnibus Bill amending 16 Acts administered within the Transport and Communications portfolio.
The most significant amendments are to the Ships (Capital Grants) Act 1987 to put in place part of the shipping industry reform package announced by the Government on 1 June 1989.

Other significant amendments are made to the Motor Vehicle Standards Act 1989 to provide for customs clearance of imported vehicles and to enable the determination of testing and record keeping practices for manufacturers or importers of vehicles.
The other amendments are mainly of a minor policy nature or correct deficiencies or errors in current legislation. I will now deal with the amendments in detail.
Ships (Capital Grants) Act 1987

The amendments to the Ships (Capital Grants) Act 1987 are to put in place the legislative elements of the Government's contribution to the shipping industry reform package announced on 1 June 1989. The amendments extend the availability of the fiscal benefits under the Act to 30 June 1997 for new ships and make grants payable for modifications to existing ships completed by 30 June 1992 which enable reductions in crew levels.

The extension of the fiscal benefits to 1997 will provide Australian shipowners with a stable fiscal environment in which to invest in new tonnage. Already 25 ships with MIDC type crews have been introduced or ordered for the Australian fleet. This represents one third of the fleet of major trading ships. The extension of the Act will encourage other shipowners or potential shipowners to invest in more modern tonnage, crewed at levels comparable with those applying on ships of OECD nations using national crews.

The amendments are also to safeguard against excessive grant payments possible under ship financing schemes which inflate the purchase price of ships by including financing costs. These changes were announced on 7 September 1989.
Motor Vehicle Standards Act 1989

The amendments proposed to the Motor Vehicle Standards Act demonstrate the continuing commitment by the Government to maintaining that a high level of safety is met by all road vehicles supplied to the Australian market for the first time.

The major amendment provides for a proper link between the Act and the Customs Act to ensure that vehicles are not allowed to enter Australia unless they meet the requirements of the Motor Vehicle Standards Act. It ensures that vehicles subject to the Motor Vehicle Standards Act will not be allowed to enter Australia without the specific approval of the Minister administering the Act.
In addition the amendments provide that determinations relating to the testing of motor vehicles be disallowable instruments, thus providing for proper parliamentary scrutiny.
The Bill also contains a number of minor amendments that clarify certain provisions and facilitate administration of the Act.
Air Navigation Act 1920

There have been some doubts expressed that the regulation making power of the Air Navigation Act does not extend to aviation security. These doubts arose following the enactment of the Civil Aviation Act 1988 which provides that the Civil Aviation Authority has responsibility for aviation safety but not for aviation security. Prior to the enactment of the Civil Aviation Act, aviation security was considered to fall within the term aviation safety. The amendment to the Air Navigation Act will remove the doubt that regulations relating to aviation security may be made under that Act.
Broadcasting Act
The proposed amendment to section 125d of the Broadcasting Act provides for the introduction of charges for the investigation of interference with the reception of radio and television programs.

Under current legislation, the Minister for Transport and Communications has an obligation to investigate and make arrangements to correct interference to broadcasting services. This obligation is currently discharged as a free service by officers of my department who investigate complaints of reception difficulties.
The requirement was initially introduced because knowledge and understanding of interference effects were seen to have an important input to the service planning process.

Because of technological development, the provision of broadcasting services is now much more scientific and predictable and the planning information obtained from investigations is negligible. Also, the service industry is now better educated in ways of overcoming reception problems.

In addition, in recent years, there has been a growing tendency for members of the public to rely on this free service. In the overwhelming majority of cases, the reception problems have been attributed to easily detectable factors such as: deficiencies in the receiving installation, for example an inadequate antenna or television receiver; people trying to tune to stations where they are well outside the station's service area; or unintended radio frequency emissions from the local electricity authority's reticulation system. These complaints are investigated by departmental officers whereas they could, and should, be handled by complainants themselves, TV repair services and electricity authorities. Because departmental officers are not in a position to fix these reception problems, this activity represents a waste of highly skilled technical resources.

This unnecessary demand is not only diverting valuable technical resources away from other important spectrum management and broadcasting planning functions, but it is also inhibiting the Department's ability to provide timely assistance to people with cases of genuine interference.

It is proposed through appropriate consumer education to encourage the public to make their own assessment of any interference problem before calling on the Department for assistance. To assist people to understand what is involved and to know what action is appropriate, a comprehensive information booklet and questionnaire will be sent free to each complainant. Provision will be made for the public to submit, at no charge, the questionnaire without requesting an investigation of their own receiving equipment. By this means the Department will be able to detect and deal with genuine cases of interference, such as those affecting a local community.

The Department will also provide an improved telephone advisory service to help residents deal with general queries and any difficulties that the local repair services or electricity authority cannot resolve.
A call-out charge will only apply where a departmental officer pays a visit in response to a specific request.

I wish to emphasise that it is not proposed to terminate the Department's interference investigation service. On the contrary Departmental officers will continue to investigate all cases of interference to radiocommunications services, as well as genuine interference problems involving broadcasting services.

This initiative is in accordance with current Government policy to encourage a more efficient and effective public service and will result in a quicker and better service to all users of the radio frequency spectrum.
Interstate Road Transport Act 1985

The Bill also amends the Interstate Road Transport Act 1985 in three respects. Firstly, to allow State and Territory Regulatory Authorities to link the prescribed fees that are payable to the Consumer Price Index. These fees are payable to State or Territory Regulatory Authorities where they perform a registration function on behalf of the Commonwealth. Secondly another amendment will strengthen the prosecution provision of the Act by ensuring that corporations, and their directors, agents and employees are subject to adequate sanctions where an offence is committed under the Act.
Finally, further amendment will allow on-the-spot fines for mass limit (overloading) offences as an alternative to prosecution to reduce the administrative burden placed on the court system.
Navigation Act
The Bill will make several amendments to the Navigation Act 1912.
Two of the amendments implement changes agreed with the States and the Northern Territory on jurisdiction over maritime matters.

The first will allow a trading ship under State/Territory jurisdiction to be brought under Federal jurisdiction should its owner wish it. (This will be of particular value to the owner of a ship that operates a mixture of intra-state and inter-state voyages-the ship will not have to move backwards and forwards between jurisdictions according to the particular voyage it is on. The procedure already works well with offshore industry support vessels.)
The second will implement revised, more flexible, arrangements on jurisdiction for enforcement of collision regulations.

The Marine Council is empowered to determine that the character or conduct of a person is such that the person is unsuitable for engagement as a seafarer. Such a determination is subject to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal but as the Act currently stands the lodgment of an appeal automatically defers operation of the determination. This automatic deferral is to be removed and deferral to be left in the hands of the Tribunal according to the facts of the individual case.

The current provisions relating to Courts of Marine Inquiry are to be replaced by a more modern and flexible system of casualty investigation. The Bill will provide for the necessary power for this to be done in the regulations.

Finally, the various statutory committees provided for in the Navigation Act are to be rationalised by combining the various functions, such as that carried out by the Crew Accommodation Committee, into the Marine Council.
Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act 1983

The Bill corrects a drafting deficiency relating to the discharge of garbage from ships in the vicinity of offshore platforms and will enable Australian ratification of Annex V of the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships (MARPOL).
Telecommunications and Postal Legislation

The Bill makes minor amendments to the Telecommunications Act 1989 and miscellaneous telecommunications and postal legislation to correct drafting errors. The most significant of these amendments will ensure OTC is able to continue to supply basic telecommunications services between external territories and other places within Australia. This amendment does not preclude Telecom from continuing to supply these same services. Another amendment will extend an existing provision preventing the sale without notice of equipment for which there is no permit to the supply of such equipment otherwise than by sale, such as by lease.
Other Portfolio Legislation

The Bill also makes minor technical amendments to the Australian Airlines (Conversion to Public Company) Act 1988, the Broadcasting Legislation Amendment Act 1988 and the Navigation Amendment Act 1980.
All amendments are revenue-neutral except the amendments to the Broadcasting Act 1942 and the Ships (Capital Grants) Act 1987.

In relation to the amendments of the Broadcasting Act 1942, the estimated cost of setting up a charging scheme for the investigation of interference to the reception of radio and television programs is $100,000. The estimated net savings in the financial year 1989/90 will be approximately $350,000.

In respect of the amendments to the Ships (Capital Grants) Act 1987, the extension of the grants scheme to 1997 is expected to involve a net cost to revenue of $52m. Savings in the form of increased industry efficiency of $80m will accrue to industry over the three years from 1989 and annual savings of $50m are expected thereafter. The cost to revenue of the grants for modification is expected to be about $2.4m. The savings from the amendment to prevent excessive claims is estimated at $13m.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Knowles) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not in what I would describe as full swing before lunch but I had commenced directing a question to the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) in respect of the estimates relating to the Film Censorship Board. I am wondering whether the Minister is about. I draw your attention, Mr Temporary Chairman, to the state of the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) will be in the chamber shortly. I cannot spin out this answer until he arrives.

SPEECH.PARA: (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to lunch I had referred the Minister to a response provided by Mr Dickie to questions I asked in Estimates Committee E. I prefaced my question by noting that the unanimous view of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material was that videos with the R classification should not be displayed with other videos, that is to say, videos rated G, PG and M, and that, if they were to be displayed at all, they should not be displayed in a place other than a place to which access by persons under the age of 18 years is prohibited. I asked Mr Dickie what had taken place in respect of that and he gave me a response which is recorded on page E146 of the Estimates Hansard. I was very well aware that in a number of States, including my own, a person can walk into a video shop and see the most horrific, violent R-rated videos side by side with PG-rated videos. It is a matter about which the Joint Select Committee was most concerned. I asked the Chief Film Censor a question and I repeat it here: what is to prevent the Commonwealth from enacting legislation which would require that to be done? I asked this because, as I understand it, a number of people take advice from the Chief Censor and he is present at various ministerial meetings. I really expected a response from him. He responded:

SPEECH.PARA: The decision of the Standing Committee of Ministers was to take no action on it in the end.
The questioning continued:

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, but that was not my question. What is to prevent the Commonwealth from taking that action?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Dickie-The Commonwealth on its own does not have that power.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has it not? Can you not make that a condition of registration of videos?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Dickie-I do not think so, Senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could you consider that and give another reply?

SPEECH.PARA: The reply that has come back is not a reply to the question as to whether the Commonwealth has the power to enact legislation requiring R-rated videos not to be displayed in the same place where PG and M videos are displayed. The response by the Chief Censor is that the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations relate only to films and videotapes imported for public exhibition and not to videotapes for sale or hire, which are regulated by State and Territory laws. Under State and Territory law throughout Australia the Chief Censor does not have any power to impose conditions on the approval of videotapes for sale and hire, except perhaps in Queensland.

That response was given to me through the Estimates Committee secretariat in a letter dated 24 October 1989, but that is not the question I asked. What he says is that under State and Territory law throughout the Commonwealth the Chief Censor does not have any power to impose conditions on the approval of videos for sale or hire, except perhaps in Queensland. That was not my question. My question was clearly this: does the Commonwealth have the power to enact legislation which would require such videos that are classified R not to be displayed? I would like the Minister to respond, if he would not mind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this examination of the appropriations Senator Harradine has again raised the question of whether it could be made a condition of registration of R-certified videos that they be separately displayed at point of sale or hire. Obviously he is not content-and I am not saying that in any pejorative way-with the decision by the Standing Committee of Censorship Ministers on 1 December 1988 that the question of whether R-classified videotapes should be separately displayed in stores was appropriately one for determination by State or Territory governments. That is certainly the position of that ministerial council and, to that extent, I suppose it is certainly the current political position which obviously has the support of various governments around Australia. The manner in which these particular videos might be displayed in a video store, particularly the question of their separation, ought to be a matter for those governments to legislate for or regulate in accordance with the various pressures, requests or lobbying put forward from within their own electorate and jurisdiction, rather than making an Australia-wide attempt to regulate this particular matter of display by way of Commonwealth law.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, Senator Harradine raises the very proper question of whether, if that were not the case and the Commonwealth were minded to do it, it could legislate to make that separation in display a requirement. The short answer to the honourable senator's question is yes, it is possible in a limited and fragmented way. One could try to rely on a number of heads of constitutional power. Conceivably, one could try to base the legislation in part on the interstate trade and commerce power or, perhaps, the corporations power. No doubt there are others, but it would be fragmented. For example-I think it is fairly obvious-if it were based on the interstate trade and commerce power, Commonwealth legislation would not apply to sale or hire occurring totally within a State. That is the advice that has been received over the lunch hour since the honourable senator made known to officials his misgivings in this area.

Equally, if it were based on the corporations power, it would not apply to sale or hire by individuals or non-trading or non-financial corporations. I myself have not had time to consider the matter and I am not necessarily saying that the heads of power identified and the particular scope in the answer I am giving are comprehensive or totally answering in the sense of a proper legal opinion, which I am not really offering. I am simply indicating that there would need to be a combination of various heads of power, none of which would comprehensively cover the various instances where the objective sought to be achieved by Senator Harradine could be guaranteed. There would be ways around the heads of power that the Commonwealth might use.

I can only repeat my view that, whilst the Commonwealth would have certain heads of power available to it, it would be a fragmented attempt. To be successful, it would have to be done in collaboration with the States, the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory. In that situation there would need to be the support of the ministerial council of censorship Ministers. When that body last considered the matter, on 1 December 1988, it regarded it as one which should be properly left to each individual State or Territory to legislate or regulate in accordance with its accountability to its own electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to get involved-and I do not suppose it would be proper in the discussion on the Estimates-in a long and detailed argument about this, but it is clear that the statement made by Mr Dickie that the Commonwealth did not have power at the time was not a correct statement. To be fair to Mr Dickie, he said that he did not think so. However, I am advised that there are a great number of ways in which Commonwealth powers could be utilised for this purpose. Presumably Mr Dickie was at this ministerial council; the question clearly arises as to whether the possibility of Commonwealth legislation in this area was suggested to it by Mr Dickie. We were talking about some uniform laws in this regard, and I would have thought that that was one of the things that Mr Dickie, or the Attorney-General's Department, could have advised the ministerial council about. Clearly that has not been done because the Department was not sure whether this could be done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —By way of clarification, I think in the Estimates Committee on 5 October Mr Dickie was trying to answer in good faith. I have the Hansard report of that hearing. At page E146 Senator Harradine said:

SPEECH.PARA: Yes, but that was not my question.
That was the decision of the Standing Committee of Ministers. Senator Harradine continued:
What is to prevent the Commonwealth from taking that action?
The report continues:
Mr Dickie-The Commonwealth on its own does not have that power.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has it not? Can you not make that a condition of the registration of videos?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Dickie-I do not think so, Senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could you consider that and give another reply?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Dickie-Yes, I will consider it.
Further questions were then put on notice. I think it is important that the actual response of Mr Dickie-if I have the correct one, and I believe I have-be noted. He said:
The Commonwealth on its own does not have that power.

I think that is the matter that I am emphasising. I believe there is some constitutional base but it is fragmented through various heads of power and, to be effective, would require the concurrence of the various Ministers at the ministerial council. I feel sure they would have been aware of the partial scope of the Commonwealth's power and I am sure the Federal Attorney, who is the Commonwealth Minister responsible for censorship, and most other Ministers responsible for censorship, who are probably Ministers for Justice or Attorneys, although not all of them are, would have been aware of this constitutional base. However, as I say, at the moment it is a matter for determination by State or Territory governments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not suggested that the answers that were given to me by Mr Dickie at the Estimates Committee were given in anything other than good faith. TALK.START.PARA: —I intervene briefly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another aspect of the Attorney-General's Department to which I wish to refer was raised in Estimates Committee E hearings. Because the Human Rights Commissioner was not there I asked my questions of an officer of the Human Rights Commission. It relates to the rights of the child. I do not have the Hansard report of the Committee with me, but the Minister will know what I am talking about. It is relevant because earlier this week the General Assembly of the United Nations adopted the Convention on the Rights of the Child. Television coverage highlighted symbolic scenes of young children occupying the national seats in the General Assembly Council. Whilst our natural reaction is to support anything which may advance the general well-being and welfare of children, we need to examine the role of the Human Rights Commission. I attempted to do that in the Estimates Committee. The Attorney-General's Department, in the explanatory notes, made a big thing about the Human Rights Commissioner being very much involved in this particular matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Each of us should examine the text of the Convention very carefully to see what may have been lost in the transformation from a declaration to a convention as the new Convention is intended to replace the 1959 Declaration on the Rights of the Child. The 1959 Declaration is very much relevant to the operation of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, that is, the Commission whose estimates we have under review at the moment. The declaration is reproduced as a schedule to the Act which governs the Commission.

When the Commission appeared before Estimates Committee E on 5 October, I directed a number of questions to its representatives. Despite the identification by the Commission of `work on the Convention' as one of its major activities in 1988-89, the Human Rights Commissioner, Mr Brian Burdekin, was not present at the Estimates Committee hearing and the Commission representative was not able to answer adequately my question about the Commission's work on the Convention. The Minister covered that well. He invited me to pursue the questions by letter, which invitation I accepted. The Minister subsequently forwarded answers prepared by the Commission. The answers to those questions were inadequate. I would use a stronger term if I were used to using such terms. I want to make the point and show why the answers were inadequate.
My principal question was:

What attempts were made by the Commissioner to ensure that the recognition of the unborn child, contained in the Preamble and Principle 4 of the Declaration of the Rights of the Child were repeated with equivalent force and status in the Draft Convention?
I asked the questions very deliberately and used words with which the Human Rights Commission would have been familiar. I should have got direct answers to those questions. I did not.
I have in my hand the terms of schedule 3 of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission legislation. My first question to the Commissioner was:

It is stated in the Departmental Explanatory Notes that `work of the Convention on the Rights of the Child' was one of the major activities and performance results for the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission in 1988-89. It is also stated in the HREOC Publication ``Questions'' and Answers that Australia `has taken a very active role in negotiating the terms of the Convention' and that these negotiations included the Commissioner.
I then asked:

What attempts were made by the Commissioner to ensure that the recognition of the unborn child contained in the Preamble and Principle 4 of the Declaration of the Rights of the Child were repeated with equivalent force and status in the Draft Convention.
The preamble of the Declaration of the Rights of the Child states:
. . . the child, by reason of his physical and mental immaturity, needs special safeguards and care, including appropriate legal protection, before as well as after birth . . .
The key point is that Principle 4, which is in the body of the Declaration, in reference to the child, states:
. . . shall be entitled to grow and develop in health; to this end, special care and protection shall be provided both to him and his mother, including adequate pre-natal and post-natal care . . .
I asked the question:

Did the Human Rights Commissioner or any other Australian Representative make any statements about this recognition to the UN Committees or working parties which examined the draft Convention? When were these made? What they were?
The Commissioner's reply was as follows:

The relevant part of the Preamble of the Declaration of the Rights of the Child is in fact referred to and precisely reproduced in the Preamble of the Draft Convention on the Rights of the Child. Questions as to any `attempts' made to this end therefore do not arise.

It is considered that the subject matter of Principle 4 of the Declaration of the Rights of the Child is fully covered by the provisions of the Convention on the Rights of the Child, including the preambular provisions already referred to and the following substantive articles: . . .

The Commissioner would have known that to use the words `including the preambular provisions already referred to' evaded the question because the preambular provisions already referred to are not part of the actual treaty text, the binding part of the treaty. Whereas the preambular provisions are in the Declaration of the Rights of the Child, there is another provision, provision 4 which I read out before, which when read together with the preambular provisions indicates that the child should be protected before as well as after birth.

Unless I am misunderstanding what Mr Burdekin has said, that is my concern. Perhaps Mr Burdekin has said something in the succeeding statements about which I would like clarification from the Minister. In referring to Principle 4 of the Declaration of the Rights of the Child, which I remind the Committee referred to the child's entitlement to grow and to develop in health and to have adequate prenatal and postnatal care, Mr Burdekin says that that is covered by Article 3 (2) of the new Convention, where it says:
States Parties shall undertake to ensure the child such protection and care as is necessary for his or her well being . . .
Does that mean the unborn child? Mr Burdekin then goes on to say that it is also covered in Article 6 (2). He says:
States Parties shall ensure to the maximum extent possible the survival and development of the child.
Does that mean the survival of the unborn child? Mr Burdekin goes on to refer to Article 24 (1), which says:
States Parties recognises the right of the child to the enjoyment of the highest attainable standard of health . . .
He refers also to Article 24 (2), which says:
States Parties shall pursue full implementation of this right and, in particular, shall take appropriate measures: (a) To diminish infant and child mortality . . .

Does that mortality relate to the unborn child? If it does not, why did the Minister try to snow me? If we are talking about Principle 4 of the Declaration, which refers specifically to the entitlement of the child to grow and to develop in health and to have adequate prenatal and postnatal care, I would like to hear from the Minister as to what is meant by these responses.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine asked that questions be put to the Human Rights Commissioner and, indeed, they were. The first question set out in his letter included:

SPEECH.PARA: What attempts were made by the Commissioner to ensure that the recognition of the unborn child contained in the Preamble and Principle 4 of the Declaration of the Rights of the Child were repeated with equivalent force and status in the Draft Convention?
As I understand the response, it refers to paragraph 3 of the Declaration of the Rights of the Child, which reads:
Whereas the child, by reason of his physical or mental immaturity, needs special safeguards and care, including appropriate legal protection, before as well as after birth . . .

That is carried into paragraph 9 of the preamble to the Convention. Quite clearly, we have an equivalence of force and status. They are both in paragraphs preceding the document. Of course, should the Convention be ratified and come into force then it will have a greater status and more force than is the case with the Declaration because the Convention will be binding in international fora on those state parties which are parties to it. In fact, to a certain extent, whilst it is true that they both formally are bound within the preamble, the preamble would have a certain greater status in harmony with the greater status of the Convention compared with the Declaration.

But preambles are preambles. I think Senator Harradine made the point that they do not have the same obligatory effect as do the articles. I think it is true to say that when the working party in 1988, I think it was, during its final session, considered this matter and amendments were made and forwarded by the Federal Republic of Germany and the Holy See, Ireland, Malta and the Philippines, seeking the inclusion of that phrase `before as well as after birth', the idea was to carry it into the preamble of the Convention-at least this was the outcome-in the terms that we have before us. It is not exactly equivalent to the words in the Declaration of the Rights of the Child. The preamble says:
Bearing in mind that as indicated in the Declaration of the Rights of the Child adopted by the General Assembly of the UN on 20 November 1959 . . .
Then the words in quotes are an exact replication.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have just argued yourself out of what you said before.
—In what way?
—I will tell you directly.

—Nevertheless, there they are. Both points are in the preamble. I believe that there is an equivalence in that sense. That obviously satisfied the working group and the Human Rights Commission which considered the report of the working group. I believe that we can see the origins of paragraph 9 in the preamble to the Convention and we can see the equivalence with paragraph 3 of the preamble to the Declaration of the Rights of the Child.

SPEECH.PARA: Principle 4 in the Declaration of the Rights of the Child is not reproduced in the Convention in the same terms. As I understand it, Mr Burdekin is making the claim that, if one looks at various other substantive articles and at their overall impact and effect, one will find that the matters of concern in Principle 4 are covered in the various articles which he outlines. For example, it is said within Principle 4 of the Declaration of the Rights of the Child that the child-and I paraphrase-is entitled to adequate pre-natal and post-natal care. Obviously that is an important matter which goes somewhat to the question which Senator Harradine is concerned about. Article 24 (1), which is included in Mr Burdekin's response which I have forwarded to Senator Harradine, states:
States parties recognise the right of the child to enjoyment of the highest attainable standard of health . . .
Article 24 (2) states:
States Parties shall pursue full implementation of this right and, in particular, shall take appropriate measures:
(a) To diminish infant and child mortality
(b) To ensure the provision of necessary medical assistance and health care to all children . . .
(c) To ensure appropriate health care for expectant mothers.

I imagine that if one provides appropriate health care for expectant mothers there is a recognition that the child to be borne and carried within the womb of the expectant mother is quite clearly as much the beneficiary of that prenatal care as is the mother herself. In other words, the appropriate health care for expectant mothers is by definition appropriate health care also for the child she is expecting to bring into the world.

In these various ways-whether it is article 24, article 6 or article 3, as mentioned in Mr Burdekin's response-Mr Burdekin believes that the types of concerns which prompted Principle 4 have been sufficiently carried into the Convention. I understand that to be his particular claim and I think it obviously has persuasive influence. I do not know precisely whether the working party and the Commission saw it in exactly the same way but quite clearly one would imagine that the working party and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission would not wish to give up the objectives which were sought to be obtained by adherence to Principle 4 and would want to see those carried into the Convention. Mr Burdekin has pointed to those articles which he believes carry those objectives through to the Convention stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel like leaving the matter there because, if what Senator Tate considers has happened has in fact happened, it would appear that he feels that the Convention on the Rights of the Child gives protection to the unborn child. But I then go to what the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission itself has said in its annual report entitled Human Rights Australia. I asked a question about that in the Estimates Committee when I said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the document . . . `What does the convention say about abortion laws in Australia' says that the Convention does not change the situation in any country concerning whether or not an embryo is a human being and it was a deliberate decision of the nations that drafted this Convention to leave this issue to each country's own laws.

The decision to leave the definition of the point at which an embryo or foetus is legally regarded as a human being to the legal system of each country was not one made by a formal vote. It was the consensus of the Working Group that no definitive solution to this issue could achieve universal or widespread acceptance.

That was not really what I asked. The Commission said that it was a deliberate decision. I do not have an answer and I want an answer to the question of when that deliberate decision was made. I would like to have a response in respect of those matters and some of the other questions of fact that are contained in this letter which are not responded to. The Human Rights Commission was not in fact a special advisor to the Working Group . . .
I did not ask that question. I asked the question following a statement about the working party by an officer of the Human Rights Commission. Mr Burdekin went on to say:
. . . but was a special advisor to the Australian delegation to the Working Group.
