I wanted to know who comprised the working party referred to by the officer of the Human Rights Commission, what that working party was and what advice the Human Rights Commissioner gave to the working party and/or officials of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in recognition of the rights of the unborn child. I asked:
When and where was such advice given and with what result? Did the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade take this advice? If not what were the reasons given to HREOC by DFAT?

They are simple questions. In order to understand all of the questions that have come to mind I think it is fair enough that one should have a response. It is appropriate that one should get a response from Mr Burdekin. I do not want to belabour the point. I know that Mr Burdekin did not know that I would be covering that particular Committee. In fairness to the Minister for Justice, I know that other senior people from the Department which he represents were there. I only thought of doing this on the run about two days beforehand. I do not want to hold up the Committee, Madam Chair but if I could have a guarantee that I could get some answers in respect of that, I think my duty at this stage would be satisfied.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can do better than that; I will try to answer some of those questions. The preamble and, in particular, paragraph 9 have to be read in conjunction with article 1 of the Convention on the Rights of the Child which says:

SPEECH.PARA: For the purposes of the present Convention a child means every human being below the age of 18 years unless, under the law applicable to the child, majority is attained earlier.

It can quite readily be seen there that a maximum age is set for the Convention's applicability to a human being under the label, title or usage `child'. But a minimum is not set. Therefore it is open to the various states parties to the Convention to have the ability within their own jurisdictions and according to their own laws to indicate what shall count as a human being-and therefore child in the sense of not being adult-for the purposes of the laws within each jurisdiction. As I understand it, the various parties to the working group and to the Commission were concerned to acknowledge the force of carrying through the words of the third paragraph of the declaration; that is that a child, by reason of his physical and mental immaturity, needs special safeguards and care, including appropriate legal protection, before as well as after birth. But, as I am advised, when one looks at the history of the final session of the working group and the outcome of the negotiations, one sees that the parties did not want that minimum time at which the existence of a human being comes into being to be determined by that preambular paragraph. I refer Senator Harradine to an interpretive statement, which was placed in what is known as the traveaux preparatories, on behalf of the entire working group, which reads:
In adopting this preambular paragraph the working group does not intend to prejudice the interpretation of article 1 or any other provision of the Convention by state parties.

We have there an indication that it was the understanding of the working group and of the Commission on Human Rights, which adopted the final report of that working group in March 1989, that whilst accepting the amendment, which I think is a very good one, proposed by the Federal Republic of Germany, the Holy See, Malta, the Philippines and Ireland, and carrying through that important paragraph from the Declaration, it was not understood to govern the interpretation of article 1. In other words, it leaves it to the states parties themselves, in accordance with their own laws and in response to their own norms, both ethical and political, which govern their law-making authorities, to determine when a human being comes into existence. That fills out a little more what is contained in the advice to Senator Harradine in answer to his fourth question. I think it is the correct answer and I think I have given Senator Harradine a little more substance undergirding the answer.
As to the final point as to whether Mr Burdekin was an adviser to the working party, the Hansard record, in a discussion between Senator Harradine, Mr Chapman and me, states:

TALK.START.PARA: —He would have been advising the working party.

—I understand that these delegations are, in fact, Foreign Affairs delegations to which the Human Rights Commissioner, or a member of the Commission, is invited as an aide to the Foreign Affairs delegation to that international conference.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that is the way in which it works. This has been the common practice for some years. It is perhaps a better way of putting it. It seems to be in harmony with the answer given that the Human Rights Commissioner was a special adviser to the Australian delegation to the working group. I hope I have clarified the further points raised by Senator Harradine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —From what the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) has said, no protection is given in the document to the unborn child. That is what it means. There is no protection in the document, as distinct from the Declaration of the Rights of the Child. That is the point I was attempting to make. Mr Burdekin should be answerable to this Parliament about this. When the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act was enacted, I, as well as others, were present in the chamber. There was a deliberate decision to include the Declaration of the Rights of the Child as schedule 3 to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission legislation. Certain rights of the unborn child-although this is only a declaration, without the force of a convention-were clearly recognised in that document. They were recognised in the preamble and in principle 4. Of course, principle 4 is to be read in conjunction with the preamble in respect of the Declaration of the Rights of the Child.

SPEECH.PARA: Surely, it was the responsibility of the Human Rights Commissioner to attempt, because he is governed by this Act of Parliament, to have those provisions placed in the Convention with equal status and force. I am not talking about the status of a declaration as compared with a convention; everybody knows that. I am talking about the schedule of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act and I am talking about the responsibility of the Human Rights Commissioner to ensure that the provisions therein are inserted with equal force and status in the new Convention which replaces the Declaration, and they have not been.

The Minister said, `Yes, there is in the preamble to the new Convention a reference to the Declaration and the words of that Declaration'. The Convention does not even contain those words. The Convention states, in effect, `having in mind the words contained in the Declaration of the Rights of the Child'. That is not good enough. But even taking that into consideration, the Minister now says that there is a statement in the traveaux preparatoires. I know that. I asked what action was taken by the Human Rights Commissioner to ensure that the clauses in the Declaration of the Rights of the Child-the preambular clause and the operative clause-which related to the child's entitlement to grow, et cetera and the child's entitlement to adequate prenatal and post-natal care, were included in the Convention. The Minister has come back with this gobbledegook about the states parties ensuring to the maximum extent possible the survival and development of the child.

I come back to the question: Does that mean the survival and development of the unborn child? Is that what Mr Burdekin is saying? If it is not what he is saying, why did he not give a straightforward answer? I want an answer to my question: what advice did the Human Rights Commissioner give to the working party and officials of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade on the recognition of the rights of the unborn child? Of course I know what happens in these commissions of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. But it was not me who said that the Commissioner was the person who was advised; it was the representative of the Commission itself who said at the Committee that it was a human, and made a big thing about the Human Rights Commissioner being very active in this area. What I want to know and what the Parliament and people are entitled to know is what advice the Human Rights Commissioner gave to the working party on the recognition of the rights of the unborn child. I want to know when and where that advice was given and with what results. Those questions have not been answered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a couple of questions in the business and consumer affairs areas of the Department. First of all, I want to say something about the Trade Practices Commission (TPC) although I am not sure that the Minister would wish to respond. It seems to me that there may be changes in the direction in which the Commission is going. This causes me some concern if only in the sense that the changes appear to be taking place without necessarily ministerial guidance and direction and certainly without the involvement of this Parliament. I congratulate the Trade Practices Commission on its achievements in the past year. It has done a considerable amount of work. It has had several very large inquiries in terms of the use of market power. It has looked at the many merger proposals. It has looked at the resale price maintenance area, unconscionable conduct, unsolicited advertising, and other aspects of fair trading. All that work is to be commended.

SPEECH.PARA: However, as I said at the outset, I am concerned about the impression that I have that the Trade Practices Commission is being diverted from what I would have regarded as its real job, and I will come to that a little later. That is not to say that the matters to which I have just referred are not part of the Commission's real job. The evidence and discussion that we had in the Estimates Committee hearings showed that more and more of the Commission's staff, time and resources are being spent on issues and in areas which the Commission does not have the necessary expertise to consider, analyse and make judgments about, and it is a moot point as to whether it has the legislative backing.

The effect of the encroachment of this new unofficial role on the Trade Practices Commission's work is that there are increasing criticisms-and certainly I get them from industry-that it is stifling the ability of Australian businesses to operate in a free, open and competitive market environment and produce the quality and variety of goods that Australian consumers so rightly expect. Over the last 12 months in particular I have received many representations from individuals both inside and outside industry which raised this concern and it is because of those representations that I raise them here.

There is a perception-accurate or not-in some quarters at least that the Trade Practices Commission seems to be getting involved in anything and everything. In other words, it has been put to me that the Commission is reinterpreting its charter on its own initiative, certainly without the knowledge and involvement of Parliament. This raises the real question of whether the Minister responsible is running the show or whether it is being run by others. I had planned to raise this issue in the Senate Estimates hearings, but at that time, after a couple of questions, it was clear in my view that the Commission was not as broadly represented at the Estimates hearings as it might have been. As a result, it seemed futile to pursue some of the questions that I would have otherwise asked, despite the fact that I had advised the Department of my intentions well in advance. The Minister and I did have some discussions on this matter during the Estimates hearings.

The legislation governing the activities of the Trade Practices Commission, namely the Trade Practices Act 1974, is quite clear about its role. Primarily, the role of the Commission is to administer the Act, which in turn is designed to ensure that competition operates in the marketplace. It is to assess practices in terms of competition issues and, as I understand it, the underlying philosophy of the Act is that if the market is able to work properly and fairly, that will cause consumers' interests to be best served. It is certainly not that anything that is of interest to consumers should necessarily fall within the ambit of the Trade Practices Commission. Essentially, the Commission is meant to be a market competition agency rather than a consumer agency. In more recent years the Commission has become involved in areas which it either does not have the expertise to consider, analyse and make judgments about or in which it possibly lacks legislative backing.

Also it is the case that the Commission is increasingly adopting what I would call elsewhere an anti-consumer consumerist approach, which involves more government regulations and interference, and a greater role for self-appointed consumerist activists, rather than consumers per se. There is a significant difference between the two. The recent inquiry into substitute breast milk has involved a large cost in terms of both money and staff time. There is a question mark over this matter and I would like the Minister to comment, if he is able to do so, as to just where the initiative came from for the Trade Practices Commission-as distinct from the Department of Health-to get involved in that substitute breast milk project. Was it generated from within the Commission, or was it something that was given to the Commission from other sources?

The recent smokeless tobacco judgment is another instance of the TPC getting into areas where it has no experience to adjudicate and again pursuing the anti-consumer consumerist approach. In the smokeless tobacco case I am advised that the Trade Practices Commission's own analysis of the scientific data proved to be inconsistent with its final recommendations. I do not know whether the Minister has any advisers with him or whether he is in a position to comment on that, but that was the advice that I received.

The Commission is also promoting a new form of industry regulation away from self-regulation towards what it describes as co-regulation. I have just received answers to questions that I put during the Estimates hearings, which were not available whilst the hearings were continuing, on exactly what proportion of the Commission's time is spent on this broad area. Last year the figure was 14.8 per cent which, as I understand it, is a significant increase on earlier figures and quite a significant use of the resources of the Commission.

Under the traditional self-regulation system, industry and government work together to devise codes under which the industry will operate. The Trade Practices Commission is the arm of government that assists in that process but, under the new system of co-regulation that is being advocated by both the Commission and some of the consumerist groups, in particular the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations (AFCO) and the Australian Consumers Association, there is an extra element, that is, more groups, particularly some of those consumerist groups, will be involved in the setting up of the codes. My main problem with that-and I would certainly welcome a comment from the Minister-is whether these organisations are really representative of the consumers to which the operations of the code are directed. These groups, particularly AFCO and the Australian Consumers Association, receive virtually all their money from taxpayers. I will not be ungenerous to them, but their approach is essentially an anti-business approach and I really wonder how closely relevant their views and actions are to the real interests of Australian consumers. They are some matters that have concerned me.

I understand that at the present time, and for some time, morale at the Trade Practices Commission has been pretty low. At the Senate Estimates hearings we were told that over the past 12 months the staff turnover has been `something like 50 per cent' and that this is occurring at `all levels'. It is not clear as to the reason for this very high staff turnover and the reason why morale at the Commission is low. I have heard some suggestions that it could be importantly related to this change in direction that the Commission seems to be taking and, if that is the case, they are matters that this Parliament ought, if not be concerned about, at least know just what the background is and what the facts are so that we can be in a position to make considered and reasonable judgments on these matters. Of course, consumer competition policy and practice in Australia is absolutely fundamental not just to the interests of the Australian consumer but also to the future well-being and economic development of the nation, and the Trade Practices Commission has a very important role to play in all of this. I would be very concerned if in fact there was a drift away from its operations which do improve consumer interests and which do improve and increase our competitiveness in an increasingly competitive world. I guess I am making that as a bit of a statement, but I would welcome any response that the Minister can make.

So it is not an internal thing. They are using it officially on their material without any legislative base. I was careful to note the deliberate refusal of the Minister for Justice to agree with what Mr Dickie said in the Estimates Committee about the use of the phrase `non-violent erotica' to describe certain X-rated videos.

I raise this with the Committee now so that the Minister can ensure that the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) is aware of this, so that the Attorney-General, in turn, can ensure that during this publicity campaign the Office of Film and Literature Classification and the Chief Censor do not use that term `non-violent erotica' to describe X-rated videos and desist from using that term in the official publications.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In giving my answer earlier, I was relying on pages E148 and E149 of the transcript of evidence where Mr Dickie, in response to Senator Harradine asking about the use of the term `non-violent erotica', said this:

SPEECH.PARA: These are guidelines which I suppose depict in shorthand form what we consider the material is in each category. The non-violent erotica is a shorthand way of saying what we would regard as material which is an X, which we use as a descriptive . . .
Further on, on page E149, Mr Dickie said this:

Could I just clarify something. We classify material as X. We do not use `non-violent erotica' on the label. If it goes out it has an X category label on it which says, `Completely concerned with sex, not available to people under the age of 18' or whatever it is. `Non-violent erotica' is a shorthand description that we have used ourselves. It does not appear on the labels, or on our classification.

That was the distinction I was trying to convey to the Committee of the Whole earlier. I do not know whether it appears in any other official publication of the Film Board of Review. But my point was that the attempt to use that label as an official guide to those who pick up a video would not be with the sanction of or as authorised by Mr Dickie's team. Nevertheless, I will take up the point that Senator Harradine has made and ensure that a copy of the Hansard containing his latest remarks is brought to the attention of the Chief Censor in relation to the publicity campaign which this Parliament is funding.
Proposed expenditure agreed to.
Sitting suspended from 6.28 to 8 p.m.
Department of Aboriginal Affairs
Proposed expenditure, $462,922,000

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 7 November, about 2 1/2 weeks ago, I visited two Aboriginal communities-the Baryulgil and Malabugilmah communities-in north-eastern New South Wales at the request of members of those communities. I must admit that I was stunned by what I found there even though I had had previous discussions with the members of those two unique Aboriginal communities in Australia. I will discuss their uniqueness in a moment. The experience of 7 November was a fairly profound one for me. I witnessed what I believe is a national and international disgrace in terms of the circumstances in which these people find themselves, the history of those circumstances and the response of government bureaucracies and the Australian community at large to those circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: Most honourable senators will be aware that Baryulgil is an Aboriginal community with between 100 and 150 permanent residents. It has become notable by virtue of the fact that it provided essentially a labour pool for James Hardies asbestos mine located nearby-a mine which began operation in 1942 and operated continuously until 1979-with significant and very grave consequences for those who provided the labour pool in support of that multinational company. For most of that period the members of the community who lived nearby and provided the labour pool were not aware that they were engaging in what is now known to be the extremely hazardous occupation of asbestos mining. Progressively, as they and the authorities have become aware of this, the issue has become increasingly complicated. The Baryulgil community is living with the consequences of having been a labour pool servicing an extremely hazardous occupation.

The other community, Malabugilmah, is a relatively new community which was developed in an attempt to relocate those from Baryulgil. That sincere and genuine attempt to resolve a difficult situation unfortunately has failed and has somewhat compounded the difficulties confronting the 200 or so people who live permanently in the area a little north-west of Grafton, a little south-west of Lismore and in the foothills of the Washpool State Forest-for the benefit of those who are not sure of the geography of those communities. They are isolated Aboriginal communities. Traditionally, they see this as their place but they have been subjected to the arrival of pastoralists, foresters and miners, and they have accommodated the impact of all those influences upon their traditional lifestyle.

I am being quite sincere when I say that this is truly a national and international tragedy because I believe that what has unfolded in that community, particularly during the 1960s and 1970s, was tantamount to slavery. We had people servicing the needs of a multinational company which was mining similar substances in other countries, including South Africa. I have it on reasonable advice that the conditions which prevailed in the mines in this community in the 1960s and 1970s were inferior to those which prevailed in other mines, for instance, those in South Africa. I do not believe that we can shy away from the social and economic realities that existed at that time; nor can we shy away from the subsequent implications as a result of what those people experienced. The results are: a debilitated community in terms of health; a community which has attempted genuinely to resolve its problems, which has found itself interfacing with a wide range of government departments, both Federal and State, but has not had its problems resolved satisfactorily; a community in which many are ill; a community which is divided in terms of its location; a community that is living in a hazardous environment; a community that is disillusioned; a community that is frustrated; and a community that is increasingly angry.

My purpose in introducing this matter in the context of the appropriations is that there could not be a more appropriate context in which to pose the following series of questions: What is the Government doing about this problem? What resources are being directed towards it? If no resources are being allocated, why not? If they are, what is their magnitude, and what is the expected outcome from their expenditure? That is a series of legitimate questions to put in the context of the appropriations debate. I do not intend to cut the question short; I intend to extend the discussion. Members of the Baryulgil community have come here to listen to it. I have deliberately primed the community to hear the outcome of this discussion because I believe the time has come-it has a lot to do with time because time is the essence in this whole process-for some effective action. There has been a lot of talk but very little outcome. I do not doubt the sincerity of the words and the endeavours; I am just citing the fact that there has been very little effective action to address the very real problems confronting the people of these two communities.

I have said, by way of background, that the mine was established in 1942 and continued to operate until 1979. The James Hardie company operated the mine for most of that time and employed in excess of 400 people. The community that provided and serviced that labour requirement has been located somewhat less than a kilometre away from the site of the now disused mine. It is, on the judgment of all those who have been there, an environmental hazard and will remain so until effective measures and steps are taken to rectify it.

So serious was the problem that a House of Representatives committee looked into it and tabled a report in October 1984. The title of the report was The Effects of Asbestos Mining on the Baryulgil Community. The committee was chaired by Mr Gerry Hand who was then a backbencher but is now the Minister responsible. He obviously has an intimate knowledge of the difficulties of this community. Mr Hand has told me that he had a personal commitment to the community. I do not doubt that. The realities are that nothing is happening. It may well be a function of the lack of resources-a lack of the dollars that we are talking about here tonight-or a function of numerous other things. There is no doubt that none of the 10 recommendations which are in the first two pages of the preliminary section of this report has been effectively implemented. They raise a whole series of difficulties. The first recommendation touches upon a very real dimension of the problem. It reads:
That the Attorneys-General of the Commonwealth and NSW consider ways and means whereby the technical difficulties presented by Aboriginality in seeking compensation may be removed.

I cite the words `difficulties presented by Aboriginality'. There is an acknowledgment in the first recommendation that these people are in a unique situation. In the first recommendation the uniqueness of their situation focuses on the question of achieving compensation. I believe that the uniqueness of being Aboriginal in this country pervades everything that has flowed from the circumstances in Baryulgil. The second recommendation-which is at the end of a lot of documented, thorough evidence-is:

That the Commonwealth establish an Aboriginal Medical Service based in Grafton to cater for the general health needs of the local Aboriginal communities and having expertise in the diagnosis and management of asbestos-related diseases.

That has not happened. There is no health service there after five years. I know there are reasons why there is no health service. I ask whether there is any allocation in the $493m under this heading in appropriations to establish the health service in Grafton? If so, how many dollars? What health service is envisaged? When is it envisaged that it will be on the ground? I will continue to ask questions about all aspects of the provision of the health service. The report then goes into a series of recommendations which compound the whole issue, and many of them are similar. It involves the Commonwealth Minister for Aboriginal Affairs recommending to the New South Wales Government the passing of legislation. It is extraordinary that a community should find itself dependent upon the recommendation of a Commonwealth Minister to a State Government. The fourth recommendation attempts to resolve the problem of what is called Baryulgil Square and its leasing. It is a matter of whether the Aborigines have the right to consider it theirs, under what conditions, for what period of time and how many of them would have the right. The third and fourth recommendations involve the Commonwealth Minister for Aboriginal Affairs recommending to the New South Wales Government that it offer a lease to certain Aborigines; in other words, that they deal with the Square problem. The fifth recommendation is:
That the Commonwealth Department of Aboriginal Affairs continue to use every effort to persuade the residents of Baryulgil Square to move . . .

Encouraging people to move to another location simply compounded the whole issue. If such a move were not done voluntarily and effectively, it would create a series of difficult spin-offs. I put to the Minister the first of a series of questions. It focuses on the second recommendation for an Aboriginal health service. Does any appropriation focus on the establishment of an Aboriginal health service in Grafton? If so, what is the amount of the appropriation; in what time frame will it be expended; and what will be delivered at the end of that expenditure?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, a health worker is employed at Baryulgil Square to improve community access to general health services. That has been in place for some two years at a cost of $59,300. I am surprised that Senator McLean does not appear to know that. As I understand it, there is an appropriation for that to continue during the course of this financial year. The health worker services that community. Quite clearly, the question of health services is a very difficult but important one. Senator McLean will know that over a three-year period some $36,000 was spent on a survey. That comprehensive medical survey final report was made available in September 1988. It recommended the establishment of a service, although earlier reports had noted that many community members were happy with the general public health facilities available, provided that transport to these facilities could be improved.

SPEECH.PARA: I note as a supplementary matter that in response to representations the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs approached the State Health Minister when it was suggested that the Bonalbo Hospital might close. That hospital is the closest facility to many of the communities in that area and it was agreed that the hospital should remain open. At the moment final proposals are under consideration although a view has developed that the proposed medical service might best be based at Bonalbo Hospital rather than Grafton. It is also important to note that the State Government has established a dedicated Aboriginal health team working from the Grafton hospital to service communities in the valley. The position in regard to the honourable senator's more specific question is that there is funding to allow the employment of a health worker and that health worker conducts a service for the community at Baryulgil Square.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The community at Baryulgil is not convinced that the process of establishing an effective health service is under way, even after five years. Some 600-plus people would be involved if a survey was made of the state of health of that community. Approximately 400-odd people worked in the mines; in addition, there were those who lived in the environment and those who now live in it. I understand that health officers have carried out a partial survey and that 84 people have been medically examined to varying degrees. Of those 84 people, 14 have been diagnosed as having complaints which could reasonably be described as asbestos related. It has been argued to me outside this place that that is a sufficient sample to arrive at a conclusion about the health state of that community. I am not prepared to accept that.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been asked, for instance, to put up evidence about the health state of that community. The real evidence is literally buried in the cemetery at Baryulgil. The report mentions that 100 people may have died as a result of diseases contracted from working in the mines, but none of us will ever know the realities. It has been suggested that because I cannot cite a series of autopsies, I cannot provide the sort of hard evidence required. A number of autopsies have been done, but only recently. The culture of the Aboriginal people does not readily accept that practice. Perhaps I cannot provide hard evidence, but there is sufficient evidence around to establish clearly a relationship between exposure to asbestos, whether blue or white, and the occurrence of diseases, particularly diseases of the lungs. The authorities have been constantly revising the figures about levels of safe exposure. Constantly, for 30 years, the figures have been revised downwards as to what is considered to be a safe level of exposure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Government contesting the health risk? Is that what you are telling us?
—I do not believe that the Government is contesting the health risk. The Government has acknowledged the health risk. But others are contesting the health risk.
—Of course we accept the health risk.

—Okay, the Government has acknowledged the health risk and it has indicated the need to undertake a health service. I am really saying that the health service is not being satisfactorily established. I am being told that the first step is to establish the need by survey. I am being told that the survey has been, or is being, done. I do not think that the survey has produced valid answers as yet and may never do so. Nor do I believe that an effective health service has been established.

SPEECH.PARA: I have taken a count from a list of the names and have come up with approximately 418 persons who have lived or worked in the environment. I think that this list was compiled by the people to whom the Minister has referred but I am not sure. However, I think that this list is the outcome. Of those 418 people, my rough calculation is that 80 per cent have never been medically examined and approximately 20 per cent have. The final calculation may be a slight variation on that.

My simple point is that the surveying that has been done to date is inadequate. It has not impacted upon the community at large to establish what its needs are. It certainly has not convinced the community at large that its risks are being acknowledged seriously and taken seriously. Nor has it given rise to a health centre at Grafton which is proposed in recommendation 2. That health centre does not exist at the relocated community at Malabugilmah, even though it is shown on the grand plan for Malabugilmah. It is not there. People visiting Malabugilmah will see that it is a disaster. The plans did not happen. Virtually none of the things that were proposed for the relocated centre has happened. So these people are frustrated about the health centre. The Minister has quoted a figure of $56,000 expended so far on employing people to do a survey which I suggest has not produced the realities and it will not produce them at that pace in the next three years. It will not give rise to an effective health centre possibly within the next five years.

Time is of the essence. For some of these people time is ticking away and it is valuable and precious because they have advancing diseases. We do not know the dimension of the medical problem within the community. Frankly, I am not convinced by the Minister's response to this first dimension which is the dimension of health. I have been to the community. I believe that the people are living in a disastrous environment. A person can literally pick up handfuls of asbestos dust. I did so two weeks ago. The preschool, in fact the whole village, is built on what is appropriately called shivers. It is a chilling expression. The reality is that the Square was filled with asbestos waste. The preschool is built on it. The residences are built on it. The roads are made out of it. It leaches off the mine site into the water supply.

These people are assured, of course, that their water supply is not contaminated and that they will not suffer any ill effect by the leaching off the mine site into the creek which supplies them with water. Twenty years ago when it was being established that asbestos was a dangerous substance these people were told that white asbestos did not affect Aborigines. They are very reluctant to accept this statement that their water supply will not be contaminated. They are very reluctant to accept the statement that the site has been adequately rehabilitated. They are very reluctant to accept the assurances that, provided the kids do not disturb the school yard, which has been covered with about two inches of topsoil, with their shoes, bare feet, fingers or sticks or whatever else or dig down to the actual asbestos dust beneath it, they are not at risk. They are very reluctant to accept these assurances because they were told that white asbestos does not affect Aboriginal people.

I believe that whole dimensions are operating within this community which are not adequately being addressed by statistics or bureaucratic regulation. They cannot be addressed by those things. I am suggesting that a whole new psyche needs to be applied to resolve this problem if we are to come to grips with what we actually have in Baryulgil and relocated communities.
I would now like to move onto a further recommendation. Recommendation 5 states:

That the Commonwealth Department of Aboriginal Affairs continue to use every effort to persuade the residents of Baryulgil Square to move to another site removed from any risk to health from the Baryulgil mine site.

In other words, the solution to the problem is for the people to move. That flies in the face of the very culture of these people and the way that they think about place and location. It shows a total lack of sensitivity. I accept the recommendation as being a very rational suggestion in some respects. But how do we apply every effort to get the people to relocate. The suggestion was that a new community would be built away from the school, away from the shops, away from the things that are required.

A plan was produced which had a swimming pool, a playing field, a sports centre, a health centre, a preschool and housing but those things were never delivered. They were never put on the ground. Otherwise the people might have actually moved. I was at Baryulgil Square two weeks ago speaking to the senior member of that community-a 79-year-old woman-who said, `When I was asked to move I had to make a decision'. She said, `I either have got the disease now or I have not got it. If I have it, I will not get up to move from my place to another place'. So she chose, like many of the others, not to move. Surely that was a predictable reaction. This woman told me, and I accept it, that she was told that if she did not leave her social security benefits would be terminated. I suppose that that could be seen reasonably to be the Commonwealth Department of Aboriginal Affairs continuing to use every effort to persuade. That is what this woman told me. She said, `Take my social security benefits if you have to. I have done without them for a part of my life and I can do without them again for the latter part of my life'. These sorts of methods of persuasion did not have effect. My understanding is that in excess of $1m-I cannot see it on the ground and I have been there-was spent on relocating this community.

There are 17 houses in that relocated situation but none of the other amenities. The 17 houses are so badly constructed that they were the subject of a question and an answer in the Estimates Committee hearings which I will return to later. The houses are actually falling apart. I am not talking about the criticism that is often made of the people who occupy these dwellings. It has nothing to do with that; it does have something to do with the actual construction of the buildings. The buildings are literally falling apart. That was acknowledged in the responses to the Estimates Committee. The people who have gone there are now saying, `What on earth are we doing in this hell?'. Honourable senators should see it. It is an appalling situation. The people want to go back to their place, and so the community is divided about even where it wants to live. These are the realities.

My next question is: How many dollars are in these appropriations to rebuild the buildings that are at Malabugilmah? How many dollars are in the appropriations to proceed to the stage of making Malabugilmah a community that they will identify with? How many dollars are in these appropriations to resolve the problems of the Baryulgil Square? If the dollars are not there, why are they not there? The strategy flowing from recommendations 4 and 5 of this report has failed tragically. There are now 17 disintegrating homes in Malabugilmah. The place is littered with stripped cars that are in the middle of the roads. People cannot drive on the formed roads but have to drive off the road onto the footpath to get around the wrecked cars. We are talking about a community that has 100 per cent unemployment. The tactic used to try to get the people to relocate was, I am told by the senior member of that community-and I must accept it-to threaten to withdraw the one lifeline the people have. I know what views are out there in the Australian community about those lifelines, but that is beside the point. It is another issue again. The second dimension of this tragedy is the attempt to relocate. My second group of questions concerns redressing or addressing the problem of relocation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question of relocation is obviously an extremely difficult one. If it were merely a matter of dollars, I suppose governments might have solved it prior to this date. As I understand it, when Senator Peter Baume, in good faith, devised the idea of this alternative living site at Malabugilmah, some residents chose to move but a core group decided to remain. I know that Senator Peter Baume has said in this Parliament before that, whilst he has gone down and pleaded and tried to point out that a move would be in the best health interests of the persons concerned, obviously all he can do, all a government can do, is point out the fact that an alternative site is available. The rights of those who wish to continue to live at Baryulgil Square cannot be simply overridden. I suppose the houses could not be bulldozed out, as might have happened in Romania, where the villages were bulldozed in the name of socialist reconstruction. Hungarian villages in particular were bulldozed and people moved into what were judged by the authorities to be better living conditions. I understand that core members of the Aboriginal community at Baryulgil still hold very strongly a wish to stay there. To a certain extent, although I do not in any sense mean it as a matter of blame, the provision of infrastructure upgrading at the Square further encourages people to stay rather than letting it absolutely deteriorate. It is a very difficult question. The more we help to improve living conditions at the Square, the less likely it is that people will wish to move. I do not know exactly how we can overcome that particular problem.

SPEECH.PARA: There are difficulties at Malabugilmah. I understand that now many of the residences and other buildings are proving to have been built in a way which is structurally unsound, with unsound foundations or on land which is giving way. The Government has provided funds for engineering surveys to be undertaken in order that a reconstruction program, if required, is based on the best possible advice rather than a piecemeal attempt to shore up every structural defect which manifests itself. The situation obviously requires a more comprehensive approach, and the engineering survey is being funded.

As I understand it, the question of the water supply has also been a worry to the residents, who fear a health hazard created by the existing water supply, the take-off point for which is below the mine site. I am advised that no technical evidence exists to support that claim. However, to ensure the safety and peace of mind of the residents of Malabugilmah, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs has agreed to move the water take-off point to a position above the mine site. Work on relocation of the water take-off point will commence this financial year and the Department has set aside $100,000 for these works and for the installation of filtration equipment. That is a positive attempt to deal with what must be a very real worry if people think that a water supply, which obviously is fundamental and crucial to any community, might be contaminated. Those steps are being taken.

To go back to some earlier remarks Senator McLean repeated about the health service, a series of community meetings have been held concerning the provision of an Aboriginal controlled health service. We have encouraged these sorts of meetings to be held. Funds of $6,000 were provided to engage the Biripi Aboriginal Medical Service on behalf of the Aboriginal communities to prepare a detailed plan and costings for the establishment of a service and those other proposals which are presently under consideration. As I say, some people have developed the view that Bonalbo hospital, rather than Grafton, might be the best base for such a medical service. At the moment, as I say, a dedicated Aboriginal health team working from the Grafton hospital services communities in the valley.

A lot is happening, but the fundamental difficulty of requiring people to move is one which governments approach with some trepidation for some of the reasons which Senator McLean mentioned. The idea that social security benefits might be withdrawn from a person at the behest of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs if he or she did not move is something which the officers here find to be anathema and it is not within the jurisdiction of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs to make a determination as to social security benefit and entitlement to it. With my present responsibilities in this chamber, there is no knowledge of such an inducement or threat being held over a person in relation to whether he or she chooses to move from the Square.

Senator McLean is not the first to raise these matters in the chamber. In May this year Senator Peter Baume engaged in a fairly lengthy exposition-as well he might, because he would be more aware than most of the problems at Baryulgil, given the solutions he tried to find when he was Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I am not trying to say that we do not need to do more. Quite clearly the health problems are such that much is required to be done. But in relation to the asbestos health risks and the damage which has been suffered by persons who were either engaged in the mines or living in the village nearby, the Government has attempted to aid those persons in their various litigation attempts to sheet home responsibility for the death and disease which may have been occasioned by the asbestos to which they were exposed.

The Aboriginal Legal Service of New South Wales has provided very substantial funds-$677,134 at last count-to allow for these particular claims against those who are responsible to be processed. As I understand it, it is handling 11 cases. The first cases have advanced through the technical hurdle of the statutory limitations period. Recent New South Wales legislation now requires cases to be presented to the Dust Diseases Tribunal. I believe that the sum of money outlined indicates that there is a very real commitment by the Aboriginal Legal Service to try to help these people to obtain compensation where it is their due for the diseases they may have contracted as a result of exposure to asbestos.

There are many facets to this problem. Expenditure is being made in the way that Senator McLean appears to desire, namely, to make Malabugilmah a more attractive place and to provide it with clean water. A program is under way with engineering consultants to ensure that there is a comprehensive response to the deterioration of the structure of that community. It cannot be said that the Federal Government is indifferent to the fate of this community. It is not simply a responsibility of the Federal Government, nor is it entirely within its power to resolve. There is the Federal Government, there is the State Government, there are the employers, the owners and the people who are working at the mine, and of course there is the community itself. Many factors have to be taken into account and many human beings and organisations need to cooperate to help remedy this situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with the Minister. I raised this matter in the Senate on 26 May. What I said is to be found on page 2824 of the Hansard. I will not repeat the facts I set out there. I drew attention then, as Senator McLean is drawing attention now, to the 1984 report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs and, like Senator McLean, I asked questions about when those recommendations would be put into effect, given that they would have an effect. I was the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs at the time that the village was moved. If Senator McLean wishes to criticise the decision, as I think he has done, by saying that it may have been an imposed decision and that we did not understand the people's desire not to move away from their place, I will take the criticism. If he wants to say that the place was badly built during the time I was Minister, I will accept that criticism. I will not patronise any honourable senator here and I do not expect to be patronised, either.

SPEECH.PARA: I was the Minister at that time. The decision was taken by me as Minister that Malabugilmah should be developed so that the people of Baryulgil Square could move. That decision was taken because the people there asked me to do this. Senator McLean should understand that I was responding to a request made by people who lived at Baryulgil Square. They took me down the road to Malabugilmah and said, `This is where we want the village'. Let us at least acknowledge that what was done was in response to Aboriginal wishes. If the site was wrong, then it was a decision taken by a Minister responding to an Aboriginal community and, quite properly, as Senator McLean says, to a disgraceful situation of which the Woodsreef people and Hardies really should be ashamed. I agree with him. The village was then built. I went to the opening of that village. It was a great gala occasion. I inspected the houses. There was no complaint then about the quality of the construction. That obviously would have developed and emerged.

I remember that as Minister I transferred the housing function from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, which I administered, to the Aboriginal Development Commission. I cannot remember whether it was in 1981 or 1982, but I did it during that period, as functions could be transferred. The function was subsequently exercised by the Aboriginal Development Commission. If blame is to be apportioned, some of it would be departmental, but those officers sitting in the advisers box tonight are good officers, and the Department they administered was a good Department. I will not be part of any criticism which indirectly applies to them.

Senator McLean has asked why people stayed on at the Square. It is a perfectly proper question. It was not just a question of Aboriginal affinity with the land. The whole story is a disaster. The original mine tailings were used to level out the Square and shacks were built there. I share Senator McLean's concern about that. But why did people stay there? First, we could not force them off the land. We were not in the business of telling people they had to go. Secondly, the accommodation provided at Malabugilmah was all taken up-every place was taken up. There was not enough to re-house all the people from the Square. The proposal was that there be a progressive construction scheme. I do not argue with the honourable senator, who said that construction did not continue. But people moved into the houses that had been vacated in the Square. They moved in from Tabulam and surrounding villages where there was an Aboriginal population. If we made one gross error it was that we did not come in with tractors and push the shacks over as each family moved out. We made an error, because they were occupied by other Aboriginals who moved in from other places who could not get housing. That new people moved back in is part of the picture of the tragedy of Baryulgil Square.

There is some legitimate criticism that that should have been possible, but there was another reason why people stayed on at the Square. The Baryulgil Square Cooperative had legal advice from a solicitor whose name I believe, from memory, was Ms Vivienne Abraham. What the Committee may wish to recall-Senator McLean has quite correctly drawn attention to the Washpool Forest and to the area-is that further up the Clarence River there is a property called Columm Columm Station, which was owned by the Baryulgil Square Cooperative. The question was: To whom would the title pass? The legal advice being given was that the Baryulgil Square Cooperative should remain because the title to Columm Columm Station, the jewel, was in question. I was not going to interfere with that advice. There was a major question as to who owned this property and we had to try to sort it out. Again, it was a matter between the Aboriginal Development Commission, the Baryulgil Square Cooperative, the Malabugilmah people and the Department. It was a very complex matter. I believe that before it was finalised-I cannot recall now-I may have left the portfolio.

I agree with the major thrust of Senator McLean's contribution that for 40 or 50 years the whole operation was a disgrace. The fact that there were children in a school which was having asbestos fibre blown in every day, that people were living in shacks built on asbestos tailings and that the company involved has done as little as it could for as long as it could, is disgraceful. Senator McLean's concern for the people is absolutely correct.

I cannot understand why the Government has not responded more adequately to the 1984 report-this is what I brought up in May-since Mr Hand himself was involved in the production of that report; in fact, I think he was the Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs. If the recommendations were ones in which he believed when he produced the report, then they were recommendations to which he could give effect when he became the Minister.

I notice that Senator Jenkins also spoke on this matter on 25 May. She was wrong on one small point. During her speech she said that a particular complication, pleural mesothelioma, was a complication of asbestos. She is quite correct. She said that it was first reported in South Africa. She then said:
In 1962 the first case of pleural mesothelioma was diagnosed outside South Africa, in an ex-Wittenoom mill worker, as reported by Dr McNulty.

Just for the record, I also used to write for the medical journals in those days and my case report was in 1960, I believe, so the honourable senator is wrong on that. We had reported. We knew what pleural mesothelioma was then. We understood the relation to asbestos exposure and that is why, when I became Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the first major ministerial initiative I took was to go to Baryulgil and, in response to the wish of the residents there, arrange to have the Malabugilmah village built where they indicated that they wanted it built. That events have been protracted and that some of the outcomes have been negative should distress us all.

I say to Senator McLean that the history is more complicated, more complex and more interwoven than I think he understood. However, that does not take away from his concern now that the recommendations of that House of Representatives Committee should be put into effect. I have no doubt that Aboriginal people will be dying as a result of their asbestos exposure. All the rules of justice and all our ideas of fairness should demand that they be promptly, generously and effectively compensated: if necessary, we should be overgenerous. We should not even fight on this matter. It is a matter which is so disgraceful that the amounts of money involved are almost insignificant. I have to say that when I spoke on 26 May Mr Hand was on the phone five minutes later asking me to have a cup of tea and talk it over. If he is listening now, I just say to him, `No cups of tea tonight, please. Let us just get some action on the 1984 House of Representatives Committee report'. On that I am arm in arm with Senator McLean. Something has to be done and it is long overdue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to respond to a number of points made by the Minister and by Senator Peter Baume. Let me take Senator Peter Baume's points first. I read his presentation to the Senate in the Hansard of 26 May and I noted and discussed with him one sentence, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Many honourable senators collect trophies and the one of which I am proudest is a photo in my office of the tree under which we negotiated with the Aboriginal community the agreement which led to the establishment of Malabugilmah village.

I accept the pride which would be associated with having arrived at that agreement with the community. What I am really challenging-and I said this to Senator Peter Baume earlier in discussion this evening-is that if he went back to that village now, as I did two weeks ago, he would still feel that way. I am afraid that that pride would be considerably dented. I do not deny the integrity and the sincerity of the officers. I am not wishing to cast aspersions on the officers or on the Ministers involved, but I still say that if the officers of the Department went to Baryulgil and Malabugilmah today I do not believe they would be proud of what is on the ground there and what has been achieved by their Department. Good, committed and devoted as those officers are, I do not believe that they would feel pride. We simply have to face the realities. It is not something to be proud of. In fact, as Senator Peter Baume has just said, it is a disgrace.

I do not really believe that the strategy to relocate was a wrong strategy; I think Senator Baume misunderstood me when I said that. I do not believe that it was a wrong strategy at all; it just was not carried through to fruition. What the people were really saying was, `We accept the concept of an adequate alternative site'. They were promised an adequate alternative site but they have got a grossly inadequate alternative site. I had dinner this evening with members of the community and I put this question directly to them: Would Malabugilmah be an acceptable alternative if it were an adequately prepared alternative? The answer was, `Of course it is'. But it is not adequate in its present disgraceful condition. It is utterly disgraceful.

A question suggested by Senator Baume-thank heavens!-and posed by Senator Tambling on his behalf to the Estimates Committee actually concerned the present state of the buildings in this alternative home-this place that was offered to the community. As I said earlier, the realities are that the buildings are a disgrace. They are falling down and we are now involved in a legal argument as to who is responsible for this disaster. Legal advice is being sought and given left, right and centre as to who are the culprits. We cannot even get an answer to the question of what the average cost of the 17 buildings was. It has been suggested that when they were built eight years ago the average cost might have been in the vicinity of $125,000 each. Somebody was on a damn good lurk if that was the figure eight years ago in the backblocks of north-eastern New South Wales. The figures I have been quoted are somewhere between $85,000 and $125,000 per unit cost. Even if it cost $85,000 eight years ago to construct buildings that are now a disgrace-we cannot even legally establish who was responsible for the disgrace in response to questions from Senator Peter Baume, through Senator Tambling, to the Estimates Committee a few days ago-that in itself warrants our attention and only compounds the frustration of the people who were seeking, agreeing to and hoping for an adequate alternative site in which they could recover from what was nothing short of an environmental and social disaster for them.

My point simply is that that strategy has not worked and I am asking: What dollars have been appropriated to rectify that failed strategy? I am asking whether that strategy will actually be continued. It may not be an unreasonable thing to recover from where the community is now. In fact, I think I would agree with Senator Peter Baume that that probably is the best of the options, but it will cost a lot of dollars to pursue it if it is the best of the options. What I am really asking is this: are those dollars in this appropriation? Are the dollars there to reconstruct the 17 buildings, to provide the other things that were on the plan eight years ago for the adequate alternative site?

Of course, people are now returning to Baryulgil Square. They are returning not only from Malabugilmah, a few kilometres away, but also from places such as Redfern. These people assemble in families and at various stages of their lives they move around, reassemble, regroup and re-relate to one another. It is their culture. The Mundine family's place is in Baryulgil Square and they are reassembling there. The problem is being compounded even more. I really do have a perception of the history of the problem and the complexities of the problem. I say to Senator Peter Baume that I do not accept that criticism. Albeit only recently, I have done quite a bit of reading, looking, listening and talking. I think I have a sense of the complexities of the problem.

I return to some of the observations made by the Minister concerning the medical service. The medical service has gone into a closed loop; it is not happening. The nature of this closed loop is very frustrating to members of the Baryulgil community. They are now being told that, if by establishing a steering committee they decide where this medical centre is going to be located, then it will happen. The recommendation of the 1984 report was that it happen in Grafton. That was very specific and very clear and it did not happen. That steering committee has now been landed with supposedly responsible decisions based on supposedly adequate surveys which I would question anyway. If it decided tomorrow that it wanted the medical centre in Grafton or in Malabugilmah, are the dollars available in this appropriation to put it there? If not, why not? That is a reasonable question.

This proposal has been on the books for five years. One would imagine that it has been a proposal in the appropriations for five years. If it is not in this year's appropriations, these people reasonably ask: why not? They believe it is because they are being conned. The expression used to me by members of that community is that they are out of sight and out of mind. They personally question whether there is any serious intention to deliver the recommendations of this report in the foreseeable future. Therefore on their behalf I pose the question: where are the dollars for this promised medical service? Where are the dollars in these appropriations for this promised adequate alternative site? I put that question bluntly now and ask for an answer before we move on to the other recommendations of the 1984 report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not going to be bludgeoned by Senator McLean into answering questions that he wants to put bluntly. I will answer a series of matters that he raised. He does not seem to want to listen. He talks about the derelict buildings and the structural deficiencies and asks why we are not building houses. It would be stupid to go in with a building program before we had the result of the engineering survey which I said we are undertaking at the moment with our dollars in order to understand those structural defects and to ensure that we do not go ahead with some piecemeal solution which does not address what must obviously be an underlying problem. When that engineers' report is received and assessed, then quite obviously steps will be taken. That is one point.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator McLean does not seem to want to acknowledge the other matter of the expenditure of $100,000 to relocate the existing water supply to reduce the fear of contamination of that very important and crucial part of community life. It should have access to a water supply in which it has confidence. In relation to the housing, it is not true that they are all eight years old. As Senator Peter Baume said, as Minister he transferred responsibility for the provision of housing from the Department to the Aboriginal Development Commission. I am advised that in 1982-83 it spent $330,000 on five houses and in 1984 it spent $251,000 on four houses. I think that, just roughly, that works out to something like $60,000 or a little more for each house. I do not know where Senator McLean got his original figures from. Did he get them from a record or are they just speculation? If they are as large as he mentioned, it might be that the cost includes initial engineering works. I just do not know. But they are the costs of the houses that were constructed in 1982-83 and 1984. There is no current funding available for housing. As I said, it would be extraordinarily foolish to undertake that at the moment before we get the structural engineer's report.

In relation to the question of health services, the community has been asked-I am glad Senator Mclean has acknowledged it at last; I mentioned it in my remarks-to give its considered view on this matter. It has been asked to deliberate on the matter rather than to have an imposed solution, even one which commended itself to a committee of the House of Representatives. I think I said during my remarks that there was something of a view developing that perhaps the proposed medical service might be best based at Bonalbo hospital rather than Grafton. If the community would state its position and if there were agreement, I am quite sure that would be something governments would listen to. In the meantime, despite Senator McLean's remarks, I believe that there is a health service being provided, although not as was envisaged and not as the community is trying to work towards. We fund the health worker. Pressure has been put on the Government of New South Wales to keep open the Bonalbo hospital, which I understand provides many facilities to the communities there. These are matters which have been undertaken by this Government, as has been the engagement of the Biripi Aboriginal Medical Service, to assist the local community in coming to a detailed plan and costings for the establishment of the service.

There is a lot happening. This is not to say that we have in any way reached a satisfactory resolution of the matter. I thank Senator Peter Baume for his extremely interesting historical survey of the problems of the establishment of the alternative living area, the alternative village. It throws further light on the difficulty we have in a society such as ours when these people, for reasons however strong, speak of family ties, the regrouping of the Square and so on. Nevertheless, there is a danger in their being there which is a factor that has to be balanced against their cultural or familial ties. It just shows the complexity and extreme difficulty of this whole situation which is not uncommon in many fields of human life. When we tell people about the danger of smoking tobacco cigarettes they nevertheless continue to smoke or take up the habit of smoking. It is extremely difficult to deal with human beings individually or as communities, and this is a classic instance of that.

The final solution is to try to listen to the community. It has been asked to make a recommendation as to the Aboriginal controlled health service that might be provided. When that is done, no doubt there will be a proper consideration of the moneys that might be made available. Whether they should be totally made available from the Federal Government or the State government is a matter which I have not considered. Quite clearly, if the matter is put to governments by a cohesive community, then governments will respond. The provision of such a health service is obviously a matter of absolute priority.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must confess at the outset that I have not been to Baryulgil; so I have not inspected the site. However, I have worked in occupational health for a number of years and I am well aware that in a number of instances private companies and government departments have been quite disrespectful of the health of the people who work for them. Perhaps the most extreme example of this lack of concern about workers' health is seen in the asbestos industry, not only here but in other parts of the world. I think fellow senators will have seen the Four Corners program several weeks ago which dealt not with this particular mine site but with several other mine sites and specifically with the operations of James Hardie Industries Ltd. Of course, the occupational problems of asbestos relate not only to the mining of it but also to the milling and processing of it.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose one could start by making the general statement that parliaments and governments do have a responsibility to care for the health and welfare of their people and also the welfare of their environment. In the case of asbestos that simply has not happened, and has not happened over a very long period. If one looks at the experience overseas, one finds abundant evidence from early in the century that asbestos was capable of causing chronic respiratory disease. Indeed, I think it is fair to say that until about the end of the First World War none of those exposed to asbestos in an occupational capacity survived long enough to develop cancer because the level of exposures was so high. It is perhaps ironic that we only learned about the links between asbestos and cancer when the exposure of workers fell to such a level that enough workers survived long enough to develop cancers.

When I spoke on this issue in May I pointed out that, to my knowledge, the first case for worker's compensation in relation to asbestos exposure was heard in the United States in, I think, 1906. So the claim which has been made by the owners of the mines and, indeed, sustained to a large extent by governments and government departments that the links between asbestos and ill-health are not proven is simply not founded and smacks of the same sort of doublespeak that one hears from the tobacco industry in relation to lung cancer and smoking.
I think it is worth while dealing with a little of the data which comes from a paper in relation to Wittenoom.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. I very rarely interrupt a senator and ask for some relevance to the estimates to be observed, but this seems to be a very long preliminary to whatever point Senator Coulter might be getting to. It seems to me that there is a general understanding in the chamber of the problem of asbestos related diseases, and I am sure that we would benefit from it being related more specifically to the plight of the Aboriginal communities on Baryulgil Square. With all due respect, I feel that, if we can stick to what is a long committee consideration of the estimates on this particular problem, we might advance a bit quicker.

—On the point of order, I am speaking specifically to recommendation No. 1. We are looking at the recommendations of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs. I wish to develop the argument that that recommendation cannot be and is not being properly implemented at the present time, and it is more appropriate for the Government to develop a different strategy in relation to that recommendation.

—I have listened carefully to the beginning of your contribution, Senator Coulter, and indeed to the preceding debate for the last hour and a quarter. I do uphold Senator Tate's appeal. The question that is before this Committee concerns the appropriations. In particular, the question is that the vote be now passed without requests. Senator McLean has raised a particular question with regard to health provision and a particular question with regard to housing provision. The fact that he has referred to asbestos, occupational diseases or even to a House of Representatives report does not, in my view, open up, as it were, a Pandora's box of debate about those matters. The point of relevance is that we are dealing with the appropriations and the motion that is in fact before the Committee. I take the occasion of the Minister's raising of a point of order to ask all senators who contribute to confine their remarks and make their remarks directly relevant to the question that is before the Committee. I ask Senator Coulter to continue and to be as relevant as he can within those guidelines.

—I wish to address my remarks to a point made by the Minister in reply to one of Senator McLean's questions, that is, the amount of money which this Government has paid and the amount of money which, inevitably, the Government and others will have to pay for the legal defence of Aboriginal people in relation to this matter. That is the point that I wish to develop. I would like a ruling as to whether I can proceed down that road, because it seems to me that that is important. I am seeking to save the Government a great deal of money.
—In that case continue.
—Senator Coulter may proceed.

—To develop this point, it is necessary to say something-and that is the point I was getting to-about the nature of the diseases from which people who are exposed to asbestos suffer. I want very briefly to deal with several of the figures which come out of a much better reference study-that is, the study of the people who worked at Wittenoom. There were 6,502 males and 410 females in that study. There have already been 94 cases of malignant mesothelioma, 141 cases of lung cancer and 356 successful compensation claims for asbestosis. However, the point I want to make is that it says in this medical study from which I am reading that it is expected that there will be a total of 692 cases between 1987 and the year 2020.

SPEECH.PARA: The nature of the disease is such that one cannot predict beforehand which people exposed to asbestos will eventually go on and develop one of these malignant conditions. Moreover, there is a very long interval, sometimes as long as 40 years or so, between the time of the exposure and the time at which those diseases will manifest themselves. I refer specifically here to the first of the House of Representatives Committee's recommendations in 1984-that the Attorneys-General of the Commonwealth and New South Wales consider ways and means whereby the technical difficulties presented by aboriginality in seeking compensation may be removed.

It is difficult enough for a well-educated European person who understands these things to face the courts and go through a process of proving that his or her particular disease is related to this exposure which occurred a long time in the past. It is extremely more difficult for an Aboriginal person to go down that difficult road. Indeed, if one refers back to the length of time of the hearings in relation to the Wittenoom workers, one finds that there was enormous procrastination. The first case ran in court for 132 days, the second case for 52 days and another one for 30 days. Surely, it is far more desirable for the Government to recognise, and get James Hardie to recognise, that there is a clear link between the exposure to asbestos and the eventual onset of these diseases for a proportion of the population, even though individuals in that proportion cannot at this stage be recognised, and to deal with this as a community problem, provide enough money for that community to address that problem, and not expect individual Aboriginal people who were exposed to go through this very lengthy court process.

The Minister in his earlier reply said that $600,000 had been provided for legal aid. I would suggest that that is a waste of money. It is far better to recognise that a significant proportion of these people-a proportion which can probably now be determined to some extent-will eventually suffer these diseases, and provide, and ensure that James Hardie provides, enough money so that compensation can be addressed now without having to go through that very lengthy and damaging legal process. Therefore, I ask the Minister, in relation to recommendation No. 1, whether he accepts that that would be a better and cheaper solution, and that brings me squarely back to the appropriations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —If a settlement could be reached between the owners of the mine-the employers of the Aboriginals-and the Aboriginals, and their families who might also have been affected because they were living close by, encouraged by governments and, no doubt, by recent decisions of the courts, that, of course, would be an ideal solution. But, as I have already mentioned, these matters fall primarily within State law, whether it be the ordinary rules as to compensation for negligent behaviour which is injurious to a person or, more particularly now, the legislation in New South Wales which requires these matters to be taken through a particular process. I am not familiar with that legislation, but I believe that that is now the case. The Dust Diseases Tribunal in New South Wales is now the forum which recent New South Wales legislation requires to be the proper body to determine these sorts of claims.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a difficult matter. It is not entirely within Federal jurisdiction or responsibility. The primary responsibility, in the legal sense, lies within the legal system devised under common law or under the aegis of the State Parliament. Nevertheless, Senator Coulter has raised a point which may well commend itself to James Hardie in particular, as it contemplates the various rulings of the courts-or, at least, the settlements which, I understand from the Four Corners program, it has already reached with myriad people.

Senator Coulter is not quite making that point.
