As I understand it, he is making the point that, rather than individual settlements being made with those who claim to have been adversely affected, a more general compensation package, perhaps worked out on a statistical basis but nevertheless available to all members of the community who were present at the relevant time, should be made available. In that regard perhaps a copy of the Hansard record could be made available not only to the New South Wales Government but also to the owners of the mine-or those who now have legal responsibility for such cases as may be pursued. I will undertake to make the Hansard record available to those other bodies to consider and, of course, it is available to the Federal Government to consider also.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is precisely the point I was making. It does not relate just to asbestos; it is a very important general point because there are a number of substances in this category, and the present legal system does not deal with them very well. I thank the Minister for accepting that point.

—I would like to ask the Minister one specific question in relation to the Dust Diseases Tribunal. Does the Minister know whether the Tribunal is available only to ex-workers in the mine, or can members of the workers' families also appear before it?

—I do not know the answer to that question. I will undertake to provide an analysis of that legislation for Senator Jenkins, but it will have to be after the conclusion of the debate, of course. I imagine it deals with all persons who would otherwise go through the normal court process in order to establish a claim that they have suffered illness or been adversely affected or injured in some way by the inhalation of what is comprehensively labelled `dust'. Obviously, that would embrace a range of materials and, I imagine, it would include asbestos. I do not think the word `tribunal' is used in the sense of an industrial tribunal, and I do not think it is confined to workers' compensation claims before an industrial tribunal. I imagine it covers a much wider range of people who can establish their claims before it. I will get a full analysis of that New South Wales legislation for Senator Jenkins and make it available to her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to raise another area of difficulty on the theme of the pursuit of compensation. I think it is generally conceded in this report and by what the Minister has said in his answers that the pursuit of compensation is seen to be a legitimate course that the community should undertake. Indeed, the first recommendation of the 1984 report cites the pursuit of compensation as being legitimate, and cites problems associated with aboriginality in relation to that quest.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Minister will be aware, the pursuit of compensation is, right now, a very vexed question in the community. Minister Hand has taken the absolute position that, if these people are to be subsidised in the pursuit of compensation, that subsidy will be through the Aboriginal Legal Service (ALS). Having spoken with members of the community, I know they do not have confidence in the Aboriginal Legal Service to address this type of litigation, which is civil/commercial and is not its area of speciality. The community has said to the Minister, `We don't believe that the Aboriginal Legal Service can deliver the goods to us in terms of representation and hence in terms of outcomes and compensation'. However, they have said that if the dollars are going to be spent, they should be spent on obtaining the assistance of experts in this specific area of litigation. I understand that the Minister has said that is unacceptable to him and there is a stand-off position. That is our starting point in addressing this problem now.

There is no doubt in the minds of the people of the Baryulgil community that pursuing compensation is something they have to do. In a question to members of that community tonight I asked: `Do you prefer an action line which pursues individual compensation, or an action line which perhaps pursues collective compensation to establish a trust to generate ongoing income and address the problem?'. The answer was, `Both'. That is the reality in the community now.

What is the record of James Hardie in responding to these sorts of legal actions? My understanding is-and I am repeating what was said by Chris Masters on the Four Corners program on 13 November-that Hardies had settled 320 compensation cases, all out of court and all with non-disclosure clauses. If I were a member of the Baryulgil community that would suggest to me that Hardies is very sensitive to its history and the manner in which it has handled this whole problem. If one wants to see how sensitive that company is, one has only to look at the report and see some of its responses in giving evidence.

The compensation question will not go away. It will be pursued by this community for quite some time and I think that it will be resisted by Hardies. Hardies' negating strategy has been very effective. Given the attitude of the community about the ALS and its pursuit of a dual compensation strategy, given the record of James Hardie in relation to out of court settlements, the difficulty in getting the matter to court and reaching a settlement, and given its attitude about disclosing what it sees as the realities, I ask the Minister what resources will be allocated next year for the pursuit of compensation. This very important question is acknowledged in the first recommendation of the 1984 report. Its special dimensions-in other words, the problems of the Aboriginal community in the pursuit of compensation-relate specifically to the appropriations. What resources are available now to pursue that aspect of the problem? Is it envisaged that those resources will be conduited through the ALS or is the Minister now sufficiently flexible to allow them to find their way to the appropriate place through another conduit?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Jenkins handed me a piece of paper the last line of which reads `NSW Dust Diseases Board in respect of possible workers compensation claims'. Senator Jenkins is not in the chamber. Her note suggests that the Dust Diseases Tribunal's jurisdiction may be confined to claims by those who were miners or workers on the site. As I indicated to the honourable senator, I will try to get an analysis of the legislation for her.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) takes the view that the Aboriginal Legal Service (ALS) is the body which, over a period, has built up a considerable expertise in the area. The delays in progressing this claim have been due to the delays that bedevil all Supreme Court lists in New South Wales. I am informed that recently the ALS received an approach from Hardies offering an out of court settlement. I understood that that is being considered and deliberated on. The honourable senator asked what moneys are appropriated at the moment. The Aboriginal Legal Service throughout Australia gets some $15m from the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio. It is up to that body in its various jurisdictions to make decisions as to those cases which fall within the criteria and those for which it chooses to make funds available. One would not expect to find a specific amount in these appropriations dedicated to the provision of legal advice and representation to this community. That would be for the Aboriginal Legal Service to decide. Given its previous history of funding, which is to the extent of almost $700,000, one could expect it to continue to make that sort of allocation of funds.

There appears to be a new factor, namely, the offering of an out of court settlement by Hardies. Obviously I do not know the extent of that offer: I am not privy to it. It is something which the ALS is considering on behalf of those persons who have indicated that they wish their matters to be processed through the Aboriginal Legal Service. If persons choose not to utilise the Aboriginal Legal Service, which after all is the body through which the Commonwealth funds these matters, it is their right to do so; but, having exercised their choice, they would have to find alternative methods of pressing their claim. That may be through the New South Wales Dust Diseases Tribunal and it may be through an arrangement with lawyers, if they are able to do it within the New South Wales jurisdiction, on a no win no pay basis. I do not know whether that is possible in New South Wales. The Minister intends that any Commonwealth dollars that are provided for legal advice and representation in this matter should be provided through the Aboriginal Legal Service.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am somewhat disappointed that Minister Hand does not accept the fact that, in the view of this community, the Aboriginal Legal Service (ALS) does not have the expertise to represent it. I am not doubting the fact that over a period of years the ALS-using the Minister's phrase-has developed considerable expertise, but it is not expertise in relation to this type of litigation. I hear directly from the community and from legal experts that the ALS does not have such expertise and therefore the community does not have confidence in that service. To create a situation where an Aboriginal community must pursue, argue and publicise its lack of confidence in its own funded legal service is very unfortunate, to my way of thinking. We are likely to have not only an unproductive outcome but also a very destructive process en route in terms of the relationship between at least this Aboriginal community and its local regional legal service. With respect, the decision lacks wisdom and it is not the way we should be going.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently I heard, and only informally, that James Hardie has offered an out of court settlement. My understanding is that the offer is in the vicinity of between $10,000 and $80,000 for 10 per cent to 80 per cent incapacity per individual. In other words, if a person was assessed-presumably he will be assessed by the tribunal to which Senator Tate has referred-as being 80 per cent incapacitated, he would receive compensation of about $80,000. By any civil standards these days that scale of compensation for such a degree of incapacity is simply absurd. It reflects the attitude that the company has shown all along while it was remunerating these people.

Early on I made the fairly emotive statement that what prevailed in the community servicing the labour needs of the Baryulgil asbestos mine was tantamount to slavery. I believe that is true in terms of the conditions under which people-they worked barefoot, barelegged and barechested-mined one of the most dangerous substances on earth. They worked for 40 hours a week. I am told that their fortnightly pay-the only hard evidence I have of the rate of pay was for 1965-was #12.6d, which equates to about $24.00. I have attempted to draw a comparison between what James Hardie was paying its labourers in situ with the basic wage. At that stage throughout the Commonwealth the basic wage was the equivalent of $30.80. James Hardie was paying its workers considerably less than the basic wage. It had a non-unionised situation on its hands. People worked as much overtime as the company required without any additional pay. I am attempting to make comparisons between the rates of pay paid by James Hardie to these labourers in situ and the rates of pay that were earned by people working in coalmines in New South Wales at the time and in goldmines in Western Australia and uranium mines in Rum Jungle. I am trying to obtain those figures; I would be very surprised if they were not extremely unfavourable.

The conditions under which these people were required to work were equally unfavourable, not to mention the fact that when they eventually twigged to the fact that they were mining one of the most dangerous substances on the earth they were told that the substance did not affect Aborigines. In addition, a couple of hundred kilometres away in Barraba, where there was another asbestos mine, a highly unionised white labour force was paid almost twice the rate of pay of those working at Baryulgil and it was compulsory for workers at Barraba to wear protective clothing and masks while they mined the same substance. That shows the value set of the company that employed this labour at Baryulgil and which is now attempting to arrive at out of court settlements that are totally inadequate. My understanding of it is quite informal; I do not know whether it is true or how reliable my sources are. However, I am told that the suggested scale of compensation is $10,000 to $80,000 for 10 per cent to 80 per cent proven incapacity. Such scales of compensation are offensive. They simply reflect the mentality of this company and its attitude towards this community and these people who serviced its needs for four decades.

I do not believe that the need for compensation-which is an acknowledged, primary need in Mr Hand's report-is being adequately addressed by the Government or that it can be adequately serviced by the Aboriginal Legal Service. The need for compensation will in no way be adequately addressed by James Hardie in out of court settlements. If we are to be honest and just about this axis of it, we have to be more realistic. I do not believe that anything is occurring on the axis of health, let alone on the axis of relocation or that of compensation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will reply to some of the compensation matters because I do not know why Senator McLean is making a plea to me as though I were the judge, tribunal and jury able to award compensation to these poor people who have been badly affected by the inhalation of asbestos while working for this company which apparently showed a callous indifference to its workers in various situations. That has been documented and was admitted by the company in various out of court settlements which apparently it has reached.

SPEECH.PARA: The frustration being experience by the Aboriginal community at Baryulgil Square is precisely the same frustration that has been experienced for decades by many other communities around Australia as they have tried to pursue their legal rights to compensation in regard to the diseases and injuries which they have suffered as a result of their exposure to asbestos. It is not as though this particular community has been singled out or discriminated against. Unfortunately, it has been the common experience, as has been well rehearsed on other occasions in this chamber, of many communities of Australians, both white and black. It is quite unfair of Senator McLean to give the appearance of saying that somehow the Aboriginal Legal Service (ALS) is particularly derelict, deficient or inadequate in its handling of the matter because it has taken so long to resolve. That has been the common experience of legal aid services and individual lawyers of great eminence over a period of decades.

These matters are now being resolved and James Hardie is making offers. If those offers are of the order suggested by Senator McLean-I have no knowledge of it-they should not be accepted. A settlement is a two-way process. Quite clearly they should not be accepted if they are as derisory and as ill-founded as the honourable senator suggests. In 1986-87, the Commonwealth Government paid for an independent study. I think counsel of some eminence in the field of compensation was engaged to see whether the approach being adopted by the ALS was effective. The cost of engaging that counsel was $2,750. The sorts of questions Senator McLean asks are valid ones. They occurred to the Commonwealth. The counsel was engaged to make an assessment of the ALS approach and it was found to be as adequate as could be expected in all these circumstances which have bedevilled many other claims, as Senator McLean will no doubt acknowledge.

It is a very difficult situation, one that I face all the time as the Minister in charge of the non-Aboriginal legal aid services throughout Australia. We fund legal aid through the legal aid commissions throughout the States and the Australian Legal Aid Office in Tasmania and the Northern Territory. Some people are dissatisfied that that is the way in which the Commonwealth distributes the legal aid dollar. They might like us to do it some other way and to have absolute freedom to move to whom they wish in order to obtain advice and be paid in relation to it. It is reasonable, given that assessment made in 1986-87 on the process and progress of litigation, that the matter continue to be funded through the ALS. I believe that an assessment of any settlement offer that has been made by Hardies will be made in a way which will not disadvantage the Aboriginal people who themselves will make the decision on whether to accept.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a general point that the Aboriginal people have been incredibly disadvantaged because of their exposure to asbestos and they will bear the health effects. It is clear that the employer in this and a number of instances, as the Minister said, has been negligent and, therefore, is perfectly challengeable for compensation. It is worth pointing out that asbestos went into a whole variety of very cheap products such as asbestos cement sheets, pipes, gutters, fencing and all sorts of things which advantaged Australia over a very long period of time. Asbestos provided an extremely cheap building material. Every one of us has probably borne some of the benefit of that cheap building material. It is appropriate, therefore, that the community pick up a considerable proportion of the cost by way of compensation because the community at large has benefited. It is the Aboriginal people and others who will suffer with the diseases. It is worth stressing to the Minister that the amount of money that the Government-or, should I say, the general taxpayer-has been prepared to put in through Government allocations does not bear any relationship to the advantages which the community has experienced through having this cheap building material over many decades.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to move the discussion on the appropriations to another area. Not only are the people of Baryulgil community dissatisfied with the state of their health and the provisions being made for it; not only are they anxious to pursue compensation for the abuses of the past, for which they are seeking dollars; but they are also asking that their immediate environment be rendered safer and healthier, and they are seeking dollars for that. Let us look at the relevant recommendations in the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs entitled Effects of Asbestos Mining on the Baryulgil Community. I believe that it is a valid approach to take these recommendations because they are the recommendations to and from the Government concerning these problems. They are still in the hands of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), who, as the honourable member for Melbourne, chaired the Committee. They are now not being reflected in the dollars being appropriated.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendations 6, 7 and 10 relate to the rehabilitation of the mining site. It is a question of who bears the responsibility. In recommendations 6 and 7, it is suggested that the responsibility for the rehabilitation of the site lies not with the Commonwealth Government but with State authorities such as the State Pollution Control Commission, the Department of Mineral Resources, et cetera. The interesting thing is that in recommendation 10 in the final analysis the Committee states:

That the Commonwealth Minister for Aboriginal Affairs request the New South Wales Government to direct the Department of Mineral Resources to require the lessees of the site of the Baryulgil mine and mill to carry out a complete rehabilitation of the area,-
and this is the rub-
and, in the event of the lessee failing to comply,-
in other words, if James Hardie says, `You can all go and jump'; if that is the attitude of James Hardie-
to direct the Department of Mineral Resources to carry out such rehabilitation work itself.

In other words, the Commonwealth Minister has said, `Tell these various statutory authorities to establish certain things about the safety of the environment'-I will come to that in detail in a moment-`tell the statutory authorities to rehabilitate the site; tell the mining company to rehabilitate the site; but if it does not do it, do it at the taxpayers' expense'. It strikes me that there is an inherent contradiction in the principle of how the Government will resolve this problem. The essential principle suggested is to direct the appropriate authorities to do certain things if that does not happen, then to direct the mining company to do certain things and, if that does not happen, the taxpayer picks up the bill and the statutory authority actually does it.

But none of this questions the fundamental requirement to rehabilitate the site. It is irrefutable. If a person goes to the site of the old mine, which is a few hundred metres from the Baryulgil Square, that person will see that it requires rehabilitation. We are told by the authorities that they have done the necessary things to rehabilitate the area. I can assure honourable senators that they have not. I have in my own home-I meant to bring them here tonight to table-lumps of raw asbestos that I just picked up off the ground. I can assure honourable senators that the tailings are lying in mounds which a person can kick and pick up like cow pats and break into asbestos fibre which is blown in the wind and is leached into the water.

There is no doubt that an environmental disaster exists within a few hundred metres of the Baryulgil Square, which is itself an environmental disaster. This is acknowledged in all of these recommendations but there are no dollars and cents appropriated to solve the problems. I ask the Minister to clarify the situation, assuming that the site has not been adequately rehabilitated and in view of the fact that the State statutory authorities have not done what they were told to do. For instance, let us look at recommendation 7, which reads:

That the Commonwealth Minister for Aboriginal Affairs request the New South Wales Government to direct the State Pollution Control Commission to continue to monitor the health risks from asbestos tailings at Baryulgil Square and to take whatever remedial measures may become necessary.

So the Minister is asking the Government to direct a statutory authority to do certain things. Let me read first the reply of a senior officer of the State Pollution Control Commission. Let me read the reply of a senior officer of the Department of Mineral Resources about monitoring the safety of the site and how much it is prepared to put into the rehabilitation and spend and then I will come to the question of how much the Federal Government is prepared to spend on it in this set of appropriations because this formula is broken down. In an interview with Sharon Davis in a program which went to air on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) on 20 November 1988 entitled There's No Place Like Baryulgil, A Town Built on Asbestos, Mr John Cook from the Department of Mineral Resources in reply to recommendation 7 that the process be constantly monitored said:
The department hasn't tested the air-
that is in the five years since it was theoretically directed to do so-
because there's no need to . . .
Talk about a circular argument. I ask honourable senators to listen to this closed logic:
The department hasn't tested the air because there's no need to . . .
Presumably, the intention of testing the air was to see whether there was a need to. It is an interesting contradiction. Mr Cook continued:
. . . there's no evidence of any dust-
of course there is not, because the Department has not tested to see whether there is any evidence-
even on a windy day.

The Department has not tested the air on windy days. It has admitted that it has not tested it. It has admitted that it is presupposing the answer to the question. This is absolute rubbish. By anybody's logic it is rubbish. So Mr Cook said that the Department had not tested the air. This is five years after recommendation 7 was made. Mr Cook continued:
The water, we haven't tested either, because most of the erosion which has been taking place appears to remain in the paddock, the eroded material appears to remain--

TALK.START.PARA: —What report is that?

—This is a comment of Mr John Cook, a senior officer of the Department of Mineral Resources in New South Wales, which is the authority that the Commonwealth Department was calling upon to do this task for it.
—What is the date?

—On 20 November 1988, in a program broadcast on the ABC under the title of There's No Place Like Baryulgil, A Town Built on Asbestos. It is in response to questions from Sharon Davis. They are real responses. I was on air with Andrew Olle last Monday when he played them back to me. We discussed them. Other officers were also on air during that debate. But let us go on. Mr Cook continued:

SPEECH.PARA: The water, we haven't tested either, because most of the erosion which has been taking place appears to remain in the paddock, the eroded material appears to remain in the paddock just downsteam of the mine.
Presumably the whole objective of testing the water would be to see whether those appearances are real or not and to move from the arena of appearances to reality. Mr Cook's closing sentence states:
Usually we carry out certain testing of the waters around a mine site after rehabilitation, there's not much use doing it before the rehabilitation is satisfactory.

How can a person tell, for heaven's sake, whether the rehabilitation has been satisfactory if the Department does not carry out these tests which it says it usually does but in this case it did not? These are the responses of the Department that theoretically is called upon by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to carry out tests as the Commonwealth Government's agent. Mr Peter Standon, who is the Director of the State Pollution Control Commission in New South Wales-the other authority that the Minister was citing as the one which would be appropriate-in the same program said:
Well, you obviously have an advantage over me in that you have seen it very recently.
He is talking about the old mine site. He is saying that he has not seen it recently. In the interview he continued:
Of course, the situation there is as you probably would have also noticed, that the tailing tends to crust over fairly firmly and my understanding-
this is an understanding, he not having been there-
and the advice I've received on that situation, is that it is a fairly stable surface.

I can tell him that it is not a stable surface, that it is badly eroded, that I can kick holes in it and that the kids slide down it and break it open with their feet. The Director of the State Pollution Control Commission continued:
. . . if there has been erosion and some of those materials have been washed into the streams, there could be the potential for some contamination.

Yet another scientific officer said that they do not test the water and they have not tested the water in this particular situation. So there could be some potential for contamination. What about the experience so far? The Director of the State Pollution Control Commission continued:

I can only say that our experience so far has been that it is not likely to cause a problem, notwithstanding the visual situation that you refer to. But you know, I'm more than happy to double check that and in fact, have someone go up to satisfy myself that there isn't any problem, in view of the observations you make.

That is a convoluted gobbledegook response by the Director of the State Pollution Control Commission, supported by another internally contradictory response by an officer of the Department of Minerals and Energy in response to recommendation No. 7. I live on another planet if that is a satisfactory response by those that the Commonwealth Minister for Aboriginal Affairs is going to call upon. I know that sometimes it is considered to be infra dig to be critical of professional officers but I cannot help but be critical of the logic quoted on a program broadcast nationally, in response to recommendations of a parliamentary report.

I believe that the strategy recommended by this report was to pass the buck downwards, assuming certain things were happening. I believe that the evidence clearly is that those things which were recommended have not happened. By the admission of John Cook, they have not happened in terms of monitoring air and water. The strategy has failed and therefore we are now stuck with the strategy outlined in recommendation No. 10, which says, `If the company does not take the necessary measures we will pick up the tab and do it ourselves because we have an obligation to the community'.

Are there any dollars in the appropriation actually to rehabilitate this site to a more satisfactory state of rehabilitation than I saw 12 or 14 days ago? There is a clear requirement and an acknowledgment on the part of the Commonwealth Minister that rehabilitation of the site is a primary area of need. It has not happened; it must happen. I am asking where the dollars and cents are for it to happen, when it will happen and who will do it. That question is directed specifically to this appropriation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not quite get the dates of all of the radio programs to which Senator McLean was referring. I think most of them were in 1988.
—Yes. The specific one from which I was quoting was 20 November 1988.

—In December 1988 the Premier of New South Wales, the Hon. Nick Greiner, responded to a request from the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Gerry Hand, to have a new survey undertaken to check the safety of the residents in regard to this continuing problem of the dangers of asbestos. The Premier requested the State Pollution Control Commission to undertake that survey. Apparently, that report was made available to the State Government in July and a copy of the report has, I have been informed, just been made available to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs in Canberra. The report sets out a proposed program of monitoring to assess the present levels of asbestos contamination, together with cost estimates for remedial works should they be required. My understanding is that the Premier has asked the relevant State agencies to examine the proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister, Gerry Hand, is obviously pressing the Premier in order to ensure that that monitoring program and any required remedial action be undertaken expeditiously. I am sure that that correspondence or contact and pressure between the two levels of government will continue in order to see that what further remedial action is indicated is in fact undertaken without delay.

I do not know whether those remedial actions can be 100 per cent effective. This discussion has been going on for over 2 1/2 hours. In many ways we come back to the point which Senator Peter Baume made-that it may come down to a question of people living on Baryulgil Square taking decisions to remove themselves from the area of contamination. If they fear that the health hazards cannot be sufficiently remedied, allayed or made less dangerous, they will have to face even more drastically the question of removing themselves to another living site. The discussion this evening brings us back to the dilemma which we know has bedevilled this matter for many years, but there is an indication that the Premier of New South Wales at least has taken up the necessity for his State agencies to, first of all, identify the problem and then suggest strategies to overcome it. That is the state of the game at the moment. I believe that in our federal system that is the correct strategy to adopt and that is where the responsibility lies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The needs of the Baryulgil community are fourfold. We have discussed them here and they all require dollars. The first is rehabilitation of the site. We have agreed that that has not occurred. I have an assurance from the Minister that the Premier of New South Wales is now committed to this. Frankly, five years after the recommendations, I am not too sure that the people of the Baryulgil community will be particularly stirred by the new found commitment of the Premier of New South Wales to their problems. Nevertheless, I might be excessively cynical about it.
—He is committed not to the rehabilitation of the site but to an inquiry.
—He is committed to an inquiry into whether the site needs to be rehabilitated, yes.
—An inquiry has taken place.

—It has taken place and has reported, but it certainly has not been referred to in my discussions with members of the Baryulgil community. I do not know whether they know of the outcome of this inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: The second need is the provision of medical services. The people of Baryulgil are not convinced that that is happening in any real sense, nor would they be convinced by the answers tonight that the dollars in these appropriations will seriously address that requirement. The third need of the people of Baryulgil is for funds in the right place to pursue compensation. I do not believe they will be convinced that the funds are in this appropriation, or will go to the right place, to pursue compensation effectively.

I want to move on to the last requirement which I will put before the Minister. It is a fairly recent one. It is apart from the recommendations of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs. It was a request that was made in a recent submission to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to appoint a project officer from and to the community-in other words, one of their own-to help coordinate health research and other aspects of this process in situ. This submission was put to Minister Hand in December 1988 and was responded to in March 1989. The refusal was revisited by the executive officers of the ex-miners association. I supported its re-submission I think around June or July of this year. In fact, I had a conversation with the Minister probably about August or September this year in which he said he would reconsider his original decision not to fund a project officer. If that reconsideration received a positive response, it would presumably be acknowledged in these appropriations.

The need, request and submission of the community was to appoint a project officer and the necessary administrative dollars to support that person in situ to coordinate on their behalf everything that was necessary for them to proceed to an effective medical service and to positive outcomes in terms of compensation claims. I had a personal assurance from the Minister some weeks ago that he would reconsider that. I am now wondering whether Minister Tate is able to give us an indication as to whether the Minister has reconsidered it and whether his reconsideration is favourable. If it is favourable, is it reflected in the appropriations and in terms of how many dollars would be available to fund such a project officer?

TALK.START.PARA: —This is getting a bit tedious. Senator McLean is playing to the gallery. He knows very well that if he made a request of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in relation to a matter only three or four weeks ago, it would not be reflected in these appropriations, which were before the Estimates Committee seven or eight weeks ago, and which obviously would have been devised and settled perhaps three months ago. It is just ludicrous to ask a question to which he knows the answer for a rhetorical point. There is no appropriation for that matter in these estimates. Senator McLean could not expect to find it in these estimates. Despite any reconsideration which the Minister may have undertaken in relation to the request, I am unable to inform the Senate as to what came of the deliberations or further consideration by the Minister. I will attempt to obtain an answer.

—I informed the Senate just a couple of moments ago that this submission was made in December 1988. It was responded to in March 1988. The sum of money involved was so minuscule in relation to the total appropriation, the Minister for Justice cannot tell me that there was not sufficient flexibility, in appropriations of $490m-odd, to accommodate a ministerial change of position, even today. I just do not believe that there is that degree of rigidity in appropriated dollars. I suggest that the Minister is arguing that this request is unreasonable.
—I did not say that. Don't put words in my mouth. I never said that.
—I think that was the sense of what the Minister was saying.

—I did not say that the request itself or the renewal of the request by Senator McLean on behalf of the community was reasonable. The point I was making was that his expectation to find an appropriation, if there were to be an affirmative response to that request, in these estimates is completely and utterly ridiculous. He knows that these were settled and printed well before he made the renewal of the request. If the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs were to decide that money could be made available for this request, no doubt there is a general fund within the appropriations that could be used. But he will not find anything spelt out in these appropriations in regard to that particular renewed request, it having been knocked back in March this year, which would have been taken into account when the estimates were written up. If it were to be made available, then it may be recorded in an additional Estimates process if it cannot be found to be funded out of some current larger amount of money. That is the point I was making. I do not know whether the Minister, in his reconsideration, has come to a decision different from that which commended itself in March.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My final comment is that quite obviously the intention here, in this appropriations debate, is to establish what financial resources had been allocated for the needs of the Baryulgil community. I think the answer is fairly clear: the resources that have been specifically allocated in these appropriations are laughable in comparison with the elaborated and developed needs of this community. This debate has now gone on for five years. The intention of my contribution and my colleague's contribution to this appropriations debate was to reveal that the appropriations are inadequate and that the inadequacy flows from a failure in real terms of action. In the final analysis, they are the only terms of any real consequence.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a failure on the part of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and on the part of the Government to acknowledge in these appropriations that real needs for action exist. That failure has gone on for five years. The buck has been passed in all sorts of directions. The Government has a very frustrated community on its hands, which is simply appealing to us to apply the necessary pressure to ensure that eventually the necessary dollars are appropriated.

I think that this is the correct context in which to raise those issues. The resource document of the report was the correct base from which to argue our case. I have simply attempted to substantiate it from other comment, public and official, that has been addressed to this vexed question. We truly believe that the situation at Baryulgil is a national and an international disgrace and that it is not being effectively addressed by this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must finally say, in response to that, that it did not require almost 2 1/2 hours of exposition by Senator McLean to bring to the attention of the Senate or the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Gerry Hand, the proper response that should be made to the plight of those who have been exposed to asbestos at Baryulgil Square. Indeed, Senator McLean's exposition has been deficient both in its understanding of the history of the matter, which was well supplemented and spoken to by Senator Peter Baume, and in his allocation of responsibility, which seems to be single-mindedly obsessed with sheeting home responsibility to the Federal Government for funding those courses of action and strategies which may be required to remedy the present living situation and to ensure compensation for those whose health has suffered as a result of their exposure. It is much more complex than that. On the responsibility side, the company is involved, the State Government is involved and the Federal Government is involved. I believe that the Premier of New South Wales and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs have come to an understanding as to how these responsibilities might be best undertaken and met. I believe that is the appropriate course to be undertaken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the very serious nature of the issue raised by Senator McLean that has had to be addressed tonight on behalf of the Baryulgil community. At the same time, I feel that the processes of this Senate have, to a very large extent, been misused by the Australian Democrats. Almost 2 1/2 hours of Committee debate has had to be dedicated to this important issue when the Australian Democrats have had available to them the appropriate forum of the Estimates committees to more properly pursue this avenue of questioning. That is the line that should have been taken. They have had available to them the opportunity to put questions on notice in the Parliament; questions could have been well lodged to ascertain a lot of this information. Of course, they could have used many other debating forums in the past few weeks. They have used almost 2 1/2 hours of the appropriation debate on this issue--
—Five years; two hours and twenty minutes.
—Two hours and 20 minutes. The Democrats have had plenty of procedural opportunity and I believe that this shows the contempt the Democrats have for the proper and due process of the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to deal with a smorgasbord of issues covering considerations in the Aboriginal affairs portfolio. I assure the Committee that I will not be taking anything like two hours to cover a whole range of issues. It is important that we look carefully at the issues that have been raised in detail in the report of Estimates Committee E. This chamber will be well aware that yesterday, the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Michael Beahan, put forward a motion, which was accepted by this chamber, that carried various recommendations that in effect referred other important and priority issues to standing committees of the Senate. Of course, Senator Beahan's motion picked up those very important things that once again highlight that the Senate and many other forums need to look very carefully at the Aboriginal affairs portfolio.

Honourable senators will recall that I have taken a very close interest in this matter since the Estimates Committee hearings of October 1988. Since that time a plethora of reports, inquiries and recommendations have had to be adopted and looked at. Some of them have been in this place; others have been by committees of the House of Representatives; and other inquiries have been properly commissioned by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) into a range of areas across the entire portfolio. Of course, many of the reports that have been tabled have been actioned. I commend officers of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC), who have given due regard to the various reports, inquiries and scrutinies that have been in place for the last 18 months or so.

I appreciate that this problem has been compounded by the political agenda of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Gerry Hand. In that period the Minister has doggedly proceeded to follow an agenda which resulted recently in the passage through this Parliament of legislation to create the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC). That legislation was probably the most amended piece of legislation ever to have passed this Parliament. It certainly required very close attention by Government Ministers in this place and by other senators. The fact that there were some 122 amendments to the ATSIC legislation only highlighted the very fundamental flaws that were inherent in it when the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, brought it forward, guillotined it and ramrodded it through the House of Representatives. Similarly, since October 1988 Estimates Committee E has given very serious consideration to the scrutinies and inquiries that have had to be in place in regard to this portfolio.

I make no apology for the number of questions I have placed on notice since October 1988, earlier this year and more recently. In fact, the numbers of questions I placed on notice for the current round of hearings were in excess of 600 and they are well documented in the additional information volumes that have been tabled. I commend them to anyone who wants to have a thorough understanding of this area.

We need to remember that the total expenditure by Commonwealth departments on special programs for Aboriginals this year is well in excess of the $915m set out in the table on page 50 of the additional information that has been tabled. Of course, in the department by department break-up that table omits several important amounts that are shown in the administrative votes of the Department of Employment, Education and Training. It also omits, because obviously the information was not available to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs at the time the table was put together, the vote from the arts, sport, the environment, tourism and territories portfolio through the appropriations of the Australia Council. So the expenditure this year on special Commonwealth programs for Aboriginals is probably in the vicinity of $950m.

Since the Hawke Government appointed Mr Hand as the Minister in July 1987 there has been a phenomenal increase in that vote. In the last 18 months Estimates Committee E has ascertained that there has been expenditure of a voluminous amount of cash that can only be described as waste and duplication in such an important area of this portfolio. So often we see the Minister throwing cash at problems rather than seeking to solve them with a proper commitment to Aboriginal affairs and to ordering priorities in an accountable and efficient manner. That has always been my priority and the agenda that I have pursued in taking such a close interest in this area. Of course, coming from the Northern Territory it is very easy to identify with the total program in this area because it is such a significant social and economic parameter in the Northern Territory. Well in excess of 25 per cent of the people who live in the Northern Territory are of Aboriginal descent and the concerns they have-political, community, economic and social-are so very important that they need to be carefully addressed.

I appreciate that, in the time available to me this evening, I will not be able to cover the issues that I will want to take up tomorrow. They relate to the very important considerations of the Australian Audit Office and the special correspondence it has addressed so often and on which it has had to take such a strong stance in reviewing this portfolio. Arising from the many inquiries of the last year or so are consequential areas that need to be looked at most carefully. In my opinion, a number of issues have not been properly addressed or answered by the Minister, and it is interesting to note that at all times when we have felt frustrated it is not the information flow from the public servants, the officers of the ADC or the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, that has frustrated our efforts; it has been the information flow from the office of the Minister.

It is also interesting to note that, going back to 4 August this year, a number of questions I have on notice that relate to important financial implications have not yet been answered. Yesterday I drew to the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs those questions that are outside the 30-day rule and therefore need to be quickly and carefully addressed. However, I will pursue tomorrow the more specific issues, as will several other senators, including areas where we believe that, unfortunately, further and more detailed inquiries will also be necessary.
