DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australia Post: Subscription Discounts-Drugs: Legislation-Kakadu National Park-Death of Toby Gangali-Darwin Airport: Air Traffic Control-Local Employment Trading System-Assassination of President Rene Muawad-Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two matters which I wish to raise on the adjournment this evening. The first relates to a matter which my colleague Senator Vanstone has raised on a number of previous occasions and which I have also raised. That is the question of the change of policy undertaken by Australia Post as it relates to discounts for publications printed in Australia with a retail price of over $5. For many years magazine format publications printed in Australia have been posted under a registered publication classification with discounts in what are called category A and category B. Category A covers religious publications and outlying or rural publications, and category B covers general interest publications. Discounts are applied on the basis of weight scales with the proviso that the editions are presorted into decreed postcode categories and bundled into decreed maximums as determined by the administration of Australia Post.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1989 a new criterion was introduced by Australia Post before its incorporation in July but that criterion was to apply after that time and progressively from October 1989 in a way which totally eliminates registered publication discounts for publications with a retail cover price of $5 or more. That means, in effect, that a subscription previously serviced for 47c now increases to $1.65 or more, depending on destination-an increase in one step of 400 per cent and up to 500 per cent in some cases. Australia Post, in the typical arrogant, pig-headed and ignorant fashion in which it often proceeds, did not consult with any of the publishers directly affected by this decision. Particularly for publishers and publications which relate to my own area of shadow ministerial responsibility, namely those in the arts and cultural area, this came as a bolt out of the blue. A simplistic and naive assumption was made that publications with a cover price over $5, by virtue of their price alone, could inherently afford such radical and unforecast cost increases. This demonstrates the ignorance of Australia Post. It indicates the extent to which that mammoth irresponsible organisation frankly does not give a fig for questions of cultural identity or cultural integrity in Australia. Nobody but an Australian Post philistine could have made this sort of intrusion into the cultural and intellectual life of Australia.

The decision itself is anomalous on several grounds. A monthly magazine such as Ita at $5 retail can be posted for 47c. A quarterly such as Habitat with a cover price of $5.50 will, however, cost between $1.65 and $2.15 to post. Another quarterly-again this affects my other shadow portfolio, the environment-Australian Wild, which has held its cover price at $4.95 for two years, cannot viably plan an increase because it would add $2 to subscription postal costs per unit.

The rationale for this radical and discriminatory price increase is that Australia Post has allocated a $20m notional loss calculation to its servicing of registered publications. Should this assessment be the case, then it is the more frequently posted subscriptions which contribute most to the loss. However, the majority of the over $5 publications affected are bimonthly or quarterly. In the case of some poetry journals, for example, they may be even less frequent than that. They may come out only when there is sufficient material for an issue to be printed and a sufficient level of subscriptions available for people to be prepared to undertake the publication.

However, the above calculation does not include the category of periodical publications which are newsprint quality publications posted at even cheaper rates than registered publications, even though many are similar in weight. It also excludes high volume publications such as Readers Digest, which has an annual distribution in Australia of five million copies, the National Roads and Motorists Association's Open Road, which posts nine million copies a year to people in New South Wales alone, or excellent publications such as Dick Smith's Australian Geographic, which has a circulation in the order of 700,000, and, because of the nature of Australian publishing, is printed in Japan. These and other publications are posted at specially negotiated rates. Moreover, those rates are secret. That is to say, the rates are not on the public record, as are registered publication discounts. However, the specially negotiated rates are known to people in the industry to be considerably less than their equivalent category. When calculating the supposed loss the largest part of Australia Post's servicing of subscription publications is excluded.

While there may be some economies of scale associated with volume handling, the fact is that all subscription journals are presorted by the publisher, bundled to specification laid down by Australia Post, and then handled by the same sorting houses, carried by the same trucks and delivered by the same postmen. Variations of hundreds of per cent are simply not viable or supportable.

If eligibility for discount is to be assessed on ability to pay, then the whole economic equation of publishing should be taken into account. Some publishers fulfil a marketing niche on the basis of high advertising ratio, less editorial content and more often cheaper quality paper which allows lower price points in the market niche for literary reader-oriented publications by which policy has a higher editorial ratio, lower advertising content and high quality paper. Some may choose to carry no advertising at all so that the reader bears the total cost of the reading matter without commercial influence. Publishers in the commercial context have to balance the factors of advertising revenue, circulation revenue and quality of production to stay viable. The reality is that most of the high quality locally printed publications with cover prices over $5 are highly specialised with the emphasis on editorial content, more costly design, and printing with only marginal profitability compared to the mass media publishers such as Packer, Murdoch, Fairfax and the others. They also tend to be less frequent than the disposable magazines.

If it is deemed appropriate by Australia Post to recover losses from a specific category of customers, I put to the Senate that the rate surely should not be an increase applying across the board by criteria which directly reflect Australia Post's costs, that is to say, weight and possibly size. If volume attracts further discount, then should not this reflect real economies of scale which are unlikely to be to the degree of 100 per cent to 500 per cent or more? Publishers who choose to operate by economies of service to produce less frequently-that is, bimonthly or quarterly-should not be penalised by the inherently lower volumes per annum this creates when, in fact, they are creating a lower impact on the postal system although they are offering the reader a similar annual amount of reading compared to smaller or less editorial content publications posted monthly or, indeed, weekly.

The potential impact of this decision has been particularly drawn to my attention by Barbara McGregor from the Australian Well Being magazine, a magazine which Senator Vanstone quoted from in some detail on the last occasion on which she spoke. She makes the point, quite rightly, that, given this sort of impost, many of these publications will cease altogether. Publishers of high quality editions may have no option but to print overseas. Presumably Australia Post will not lose a moment's sleep over that. Australia Post has never demonstrated the slightest commitment to Australian publishing. That in its own way will contribute to increasing further debt, with savings which would offset the radical increases in subscription postage. In fact, Australia Post is part of a system which, if this is pursued, will entrench the interests of major publishers to the disadvantage of smaller independent publishers. New enterprises and new publications will have a cost hurdle to overcome which would be virtually insurmountable were they to plan to compete with established high volume or highly commercial operators.

Australia Post is now in a position in which its decisions are virtually unreviewable except by its own board. Ministers, in the sort of gutless approach that we are used to from this Government, plead that they are unwilling or unable to intervene. All the high sounding rhetoric from the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) about how he wants to increase Australian cultural identity is set at naught when he then stands up and says, `Well, so literary magazines get squeezed out of existence, poetry journals disappear, magazines in the environment movement are going to be forced to close. That is Australia Post's decision. You can't expect me as a mere Minister in the Government actually to take some role in putting my money where my mouth is'. One would not expect him, in fact, to have the intestinal fortitude to do that.

In terms of making these decisions, Australia Post demonstrates no understanding of what it is that actually imposes the costs upon the Australia Post system or, indeed, what will be the effect of the decision in adding to the burden of those literary, cultural and environmental magazines which have previously enjoyed a degree of subsidy, that degree of subsidy being seen by the Parliament and by previous governments as a legitimate expenditure of public money in support of a particular activity.

Once the magazine is inside the envelope, Australia Post has no idea what the price on the cover actually is. If a magazine were simply to be printed without a cover price on it, how would Australia Post make the assessment that the cover price is one which should cause the subsidy to be forfeited? Everybody knows that when one buys a pair of shoes in Australia these days, whatever number of dollars one pays for a pair of shoes, one can bet one's life that the cent value will be 95 or 99 cents. It keeps it below the next dollar value. So anything that was published at $4.99 cover price would not attract this arbitrary impost by Australia Post but anything at $5 would. It may well be that the answer for the Australian publishers is to go through the farce of reducing to $4.99 everything which is now $5. That is the sort of idiocy one gets from an organisation such as Australia Post.

What ought to be the criteria are questions of weight, size, conformity with specifications such as packaging, pre-sorting, bundling, postcode arrangements, or whatever it happens to be. But Australia Post has cast itself now in the role of a de facto censor, a tax levier or, indeed, a price setting authority. It is contributing to a monopolisation of a particular field in which it specialises and has exclusive right to provide the service.

One of the things that Opposition policy will achieve is to challenge the monopoly position of Australia Post in many of these areas-and a good thing it will be too. Nevertheless, freedom of speech, equality of opportunity, and encouragement for the small value added and creative entrepreneurs, which we believe are fundamental to Australian society and its future, are jeopardised by this lunatic decision of Australia Post. Any action by a government body, whether it is supposed to be profit oriented or not, which defeats those overwhelming democratic and cultural imperatives in Australia is injurious to the nation and is something which, frankly, ought to be eliminated and in which government ought to be prepared to take a hand.

One other matter I propose to raise very briefly is the question of the public debate about the legalisation in Australia or otherwise of drugs such as heroin, which has proceeded with some renewed interest in the course of the last couple of months. My colleague Senator Peter Baume has spoken on the subject and Senator Tate, the Minister on duty at the moment, has put his view into the public arena. Whatever the outcome of that debate, all I can say is that I think there has been a healthier attempt to analyse the issues in the course of the last couple of months than has been evident in the past. There are strongly held views on either side of that particular debate. My colleague the honourable member for North Sydney, Mr John Spender, for example, has also recently published an article on this subject. The debate is clearly one which over the next couple of years is likely to occupy a fairly central place in the public debate about drug strategies, response to the acquired immune deficiency syndrome problem and, indeed, the efficacy of drug strategies and prohibitive versus more liberalised regimes.

On 17 August Mr Milton Luger presented a paper to the Law Society conference entitled Youth need heroes, not heroin, which was a major paper on that subject. In the same spirit, Dr Stephen Mugford has prepared a response to that paper entitled On heroes and heroin: A comment on Milton Luger's paper. Rather than go through the arguments presented, I simply seek leave to table those two papers and make them available for honourable senators and anybody else who would wish to examine them.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I believe that these two papers make a significant contribution to the debate and indeed will repay honourable senators a close and detailed study.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have all heard a lot about the Government's non-decision of 5 October to postpone a decision on the mining of Coronation Hill. The general view of Kakadu stage 3 has certainly changed since Senator Gareth Evans, as Minister for Resources and Energy, said that it was clapped-out buffalo country. I notice with approval Mike Seccombe's misquotation from Fawlty Towers in the Sydney Morning Herald of 28 October:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . what did you expect, Senator Evans, herds of wildebeest, sweeping majestically across the plains?

Apparently, Senator Evans did see herds sweeping across the plain; but it must have been a trick of the light because I am informed that buffalo damage to stage 3 is quite minor-about one per cent-and that the eradication program has been quite successful. In fact, when I was up in Kakadu not so long ago I met some buffalo hunters and, while they were quite frightening looking creatures, like something out of Mad Max, they were clearly doing a very good job and also managing to earn a living out of it.

More recently, strong statements have been made by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, and a very confusing set of contradictory position statements from the Opposition. The latest from Senator Puplick suggests that a coalition government would allow mineral exploration in stage 2, a World Heritage area, but no mining, so that we will know what we are missing out on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Exploration. If the silly woman could actually read the English language she wouldn't get it wrong.

—Senator Puplick can make a personal explanation tomorrow. It is unclear who will fund this expensive exploration effort purely for the satisfaction of Senator Puplick's curiosity. Reactions amongst conservationists have been mixed. It is hard to resist the temptation, when so many arguments on conservation have been lost, to applaud and offer approval to decisions which seem to be going in the right direction-and I stress the word `seem'. I am reminded of the well known lines on temptation in T. S. Eliot's poem Murder in the Cathedral:

SPEECH.PARA: The last temptation is the greatest treason,
To do the right deed for the wrong reason.

Unfortunately, this is a temptation that our governments succumb to effortlessly. The distinction between the right and the wrong reasons is not just a moral quibble but a very practical discrimination. In this case we are keenly aware of the electoral motive for the Government's decision. We are also aware that this motive will no longer exist after the next election. This is the antithesis of the longterm planning this nation needs. We all know the reasons and excuses for this state of affairs, but the Australian people deserve better service from their governments than this cyclic obsession with grabbing power.

Kakadu National Park is one of the world's great wilderness areas. It is one of the few tropical reserves in a developed country and, despite our economic woes, we can afford to preserve it. In the long term, a decision not to preserve this rich natural asset will be seen as gross environmental and economic irresponsibility. Mining in areas of widely recognised significance such as those listed as World Heritage areas must be avoided. This is a remarkable area. Let me quote again from the remarks of the levelheaded Mr Seccombe:

You have to come here to fully appreciate the richness of it. There are at least 1,275 types of plants, 280 types of birds (one-third of the total Australian species), more than 100 different reptiles, more than 62 mammals and more than 77 fish species (three times as many as in the Murray-Darling system). And an estimated 10,000 types of insects.
Again, he says:
Kakadu is unique in the world in that it encompasses a complete wet/dry tropical river system-the Alligator river system.

Already, Kakadu National Park has been compromised by the presence of the Ranger uranium mine within its boundaries, although the mine has been garlanded by an excised portion of the park. It has been proposed that other uranium deposits such as Koongarra and Jabiluka within the general confines of Kakadu should also be allowed to proceed. This development would greatly increase any threat to Kakadu Park. Although Ranger uranium mine has not had a catastrophic accident affecting the park, there have been a number of minor incidents and the potential for a major disaster always lurks just below the surface.

There has been ongoing conflict between the Office of the Supervising Scientist and the Ranger uranium mine operators, who, would obviously like to weaken the tight controls on the Ranger operation. This history of conflict augurs ill for the effectiveness of less stringent controls like those likely to be imposed on the mine at Coronation Hill and any other mines in this region. The potential problems associated with the Ranger mine may be realised if the increased production suggested by the mine owners and Government Ministers is allowed to proceed. There have been a number of recommendations on the desirability of preserving vital elements of the Kakadu environment. The Fox Commission report-the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry-recommended as follows:
That if possible the national park include at least one large total river catchment; the South Alligator catchment is the most suitable.
This is the river that will be contaminated by accidents or carelessness. In 1985 the National Parks and Wildlife Service stated in a report on the national park value as follows:

These wetlands, (in stage I and II) representing the major part of stage 2 and significant areas of stage I and Goodparla, are vulnerable to changes in the quality of water from the upper reaches of the South Alligator. Unsympathetic land use practices upstream could seriously diminish these wetland values.

The current Government's response to the management of stage 3 has been initially to set 35 per cent of it aside for exploration in the perversely named `conservation zone' and place the remaining 65 per cent in stage 3 of the national park. This occurred in 1986. The precise boundaries of the conservation zone could never be agreed upon; so, for three years, the exploration program did not progress. Thus, there is still no detailed assessment of the mineral value of this area-the supposed justification for setting this area aside.

On 5 October 1989 the Government placed most of the conservation zone into stage 3 of Kakadu. However, it kept the highly prospective areas from El Sherana to Coronation Hill out of the park as an exploration zone, and will probably allow mining to proceed in these areas, although it will certainly not say that before the next election. The net result of this compromise is that the mineral potential of the area will not be assessed, but the most important area from a conservation point of view- the South Alligator River Valley-will probably still be mined, thus ensuring a continued threat to the World Heritage areas of Kakadu stages 1 and 2, and the potential World Heritage area of stage 3.

The matter of future development has been referred to the Resource Assessment Commission, which will take 12 months to produce a report which will be `comparable in detail to an EIS'-yet another environmental impact statement. A major difficulty for the Government is that it clearly indicated to the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and its partners in 1986 that the Coronation Hill mine would be able to go ahead if it met certain requirements. Now that BHP has met those requirements the Government has added yet another set of hurdles to delay the decision until after the election, rather than making real judgments on these important issues. I acknowledge that this is unfair to BHP, and it would be only just if the Government repaid the costs of the environmental impact statement (EIS) it demanded as a condition of development. It would also release members of Cabinet from any lingering feeling of obligation to BHP if they have the good fortune to meet again on this matter after the next election.

The Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, in its response to the EIS, gave the mine implicit approval to go ahead. In one of his famous casuistical bets-hedging statements, in the Australian Financial Review of 22 September 1989 Senator Richardson said that if Coronation Hill `was a one-off development, I would not recommend against it as a result of the assessment report'. I understand by that that he would approve it, although I recognise the logic of his argument that, after the approval for the first mine, his Government would find it impossible to refuse subsequent applications.

I believe that this Government and the private sector have hoped for too much from tourism. It has been another quick fix for our economic problems, but tourism is important to the economy of Australia and especially the Northern Territory. Kakadu National Park is one of the major attractions of the region. In 1987 approximately 200,000 tourists visited Kakadu National Park. Since 1987 the number of tourists has continued to increase, with current levels in excess of a quarter of a million. This compares with 180,000 visitors to the Katherine Gorge and 250,000 to Uluru and the Olgas. In addition, the average visitor to Kakadu stays four to five days rather than the 1.5 days and two days for Uluru and Katherine Gorge respectively.

Kakadu must be considered as a valuable economic resource both now and in the future. Australia has an unfortunate record in the destruction of its national assets. Fresh in my mind is the pungent example of Sydney's beaches, which I referred to in my second reading speech supporting my Bill to amend the Australian Heritage Commission Act. I have not calculated the cost to our tourist industry of our once famous but now notoriously befouled beaches-I think it would be considerable-but I have sought information giving a rough calculation of the cost of a partial degradation of Kakadu. Let us be conservative and calculate the cost to the region and Australia if there was only a 10 per cent reduction in overseas visitors, a 5 per cent reduction in domestic visitors and another 5 per cent reducing their stay by 50 per cent. The loss to Australia in these circumstances would be approximately $6.75m per annum.

One of our major problems is our willingness to use our non-renewable resources to generate short term emergency cash without considering future generations or the planet as a whole. This `dig it up now' mentality threatens the long term sustainable future of Australia, and we must begin now to restructure the use of our resources. If we do this, mining may well continue to be an important element of our economy, but it should be the cream, not the major component-nearly 50 per cent-of our exports. If we can be less dependent upon our mineral exports we will be less often the victim of our powerful customers in a buyers' market.

The Coronation Hill deposit does not rank among the top few deposits. It is predominantly a gold deposit with the production of platinum group metals only a relatively small component. Thus, arguments for a go-ahead because of the strategic value of the platinum group metals are not particularly convincing. It could be argued that investment in other properties in areas of lesser environmental significance would be in the best longer term interests of Australia. It can also be argued that, although Coronation Hill itself is not a dramatically large deposit, the region from El Sherana to Coronation Hill may well be a world class mineral province. However, there has been no study of the impact of mining on the entire region, and until this is done the potential damage of large scale mining operations can only be guessed at. It is very hard to imagine that substantial adjacent mineral developments, all in the South Alligator River valley, would not eventually lead to considerable environmental problems.

It is also likely that the ore from other mines, such as El Sherana, would most probably be processed in the Coronation Hill plant. This will require either the disposal of considerably more waste rock and water in the Coronation Hill area, which could greatly increase the stress on the area and pose tremendous problems for long term safe storage-primarily because of the bioaccumulating heavy metals in the tailings piles-or the transport of the waste to another site for disposal. This would result in considerably more traffic in the region and, as crossings of the South Alligator River may well be involved, the risk of damage to the river system and its delicate ecosystem as well as the wetlands downstream in the remainder of Kakadu National Park. There has been much mention of cyanide in discussions about ecological risks, but cyanide would probably only be a problem in the immediate vicinity of the mine. The minerals released by extensive disturbance of soil in the region could well be much more of a problem.

Stage 3 of Kakadu is an important area for flora and fauna and is particularly rich in a wide range of animals. It is a major breeding area for both the pig-nosed turtle and the hooded parrot. Many plants and animals are unique to stage 3 of Kakadu and widespread mining and exploration activity may well threaten their survival. In 1985 the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service stated:
The case for the incorporation of Gimbat and Goodparla in the Kakadu National park is largely based on the following factors:

(i) inclusion of a total large river catchment i.e. South Alligator River; (ii) geological, geomorphological and other physical values; (iii) biological values; (iv) presence of rare or threatened species and their habitats; (v) Aboriginal values; (vi) recreational and educational values.
In all of these categories Kakadu stage 3 is exceptional. The Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service also stated:

In accepting the nomination of Kakadu National Park for World Heritage List, the World Heritage Committee noted the Australian Government's intention to proclaim additional areas as part of Kakadu and recommended that such areas be included on the World Heritage List.
This should be done. Full protection of the entire South Alligator River is essential to the long term health of all stages of Kakadu.

The area, including Coronation Hill, is of vital cultural importance to the Aboriginal Jawoyn people. It is known as the `sickness country' and is an area with many connected sites sacred to the creation god Bula and, according to the Jawoyn belief, is still occupied by this god. They believe that sickness and death will befall them as custodians of the sickness country if mining is allowed to proceed. They also claim that sickness and death was associated with the extremely limited mining activity in the 1950s and the 1960s and that the large scale mines now envisaged would be devastating. In their submission on the Coronation Hill environmental impact statement the Jawoyn people stated:
Jawoyn and non-Jawoyn Aboriginal people believe that any disturbance of Bula will mean disaster for everyone in the world, not just for Aboriginal people.

The speculation that the traditional Jawoyn `sickness' designation of this area might have arisen from the poisonous heavy metal concentrations in this area and other speculations about the genesis of the creation story in this dramatic landscape, while interesting, are irrelevant to the beliefs of the local inhabitants.

It is not my practice to denigrate anyone's belief and the Jawoyn beliefs sound no more implausible to me than many hawked door to door or sonorously declaimed from pulpits-or, for that matter, declared on the floor of this chamber. The fact is, although we live in a secular society, freedom of religious belief is a vital traditional freedom that I, and I believe other senators, would vigorously defend. Most of our treasured freedoms have a price; civil rights can protect the guilty as well as the innocent, and freedom of religious belief can at times impose considerable costs.

Because the beliefs of the Jawoyn are tied to a geographical area, any recognition of the right of the Jawoyn people to hold these beliefs means at least some circumspection in any plans for the use of that land. We must also remember that we are dealing with a fragile culture, a culture under considerable pressure from the modern world. As a nation we have declared our concern to protect these indigenous cultures and we have a difficult task trying to do this without imposing our own blueprints of stasus, synthesis or progressive assimilation. The best policy is clearly `hands off', leaving indigenous peoples with as much cultural self-determination as possible.

During the debate on the Coronation Hill joint venture a variety of views have been offered on the strength of local beliefs in the `sickness country' and other traditional concepts. This is scarcely surprising. Since Heisenberg we have become more aware of the intrusive role of the observer and we have many examples of anthropologists imposing their own views or fantasies on other cultures while attempting to be objective. Investigators and negotiators with a strong motive to sweep aside traditional beliefs-so that they can start mining-are likely to emphasise views in the community that are in harmony with their own. There is also some evidence of genuine misunderstanding, where politeness has been mistaken for acquiescence.

This is not an easy area in which to strike the right balance and I would not suggest that the traditional religious beliefs of any group should always take priority over the interests of the rest of the community. However, there is plenty of evidence of the various damaging effects of the intrusion of mining development into local Aboriginal communities and, in this case, there is the associated assault upon traditional beliefs. This weighs heavily against any decision to allow mining projects in this area to go ahead. I think that the seriousness of this aspect of the debate has been undervalued and that, together with the potential environmental losses associated with the possible future mining developments in this areas, combines to make a strong case for a firm `No' to any mining at Coronation Hill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —A man of great integrity and vision passed away in the Northern Territory today. Toby Gangali, who was 59 years of age, will be remembered for his outstanding contribution to the financial and cultural autonomy of the Gagudju people. A modest and unassuming man, Toby, along with Mick Alderton and the late Nipper Kaparigi, shaped the operation of their people's own royalty association. Back in the early days Toby worked as a buffalo shooter at Munmalary station and was regarded as a crack shot and a superb horseman. Toby played a key role in the Fox Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry and was the main witness in the Alligator River stage 2 land claim. He became instrumental in the establishment of the Kakadu National Park plan of management and, with Nipper Kaparigi, helped the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service record and map sacred sites, dreaming trails and seasonal camps throughout the area as well as the mythological significance of the country. Toby also involved himself in all aspects of the park's operation.

SPEECH.PARA: A member of the Mirrakundjeyimi clan, Toby was the chief custodian of a number of sites of significance and, as a traditional owner of an area encompassing Ranger, Mudginberri and Pan-Continental, he aspired for the self-sufficiency of his people. Today his association spends its royalty resources on a range of activities normally funded by the government.

Toby, who lived at Nourlangie, steered the Gagudju Association from its inception in 1980. It is significant to note that payments to individuals were limited and that traditional owners resolved that decisions about the distribution of the Association's income had to be decided by a unanimous vote of Association members, not merely by members of its committee. Such an approach has given the Gagudju Association the freedom to provide its members with services tailored to meet their specific needs, such as the development of outstations and services, the provision of schooling and health services, and the establishment of a children's trust.

Not surprisingly, sometimes there were strained relations between Toby Gangali's Gagudju Association and the more ambitious, insensitive and political Northern Land Council. The Gagudju Association pursues a policy of investing in local business and, as a result, owns the Cooinda Hotel, the Crocodile Motel at Jabiru, the Border Store at Cahill's Crossing and property in Darwin. It also services various contracts in Jabiru. Toby Gangali is survived by his wife Ruby and his four daughters and three sons. He was described by a former executive officer of the Gagudju Association, Gerry Thomas, in these terms:
That man was Kakadu.

I would like to take the opportunity that the adjournment debate affords me to raise an issue concerning air traffic control at Darwin Airport. Yesterday, during the Committee's consideration of the estimates for the Department of Transport and Communications, I had the task of eliciting from Senator Evans an answer to a question that I had asked on notice some seven weeks previously-through the courtesy of Senator Brownhill-at a Senate Estimates committee hearing. The Department of Transport and Communications seemed most reluctant to provide the answers requested. It was only after a veiled threat yesterday that we would postpone consideration of the Department's Budget provision until the answer was forthcoming that I was finally provided with an answer.

Five questions were asked relating to decisions concerning air traffic controller operations, and their implications for staffing, costings, safety and the consultation process. I was given a reasonably comprehensive answer. As a result of that and other information that came forward during the debate yesterday on the Federal Airports Corporation and Darwin Airport, I issued a press release yesterday in which I pointed out that Darwin's air traffic control faces cutbacks. As a result of the media comment on that press release, I received representations today from the Northern Territory councillor, a Mr Jim Bramich, of the Civil Air Operations Officers Association of Australia, in effect, the body that looks after the interests of the air traffic controllers at Darwin Airport. The information from Mr Bramich pointed out very succinctly that it would appear that within the Department of Transport and Communications the left hand does not know what the right hand is doing.

Yesterday in the Senate the Minister provided me with a detailed and comprehensive answer setting out information of the Government's intentions with regard to the reductions in staffing and cost savings that were to be effected at Darwin Airport. It would appear that Mr Bramich, on behalf of the Civil Air Operations Officers Association, has also been engaged in discussions and consultations with other members of the Department of Transport and Communications who have, in effect, advised him that there were not to be any such changes or consolidations in the staffing arrangements at Darwin Airport. Time will tell whether the Minister in the information he provided to me yesterday is right or whether other officers of the Department who have assured a union that there were not to be those same cuts and changes are right. It is important for the record of this issue that I seek to have incorporated in Hansard the question and answer, my media release and the correspondence my office received from the CAOOAA.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
SENATE ESTIMATES COMMITTEE-1989/90 ESTIMATES
QUESTION FROM SENATOR TAMBLING
TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS-PROGRAM 1: AVIATION
Subject: Sub-program 1.7: Civil Aviation Authority
Question
1. What decisions have been made to reduce air traffic controller operations from the Northern Territory?
2. What are the staffing implications?
3. What are the costing implications?
4. What are the safety implications?
5. What consultations have been engaged in with the Northern Territory Government?
Answer

1. The Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) airways investment program provides for air traffic services at remote locations to be consolidated to major centres. The consolidation program provides for continuing provision of the pilot briefing activities and approach control services from Darwin, with the other air traffic services to be relocated to Adelaide and Perth in January 1991.

2. With provision of briefing and approach control services from Darwin, staff members in Darwin will halve from 40 to 20. If SAR services are also retained, an additional 5 staff will remain in Darwin.

3. Cost savings of about $344,000 pa will be achieved by location briefing and approach control functions only in Darwin. If SAR services are also retained in Darwin these savings will reduce considerably.

4. Safety will not be compromised. The use of modern technology offers the opportunity to improve productivity without any deterioration in the quality of the services provided. The CAA will ensure that the arrangements finally agreed under the consolidation program will maintain a safe airways system to the satisfaction of the Government and the industry.
5. The NT Minister for Transport and Works has been briefed and officers of the CAA and the NT Department of Transport and Works have discussed the program on a number of occasions.
MEDIA RELEASE
DARWIN AIR TRAFFIC CONTROL FACES CUTBACKS
A plan to slash air traffic control operations at Darwin Airport cast doubt over the future of the entire airport redevelopment program, Northern Territory Senator Grant Tambling said today.
The CLP senator revealed that the Civil Aviation Authority intended halving its staff in Darwin and relocating important air traffic services interstate.

``The Federal Transport and Communications Department confirmed that, under the proposal, 20 out of 40 staff would lose their Darwin jobs and important air traffic services would be relocated to Adelaide and Perth by January 1991.

``The downgrading of air traffic control operations at Darwin Airport casts a shadow over claims by Labor Senator Bob Collins and Labor Federal Member, Warren Snowdon, that the Hawke Labor Government is still committed to the redevelopment of the airport.
``I will believe it when I see it.''
Senator Tambling said information provided by the Civil Aviation Authority showed that a combination of staff cuts and a relocation of air traffic services would save $344,000 a year.

``I find it hypocritical that the Hawke Labor Government talks loudly about pouring millions of dollars into the redevelopment of Darwin Airport and, at the same time, plans to move the staff and services of a major aviation authority interstate.

``I challenge Labor's mouthpieces in the Northern Territory, Senator Collins and Mr Snowdon, to reaffirm the Federal Government's commitment to the present design and construction timetables of Darwin Airport.''

Dear Tiz,
Thank you for the fax of Senator Tambling's media release and the response to his questions.
This fax is in response to our discussion of this morning regarding the Senator's press release concerning Darwin Air Traffic Control cutbacks.
CAOOAA is the professional body which represents Air Traffic Controllers within Australia.
CAOOAA's NT Division, which I represent on our Association's Central Council, is, and has always been opposed to any consolidation of Air Traffic Control Services from Darwin.

One of the main reasons for opposing consolidation is that CAA have failed to adequately demonstrate that the cutbacks will be cost effective (i.e. save money) and be of a benefit to the aviation industry.
CAA have already carried out two consolidations of Air Traffic Control Services under their consolidation plan for the NT.
The first of these involved the transfer of enroute control (sector control) from Alice Springs Tower to Adelaide.

This move was generated by a proposal to cut the hours of Alice Springs Control Tower. It was proposed that instead of providing a 24 hour service, Alice Tower would close overnight, thereby permitting a saving in staff numbers required to man the Tower together with of course a saving in salaries.
In order to achieve this saving it was necessary to transfer the enroute control functions of Alice Springs Tower (a 24 hour service) to Adelaide.

To take over this traffic in Adelaide, it was necessary to create at least three new ATC positions in the Adelaide Area Approach Control Centre, at a cost I would suggest exceeding $150,000 per annum. This figure is for salaries alone, it does not take into account any engineering costs, nor does it take into account leave relief for these three additional controllers in Adelaide. There was no staff reduction at Alice Springs.
Shortly after Adelaide took over the enroute control function from Alice Springs Tower it was decided, due to public and aviation industry pressure, not to close the Tower at night.

The net result of this exercise was the creation of 3 additional ATC positions in Adelaide, no reduction in Alice Springs staff, but yearly additional costs to CAA, and ultimately the aviation industry, of at least $150,000.
The other consolidation is that of transferring Operational Control/Search and Rescue functions from Alice Springs to Darwin.

I have attached copy of a letter from Mr Brian Miller, the Assistant General Manager, Air Traffic Services, SA/NT Field Office CAA which details the supposed cost savings resulting from this exercise.
I believe Mr Miller's figures to be inaccurate in that they do not take into account the following:

- there was a net gain in Darwin staff of three, not two controllers in Darwin as stated by Mr Miller. This means that $53,000 should be added to his Darwin salaries. This also means an additional family leave fare of $2652.
- there was an upgrade of one Darwin class 3 controller to class 4 which would have cost approximately $5000.

In the agreement for the transfer is contained an agreement for two familiarisation trips for Darwin Search and Rescue staff to Alice Springs per year. This would be something of the order of four staff a year at something of the order of $1500 per person for a total of $6000.
Therefore, under the Darwin costs given in Mr Miller's letter should read as follows:
3 X ATC 4 salaries...
1 X upgrade ATC 3 to ATC 4...
1 1/2 transfers/year...
3 family leave fares...
4 X familiarisation trips...
Total...
This therefore gives a net annual cost of $4,380. That is the consolidation, which was done to save costs, has in fact cost over $4,000 per annum.

The above figures are only ongoing costs, and do not take into account capital costs. In order for the transfer to take place, it was necessary to upgrade the Darwin Operational Control Centre. This took the form of new consoles, additional satellite intercoms, a new telephone system etc, and would probably have cost something of the order of $100,000. The building in which this upgrade took place is scheduled to be handed over to the RAAF in the next three or four years, and so the figure of $100,000 must be amortised over this period. I have requested costings for this upgrade, and other engineering works associated with the consolidation, but as yet have not received them.

There were also seven familiarisation trips for Search and Rescue staff to Alice Springs, together with two trips by the Darwin check controller, prior to the Alice Springs closure, for a total cost of about $13,500.
Additionally, should a Search and Rescue action take place in the Alice Springs area, it will now be necessary to fly in Search and Rescue staff thereby generating additional costs.

Apart from appearing to cost more money to provide, the Operational Control and Search and Rescue service for Alice Springs, now provided from Darwin, must be of a lesser quality due to the distance involved, lack of local knowledge time taken to get staff to the area etc.

Another consolidation which has taken place in the last couple of years was that of Townsville Operational Control and Search and Rescue to Brisbane. CAA has not provided any costings for this consolidation, but it would also appear that there has been little if any cost savings.
I would suggest that if Senator Tambling were to obtain the costings for the above consolidations from the appropriate Minister that they should make interesting reading.

As mentioned to you on the telephone earlier today, Mr Miller advised a meeting of CAA's NT Consultative Council, which took place on the 14th of November, that he had placed a freeze on CAA's NT consolidation plans pending the outcome of a review. He advised that he was concerned with the timetable, and the level of service which would be provided post consolidation.
This is at variance with the answer to question 1 which you faxed to me.

Mr Miller also said that following a review done to determine the effectiveness of providing a Search and Rescue (SAR) Service from a remote locality as opposed to Darwin, it had been decided that a SAR presence should remain in Darwin.
The above comments will be recorded in the minutes of the meeting. As yet these minutes have not been distributed.
I hope the above is of some use to Senator Tambling. Should yourself or the Senator have any queries now, or in the future, do not hesitate to contact me.
Yours faithfully,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to discuss this evening a program known as LETS. The acronym stands for local employment trading system. It is a barter system under which people exchange local goods and services without the need of Australian currency through creating a local currency of their own under their own control. It is quite a novel idea, but one which is gaining a lot of popularity. Certainly in Western Australia LETS groups are mushrooming all over Perth and have been operating in Margaret River. They are now also operating in the other country centres of Bunbury, Albany and Cunderdin.

SPEECH.PARA: LETS is a system under which no interest is charged. People cannot use a LETS currency to make more money, so there is no value in hoarding. It is a system in which there is no possibility of theft because the currency is not carried from place to place and so cannot be stolen. There is no borrowing or lending and therefore no repayment schedules, no debt collectors, and no tight squeezes to cover loans. It is important to understand that money creates many problems for many people, the main one being that most of us simply think we do not have enough of it most of the time. However, when Australian dollars are scarce our local economy dries up for lack of money. Unemployment rises at the same time as people are unable to meet even basic needs of food, clothing and shelter. Because money is scarce, people have to compete in order to obtain it and the costs of the security of money are rising. People who wish to cooperate are thought naive or get ripped off in the economic jungle. Money is used to make money, not to meet people's needs. It is outside local control and tends to flow into the hands of those who already have the most. Clean water and fresh air, on the other hand, which cannot be bought and be sold, are considered valueless, or `free' to pollute at no cost to the community until expensive cleaning up is required. Then everybody screams very loudly about the costs involved. Unless there is money to pay for local skills, they are undervalued or dismissed as worthless. There has to be a better alternative, particularly as we are approaching the post-industrial age when full employment is a thing of the past.

People trading in the LET system notify trustees set up by the local group of the agreed upon value of the energy transfer between them. This is recorded against an account held in each person's name. To get an account, a person joins the local system and makes a list of the various skills and services he or she has to offer other people. That is all put on to a computerised sheet and a person is able to see what goods and services other people in the community may have to offer in return. Everyone's account starts at zero and LETS currency is created every time two people decide to trade. Local currency, therefore, never dries up. It is always available and depends only on the time and energy individuals have to offer. Because it is valid only in the local community, it can never leave the local economy and helps people save Australian dollars to use for the goods and services not available locally.

Most LET systems are incorporated as non-profit associations run by their members who elect a board of advisers to appoint their own trustees. There is no obligation upon members to trade and no setting of prices for goods and services. The system began in Canada six years ago and spread rapidly to the west coast of Australia, but had its early life in this country on the east coast. It enables participants in communities to replace dollars and cents with any agreed local currency such as cowry shells, which one of the local Western Australian groups is using, to trade for goods and services among themselves. We see then a never ending supply of costly goods and services such as babysitting, gardening, hairdressing, language lessons, organically grown vegetables, car repairs, taxation returns, computer skills and the like being available under the scheme. It works this way. If person A, whom we will call Mike, needed a babysitter and decided to ask person B, whom we will call Mary, they would first agree on a price, say 20 cowry shells. Then one of the people would contact a LETS trustee and both accounts would be settled in the books. Mike would be 20 cowry shells in deficit and Mary would be 20 cowry shells in credit. If Mary later wanted her lawn mown and settled on a price of 15 cowry shells, her account would then go down from 20 to 5. To even one's account, one simply offers one's products or services to other people so as to build up more cowry shells against one's name.

I am indebted to Mr John Croft of the group in Western Australia and to Vivienne Elanta who organised one of the groups in my area in Western Australia, which is working particularly well. Mr Croft believes that particular groups within society will benefit greatly from LETS which he says could be used to increase the nation's wealth. It seems that a lot of the good side effects from the system are for people on low incomes, such as the elderly and disabled pensioners. These people can use a local currency to purchase local goods and services while their pensions are free for things that are not usually available to people in that income bracket.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you use plastic shells?
—Ask Senator Walsh whether he will take his taxes in cowry shells and see how you go!

—Honourable senators interjecting might be on the receiving end of some of these goods and services one day. It would pay them to listen to this with a little more interest than ridicule because it is something that is becoming very prevalent in the community as people are being increasingly squeezed by our monetary economy.

SPEECH.PARA: Up to now skills like childminding and dressmaking have been greatly undervalued. People with such skills now have the opportunity to profit from them. People in the lower income groups and women who choose to be at home in particular will benefit greatly. Although LETS has opened many amazing new doors and avenues, there can also be a few problems which LETS organisers are trying to overcome. Taxation is one of them. How do people declare something like this to the Australian Tax Office? The Australian Taxation Office has been asked this very question by Maxine Brown, a journalist with the Sunday Times in Perth. A spokesperson for the Australian Taxation Office in Perth, Mr Peter Kidbey, said that he was satisfied that the Government would not lose any revenue from LETS. He is quoted as having said:
The scheme is assessable given the provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act.
There is nothing illegal about it.
Mr Kidbey said that under the Act non-cash business benefits must be converted to a declarable dollars and cents profit. It remains to be seen just how well that will go.

In Australia the scheme got going in the small southern Queensland town of Maleny. In the early 1980s a woman by the name of Jill Jordan was involved in the formation of the Maple Street Cooperative in Maleny and the Maleny District Community Credit Union flowed on from there. Jill Jordan believes in community development, regional autonomy, and personal empowerment; and local control of resources depends to a large extent on economic empowerment. The credit union was a logical and large step in this direction, yet it was still influenced to a large extent by forces outside the control of the local people. It is the old story: those who have get more, while those who have not pay interest to those who have for such basics as land, housing, food and transportation.

The next step was clearly a local economy independent of the fortunes of international currency that is often based on plundering and polluting the planet. Enter Permaculture founder Bill Mollison who met the LETS founder, Canadian Michael Linton, when they were both attending a Bio-Regional conference in the United States. He passed on information about the LET system in Canada to Jill Jordan who with the help of friends got LETS going at Maleny in Queensland. An association was formed there from a meeting of about 80 people and trading began. Although a little tentative at first, Maleny LETS had 100 members after three months and 160 members at the end of the first year. Maleny called its local currency bunyas after the nuts so beloved by local Aborigines and in the first year over 22,000 bunya units were traded.

Other LETS systems were springing up. In Rockhampton LETS members traded in loaves and fishes. In Taree the currency was called figs. Jill Jordan says that she is forever hearing of other groups in formation. She said, `We do not know how many LETS groups there are in Australia. They do not have to ask anyone's permission to start. They just call a public meeting and begin'. In Bellingen in New South Wales the LETS system started with over 100 members and the group is growing steadily. Every month members list all of their requirements and offers and the resultant computer printout is a wonderful catalogue of local resources. As the system grows the printed noticeboard will become the most effective advertising and information service in the area and, at a small charge in LETS dollars, easily the cheapest.

The LETS team initially worked long voluntary hours to establish the Bellingen system. But it is getting to the point where LETS administration will now be paid in the local currency. It has an office which it opens only a few hours a week for new memberships. Business is conducted directly between members by telephone and transactions are either mailed to the LETS office or details are left on the office telephone-answering machine. However, there is a small service charge for transactions because Telecom Australia, of course, needs to be paid in real Australian dollars.

The LETS system highlights the need to become more self-sufficient regionally and not so dependent on uncontrollable outside market forces. The system best suits small communities and works well with between 50 and 200 members. It is effective in country towns, suburban neighbourhoods and blocks of units-wherever people have shared interests. Artists and craftspeople are usually the first to suffer when real currency is in short supply. Ms Jill Jordan says, `If you are going hungry, you are not going to buy a painting'. Under LETS cottage industries flourish and it is not just the very wealthy who have the opportunity to own works of art. Participants in LET systems feel more generous making acknowledgments. There is scope to do quality work and ethical projects are not necessarily overlooked. The LET system frees up the way in which we think about money. As LETS currency has no value, there are no security problems with it. As it does not collect interest there is no sense in hoarding it.

In summary, these are the advantages of the LETS system: it is a fantastic way to build up a personal support network which meets an individual's personal needs; it permits people who have ideas for starting up their own small businesses to try them out without risking Australian dollars; it allows age pensioners to continue to contribute their skills to the local community and to get recognition for their contribution without its affecting their pension; it is good for recompensing volunteers of community organisations who give selflessly of their time and effort; and, finally, LETS allows people to improve the quality of their lives and to enhance feelings of self-esteem and self-worth by gaining recognition for skills from the local community. It is certainly very good for building that sense of community spirit. I think that is something we need to encourage in this world where our young people in particular feel a great deal of alienation. In future when we cannot expect a return to full employment the LETS system will be increasingly valuable as people find new ways of ordering their lives creatively.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition deplores the assassination of Lebanese President Rene Muawad in Beirut last night. Like President-elect Beshir Gemayel some years ago, Rene Muawad was murdered by a car bomb in an explosion which also took the lives of 16 others in his party. We are appalled that a man of vision such as Rene Muawad, a courageous man who knew he was gambling with his life when he took office but was convinced that he had to in order that he might help to bring peace to his country, should be so tragically cut down. Rene Muawad was only 17 days into implementing a peace plan of which his election was part. His killing is testimony to the searing hatred that has torn Lebanon apart and kept it apart for 15 years since fighting broke out in Beirut in April 1975.

SPEECH.PARA: The city of Beirut has, since the war of liberation announced by Christian General Michel Aoun in March this year to expel Syrian troops, been under heavy and continuous shelling as General Aoun's and Syrian forces battle for control of the capital. The suffering has known no religious boundaries as both Christian and Moslem civilians, ordinary families, have been caught up in the civil war. The imperative in Lebanon was to stop the killing, to reconcile seemingly irreconcilable demands and interests. Hopefully the time bought by a period of peace could be used to establish trust that was not in evidence and is certainly not in evidence after the events of last night.

We want to use this occasion to recognise the efforts of the Arab League to bring peace to Lebanon, starting with the Arab summit in Morocco which in May this year formed a committee comprising members from Saudi Arabia, Algeria and Morocco and charged them with finding a way to resolve the crisis in Lebanon. Despite heavy odds, the Arab League was successful in arranging a cease-fire which came into effect on 23 September, ending six months of the most intensive battles in 14 years of continuous fighting. We in the Opposition were heartened by that. We were further heartened when on 30 September Moslem and Christian members of the Lebanese Parliament met in Saudi Arabia to discuss the Arab League's peace plan, a document for political reforms which we noted were supported by Syria.

We will never know the contribution that Rene Muawad could have made. We were certainly encouraged by his determination and optimism. In his first address to the Parliament on 5 November on the occasion of his swearing in, he described himself thus:

I am one of you and you know me as a man of reconciliation dedicated to the concept of unity, a man who has gambled his life in return for the reconciliation of all the Lebanese irrespective of their persuasion.
Pointing out that after 15 years of killing and destruction Lebanon was badly in need of a breathing space, he pledged:
We shall work towards forming a government of national reconciliation, to include all Lebanon's factions, which will reunite what has been disjointed.
He went on to say:

I shall never rest . . . until the new republic is fully established . . . I shall never rest until we rebuild whatever has been destroyed, relocate the displaced and return those who left the country under the pressure of want and in pursuit of bread overseas, and lack of security.

Mr President, you, as one who I know has taken a particular interest in Lebanon, will realise how tragic it is that a man with such conviction and understanding of the problems of his country and of moderate views needed to be cut down in this awful way. He shall never have a chance to fulfil the pledge he made on taking office. However, we hope that his vision for peace has not died with him. We hope that a new leader will soon be elected to pursue these sensible and practical points contained in the Arab League's peace plan.

We use this occasion to remind ourselves of the principal provisions of that plan because we hope its ultimate implementation will be his legacy. Those provisions include that executive power be transferred from the President to a Cabinet with equal numbers of Moslem and Christian Ministers; Parliament to have an equal number of Moslems and Christians instead of a Christian majority; Syrian troops who were in control of two-thirds of the country to pull back to eastern Lebanon within two years; the presidency to be reserved for a Maronite Christian; the Prime Minister's post to be reserved for a Sunni Moslem; the Speaker's post to be reserved for a Shiite Moslem; and lesser posts no longer to be allocated on religious lines.

The Opposition has long supported and I reaffirm our support for the path of negotiation and compromise as the only way to bring peace to Lebanon. We hope that the various parties in the Lebanese conflict will remember and respect President Muawad's desire for peace and national reconciliation. Above all, we hope that there will be no reprisal leading to renewal of the violence that has plagued Lebanon for so many years. I reiterate what I said in speaking to the motion of which I gave notice this morning, which I trust will be passed by the Senate tomorrow: it is the wish of the Opposition, and I hope this Parliament, to see commonsense prevail in Lebanon. I hope that efforts to find a durable peace in Lebanon will continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to clarify a point that has been raised publicly by the Australian Democrats senator from Western Australia, Senator Jenkins. In a publication called Business World that is circulated in Western Australia she has claimed that `on this occasion the Democrats were joined by the coalition Opposition, which meant the changes had been temporarily stalled'. In the article she was actually referring to our initiatives-not those of the Democrats-to have stalled or reversed the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal (PBRT) decision to cut pharmacy income by 23 per cent. That was an initiative of ours. The National Health (Pharmaceutical Benefits Revocation and Tribunal Membership) Amendment Bill, a private member's Bill of my colleague Senator Puplick, who is in the chamber at the moment, moved to disallow the PBRT decision. It was also our decision to move amendments to the National Health Amendment Bill, yet Senator Jenkins has gone public and used Business World for party political purposes to say that the Democrats had initiated this.
—Shameful!
—Of course it is shameful. Senator Puplick is quite right, but it is something we have become accustomed to.
—Shameless!

—That is right, shameless. It is something that we have become accustomed to from Senator Jenkins because she has little respect for the fact that there is some truth that needs to be spelled out both in this chamber and in the public debate. The Opposition has quite clearly and unequivocally resisted the change in the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal's decision, the deduction in margins that the pharmacists have incurred, and all the other decisions that have impinged upon the pharmacists' contribution to the community provision of health services throughout Australia. Yet here Senator Jenkins and her Party are masquerading as the people who initiated the measures to revoke the decisions of the PBRT. As I say, that is not necessarily surprising because Senator Jenkins really does treat the truth with little respect.

—On a point of order, Mr President: I am not quite confident at this late hour but I think Senator Knowles might be going a little close to the wind in speaking of an honourable senator not having a real regard for the truth. It seems to me to be a very polite way of saying `tells lies'. I am not quite sure, Mr President; I raise that in a protective manner and seek your guidance.
—On two occasions the honourable senator has gone very close to offending the Standing Orders. I warn her and she can continue.

—I will heed your warning, Mr President, and amend what I have said by saying that Senator Jenkins has treated the facts with disdain and that she has not, either individually or on behalf of her Party, sought to do what we in the Opposition have done-protect the pharmacy network throughout Australia. As I have said before, the Australian Democrats have difficulty not only with what they stand for but also with knowing where they are at and where they live. I even have a letter here from the Publicity Officer of the Australian Democrats. Ironically, he happens to be Mr Brian Jenkins. He is a publicity officer for the Australian Democrats and a spouse of a senator in the Australian Democrats, and he is a staff member of the Australian Democrats.
—What do you have to do to get a job like that?

—That is a very good question. I am not too sure what one has to do to get a job like that but it is obviously rather cushy. Obviously Mr Jenkins does not know where Canberra is-or where Western Australia is, for that matter. This letter in front of me is addressed to me, Senator S. Knowles, Parliament House, Canberra, Western Australia, 6000. It is a bit of a hiccup, I suppose; nonetheless it clearly demonstrates that the Democrats do not know what they are talking about, where they live or where their constituency is. I am very concerned that Senator Jenkins is using a reputable newspaper like Business World--
—Never heard of it.
—Senator Tate says, in a deprecating fashion, that he has never heard of it. That is disgraceful.

—Business World is quite a well renowned publication in Western Australia and is circulated very widely among the business community, where it has a very wide readership. I would not raise this issue on the adjournment tonight if I did not think it was important enough, because of the circulation that the publication has, to say that Senator Jenkins has simply misrepresented the actual fact that in this chamber the Democrats followed in the coalition's wake and were the ones that were forced to support our initiatives-and Senator Puplick's initiatives in particular. Senator Puplick put very clearly and succinctly to this chamber and to the public of Australia the case for why we should maintain pharmacy as it is and not see 37 per cent of Australian pharmacies going to the wall because of the decisions that have been made, as has been cited in the information that is supplied from the office of the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) and as has been supported by information from a statistician from the Australian Labor Party that was presented to its back bench Caucus committee on health but nonetheless was rejected as not being factual.

SPEECH.PARA: We have stood in a position that has been absolutely non-negotiable-we will not see those pharmacies go out of business but will maintain pharmacy throughout Australia, maintain a fair remuneration system to pharmacies and maintain a fair margin to pharmacies. In other words, they can stay in business. The sad reality of what has been happening is that pharmacies-or any business for that matter-cannot stay in business without adequate margins. It is a great pity that Senator Jenkins seeks to make political mileage when the Democrats have not sought to take the initiatives taken by us in the Opposition and when she completely misrepresents the Hansard record of this place.

As I say, it substantiates the fact that the Democrats do now know what they stand for; they purely and simply say that they will stand for anything that suits the purpose of the day, because they will never be in government, so they will never have to deliver any of their promises. We hear Senator Haines say that they stand for this and this and this in regard to taxation, immigration-or pharmacy, for that matter. They can stand for anything. The Australian public slowly but surely is starting to realise the fact that they can stand for anything because they will never be in government and be forced to deliver their promises in a way in which both the Opposition and the Australian Labor Party will have to do. Therefore, as I say, we have the situation where they promise everything and deliver nothing. Added to that, a staff member cum spouse publicity officer for the Australian Democrats does not even have a clue where Canberra is or where Western Australia is because suddenly Canberra has been moved to Western Australia-which we would not mind but Canberra, or Western Australia, might be a bit disturbed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps you will take the local Assembly with you.
—No, we draw a line at that. We will not take the local Assembly with us. I am very disturbed that Senator Jenkins has sought to misuse Business World in such a manner.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, upon notice, on 5 September 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many Belarus Tractors have been imported into Australia to date?
(2) In what year did the importation of Belarus Tractors to Australia begin?
(3) How many Belarus Tractors have been sold in each State?
(4) How many Belarus Tractors were bought by State or Federal Government instrumentalities?
(5) How many models of Belarus Tractors are or have been available in Australia?
(6) What evidence, in the form of complaints or statements to consumer organisations or tribunals, is the Minister aware of, regarding the reliability and performance of the Belarus Tractor?
(7) Is the Minister aware of a report, prepared on behalf of Unisearch Limited for D. C. and M. J. Evans of Garran A.C.T., on a Belarus model 920 Agricultural Tractor?

(8) What steps will the Minister take to ensure that: (a) Belarus products sold in Australia are of acceptable quality; and (b) Australian purchasers of the Belarus products are ensured of adequate recompense in the event of product failure?

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

(8) (a) Both the common law and Sale of Goods legislation in each of the States and Territories implies into contacts for the sale of goods a condition that the goods are of merchantable quality. This implied term, however, may be excluded by the parties. A similar condition is in some cases implied into contracts other than for the sale of goods, depending upon the operation of particular State/Territory law regulating such transactions. In relation to contracts for the supply of Belarus products costing less than $40 000 or which are of a kind ordinarily used for personal, domestic or household use or consumption, additional protection for the consumer is afforded by Part V, Division 2 of the Trade Practices Act 1974 by way of implied non-excludable conditions and warranties. Part V, Division 2a of the Trade Practices Act 1974 confers, in relation to goods of a kind ordinarily acquired for personal, domestic or household use or consumption, additional rights on the consumer to take legal action against the manufacturer or importer of goods which are not of merchantable quality.

(b) The means of redress in relation to implied terms lies in an action against the supplier of the goods for breach of contact. In relation to the rights conferred by Part V, Division 2a of the Trade Practices Act 1974, that Act provides for a statutory cause of action which may be instituted in any court of competent jurisdiction.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority and National Industry Extension Service

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 4 October 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What grants have been provided by the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority and the National Industry Extension Service in each year since their establishment.
(2) What is the name of each grant recipient, the amount of the grant, its purpose, and the date of approval.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority (TCFDA)
(1) Total NIES grants by the TCFDA since its establishment in May 1988 were $1.045m in 1987-88, $1.883m in 1988-89 and $1.835m in 1989-90.

(2) The grants which were provided to State Government NIES over the past few years under the TCFDA Management and Business Skills Scheme are shown in Attachment 1. A total of 389 company subsidies have been provided under the scheme to 30 June 1989. Of this total, 137 were for business plans and the remaining 258 for other specialist consultancies provided through NIES.

The purpose of the Management and Business Skills Scheme is to increase the TCF industries' access to expert advice relevant to each company's particular needs. This advice takes into account the changes to import arrangements that are occurring under the TCF Plan and the implications for individual companies.
Information on grants provided to individual companies is treated as commercial-in-confidence by NIES.
National Industry Extension Service-(NIES)
(1) Total grants by NIES to agencies in each year since its establishment were $6.63m in 1986-87, $4.268m in 1987-88 and $4.648m in 1988-89.

(2) The grants provided by NIES to individual agencies are shown in Attachment 2. They were approved in the context of the Budget Appropriations except for the $350 000 payment to Standards Australia in 1988-89 which was approved on 16 June 1989.

In 1986-87, its first year, NIES continued earlier arrangements that provided grants to agencies delivering a range of specialised services aimed at facilitating the accelerated adoption and diffusion of appropriate technology at the company level and, correspondingly, at fostering attitudes in management which were receptive to change. The services were in areas such as design, productivity improvement training, quality assurance, standardizations and technology transfer.
Financial support provided through the Department supplemented industry contributions to the agencies.

Grant arrangements other than those for the National Association of Testing Authorities (NATA) and Standards Australia (SA) have been terminated. Payments to NATA and SA are now generally made in the context of Memorandums of Understanding with those organisations to assist them in fulfilling national interest activities and in meeting other provisions agreed with the Commonwealth. Any payments to the other agencies are now in exchange for specific services of a national interest nature, in the same way as other organisations can be contracted to perform specific services.
The payments in 1988-89 to SA include an additional $350 000 to assist it in performing its functions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 16 October 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In relation to the studies being undertaken by the Department of Administrative Services (DAS) in conjunction with the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to investigate the feasibility of using unbleached or recycled paper in Government offices, can the Minister say how close DAS is to drawing a conclusion on the use of recycled paper.
(2) Is it true that the provision of recycled paper to electorate offices of Members of Parliament will depend upon the favourable outcome of this feasibility study.
(3) Have any Members of Parliament requested recycled paper for their electorate offices.
(4) Have any members of Parliament been provided with recycled paper for their letterhead and other stationery requirements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A review by the Department of Administrative Services into the Potential for Using Recycled Paper and Paper Products has been completed. I released the Summary and Recommendations of the Review on 2 November. The Review was overseen by the Steering Committee consisting of a Deputy Secretary from my Department and senior officers from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Conclusions have been reached about the use of 100 per cent recycled paper and other recycled paper products containing a mixture of recycled fibre and new fibre.

(2) Members of Parliament who approached my Department about recycled paper were informed that provision of such paper to electorate offices would depend upon the outcome of the Recycled Paper Review.
(3) Yes.

(4) Letterhead stationery is provided to Members of Parliament by the Parliamentary Departments. I am writing to the Presiding Officers seeking their support in making letterhead stationery available on recycled paper. Other stationery requirements such as scribble pads, plain paper and notebooks are supplied by the Department of Administrative Services. Prior to completion of the Recycled Paper Review, plain recycled paper had been provided to electorate offices in some States. Steps are being taken to acquire stocks in all States which can be drawn on when needed.
